abstract: Rev. Mr. CORBETT, of the Methodist Episcopal Church in Greene-street, delivered a sermon last evening, designed for those classes of the community (male and female) which are generally regarded as beyond the pale of religious influence or moral sentiment. A large concourse, principally of gentlemen, was present, and crowded the Church to its utmost capacity. A large number of detective Policemen were in attendance, and these, at the close of the services, informed our reporter that, so far as they could discern, there were not more than, twenty mauvais sujets of either sex present. The exercises were commenced by the singing of the hymn, "Lord, we are vile and conceived in sin."

abstract: A new impulse is being given to the royal game of chess by the chess-column, conducted by PAUL MORPHY, in the New-York Ledger. In the last number of this popular journal is a specimen of pawnplay, in the notes to a game by MCDOWELL and LABOURDANAIS, which is said by amateurs of the game to be unsurpassed in skill and interest. Mr. MORPHY, being in New-Orleans, and of course compelled to furnish contributions by letter, it has been found convenient to associate with him in the editorship of the chess department, W.G.A. FULLER, Esq., who has long and favorably been known to the public in this capacity, to reply to chess correspondents.

abstract: Sniffen vs. McNeil. This suit was brought in the Common Pleas, and came before Judge BRADY at Special Term lately, on an appeal from a taxation of costs by the clerk. The question was whether a witness who had attended court from day to day, to testify on the trial, returning home at night, was entitled to traveling expenses for each journey made.

abstract: At 1 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning a strong odor of gas coming from the fancy goods store of Mr. JOHN GILARD,No.127 Fourth-avenue, induced the wife of the proprietor to go and ascertain what caused it. On approaching the meter the escaped gas came in contact with the flame of her lamp, causing an explosion, which set fire to the stock in the store, and injured it to the extent of $400. Insured fully in the Importers and Traders' Company.
lead_paragraph: At 1 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning a strong odor of gas coming from the fancy goods store of Mr. JOHN GILARD,No.127 Fourth-avenue, induced the wife of the proprietor to go and ascertain what caused it. abstract: We have already expressed the opinion that CRIMMINS, who was hung on Friday, did not deserve his fate; and that Gov. MORGAN, by refusing to commute his sentence, or even to postpone its execution, had sacrificed justice to his own reputation for firmness and consistency. The circumstances of his refusal confirm this conviction.
lead_paragraph: We have already expressed the opinion that CRIMMINS, who was hung on Friday, did not deserve his fate; and that Gov. MORGAN, by refusing to commute his sentence, or even to postpone its execution, had sacrificed justice to his own reputation for firmness and consistency. The circumstances of his refusal confirm this conviction. It will be remembered that the jury, feeling constrained under the ruling of the Court to find a verdict of guilty, still recommended him to mercy, -- and that the Governor regarded this action on their part as an attempt to evade their own responsibility by throwing it upon him.
headline: {'main': 'The Execution of Crimmins.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Execution of Crimmins.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The important struggle between the Greeks and Bulgarians, of which some account was given in a late number of the TIMES, still continues with unabated ardor on both sides. It will be remembered that the scene of the conflict has been the City of Philipopolis, and more particularly the churches of the Greek communion; and that the Bulgarian parishioners, becoming tired of services performed in a tongue quite unknown to the majority of them, have been waxing strong in their demand that the liturgy should be read in a Bulgarian translation. They have at last met with success. A letter was received from the Patriarch of Constantinople, in which that dignitary, in virtue of the authority he claims to possess over all the "Orthodox," decided that henceforth the church service should be read alternately in Greek and Sclavic, in the two most central churches of the city. The proclamation was made to the assembled population immediately after the reading of the gospel. The reader had scarce finished, and had not yet descended from the ambon, when a scene of indescribable confusion arose. The gratified Bulgarians intoned, on the spur of the moment, a loud anthem of praise to the Sultan for the welcome concession. Nor were they far out of the way in ascribing the credit to him; for the decision was undoubtedly arrived at among the members of the Divan before it was pronounced by the holy prelate. The Greeks, meanwhile, far from joining in the jubilant paean, loudly cried out that they would not submit. This, in turn, occasioned an assault from the Bulgarian side, and many a Greek retired, it is said, from the holy spot, bearing on his person the marks of having participated in a very unspiritual warfare. So much for the incidents of this Sunday's combat. A telegraphic dispatch, received just before the departure of the steamer from Piraeus, announces the sequel. A new service, on a succeeding feast-day, brought with it a fresh opportunity for polemics, and these attended by more fatal results, for it is said that in the melee which took place some twenty five individuals fell victims to the fratricidal fury. But, as all know the magnifying power of the electric telegraph, we may hope that the number at least may have been exaggerated.
lead_paragraph: The important struggle between the Greeks and Bulgarians, of which some account was given in a late number of the TIMES, still continues with unabated ardor on both sides. It will be remembered that the scene of the conflict has been the City of Philipopolis, and more particularly the churches of the Greek communion; and that the Bulgarian parishioners, becoming tired of services performed in a tongue quite unknown to the majority of them, have been waxing strong in their demand that the liturgy should be read in a Bulgarian translation. They have at last met with success. A letter was received from the Patriarch of Constantinople, in which that dignitary, in virtue of the authority he claims to possess over all the "Orthodox," decided that henceforth the church service should be read alternately in Greek and Sclavic, in the two most central churches of the city. The proclamation was made to the assembled population immediately after the reading of the gospel. The reader had scarce finished, and had not yet descended from the ambon, when a scene of indescribable confusion arose. The gratified Bulgarians intoned, on the spur of the moment, a loud anthem of praise to the Sultan for the welcome concession. Nor were they far out of the way in ascribing the credit to him; for the decision was undoubtedly arrived at among the members of the Divan before it was pronounced by the holy prelate. The Greeks, meanwhile, far from joining in the jubilant paean, loudly cried out that they would not submit. This, in turn, occasioned an assault from the Bulgarian side, and many a Greek retired, it is said, from the holy spot, bearing on his person the marks of having participated in a very unspiritual warfare. So much for the incidents of this Sunday's combat. A telegraphic dispatch, received just before the departure of the steamer from Piraeus, announces the sequel. A new service, on a succeeding feast-day, brought with it a fresh opportunity for polemics, and these attended by more fatal results, for it is said that in the melee which took place some twenty five individuals fell victims to the fratricidal fury. But, as all know the magnifying power of the electric telegraph, we may hope that the number at least may have been exaggerated.

abstract: To say that Lord JOHN RUSSELL'S new Reform bill does not meet with general approbation in England, is not saying much in condemnation of it. No Reform bill since 1832 has ever been received by either Parliament or the public with anything approaching to acclamation, and the best thing which the general verdict has ever said of any of them has been, that it might have been worse.
lead_paragraph: To say that Lord JOHN RUSSELL's new Reform bill does not meet with general approbation in England, is not saying much in condemnation of it. No Reform bill since 1832 has ever been received by either Parliament or the public with anything approaching to acclamation, and the best thing which the general verdict has ever said of any of them has been, that it might have been worse. The most ambitious attempt in this direction of late years was Mr. DISRAELI's, and it is by a comparison with this that Lord JOHN RUSSELL's will undoubtedly be either approved or condemned. In both of them the principle that the constituency should be greatly enlarged, and that the House of Commons must have a much wider and more popular basis, to enable it to retain its relative position in the Government in the face of the immense increase of the Peerage which the last thirty years have witnessed, is fully and frankly recognized.
headline: {'main': "Lord John Russell's Reform Bill.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Lord John Russell's Reform Bill.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Health bill seems to be the most popular, as it certainly is the most important, measure before the Legislature. Not far from three thousand petitioners, representing the most respectable and influential class of this community, have prayed for the immediate enactment of such a law, and not a solitary remonstrance has been made against it. Members of the Legislature individually acknowledge its importance, and seem ready and anxious to give their votes in its favor. Were we not familiar with the nature of the influences which finally defeat such measures as aim to accomplish great public good[???] by supplanting unworthy officials, we should rest satisfied with the present position of the Health bill, and believe that this Legislature could not adjourn without making it a law.
lead_paragraph: The Health bill seems to be the most popular, as it certainly is the most important, measure before the Legislature. abstract: Not very long ago, Samuel Sprince, an old man whose reputation as a receiver of stolen goods is extended, was convicted of that offence in the Court of General Sessions, and, to the utter amazement of everybody, Judge Russell discharged him upon his payment of a fine of six cents. Early on Saturday morning, three thieves drove up to the premises No.38 Walker-street, and broke open the store of Mr. Godfrey Sellers, on the third floor, whence they stole pieces of woolen goods, valued in the aggregate at $251 25, besides a piece of broadcloth valued at $47, the property of Mr. Benj. B. Nichols, who occupied a portion of the same store, which they threw into the wagon and then started off in a hurry. A gentlemen observed these suspicious movements and followed the thieves to the well-known residence of Sprince, No.10 Greene-street, where the goods were left. He immediately informed Officers Lattor and Cole, of the Fifth Precinct, and they, accompanied by Mr. Sellers, succeeded in securing a portion of the property from Sprince and his two sons, Julius and Bernard, which at the time was supposed to be all that had been stolen. Subsequently, when me error had been found out, the officers returned for the remainder of the property, with orders to arrest the old man and his sons. Upon searching the house they discovered the other part of the goods, but Sprince the elder had gone, and so far has eluded the Police. His sons Julius and Bernard were apprehended, and Justice CONNOLLY, before whom they were taken, held them for examination. Nothing is known of the burglars.

A gentlemen observed these suspicious movements and followed the thieves to the well-known residence of Sprince, No.10 Greene-street, where the goods were left. He immediately informed Officers Lattor and Cole, of the Fifth Precinct, and they, accompanied by Mr. Sellers, succeeded in securing a portion of the property from Sprince and his two sons, Julius and Bernard, which at the time was supposed to be all that had been stolen. His sons Julius and Bernard were apprehended, and Justice CONNOLLY, before whom they were taken, held them for examination. Nothing is known of the burglars.

abstract: The election in Connecticut takes place today. It is an important contest, and efforts have been made by both political parties corresponding to the extreme interest felt in the result. The whole State has been canvassed with a degree of vigor, activity and enthusiasm seldom evinced in any State contest.
lead_paragraph: The election in Connecticut takes place today. It is an important contest, and efforts have been made by both political parties corresponding to the extreme interest felt in the result. The whole State has been canvassed with a degree of vigor, activity and enthusiasm seldom evinced in any State contest. Able men from both parties have been brought from other States, and have addressed public meetings day after day, in every part of the State; -- immense sums of money have been expended in the canvass, -- and no stone has been left unturned by either party to secure success to its candidate.
headline: {'main': 'The Connecticut Election.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Connecticut Election.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The second trial of James Shepherd for murder and arson was concluded on Saturday, after a long address to the jury, for the defence, by Mr. Ashmead, and a reply from Mr. Waterbury. In the first division of his charge to the jury, Judge RUSSELL instructed them to convict the prisoner; in the second division, or concluding half of the charge, he instructed them to acquit. They retired at 4 o'clock on Saturday afternoon, and are still out, being entirely unable to agree.
lead_paragraph: The second trial of James Shepherd for murder and arson was concluded on Saturday, after a long address to the jury, for the defence, by Mr. Ashmead, and a reply from Mr. Waterbury. In the first division of his charge to the jury, Judge RUSSELL instructed them to convict the prisoner; in the second division, or concluding half of the charge, he instructed them to acquit. They retired at 4 o'clock on Saturday afternoon, and are still out, being entirely unable to agree.

abstract: UNPAID BONDS OF THE CITY OF MILWAUKEE. -- A meeting of the bondholders of the unpaid bonds and coupons of the city of Milwaukee, was held on Saturday evening at the Brevoort House. Over forty persons were present, and $600,000 of the bonds were represented. WATTS SHERMAN, Esq., of the firm of DUMCAN, SHERMAN & Co., presided. Mr. SIMEON DEAPER, who has recently been to Milwaukee on behalf of the bondholders residing in this City -- nearly one-half of the bonds being in the hands of New-York merchants -- made a statement of the result of his visit and inquiries. He gave it as his opinion that a full and satisfactory adjustment of the securities would be made, and presented a letter from Mayor PAGE, of Milwaukee, to this effect. A resolution was passed directing that all the bondholders send their names, residences and the number of bonds respectively held by them, or represented by them, to Messrs. DUNCAN, SHERMAN & Co., of this City, on or before the 15th inst. Messrs. Chas. Moran, Abijah Mann, Simeon Draper. A. Bursch, John A. Stevens, O. Van Hoffman and Watts Sherman were appointed a Committee to arrange the classification of the bonds, and call a future meeting.

abstract: INCENDIARY FIRES -- AN ARREST. -- At a little past 10 o'clock Saturday night a blacksmith's shop on DeKalb, near Hudson-avenue, was discovered to be on fire by the Police, who extinguished the flames with a few buckets of water. A few minutes after a fire burst out in a stable in Fulton place, between Fulton-avenue and Livingston-street. The stables with four horses, and a carpenter-shop were detroyed. The loss is estimated at $1,000. Mr. CHARLES MILLER owned the property. There was no insurance upon it. From a variety of circumstances Fire Marshal BELKNAP concluded that both of these fires were the work of an incendiary, and late the same night Officer MUNSON, of the First Precinct Police, arrested a man well known to the Police, named NOAH L. BROWN, supposed to have caused them. He was committed for examination......Between 10 and 11 o'clock Saturday night a small stable in Classon, near Flushing-avenue, was destroyed -- by an incendiary, it is alleged. Loss $100. No insurance......At 1 o'clock Saturday afternoon a fire was discovered in the ship-yard of E. WILLIAMS, Greenpoint. The fire was extinguished without much damage.......Between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in SIMONSON's ship-yard, at the foot of Milton-street, Greenpoint. The mould loft was destroyed, involving a loss of about $3,000. This fire also was the work of an incendiary.

abstract: When, in the development of a steam-propelled age, each function of daily life is in some measure dependent upon the arts of engineering; when every branch of commerce and production is calling for new help from the inanimate motors; and when, at the same time failure cuts short the career of most of the new inventions which swarm from the Patent Office, and the unscientific practice, or the impracticable scheming of inventors as a class,
lead_paragraph: When, in the development of a steam-propelled age, each function of daily life is in some measure dependent upon the arts of engineering; when every branch of commerce and production is calling for new help from the inanimate motors; and when, at the same time failure cuts short the career of most of the new inventions which swarm from the Patent Office, and the unscientific practice, or the impracticable scheming of inventors as a class, has forfeited the general confidence in mechanical novelties, we naturally look to our schools and colleges for aid. We look to them for the reconciliation and alliance of theory and practice -- for the culture of unlettered ingenuity in the laws and history of Science, and the putting of a speaking tongue into the dumb mouth of Rule and Formula -- for restraining erratic genius within the limits of practicability, and clothing the impalpable spirit of Theory with a working body and iron arms -- that Science may no longer shine under a bushel, and that Practice may no longer grope in the uncertain light of instinct and limited experience. It is too late to restrict the learned professions to three; a fourth, delving at an equal depth into the great unknown, and revolutionizing the whole world with its benefits, has taken the foremost rank among the allies of civilization. There is, indeed, a grim dignity in the old fashioned regime of classical culture, and a decoction of Greek roots is capital bitters for the youthful understanding, but there is a field not only for intellectual culture, but for intellectual achievement of the highest order, in the not less comprehensive, and rather more intricate theme of dynamics. It devolves upon our schools and universities, not only to fit the mind for work, but to set-it at work. What is the fact in the case?

abstract: The examination in the case of the Chinaman Jackalow, of the sloop Spray, was resumed on Saturday morning, at Jersey City, before United States Commissioner VROOM. The sloop has been hauled up on to the beach, and a full examination of her cabin made. The only new articles discovered were a revolver, with one barrel loaded; a double-barreled shot-gun, not loaded; a daguerreotype, a pair of silver sleeve-buttons, and fifty pennies. A quantity of vermilion was found under the captain's berth, from which it is supposed that the red stains on the mattress, which were thought to be blood, were derived.

abstract: By the Bavaria, arrived at this port yesterday, we have one day's later news from Europe. The Brussels Nord has been seized at Paris for printing ANTONELLI'S reply to THOUVENEL'S Dispatch in advance, contrary to diplomatic usage. It was rumored that the Moniteur was about to publish an official declaration that France would ratify the annexation of Central Italy to Piedmont. We have the text of the official protest of the Swiss Government against the annexation of Savoy.

abstract: PATRICK ROAKE, aged 21 years, was shipped as seaman last Saturday, on the ship Niagara, now lying off the Battery, but about to depart for New-Orleans, going on board while intoxicated, he first threatened the lives of the officers of the vessel; then entering the forecastle, he shot himself in the neck with a pistol, inflicting a wound which immediately resulted fatally. Coroner JACKMAN was summoned to hold an inquest.

abstract: Mr. BUCHANAN must be presumed to be sincere in the desire which he so pathetically expressed, in his late message to the House of Representatives, to have the President of the United States held in proper respect by Congress as well as the community at large.
lead_paragraph: Mr. BUCHANAN must be presumed to be sincere in the desire which he so pathetically expressed, in his late message to the House of Representatives, to have the President of the United States held in proper respect by Congress as well as the community at large. Of the various ways in which this respect can doubtless be testified, however, he only mentioned one -- and that was rigid abstinence from all inquiry into the way in which he and his subordinates have been carrying on the Government. As this manner of displaying reverence for himself and his office happens to be just now singularly distasteful to the public, and will, in all probability, not be resorted to, we are prepared to supply him with a hint as to the best mode of beginning to excite the sympathy in his favor, of which he just now seems to stand so greatly in need, and if he is wise he will avail himself of it. It is the more valuable, though we praise it who shouldn't, from the fact that it suggests nothing for the execution of which he is not himself amply capable. It is neither more nor less than effecting an immediate change in the tone and language of his official organ, the Constitution; or if -- as the world would not be at all astonished to hear -- this little task should be beyond his powers, putting a final, formal and public end to his connection with it.
headline: {'main': "The President's Organ.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The President's Organ.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A special meeting of the Board of Ten Governors was convened at the Rotunda yesterday, to take action on the death of ISAAC TOWNSEND, a Governor since the Board was organized in 1849, excepting one year, during which he was necessarily absent.
lead_paragraph: A special meeting of the Board of Ten Governors was convened at the Rotunda yesterday, to take action on the death of ISAAC TOWNSEND, a Governor since the Board was organized in 1849, excepting one year, during which he was necessarily absent. All the members excepting Gov. DUGRO were present. Gov. B.F. PINCKNEY was in the Chair, and opened the proceedings by alluding to the sudden demise of Mr. TOWNSEND, pronouncing an appropriate eulogy upon the character of the deceased.

abstract: The bids for the construction of a number of sewers were opened yesterday at the office of the Croton Board, and awarded as follows: That for the sewer in Second-avenue, to and through Forty-seventh street to Thirdavenue, and in Third-avenue, from Forty-seventhstreet to a point midway between Forty-fifth and For...
lead_paragraph: The bids for the construction of a number of sewers were opened yesterday at the office of the Croton Board, and awarded as follows: That for the sewer in Second-avenue, to and through Forty-seventh street to Thirdavenue, and in Third-avenue, from Forty-seventhstreet to a point midway between Forty-fifth and Forty-sixth streets, and also in Forty-eighth-street -- was awarded to W. GALLAGHER, the lowest of seven bidders. He gives sureties in $5,000. The contract for the sewer in Second-avenue, from Thirty-ninth-street to Forty-first-street, was awarded to J. BOWEN, the lowest bidder out of five. Sureties for $3,000 were given by him. That for the sewer in Sixth-avenue, from Forty fourth to Forty-seventh-street, for which there were three bids, was awarded to J. CROWLEY, who gave sureties in $2,000. That for the sewer in Fourth-avenue, commencing at Forty-seventh-street thence to Forty-sixth-street, and through that street to a point within 60 feet of the Fifth-avenue, for which there were nine bids, was awarked to J. BOWEN. He gives surety for $3,000.

abstract: MARTIN DORSCHER, a young German laborer, employed by a gardener named JOHN MILLER, was driving with a load of manure down a steep hill in Broadway, near One Hundred and Twentieth street last Saturday, when his horse becoming restive, he determined to detach him from the vehicle and allow it to roll down the hill of itself.
lead_paragraph: MARTIN DORSCHER, a young German laborer, employed by a gardener named JOHN MILLER, was driving with a load of manure down a steep hill in Broadway, near One Hundred and Twentieth street last Saturday, when his horse becoming restive, he determined to detach him from the vehicle and allow it to roll down the hill of itself. As he held one of the shafts to direct the wagon's course, a large stone suddenly arrested further progress, and the shaft striking the deceased, caused him to fall. He was found some time afterwards quite insensible and badly injured about the head, and in spite of every effort to restore him to consciousness he expired. Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest at the late residence of deceased in Seventy-third-street, corner of Eleventh-avenue.

abstract: Soon after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a man named PETER HALL was beaten to death in the liquor store kept by HERMAN LOHMAN, at the northwest corner of Rutgers and Water streets. From the statements of parties who witnessed the occurrence, it appears that HALL, who is by occupation a ship carpenter and caulker, has for some time past led a...
lead_paragraph: Soon after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a man named PETER HALL was beaten to death in the liquor store kept by HERMAN LOHMAN, at the northwest corner of Rutgers and Water streets. From the statements of parties who witnessed the occurrence, it appears that HALL, who is by occupation a ship carpenter and caulker, has for some time past led a very dissolute life, spending what little money he earned for liquor, and becoming very quarrelsome when under its influence. Yesterday he passed most of the day in the liquor shop in question, occupying himself in drinking and playing dominoes, and at the time of the affray which resulted in his death, he was much intoxicated. About 4 o'clock, one PATRICK MURPHY, a laborer employed on NICHOLSON's large box dry-dock, lying between Rutgers, and Pike streets, in company with JOHN MCCARTY, a fellow-workman went was into LOHMANN's for a drink. At this time HALL was standing at the bar, and MURPHY so excited his ire by accidentally pushing against him that he made use of very abusive language. MURPHY in turn became incensed, and an altercation ensued, which finally resulted in his receiving a blow from the drunken man. MURPHY, who is a powerful fellow, retorted by knocking his assailant down, after which he stamped with his heavy boots upon his head and chest, inflicting such injuries that he died almost immediately, the occurrence having transpired in such a brief space of time that the bystanders had no chance to interfere. MURPHY immediately started off, and, although the police were quickly apprised of the murder, and a large force was immediately dispatched in pursuit of him, he has so far eluded their search. Deceased much bruised and disfigured, was removed to the Station-house, and a physician having been called, he was examined and pronounced to be dead. An inquest will be held upon the body to-day. HALL, was a Scotchman, 35 years of age, unmarried, and boarded in Rutgers-street, near Monroe. MURPHY the alleged murderer, resides with his wife and three children at No. 379 Cherry-street. He is a rather good-looking Irishman, 26 years of age, and is said to be of a quarrelsome disposition. The Police hope to effect his arrest.

abstract: -The Board of Su  pervisors yesterday again refused to pay Mayor WOOD'S bills for advertising the ordinances and resolutions awaiting his approval. This is perfectly right and proper. There is no law authorizing any such publication on his part, and he has no more right to expend money in this way than in any other.
lead_paragraph: -The Board of Supervisors yesterday again refused to pay Mayor WOOD'S bills for advertising the ordinances and resolutions awaiting his approval. This is perfectly right and proper. There is no law authorizing any such publication on his part, and he has no more right to expend money in this way than in any other. If he may advertise in one paper he may in a dozen. He has just as much authority to expend a million dollars as he has a hundred. The Board of Supervisors have discharged a public duty in refusing payment.

lead_paragraph: The semi-annual session of the Third Presbytery of New-York (New School) commenced in this City yesterday, at the Mercer-street Presbyterian Church. About forty members were present, twothirds of whom were ministers. Rev. WALTER CLARKE, D.D., of the Mercer-street Church, was elected Moderator for the ensuing six months; and Revs. C.C. WALLACE and E.W. FRENCH were chosen temporary Secretaries. On motion of Dr. HATFIELD, the Presbytery went into a viva voce nomination of Commissioners to the next General Assembly, to be held at Pittsburgh on the third Thursday in May. The following gentlemen were put in nomination, and will be voted on to-day:

abstract: In January, 1859, a dispute occurred in a drinkingplace in Fulton-street, between a number of well known rowdies, and one of them named Patrick Cosgrove alias "Cockroach," was stabbed in the melee which resulted. The injured man lingered along for several months, but finally died in July last.
lead_paragraph: In January, 1859, a dispute occurred in a drinkingplace in Fulton-street, between a number of well known rowdies, and one of them named Patrick Cosgrove alias "Cockroach," was stabbed in the melee which resulted. The injured man lingered along for several months, but finally died in July last. During his illness he repeatedly stated that he knew the name of his assailant, but persistently refused to disclose it, for the reason that he hoped to recover and take the law into his own hands. Just previous to the recent Charter election Ex-Counciiman McCarty, of the Third Ward, was apprehended on a charge of having been implicated in the affray which caused Cosgrove's death, and now Barnett Coles, an oysterman, has been arrested on a bench-warrant upon a similar charge. The accused will be arraigned in the Court of General Sessions.

abstract: After having been locked up forty-two hours, the jury in the case of James Shepherd, on his second trial for murder and arson, came into Court yesterday morning and stated that they were still unable to agree, and that there was no prospect of a consummation so much to be desired; whereupon Judge RUSSELL dismissed them, and Shepherd was returned to the Tombs to be tried a third time on a speedy occasion.
lead_paragraph: After having been locked up forty-two hours, the jury in the case of James Shepherd, on his second trial for murder and arson, came into Court yesterday morning and stated that they were still unable to agree, and that there was no prospect of a consummation so much to be desired; whereupon Judge RUSSELL dismissed them, and Shepherd was returned to the Tombs to be tried a third time on a speedy occasion. The April term of the Court was then opened by Recorder BARNARD. Owing to the fact that a Grand Jury was in session in the Oyer and Terminer, (two grand inquests at one time in the same county being contrary to law,) the gentlemen summoned to this Court as Grand Jurors were ordered to attend in two weeks, and dismissed to that time.

abstract: The advanced skirmishing parties of the two armies who are to meet in deadly fray over the Presidential issue, next autumn, had a keen encounter yesterday, in Connecticut. Rarely have such effort and preparation been brought, as in this instance, to a State canvass, where none but State officers were in question; and the intense...
lead_paragraph: The advanced skirmishing parties of the two armies who are to meet in deadly fray over the Presidential issue, next autumn, had a keen encounter yesterday, in Connecticut. Rarely have such effort and preparation been brought, as in this instance, to a State canvass, where none but State officers were in question; and the intense excitement of the electors at the polls, and in drawing out a full vote, proved that the effects of imported oratory and capital were large and extremely satisfactory. We are still without means of judging the event decisively. Our latest despatches, however, seem to indicate that while in the towns heard from, constituting more than one half the State, Mr. SEYMOUR, the Democratic candidate for Governor, had made very heavy gains, they still fell a great way short of overcoming the Republican majority of last Spring; and unhappily, they embrace returns from the strongest Democratic localities. It may not, therefore, be hazardous to anticipate the reelection of Mr. BUCKINGHAM, (Rep,) by a majority seriously reduced, not varying perhaps materially from 1,000. According to the Republican figuring the vote for the Legislature, thus far, promises a decided Republican majority in both branches. This presentation of the matter may, however, be entirely reversed by returns in a later edition.

lead_paragraph: POLITICAL--The charter election, which takes place to-day, bids fair to be an exciting one, and doubtless a respectable vote will be polled. There are three "department" offices to be filled, viz.: Collector of Taxes and Assessments, Street Commissioner, and Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies. For these offices there are four tickets in the field -- one Republican, two Democratic, and one, the "Eclectic" or American, composed of the Democratic and Republican candidates. An unusual amount of political labor has been performed during the past week, particularly by the candidates and their friends of the respective wings of the Democratic Party, and much bad blood has been created, threatening to produce a general row. Several collisions of a petty kind took place last evening -- one, at MCCARTY's barroom, just at the rear of the City Hall, bid fair at one time to be serious in its results. But the prompt action of the Police in arresting the principals in this disturbance rendered the attendance of a Coroner unnecessary. Last evening the "Mozart Hall" wing held a mass meeting at the corner of Grand and Second streets, E.D., when the principal orator of the occasion was Mayor WOOD. The announcement of his name brought together a large crowd of people, representing all parties. The managers of the meeting fortunately invoked the aid of a special police force, and the numerous turbulent spirits were kept in check, so that no serious disturbance occurred. The meeting, of course, was enthusiastic. Besides the "Department" offices to be filled, there are the following Ward officers to be elected: An Alderman in the even enumerated and an Assessor in the odd enumerated Wards, and a Supervisor and Constable in each Ward. The Democrats are more or less split up in every Ward. The Republicans being united, they expect to elect their "Department" ticket and a sufficient number of Aldermen to secure a majority in the Common Council. Whether their expectations will be realized or not can only be ascertained after the votes are counted to-night. The police arrangements for the day are ample for the protection of all persons who wish to approach the polls.

abstract: The Philadelphia North American exults in rather an unfraternal spirit over the sevenleagued strides which the City of Brotherly Love is making to overtake and pass NewYork. Our contemporary discovers that, while Philadelphia has multiplied her population, since 1850 at the rate of 67 per cent., New-York has...
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia North American exults in rather an unfraternal spirit over the sevenleagued strides which the City of Brotherly Love is making to overtake and pass NewYork. Our contemporary discovers that, while Philadelphia has multiplied her population, since 1850 at the rate of 67 per cent., New-York has gained during the same time an increase of only 55 per cent.; and thence infers that, in less than ten years, Philadelphia will "outstrip us," while in "less than thirty years she must double us in numbers." The prospect is solemn, but it does not seriously alarm us, for the experience of London and Paris has proved that the growth, however rapid, of any important suburb, always results in the increased prosperity of the metropolis; and though our contemporary rather cruelly turns Gotham over to the "excessively wild, extravagant and ambitious," and reserves Philadelphia for the decent, orderly, quiet and industrious, we make no doubt that the more people there are in Philadelphia, the more business we shall be doing in New-York. So we trust that holders of property in this "fast and furious" town, where everybody must expect "to die at 26," will not rashly sell out all they have, and reinvest in Philadelphia, for the chance of living "without glaring temptations, to the age of 56." If mere longevity be an object, it would be wiser to take stock in the Bahama Banks, where highly respectable turtles have been known to live for more than a century, and to be in all that time fully as "quiet, orderly and moral in all their habits and movements" as any of the children of PENN.

abstract: At the regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen ast night, a resolution tending to the reduction of the interest now exacted by pawnbrokers on sums less than $25 was adopted, as was a resolution directing the Counsel of the Corporation to prepare a remonstrance against the passage of a bill now before the...
lead_paragraph: At the regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen ast night, a resolution tending to the reduction of the interest now exacted by pawnbrokers on sums less than $25 was adopted, as was a resolution directing the Counsel of the Corporation to prepare a remonstrance against the passage of a bill now before the Legislature providing for the removal of the City Hall to Madison-square. The Committee on Street Cleaning was also required to report whether the interests of the City in making contracts for cleaning the streets would not be best secured by a division of the City into small districts.

abstract: DEATH OF MURPHY, THE BURGLAR--CHARGES MURPHY, the young man who some six weeks ago, in company with one BEENOWSKI, a Pole, broke into  the warehouse No. 540 Pearl-street, and jumped from the roof of the building in his effort to escape from the officers who had discovered him, died yesterday morning at the New-York Hospital, in conse  quence of the injuries he then sustained.
lead_paragraph: DEATH OF MURPHY, THE BURGLAR--CHARGES MURPHY, the young man who some six weeks ago, in company with one BEENOWSKI, a Pole, broke into the warehouse No. 540 Pearl-street, and jumped from the roof of the building in his effort to escape from the officers who had discovered him, died yesterday morning at the New-York Hospital, in conse quence of the injuries he then sustained. MURPHY was under the care of House Surgeon HULL, and as his fractured limbs united properly and his constitution was good, it was at one time believed that he would recover. Latterly, however, the discharges from his wounds have exhausted his system, and, at the time of his death, he had become worn away to a Skeleton. His wife, who is much older than himself, has been constant in her attendance on him. She asserts that the name MURPHY is assumed, that her husband belongs to a very respectable family in Canada, and that his brother now holds a responsible position in one of the City banks. Neither MURPHY for the woman could be induced, however, on account of the disgrace attaching to the matter, to reveal the real name. Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest upon the body. Deceased was 23 years of age.

abstract: There is an old  French proverb which avers that "in the kingdom of the blind the one-eyed is king ;" and we presume that Mayor WOOD has relied upon what Mr. EMERSON would call the "great truth" embalmed in this saying to acquire for himself the Supreme control of the New-York Democracy. But it now appears that the immaculate...
lead_paragraph: There is an old French proverb which avers that "in the kingdom of the blind the one-eyed is king ;" and we presume that Mayor WOOD has relied upon what Mr. EMERSON would call the "great truth" embalmed in this saying to acquire for himself the Supreme control of the New-York Democracy. But it now appears that the immaculate FERNANDO is not the only one of his party who can boast of a "single eye." The Mayor's pocket-organ in this City yesterday devoted one of its most solemn and tremendous strains to expose the machinations of some mysterious colossus, whom it describes as the "Tammany Cyclops," and who is exerting himself, in company with "the Antaeus of the State Capital," to oust the Mayor from his natural control of the coming Charleston Convention. This monster, it seems, has "adopted a system of dynamics," one object of which is to "disseminate Republican poison in the Democratic ranks of Connecticut;" while still another is to seduce "the Washington of the President," and so bring about a state of things in which "consistency and honor will fare but ill." What the result of this profoundly inscrutable battle of the one-eyed shall be, time alone can determine. We can only call the attention of all the world and the rest of mankind to the struggle, unmatched since the days of the Odyssey. At the present moment the "Tammany Cyclops" seems to be winning, on one point, at least, as we infer from the following lament of the Mayor's organ:

abstract: ST. LOUIS, Sunday, April 1. Major WRIGHT closed his argument in the Car  stang-Shaw case last evening. His speech occupied nearly eight hours in delivery, after which the jury retired, and in twenty minutes rendered a verdict for the defendant. A motion for a new trial was immediately filed by the plaintiff's counsel. In case the motion is refused, the case will be appealed to the Supreme Court.

abstract: Early on Saturday morning the woods on the North Beacon Mountain caught fire, as is supposed from the carelessness of a gunning party.
lead_paragraph: Early on Saturday morning the woods on the North Beacon Mountain caught fire, as is supposed from the carelessness of a gunning party. The flames spread rapidly until night-fall when they covered an area of nearly one thousand acres. At one time it was feared that the village of Matteawan would be destroyed, and at the ringing of the alarm bell the citizens turned out en masse to check the progress of the fire. This they succeeded in accomplishing after great exertions. Besides the standing trees, 200 cords of cut wood were consumed.

abstract: -Our readers prob  ably remember that some months ago a Miss CARSTANG, of St. Louis, sued Mr. Shaw, a wealthy citizen of the same place, for having broken his promise to make her his wife.
lead_paragraph: -Our readers probably remember that some months ago a Miss CARSTANG, of St. Louis, sued Mr. Shaw, a wealthy citizen of the same place, for having broken his promise to make her his wife. The Jury gave her the munificent verdict of $100,000 damages. She was contented but Mr. SHAW was not, -- so he moved for another trial, and obtained it. It has just been brought to a close, and Miss CARSTANG gets -- just nothing at all. It will be her turn now to apply for a new trial, though the experience of this last one will probably not inspire her with any very ardent desire for its repetition.

abstract: EXPLOSION AT THE TUNNEL--JOSEPH HARNDEN, one of the workmen at the tunnel, yesterday morning went to the powder chest, in which there were two kegs of powder with the heads out, for the purpose of obtaining a supply for blasting purposes.
lead_paragraph: EXPLOSION AT THE TUNNEL--JOSEPH HARNDEN, one of the workmen at the tunnel, yesterday morning went to the powder chest, in which there were two kegs of powder with the heads out, for the purpose of obtaining a supply for blasting purposes. As he was leaning over a spark fell from the lamp which was attached to the top of his hat and ignited the powder, which exploded with such force as to throw him near 30 yards. He was shockingly mutilated and it is feared that his injuries will prove fatal.....The recent strike at the tunnel has terminated, all the men having been paid up to to the first of March. About 150 men are now at work at the eastern approach and at shafts Nos. 3, 4 and 5.

abstract: Mr. ISAAC TOWNSEND, a member of the Board of Ten Governors, died at his residence in this City on Sunday. His age was 55. Mr. TOWNSEND was engaged in mercantile pursuits during the greater part of his life, but retired some years since from active business. He was formerly President of the Board of Almshouse Governors, and at the time of his death was an efficient member of that body. He was also Vice-President of the Bank of the State of New-York, and a Director of the Panama Railroad Company.

abstract: At the Mayor's Office, yesterday, oc  curred another illustration of the lamentable inefficiency of that tribunal for the administration of justice. We referred the other day to the habit of discharging swindlers brought before the Mayor, upon the payment by them of the money...
lead_paragraph: At the Mayor's Office, yesterday, occurred another illustration of the lamentable inefficiency of that tribunal for the administration of justice. We referred the other day to the habit of discharging swindlers brought before the Mayor, upon the payment by them of the money they have fraudulently obtained, instead of handing them over to the proper officers for judicial examination. Yesterday the keeper of a sailor's boarding-house was brought up on complaint of three Spanish sailors whose clothing he held as security for money which he had paid a runner for delivering them into his clutches. When reproved for the imposition, he defended it by explaining that it was the usual custom -- for the violation which he would be "expelled from his society" -- to pay runners a dollar apiece for every boarder secured, and then to charge the item in the victim's bill, thus making the sailor pay for the privilege of being swindled! The Spaniards were willing to pay for the breakfast they had had, but not the tax on their own capture.

lead_paragraph: A bridge of eighty feet span, and about thirty feet above a small stream on the Harlem railroad, near Hillsdale, was burnt yesterday (Monday.) The passengers will for a day or two be exchanged into trains on opposite sides of the opening. Another bridge will be put up complete in two or three days. Arrangements are made so that the detention for even that time will be trifling. The loss to the Company is two or three thousand dollars.

abstract: DEACON--Most happy am I to meet you, my friend; and at this hour, when we can have a full and candid interchange of views upon a subject which to me is of deep and abiding interest. Like you, I have for years been an ardent friend of the American Tract Society, have loved its great principle of catholic union, have admired its work, ...
lead_paragraph: DEACON--Most happy am I to meet you, my friend; and at this hour, when we can have a full and candid interchange of views upon a subject which to me is of deep and abiding interest. Like you, I have for years been an ardent friend of the American Tract Society, have loved its great principle of catholic union, have admired its work, had unbounded confidence in its Executive Committee and officers, have prayed for God's blessing upon it, and rejoiced in its large success; but during these last years I have heard and read so many complaints against it, that I confess my confidence is shaken; and as another society is proposing to carry forward the work which it is said the American Tract Society at New-York fails to perform, I have thought it might be best to leave the national society and give the other organization my funds, sympathies and prayers. As you understand the whole subject, will you candidly answer my questions, and if possible remove my difficulties?

abstract: At last we have laid our hand upon one of the most "illustrious obscure" of modern times. We have not, indeed, arrested the miscreant who struck William Paterson, nor unearthed ...
lead_paragraph: At last we have laid our hand upon one of the most "illustrious obscure" of modern times. We have not, indeed, arrested the miscreant who struck William Paterson, nor unearthed the cruel parents of Casper Hauser, nor settled the authorship of Junius, nor revealed the true features of the Man in the Iron Mask. But we have discovered the style, title, calling, quality, and very nature of the real Original Jacobs. In, and of itself, this achievement is not, perhaps, particularly worth mentioning, and might be more appropriately chronicled in the calm and spacious pages of the Notes and Queries than in the close and crowded columns of a daily journal. But the Original Jacobs proves to be a political type as well as a curious idiosyncracy. As a mere subject for speculation, he is no doubt as interesting as the Dodo or the Ornithorhynchus; as a power in the State, and the representative of powers greater than himself, he merits grave consideration.

abstract: BUSINESS AT LAWRENCE. -- The new Pemberton Mill will, it is said, be completed about the first of July next. The building will be larger than the old structure, which was so suddenly destroyed. Wooden pillars will be substituted for the iron supports in the old mills. Nearly all the manufactories have as much as they can do to supply with sufficient rapidly their articles of manufacture. A few of the establishments sometimes keep running in the evening. Every thing betokens a very successful months �- a circumstance which, so far as material prosperity can do it, will greatly mitigate the effect of the disaster that occurred in that city on the 10th of January last. -� Bostags Transport

abstract: At a recent monthly meeting of the Massachusetts State Temperance Alliance in Boston, two agents of the Society narrated sundry incidents of the temperance movement, and both agreed that much of the liquor traffic in Boston was caused by the discontinuance of the traffic in the country.
lead_paragraph: At a recent monthly meeting of the Massachusetts State Temperance Alliance in Boston, two agents of the Society narrated sundry incidents of the temperance movement, and both agreed that much of the liquor traffic in Boston was caused by the discontinuance of the traffic in the country. Numerous convictions have been obtained, and others, fearful of prosecution, had fled from the country to the city. Mr. Thompson mentioned two cases from two towns. In one case the man had kept a rum-hole, gambling-saloon and brothel in the same house. Both men had left precipitately, had taken refuge in Boston, and had reopened their trade.

abstract: No person who is capable of passing a judgment upon poetry of the class to which the works of Mrs. BROWNING belong, will need the assurance of her preface to convince him, after he ...
lead_paragraph: No person who is capable of passing a judgment upon poetry of the class to which the works of Mrs. BROWNING belong, will need the assurance of her preface to convince him, after he has read but a single one of these "poems before the Congress," that "they have been written simply because the writer loves truth and justice, quand meme, 'more than PLATO' and PLATO's country, more than DANTE, and DANTE's country, more even than SHAKESPEARE, and SHAKESPEARE's country." Their every verse rings with the clear silver accent of sincere conviction; and the intenser emphasis which sometimes for a moment flings this conviction out with a half-dissonant sharpness like the angry notes of a challenger's trumpet, is the unconscious emphasis of a proud, pure nature deeply stirred, impatient of the skeptic sloth of others, and not untinged with scorn of the dullness and distrust to which it knows it must so often speak.

abstract: A large and most interesting company (over 50 boys and girls) left the City for the West yesterday afternoon under the charge of Mr. HENRY FRIEDGEN. They were brought together by the Children's Aid society, and were for the most part orphans and destitute boys and girls. They were handsome and well dressed children, and appeared exceedingly happy, anticipating a bright future in the land of the West.

abstract: The memory of WASHINGTON IRVING was, under the auspices of the Historical Society, fittingly honored by an assemblage of unusual numbers at the Academy of Music last evening. And not alone in numbers, but in the character of the meeting, was the occasion remarkable.
lead_paragraph: The memory of WASHINGTON IRVING was, under the auspices of the Historical Society, fittingly honored by an assemblage of unusual numbers at the Academy of Music last evening. And not alone in numbers, but in the character of the meeting, was the occasion remarkable. The general audience was creditably attentive through a series of exercises lasting three hours, while among those who were provided with seats on the stage were Hon. LUTHER BRADISH, who presided, Gen. Winfield Scott, Hon. Edward Everett, Hon. Gulian C. Verplanck, Hon. George Bancroft, Dr. John W. Francis, Gov. Hall, of Vermont; George Ticknor, Ex-Governors King and Fish, Charles King, LL.D., Dr. Cogswell, Prof, Geo. W. Greene, District-Attorney Roosevelt, Horace Webster, Wm. B. Astor. Rev. Dr. Osgood, John Jacob Astor, the officers of the Historical Society, and many other persons of equal note.

It is the law of God as well as the law of man. It requires no defence."

abstract: There were reported to the Senate bills organizing the Territories of Arizona and Colorado. Mr. GREEN, of Missouri, subsequently introduced resolutions suggesting charges against WILLIAM MEDILL, Comptroller of the Treasury, the principal ...
lead_paragraph: There were reported to the Senate bills organizing the Territories of Arizona and Colorado. Mr. GREEN, of Missouri, subsequently introduced resolutions suggesting charges against WILLIAM MEDILL, Comptroller of the Treasury, the principal misdemeanor being his refusal to adjust an account with the contractors for the Vera Cruz mail, notwithstanding an act of Congress directing him to do so. The resolutions demanded the removal of Mr. MEDILL. Resolutions providing for the payment of expenses to be incurred in bringing the Japanese Embassy to this country were adopted. The House bill in regard to new contracts for a daily overland mail was referred. A commission was ordered for the adjustment of American claims upon Paraguay. The Homestead bill of the House was called up at the instance of Mr. JOHNSON, of Tennesee, who urged its passage, and was followed in an able and telling speech by Senator WILKINSON, of Minnesota, who also sustained the measure. The House surrendered itself to polygamy and Mormonism, Mr. MCCERAND, of Illinois, opening the day with a set speech in opposition to the pending prohibitory bill. Mr. LAMAR, of Mississippi, was in favor of the bill, as was also Sir. VALLANDIGHAM, of Ohio. Mr. NOELL urged a variety of reasons against it, which were strenthened by the arguments of Mr. KEITT, of South Carolina. Mr. THAYER, of Massachusetts, was for partitioning Utah between the two projected Territories upon its eastern and western frontiers; and so solving the difficulty, without direct legislation. At the same time, He was unfriendly to the organization of the new Territories. At the adjournment, Mr. KEITT was still speaking adversely to the bill.

CANNON, Esq., the United States District-Attorney, having recovered from his recent illness, was present, and took charge of the case on behalf of the Government. He deemed it unnecessary to dwell upon the case, which had beeen closed by Mr. JELLIFFE on Saturday, ...
lead_paragraph: The examination of the Chinaman was concluded yesterday, at Jersey City. G.S. CANNON, Esq., the United States District-Attorney, having recovered from his recent illness, was present, and took charge of the case on behalf of the Government. He deemed it unnecessary to dwell upon the case, which had beeen closed by Mr. JELLIFFE on Saturday, and asked that JACKALOW be committed to the custody of the United States Marshal, and kept in the Essex County Jail, to await the action of the Grand Jury upon the charges -- first, of murder; second, of piracy; and third, of robbery, the latter being for running away with the sloop Spray with the intention of stealing her.

abstract: SALE OF THE EVERETT HOUSE PROPERTY.--That section of the Everett House property which formed a portion of the estate of the late ANSON G. PHELPS, was sold at auction yesterday, to close the estate. The part sold has a front of 54 feet on Seventeenthstreet, and 100 feet on Fourth-avenue.
lead_paragraph: SALE OF THE EVERETT HOUSE PROPERTY.--That section of the Everett House property which formed a portion of the estate of the late ANSON G. PHELPS, was sold at auction yesterday, to close the estate. The part sold has a front of 54 feet on Seventeenthstreet, and 100 feet on Fourth-avenue. The property was sold subject to a lease held by the present proprietors of the hotel, until 1866, at an annual rent of $11,000; to a party-wall agreement, and to mortgages amounting, in the aggregate, to $100,000. For some time after the property was offered; for sale there was not a bid for it. Finally, Mr. ADAM NORRIE offered $101,600, and it was knocked down to him. The sale of the property does not in any way interfere with the business of the hotel.

abstract: Christopher Cox, while at the house of John Saaecka, at the corner of Thirty-first-street and Tenth- avenue, between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday morning, became engaged in an altercation, during progress of which he drew a knife and stabeed Saaecka in various places, inflicting injuries of such a nature that his life is despaired of.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Cox, while at the house of John Saaecka, at the corner of Thirty-first-street and Tenth- avenue, between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday morning, became engaged in an altercation, during progress of which he drew a knife and stabeed Saaecka in various places, inflicting injuries of such a nature that his life is despaired of. Twentieth Precinct hearing the cries of saaeckas wife for aid, ran into the room, but did not succeed in securing the desperado until, in his attempts to stab him, he had cut his coat in several places. Cox was held on a charge of felonious assault, and his victim was placed under the care of physicians.

abstract: Messrs. WM. HALL  SON have just issued, in fine folio style, the complete score for voice and piano of Mr. W.V. WALLACE'S new opera of "Lurline," recently produced in London with unequaled success. Considered simply in its mechanical aspects, the volume ...
lead_paragraph: Messrs. WM. HALL SON have just issued, in fine folio style, the complete score for voice and piano of Mr. W.V. WALLACE'S new opera of "Lurline," recently produced in London with unequaled success. Considered simply in its mechanical aspects, the volume is most creditable, and evidences both progress and enterprise in American matters musical. A few years ago the publication of such a work would have been regarded not only as an impossible, but even a ridiculous feat. Now every amateur of pretension prides himself on familiarity with the partitions of new operas. We do not propose to criticize the music of Mr. WALLACE's opera until we are justified in doing so by a dramatic performance of it. Gathering, however, a general idea of the work from the score, we have no hesitation in pronouncing it a remarkable addition to the repertoire of the English stage. The ensembles are numerous, and display rare powers of invention and knowledge of lyric effect. The ballads and sensation pieces are full of telling melodic points, and frequently, very striking in harmonic treatment. In two words, the work is both popular and musicianable, and perused in dry detail, accounts for the extraordinary enthusiasm which prevails in London concerning its merits. There are 32 numbers and 300 pages in the complete edition, which, in every typographical respect, reflects credit on the enterprising house to whom we are indebted for it.

abstract: The Legislature yesterday took some important action concerning property in this City owned by the State. A bill was passed directing its survey and sale to the City, and authorizing the Comptroller to settle any judgements ...
lead_paragraph: The Legislature yesterday took some important action concerning property in this City owned by the State. A bill was passed directing its survey and sale to the City, and authorizing the Comptroller to settle any judgements that may have been recovered against the City for the use of such lands hitherto. We believe this latter provision relates to the Washington Market property, to which the State has recently established a title, although the rents upon it have been collected by the City for ten or twelve years past.

abstract: Coroner JACKMAN yesterday investigated the circumstances attending the death of Peter Hall, the facts of whose murder, on Monday evening, by PATRICK MURPHY, in the porter-house of HERMAN LOHMANN, at No. 514 Water-street, have already been published. Mrs. WELTJE and BEACH made a postmortem examination, showing that compression of the brain had produced death and a verdict charging MURPHY with having perpetrated the murder was rendered. The accused is still at large.
lead_paragraph: Coroner JACKMAN yesterday investigated the circumstances attending the death of Peter Hall, the facts of whose murder, on Monday evening, by PATRICK MURPHY, in the porter-house of HERMAN LOHMANN, at No. 514 Water-street, have already been published. Mrs. WELTJE and BEACH made a postmortem examination, showing that compression of the brain had produced death and a verdict charging MURPHY with having perpetrated the murder was rendered. The accused is still at large.

abstract: The Conference Committee of the Senate and Assembly on the Railroad Toll bill disagree. The Senate Committee offer various propositions, one of which is to raise the compensation for tolls to $1,300,000, and to remove the restrictions on the fare of the Central Road. The Assembly Committee decline this, and insist on their own bill imposing tolls, or on the repeal of the law removing the tolls.

abstract: The Republicans have carried Connecticut-- by a very small majority to be sure, but with a decided ascendancy in each branch of the Legislature.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans have carried Connecticut-- by a very small majority to be sure, but with a decided ascendancy in each branch of the Legislature. Their candidate for Governor is elected by 517 majority. "It is not so deep as a well, nor so wide as a church door -- but it will do." They have achieved a victory of very marked importance -- one which will have a decided effect upon the action of both political parties at their National Conventions. It will encourage the Republicans to rely with confidence upon their own principles, their own organization, and their own candidates; and will, at the same time, teach the Democrats that they cannot carry any New-England, and probably no Northern State, with such a platform and such candidates as their Southern wing threatens to impose upon them.

abstract: The association known as "The Marine Temperance Society of the Port of New-York," held its twenty-seventh meeting last evening in the Mariner's Church, corner of Catharine and Madison streets. abstract: Lefevre vs. Picrson et al. -- This was an action for an alleged, trespass. The suit arose out of the following facts. In January, 1859, H.H. Morange, Esq., caused an attachment to issue against the plaintiff as an absconding debtor, which was levied by the defendant Pierson. The plaintiff gave the defendant $360 in lion of the goods seized. The plaintiff afterward commenced this action to recover damages for the alleged illegal levy of the attachment; the objection being that the attachment was issued without due authority by the Justice.

abstract: On the 23d ultimo a fight occurred between a number of men at the drinking-saloon No. 80 West-street, and during its progress two of the belligerents, named WILLIAM HICKEY and JOHN KEEVAN, were stabbed by the proprietor of the place, who was arrested. The wounded men were taken to the New-York Hospital, where HICKEY died within a few days of his admission, and KEEVAN, having lingered until Tuesday, finally sank from the effects of his injuries. Coroner SCHIRLIER yesterday held an inquest at the Trinity-place Station-house upon the body of KEEVAN, at which similar evidence to that taken in the case of HICKEY was adduced, resulting in a verdict that death had been caused by peritonitis, the result of wounds at the hands of DUNNIGAN. The prisoner states that he used the knife in self-defence, but the evidence does not verify his assertion. The friends of the deceased parties are greatly enraged against DUNNIGAN, and threats of lynching him having been made by the crowd on his appearance yesterday at the inquest, the officers had to remove him to another room. DUNNIGAN is a vicious-looking fellow, and is said to have stabbed a man named CHRISTOPHER MORAN, at the drinking-saloon No. 25 State-street, Brooklyn, about a month ago; but he was never tried for the offence, on account of the refusal of MORAN to appear against him.
lead_paragraph: On the 23d ultimo a fight occurred between a number of men at the drinking-saloon No. 80 West-street, and during its progress two of the belligerents, named WILLIAM HICKEY and JOHN KEEVAN, were stabbed by the proprietor of the place, who was arrested. The prisoner states that he used the knife in self-defence, but the evidence does not verify his assertion. abstract: The New Haven Journal, of yesterday, gives returns from every town in the State except five. The Republican majority on the Gubernational ticket is 351. The remaining towns, it is thought, will increase this figure. The Courant claims 600 majority for BUCKINGHAM, but the returns show only the figures as stated by the Journal. The aggregate vote polled at this election was 86,000; an increase of nearly 6,000 over that of the Presidential campaign of 1856.

abstract: Mrs. Bridget Smith, who resides in Eighty-fourth-street, near Eighth-avenue, a few days since received a destitute married couple, named Patrick and Bridget McDermott, into her house, until such time as they should be able to obtain other accommodations. After remaining a day or two, they repaid her kindness by absconding with her little hoard of $50. Officer Bernholz, of the Twenty-second Ward, succeeded in arresting the graceless vagrants, and recovered the money, which the woman had concealed in her stocking. The prisoners were committed by Justice QUACKENBUSH to answer for the larceny.

abstract: The Rhode Island election has terminated, as was to be anticipated, in the triumph of the Democratic-Republican coalition. Mr. SPRAGUE, who was on the allied ticket for Governor, has unquestionably been chosen, by a majority not varying greatly, it is supposed, from 1,500. The Republicans have also lost both branches of the Legislature. The election was the occasion of very great excitement. Money was openly offered for voters; and our correspondent states that men of known wealth exposed their ballots to sale at prices ranging from ten to fifty dollars. No acts of violence are reported. The victory was celebrated at Providence, among the triumphant party, with a feast, and a serenade to the Governor elect.
lead_paragraph: The Rhode Island election has terminated, as was to be anticipated, in the triumph of the Democratic-Republican coalition. Mr. SPRAGUE, who was on the allied ticket for Governor, has unquestionably been chosen, by a majority not varying greatly, it is supposed, from 1,500. The Republicans have also lost both branches of the Legislature. The election was the occasion of very great excitement. Money was openly offered for voters; and our correspondent states that men of known wealth exposed their ballots to sale at prices ranging from ten to fifty dollars. No acts of violence are reported. The victory was celebrated at Providence, among the triumphant party, with a feast, and a serenade to the Governor elect.

abstract: The sixth and last of a course of lectures in aid of the First German Presbyterian Church, in Sixth-street, was delivered in that Church last evening, by Rev. Dr. ADAMS. His subject was "Labor," which he proposed to consider in its relations to character, rather than in its connection with political economy. The phrase "laboring classes" he disliked, as tending to perpetuate distinctions that did not exist, and to engender false notions upon the whole subject of labor. According to the Christian dispensation, we are all laborers, and the labor of all, provided it is legitimate and necessary, is alike honorable. Half of the trouble that arises out of this subject of labor would be avoided by a recognition of the doctrine of the New Testament, of the honorable character and mutual dependence of all varieties of labor. The professional man and the mechanic, the student and the farmer, though laboring in different fields, were mutually dependent upon each other, and were engaged in equally useful and respectable occupations. It was a great mistake to suppose that the man who works with his mind is not a laborer; his is the hardest kind of labor.

abstract: Such has been the uniform growth of the United States for seventy years past, that the aggregate result of the census of 1860, in regard to population, is no mystery. We know almost exactly what the aggregate is to be -- and for a majority of the States, we know almost the precise results. In the general and particular estimates, there are, however, two variables. These are, first, the amount of foreign immigration and its distribution; and, secondly, the amount and distribution of domestic migrations. But, to correct these, we have some very accurate data.

abstract: We understand that a project is on foot, which will go into effect next week, for supplying the country with New-York newspapers still more promptly and generally than hitherto. Mr. SHEARS, who has for some time past had the contract for transporting newspapers and periodicals over the Hudson River Road, has made an arrangement to run a special Newspaper Express, leaving New-York at 4 o'clock in the morning, and reaching Albany in time ...
lead_paragraph: We understand that a project is on foot, which will go into effect next week, for supplying the country with New-York newspapers still more promptly and generally than hitherto. Mr. SHEARS, who has for some time past had the contract for transporting newspapers and periodicals over the Hudson River Road, has made an arrangement to run a special Newspaper Express, leaving New-York at 4 o'clock in the morning, and reaching Albany in time for the first morning train for Buffalo at 8 1/2 o'clock. A locomotive and baggage-car only will be run to Poughkeepsie, and will not stop this side of that place, except for wood and water. At that point the engine will be changed, and a single passenger-car will be attached. The whole train, however, will be run by Mr. SHEARS, and at his own expense, for the express purpose of supplying the North and West with New-York papers from three to ten hours in advance of the time they are now received.

abstract: The People vs. The Mayor and Common Council of Brooklyn, This was a motion for an injunction against the Common Council of the City of Brooklyn, to restrain that body from authorizing the Ferry Committee to use any sum of money to be voted by the Common Council from the Treasury of the City, in any attempt to influence the "Courts and Legisla- ...
lead_paragraph: The People vs. The Mayor and Common Council of Brooklyn, This was a motion for an injunction against the Common Council of the City of Brooklyn, to restrain that body from authorizing the Ferry Committee to use any sum of money to be voted by the Common Council from the Treasury of the City, in any attempt to influence the "Courts and Legislature" in regard to "cheap ferriage." The motion is based upon the affidavit of Edward White, a resident and tax-payer of that City, who avers that in a secret session of the Common Council, on or about March 26, they voted $20,000, to be used by their Ferry Committee for such purposes.

abstract: THE LATE ISAAC TOWNSEND. -- The funeral of ISAAC TOWNSEND, late Governor of the Almshouse, took place yesterday afternoon from Grace Church, and was attended by the Mayor of the City, both branches of the Common Council, the Board of Ten Governors, and a large concourse of prominent citizens and friends of the deceased. The services were conducted in the Episcopal form, by Rev. Dr. TAYLOR, rector of the Church, assisted by Rev. Dr. HIGBEE, and Rev. Mr. HAUGHTON. The following list of pall-bearers, selected entirely from the business associates of the deceased, testifies to the high standing, which he held in the mercantile world: Wm. E. Wilmerding, Geo. Duer, R.S. Hone, Reuben Withers, John Steward, Auguste Belmont, Jno. J. Kingsford Wm. H. Aspinwall, Isaac Bell, Simeon Draper. The attending physicians were Drs. Delafield, Marcoe, Clark, and Elliott. The body was deposited in the family vault at Trinity Cemetery. A meeting of the Medical Board of Bellevue Hospital was held on Tuesday at the house of Dr. James R. Wood, to take action in regard to the death of Mr. TOWNSEND. Drs. Clark, Parker and Jas. R. Wood, were appointed a Committee to draft suitable resolutions, and submitted the following, which were adopted unanimously:

abstract: A case of peculiar hardship, caused by the fraud of a well-known lawyer, who fled the country in 1854, leaving behind him as large a record of deliberate villainous malversation of trusts as has been known for many years, was brought to the notice of the Comptroller yesterday. In 1853 the lawyer in question sold to a man in moderate circumstances a lot of ground on Eighteenth-street, upon which there was a mortgage for $1,000, held by the City, but no mention was made of this at the time, nor was any search of title instituted, the purchaser being willing to take title of the City. The lawyer paid the interest on the $1,000 regularly up to the time of his flight, so that notice should not reach the purchaser, and after his departure a mortgage of $1,900 given to the lawyer was paid to his assignee, and this, it was supposed, paid for the property. Mr. FRANKLIN, collector of City revenues, discovered yesterday, however, that for five years no interest had been paid, and this, (which, unless relief is granted, subjects the property to resale,) was the first intimation the purchaser had of the fraud which had been practiced on him. An application to the Supervisors may possibly save the victim from a second payment.
lead_paragraph: A case of peculiar hardship, caused by the fraud of a well-known lawyer, who fled the country in 1854, leaving behind him as large a record of deliberate villainous malversation of trusts as has been known for many years, was brought to the notice of the Comptroller yesterday. The lawyer paid the interest on the $1,000 regularly up to the time of his flight, so that notice should not reach the purchaser, and after his departure a mortgage of $1,900 given to the lawyer was paid to his assignee, and this, it was supposed, paid for the property. Mr. FRANKLIN, collector of City revenues, discovered yesterday, however, that for five years no interest had been paid, and this, (which, unless relief is granted, subjects the property to resale,) was the first intimation the purchaser had of the fraud which had been practiced on him. An application to the Supervisors may possibly save the victim from a second payment.

abstract: The result of the Rhode Island election was not a Democratic victory, though it was a Republican defeat. abstract: Time was that when the enacting clause was out a bill would die, but our enterprising representatives at Albany have changed all that. They can bear that good bills should perish stillborn; but they cannot endure that a bad bill once killed should stay killed forever, and so refuse their successors the pleasure of killing
lead_paragraph: Time was that when the enacting clause was out a bill would die, but our enterprising representatives at Albany have changed all that. They can bear that good bills should perish stillborn; but they cannot endure that a bad bill once killed should stay killed forever, and so refuse their successors the pleasure of killing it once more. In accordance with a venerable Western custom, derived from those primitive times in which men helped each other to log houses, instead of hindering each other as now they do from brown-stone fronts, our Albany legislators have organized themselves into a Mutual Assurance Company for the passage of all measures which have no merits of their own whereby to pass. Yesterday morning three bills -- one levying a tax of one mill on all assessed property in the State of New-York in aid of the Albany and Susquehannah Railroad; another organizing a new County, by the name of Highland, to be formed from portions of Ulster and Orange Counties; and a third, known as the Anti-Rent bill, altering the Revised Statutes in regard to the alienation of property, with a view to favoring the Anti-Renters -- were passed in the House. Each of these bills had been previously "killed;" they were revived simultaneously, and came to life by almost exactly the same vote in each particular case.
