abstract: SALE OF VASES ONCE OWNED BY LOUIS PHILLIPPE AND ANTIQUE PAINTINGS AND FURNITURE. At the sale of the contents of a private house in Ninth-street, near Fifth-avenue, yesterday, some rare articles were disposed of.
lead_paragraph: SALE OF VASES ONCE OWNED BY LOUIS PHILLIPPE AND ANTIQUE PAINTINGS AND FURNITURE. At the sale of the contents of a private house in Ninth-street, near Fifth-avenue, yesterday, some rare articles were disposed of. An exquisite piece of statuary, a sleeping infant, in white marble, by POMPOLON, of Florence, which headed the list, was knocked down for $100, to Mr. NIBLO, of Niblo's Garden. The eighth article, as stated in the catalogue, was a "Louis Philippe Vase, purchased at his auction in Paris." The purchaser was an elderly Frenchman. The vase is of Dresden China, and the shape and size of a medium punch bowl, and elegantly mounted. It bears the stamp of Sevres, besides the impress of the words "Palace" and "Tuilleries," to counterfeit which used to be felony. On one side is a representation of two cupids, holding between them a flower wreath, and beneath a crown, over the initials P.L. The vase has been mended several times. A trousseau box from Florence, said to be 400 years old, brought $65. A carved bedstead, reported of the same age, and taken from an old palace near Lucca, was sold for $60. There were several vases sold which were taken from Pompeii. Some dozen paintings were included in the sale, principally copies of old artists. Among the copies was one of the "Immaculate Conception," by MURILLO; another of the "Tabernacle," by FRA ANGELICO; the "Virgin of the Harpies," "Achilles Discovered," after BATTONI; "The Deluge," by POUSSIN. The paintings commanded good prices. Carpets, chairs and crockery, bureaus and bedsteads, and stoves and sofas were the closing articles of sale, and when these were reached, the bidding took, as it usually does, a lively turn.

abstract: Mr. F.B. SANBORN is in some respects a much more fortunate man than Mr. THADDEUS HYATT. Instead of being quietly conveyed to Washington, quietly produced before the Senate, quietly permitted to maintain his rights before empty benches, and then quietly consigned to a tolerably comfortable prison, he has managed ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. F.B. SANBORN is in some respects a much more fortunate man than Mr. THADDEUS HYATT. Instead of being quietly conveyed to Washington, quietly produced before the Senate, quietly permitted to maintain his rights before empty benches, and then quietly consigned to a tolerably comfortable prison, he has managed to throw Concord into convulsions, have himself solemnly commiserated by the State Legislature, and solemnly discharged by the full bench of the Supreme Court. While the unfortunate HYATT is pining in obscurity, SANBORN is the hero of the day in his native town -- crowned with the honors of a triumph over the United States, achieved after a pitched battle in the streets, and a legal struggle in the Courts.

abstract: The Indian Appropriation bill coming up yesterday in the Senate, Mr. LATHAM moved as an amendment, that California be permitted to provide for her own Indians. He urged the proposition upon economical grounds. Without further discussion, the subject was laid aside, and the Homestead debate was resumed. The amendment offered by Hr. FITCH, providing for the retention...
lead_paragraph: The Indian Appropriation bill coming up yesterday in the Senate, Mr. LATHAM moved as an amendment, that California be permitted to provide for her own Indians. He urged the proposition upon economical grounds. Without further discussion, the subject was laid aside, and the Homestead debate was resumed. The amendment offered by Hr. FITCH, providing for the retention by Government of alternate quarter sections, was rejected. Mr. BROWN, of Mississippi, referred to a bill he had to offer as a substitute, the distinctive trait of which was to extend the period of preemption, and to prevent the ejection of settlers. For such a measure he declared he should be able to vote; but not for either the Senate or House bill. Mr. GREEN, of Missouri, attacked the whole scheme of free lands or homesteads as mischievous, and as a product of reckless and dangerous partisanship. He added, however, nothing to the arguments previously urged against the measure. Mr. SHERMAN, from the Committee of Ways and Means in the House, reported the Post-office Appropriation bill. Mr. NELSON then resumed and closed his speech in favor of the Utah Polygamy bill, and was followed by Mr. HOOPER, the Mormon delegate, who threatened that the passage of the act would revive the ill-feeling between his people and the Government, which had so lately been extinguished. The substitutes proposed by Messrs. BRANCH and MCCLERNAND were successively put to vote and rejected. The bill finally passed by 149 yeas to 60 nays. Mr. SICKLES, of New-York, claiming to speak to a privileged question, referred to the contest for his seat, and produced and commented upon the notice which Mr. WILLIAMSON, in response to the House resolution, had caused to be served upon him. After some difficulty the Republicans succeeded in silencing him, and in referring the subject to the Committee upon Elections. The Tariff Loan bill was taken up in Committee of the Whole; and Mr. LOVEJOY, of Illinois, made a violently radical speech on the Slavery issue. A portion of his remarks caused great excitement among Southern members. For awhile a collision seemed inevitable; but the orator moderating his tone, closed his philippic without disturbance.

abstract: THE MELEE IN THS HOUSE.  Quite a scene was presented in the House, today, while it was in Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union. The Chairman, finding he could not restore order, called the Speaker to his seat. Mr. PENNINGTON'S appeal and the mace of the Sergeant-at-Arms had the desired effect, and the members became quiet.

abstract: All who know the story Of WASHINGTON IRVING'S life must have missed from the circle of more or less distinguished persons who assembled to do honor to his memory, on Tuesday evening last, the name of JAMES K. PAULDING. Comrades as well as contemporaries, the joint authors of Salmagundi had outlived together the common span of human years.
lead_paragraph: All who know the story Of WASHINGTON IRVING'S life must have missed from the circle of more or less distinguished persons who assembled to do honor to his memory, on Tuesday evening last, the name of JAMES K. PAULDING. Comrades as well as contemporaries, the joint authors of Salmagundi had outlived together the common span of human years. The elder of the two was destined to see his friend and fellow-laborer, the partner of his early renown and the neighbor of his declining days, pass away into the hush of a tranquil Autumn night, and to gather up alone the tributes of admiration and respect which all were so eager to shower upon a grave not less worthy than the grave of ALBERT DURER to bear the inscription, "Emigravit," in token of that life of genius which symbolizes so well in its earthly immortality the undying destiny of the universal spirit of man.

abstract: A fire originated from some unknown cause, about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, near the boiler on the lower floor of the three-story frame building in Second-avenue, between Fifty-third and Fiftyfourth streets, occupied as a planing and moulding ...
lead_paragraph: A fire originated from some unknown cause, about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, near the boiler on the lower floor of the three-story frame building in Second-avenue, between Fifty-third and Fiftyfourth streets, occupied as a planing and moulding shop by LAWRENCE & MOWBRY. So quickly did the flames spread that the workmen with difficulty escaped from the building, Mr. ABRAHAM CODY, who manufactured sashes and blinds on the third floor, having with his employer, to save themselves by jumping from the windows to a shed some distance beneath. Messrs. LAWRENCE & MOWBRY's loss on the building is $6,000 and on their stock $4,000. They are insured for $1,000 each in the Lenox, Rutgers, Williamsburgh City, and East River Companies, besides $700 in the Park Company. Their safe was recovered with its contents much charred. Mr. CODY's loss amounts to $2,000. He is uninsured. A pile of lumber in the adjoining yard, owned by BROWN & STONE, valued at $150, was also consumed.

abstract: In 1857 an act was passed by the Legislature authorizing the widening of Broadway at its junction with Fifty-ninth-street and Eighth-avenue, so far as to afford a finer and broader entrance to Central Park. The Street Commissioner has decided to widen the street on the east side by taking off a triangle, the base of which is about two hundred feet. This affords a view of the Park and entrance for a long distance, which otherwise would be obstructed until visitors were directly at the gate.

abstract: During the months of April, May and June, the Hudson River, as everybody who has seen it knows, is studded with poles belonging to the shad fishermen, who, from time immemorial, have obtained profitable returns from the heavy investments of money and labor which they have made in the fishery. The extensive way in which this business has been conducted.
lead_paragraph: During the months of April, May and June, the Hudson River, as everybody who has seen it knows, is studded with poles belonging to the shad fishermen, who, from time immemorial, have obtained profitable returns from the heavy investments of money and labor which they have made in the fishery. The extensive way in which this business has been conducted in the Harbor of New-York, has for many years been a source of much danger and inconvenience to the commerce of the port, as it has been next to impossible for any vessel to pass between the serried columns of hickory poles which stretched across the river, almost from shore to shore, without sustaining damage. The invariable consequence to a sailing vessel that comes in contact with one of these poles, is the stripping of the copper from her bottom, and to a steamship the breaking of the buckets of her wheels, while it is an incident of almost every day occurrence for a small boat to be driven against them by the tide and overset. Not long since the Cunard steamer Africa was delayed in her departure for four hours, in consequence of a pole having become jammed into her wheel.

abstract: The dullness which usually precedes the gay return of Easter has affected more or less all the City theatres during the present week. At the best and most popular the attendance has been small, -- LAURA KEENE taking the largest share. Something of this result is undoubtedly due to Holy Week, which affects a large class of the permanent amusement-going people; but more is attributable, we fancy, to the fact that managers Easter and thereby teach the public to wait patiently until it comes round. With the approaching Monday we may expect a brilliant opening of the spring season, both musically and dramatically. Two of the best temples of the drama, however, change completely the character of their entertainments: -- at the Winter Garden we are to have opera, under the able direction of Mr. Max MARETZEK, and at Niblo's Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS retire, in favor of Cook's Royal Amphitheatre. There will, in consequence, be but two up-town places of theatrical entertainment open in Broadway -- WALLACK'S and LAURA KEENE'S. At the first-named of these establishments a couple of novelties are announced for to-night -- a new comedy, called "Leading String," and a farce called the "Marriage Bliss of Box and Cox." All the prominent members of Mr. WALLACK'S's superb company appear in these pieces. At LAURA KEENE'S Theatre the drama of the "Colleen Bawn" is of course the present novelty. Without any unusual degree of excitement, this piece has done well. The classes most likely to be interested in its performance hare as yet scarcely been able to pay their devoirs, owing to the religious restraints of Lent, and for this reason the work will only enter upon its Irish career during the coming week. Mr. BOURCICAULT'S countrymen will undoubtedly pay homage to a work of such startling originality, and beyond this its striking merits as a sensational drama will insure for it a steady run to the end of the season. We may here state for the edification of people interested in such topics, that the season will close about the 15th of May, and a change of management immediately ensue. An eminent comedian is spoken of as the successor to Miss LAURA KEENE, and under his direction a Summer season of three or four months will be inaugurated. Mr. BOURCICAULT, it is almost superfluous to add, is not the gentleman referred to. "The public will regret to lose an actress so thoroughly admirable and a manager so energetic and enterprising as Miss. KEENE. I[???] health, we are informed, is the cause of the lady's retirement.

It has many excellent provisions, and some errors which render the bill almost worthless.

abstract: Mr. WASHBURN'S bill, before Congress, intended to promote comparative safety in that now most perilous of undertakings, going down to the sea in ships, is severely criticised for two reasons first, the proposed penalties in case of calamities are very severe; second, and chiefly, the limited number of psengers and the unlimited number of life-boats will materially curtail the profits of steamship owners.

abstract: George De Noir, alias George Smith, a prisoner on Blackwell's Island, yesterday concealed himself behind a wall in the stone quarry, just before the dinner hour, and when the keepers had gone away, emerging from his hiding-place, he entered a small boat which two of his former companions had in waiting for him, and was rowed down to Williamburgh, where the boat was abandoned.
lead_paragraph: George De Noir, alias George Smith, a prisoner on Blackwell's Island, yesterday concealed himself behind a wall in the stone quarry, just before the dinner hour, and when the keepers had gone away, emerging from his hiding-place, he entered a small boat which two of his former companions had in waiting for him, and was rowed down to Williamburgh, where the boat was abandoned. The three men crossed Grand-street Ferry, but were soon met by a former keeper on the Island, who recognized De Noir, and suspecting that he had just escaped, followed him through various streets until Officer Gale, of the Fourteenth Ward, was encountered, and the convict's arrest was effected. De Noir protested that he had just been discharged from the Island, and said that his name was Gray. He was nevertheless taken before the magistrate at Essex Market, but as neither the officer nor keeper could swear that he was an escaped convict, they took him to the office of the District-Attorney for information. Learning there that the sentence of a man named GRAY expired on the 6th inst., they were inclined to credit the repeated assertion of the man that he was that individual, and that he had just been discharged; Before letting him go, however, they decided to take him to Police headquarters, where soon afterwards a dispatch was received from Blackwell's Island that a prisoner had escaped, and subsequently a keeper came over and identified DE NOIR as the fugitive. He was confined for the night in the Fourteenth Ward Station-house, and to-day he will be returned to his old quarters.

abstract: One of the most inveterate traditions of our fathers was the immobility of Royalty. That the King should remain habitually within a certain radius of his capital, and never go beyond it, except for the purpose of making a solemn and formal visit to some loyal province, was with the latter sovereigns of the House of Hanover almost an article of faith.

abstract: Within the past four weeks one of the best organized of those bands of thieves, which make their living by depredations upon the mercantile community, has been dispersed through the indefatigability and shrewdness of Officers CORNELL, LEE and BLACKWELL, of the Harbor Police force. The leading spirit of the gang was one JOHN MINCH, a man some 30 years of age, who came from Buffalo to Brooklyn some six years since.
lead_paragraph: Within the past four weeks one of the best organized of those bands of thieves, which make their living by depredations upon the mercantile community, has been dispersed through the indefatigability and shrewdness of Officers CORNELL, LEE and BLACKWELL, of the Harbor Police force. The leading spirit of the gang was one JOHN MINCH, a man some 30 years of age, who came from Buffalo to Brooklyn some six years since. In the latter city he soon gathered about him a number of kindred spirits, whose illicit operations have involved losses to merchants and others amounting in the aggregate to thousands of dollars, and whose plans were prosecuted almost with impunity, on account of the perfect organization of the band, and the skillful arrangements which it had made for baffling the most cunning attempts on the part of the police to disperse it.

abstract: We copies from the leading Western organ of the Republican Party the Chicago Press and Tribune a few days since, an article complaining that the party at Washington had no clear and well-defined policy on the subject of our Foreign Relations. In the Senate its leaders have contented themselves with defeating all the important treaties with foreign Powers submitted to their action.
lead_paragraph: We copies from the leading Western organ of the Republican Party the Chicago Press and Tribune a few days since, an article complaining that the party at Washington had no clear and well-defined policy on the subject of our Foreign Relations. In the Senate its leaders have contented themselves with defeating all the important treaties with foreign Powers submitted to their action. The treaty with Nicaragua -- negotiated with a good deal of difficulty, and calculated to protect American interests on the Isthmus, as well as to promote the peace and prosperity of both countries -- was rejected. The Mexican Treaty has experienced the same fate, -- though there is a chance that their action upon this may yet be reconsidered. But in neither of these cases has any good reason been offered for the action of the Republican Senators, nor have we any information as to the principles or the policy on which they would have our relations with these States conducted.

abstract: The effect upon our City of the opening of the railroads and canals, which have so greatly contributed to her present prosperity, is shown in a striking manner by the accompanying Figure, for the idea of which we are indebted to Dr. GILLESPIE, of Union College, whose remarkable "Diagram of the Ups and Downs of the States," published by us some years ago, will be remembered by many of our readers.
lead_paragraph: The effect upon our City of the opening of the railroads and canals, which have so greatly contributed to her present prosperity, is shown in a striking manner by the accompanying Figure, for the idea of which we are indebted to Dr. GILLESPIE, of Union College, whose remarkable "Diagram of the Ups and Downs of the States," published by us some years ago, will be remembered by many of our readers. In the engraving now before us, the dotted upright lines represent the assessed values of the property (real and personal) in the City of New-York for the years at the foot of these lines, (ten years to an inch,) and each inch of the lines themselves stands for two hundred millions of dollars. The zig-zag line which joins the tops of these dotted lines shows our financial Ups and Downs. Thus it is level for the years in which the wealth of the City remained stationary, as from 1815 to 1818, and from 1819 to 1823; the line runs upward when this wealth increased, as from 1831 to 1836; it runs downward when the assessed value decreased, as from 1836 to 1843; and the degree of slope of this line is proportional to the rapidity of this increase or decrease of wealth. The notes inserted at some of the points of change indicate their material causes. They are more fully developed in the following extract from a late message of Gov. STEWART, of Missouri, who used these data as a strong argument for the extension of the railroads of his State. Referring to a numerical table of the assessed values, (which our diagram given by lines,) he says:

abstract: Quite a calm prevailed in the House, to-day, after the storm of yesterday, although many Southern men are still grumbling about what they denominate the outrage upon them by Mr. LOVEJOY. Gatherings of Southern Democrats could be seen in different parts of the Hall, consulting as to what ought to be done under the circumstances of the case. Mr. LOVEJOY expresses himself as entirely indifferent to the result of such consultations.

abstract: We are perfectly aware that it is hopeless to command the attention of a Legislature absorbed in schemes of public plunder and private gain, for a measure which merely involves the lives and the health of a million of people. It is almost as impossible to awaken any interest in the subject among those very people themselves. Nevertheless, while the Legislature is in session, and there remains any chance of securing action upon the New-York Health bill, we feel bound to repeat and insist upon the considerations which ought to secure its prompt and unanimous passage.
lead_paragraph: We are perfectly aware that it is hopeless to command the attention of a Legislature absorbed in schemes of public plunder and private gain, for a measure which merely involves the lives and the health of a million of people. It is almost as impossible to awaken any interest in the subject among those very people themselves. Nevertheless, while the Legislature is in session, and there remains any chance of securing action upon the New-York Health bill, we feel bound to repeat and insist upon the considerations which ought to secure its prompt and unanimous passage.

abstract: Two of the "Knights of the Golden Circle" in New-Orleans have published a card denouncing Gen. BICKLEY, the Commander-in-Chief of the Order, as an impostor. Whether the epithet be technically correct or not, there has certainly been a vast difference between what the General has said and what the General has done.
lead_paragraph: Two of the "Knights of the Golden Circle" in New-Orleans have published a card denouncing Gen. BICKLEY, the Commander-in-Chief of the Order, as an impostor. Whether the epithet be technically correct or not, there has certainly been a vast difference between what the General has said and what the General has done. In this City, last Fall, he endeavored to recruit a regiment of men with the avowed object of colonizing Mexico -- peaceably, but in sufficient force to provide for all contingencies. The Colonel of a celebrated New-York regiment was appointed to the command of the corps, which, it was said, would constitute but a small fraction of the large army already enrolled in various parts of the United States. The Colonel has since declared that he would have nothing to do with the organization, and the few who joined it soon ascertained that the initiation fees and other sums they had paid, were just so much money out of pocket. The large stories about arms and munitions stored away, and plentiful funds to be provided for the successful prosecution of the enterprise; of the desire of JUAREZ and Mexican Provincial Governors to secure the services of the legion in a cause similar to that for which LAFAYETTE had shed his blood; of the distinguished military career of the Commander-in-Chief in the Crimea, where he had rapidly risen in the ranks of the Russian Army to the position of General, and had been decorated with the Cross of Honor by the Czar; of what the Czar, in conversation, had said to him, and of the particular inquiries afterwards propounded to him by NAPOLEON III., in person, concerning the reasons that had induced him to join the Russian forces instead of lending his mighty sword and military abilities to the allies; of what he had done when he was an officer of the American Army in Mexico, and of what Gen SCOTT had said to him concerning the ease with which the "K.G.C." could accomplish anything and everything, -- all this grandiloquent language came to be regarded with distrust by the hundred men, more or less, who had signed the roll.

abstract: Nessr-ed-din, Shah of Persia, whose decease is just announced, was born about the year 1833. He was the son of Mehement Shah and Queen Velliat, of the Kadjar tribe. Abbaz Mirza, whose reign was so brief but brilliant, was his grandfather. Nessr-ed-din was called to the throne in 1849, while he was living with one of his uncles, away from the Court. Fortunately much attention had been paid to his education. Besides a knowledge of the Persian and Turkish languages, he is said to have studied French and English with success and not to have slighted history. The result of this mental training was exhibited in the liberal manner in which he governed his subjects. He is described as having been mild and gentle in his manners, but energetic when occasion required, and simple in the habits of his private life. It was his custom to rise early, breakfast at 8 o'clock, meet his Prime Minister at 9 for an hour's conference on matters of State, and then to give audience to any one of his subjects who had a complaint to make or a petition to present. These duties through, he was at leisure until 6 o'clock, when he was accustomed to dine with his family. Occasionally, also, he is said to have admitted to his table the great nobles of his Empire.
lead_paragraph: Nessr-ed-din, Shah of Persia, whose decease is just announced, was born about the year 1833. He was the son of Mehement Shah and Queen Velliat, of the Kadjar tribe. Besides a knowledge of the Persian and Turkish languages, he is said to have studied French and English with success and not to have slighted history. The result of this mental training was exhibited in the liberal manner in which he governed his subjects. He is described as having been mild and gentle in his manners, but energetic when occasion required, and simple in the habits of his private life. It was his custom to rise early, breakfast at 8 o'clock, meet his Prime Minister at 9 for an hour's conference on matters of State, and then to give audience to any one of his subjects who had a complaint to make or a petition to present. These duties through, he was at leisure until 6 o'clock, when he was accustomed to dine with his family. Occasionally, also, he is said to have admitted to his table the great nobles of his Empire.

abstract: A grand reunion of scientific men from all parts of the world is to be held in Paris during the coming August, and preparations are now being made to assemble a great number of Continental, British and American savans. It will be conducted on principles somewhat different from those of the British Association, and it is proposed to be held annually in one of the capitals of the world.

abstract: On the 19th ult., Mr. KINGLAKE rose to ask the noble lord the Foreign Secretary a question of which he had privately given notice; but, as he wished to make a short statement to the House, to put himself in order, he would conclude with a motion. He never rose to address the House with more pleasure than he did at that moment, [a laugh,] for he rejoiced to be able to say that, unless he had been deceived by a very inexplicable hoax, the news from Nice was of the most gratifying description. They had been told that the people of Nice anxiously desired to become annexed to the great empire of France, and that, if there might be a small group of persons in that country who perversely wished to remain attached to the throne of Sardinia, it was hardly tolerable that so insignificant a fraction of the population should be permitted to innulge in that malignant species of loyalty. Within the last hour and a half, however, he had received a telegram which informed him that the Municipal Council of Nice had voted to remain under the dominion of Sardinia, [cheers,] and had also declared that if Prance should insist that its remaining united to Sardinia was incompatible with the safety of the French frontier, then the Municipal Council of Nice anxiously prayed that their country might be an independent State. The telegram went on to say that a deputation had proceeded from Nice to Turin, to carry this decision thither, and it added that a vote of thanks had been given by the Municipal Council to three members of the English House of Commons, one of whom was the honorable member for Horsham, (Mr. S, FITZGERALD,) and another his honorable friend the member for Tamworth, (Sir R. PEEL.) He hoped he might be permitted to congratulate his honorable friend on the extremely gratifying fact that the son of one whose voice once exercised a vast influence within these walls, and, through the House of Commons, over the whole of Europe, had been honored by the vote of thanks thus proffered to him. [Hear, hear.] The question of which he had given the noble lord notice he wished to ask in order to guide him with reference to his pending motion. Very naturally a good deal of anxiety had been evinced by honorable members as to the course he intended; to take with regard to that motion. The truth was, the project for annexing Savoy and Nice had been so constantly passing into new phases that it had been exceedingly difficult for any gentleman charged with the duty of bringing forward a motion of this kind to know the exact time and the exact form for submitting it to the House. The communications they had received from her Majesty's Government on that subject had from time to time considerably varied. He did not say that in any taunting spirit, because it might be quite consistent with the fact and with the absence of divided opinions that one thing should be true on Tuesday and another on Friday. On Tuesday they were told by the noble lord at the head of the Government that he had every reason to suppose that the consent of the great Powers would be sincerely asked and sincerely abided by by the Emperor of the French, and on Friday the noble lord the Foreign Secretary said that which went very far to dissipate that assurance. Under these circumstance, all he could state was that he trusted he should be able to place his motion before the House in Mich a shape as would tend to strengthen the hands of Her Majesty's Government. If, however, he found the conduct of the Government was not such as enable him to put his motion in the form he would best like, he should not shrink from the duty of putting it in such a from as the justice of the case required. He must frankly add that he would feel relieved if any other honorable gentle man undertook the task which, by accident rather than by any seeking of his own, had become imposed upon him. The inquiries which he low wished to make of the noble lord were -- first, whether Her Majesty's Government had received the appeal that was understood to have been addressed by the swiss Government to the great Powers of Europe; secondly, whether Her Majesty's Government would give the statement contained in that appeal due consideration before they replied to the dispatch lately receive from M, THOUVENEL; and, lastly, whether Her Majesty's Government, before answering the Bote from the Swiss Government, would put themselves in communication with the other Powers to whom that note was also addressed, with a view, if possible, to arrive at some common action on the subject. He now begged to move the adjournment of the House.

abstract: The arrival of the steamship Kangaroo, at this port, with files from England and the Continent to March 21, and telegraphic advices through Queenstown, to March 22, supplies intelligence of interest. The Savoy and Nice annexation question was approaching a solution. The Treaty of Cession had been signed at Turin, and nothing remained but to complete the formality of a vote, and an appeal to the Great Powers, to consummate the transfer. Nice is represented to be obstinately averse to the change. French troops were said to be under orders to enter and occupy the two States. Our latest dispatches, however, make no mention of actual movements. The London Times declares it is simply useless to withstand the will of NAPOLEON in the matter; admits the fact of annexation to be substantially une affaire finic; and counsels a cessation of agitation in regard to it. The result of the plebscitum in the [???]Emilian Provinces has completed the breach between the Pope and the King of Sardinia. His Holiness had addressed a letter to the King, bitterly censuring his policy, and concluding by launching an excommunication at the royal head. The missive and the thunder seem to have produced no effect upon the obdurate monarch. The King of Naples, it was reported, had announced an intention to advance his army into the Roman States simultaneously with the entrance of the Piedmontese troops into the Legations. Further conflicts of a sanguinary sort had attended the Spanish operations in Morocco. In addition to the battle in the neighborhood of Tetuan previously reported, a second contest in the same neighborhood occurred on the 11th ult., in which large masses of both armies were engaged, and the Moors were repulsed with great loss. From Hungary we learn that the excitement there is still fermenting The anniversary of Austrian perfidy in 1848 had been generally observed on the 15th of March. The death of the Shah of Persia is announced. The English news is of slight interest. Mrs. ANNA JAMESON, the distinguished writer upon topics associated with literature and art, was dead.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of the steamship Kangaroo, at this port, with files from England and the Continent to March 21, and telegraphic advices through Queenstown, to March 22, supplies intelligence of interest. The Savoy and Nice annexation question was approaching a solution. The Treaty of Cession had been signed at Turin, and nothing remained but to complete the formality of a vote, and an appeal to the Great Powers, to consummate the transfer. Nice is represented to be obstinately averse to the change. French troops were said to be under orders to enter and occupy the two States. Our latest dispatches, however, make no mention of actual movements. The London Times declares it is simply useless to withstand the will of NAPOLEON in the matter; admits the fact of annexation to be substantially une affaire finic; and counsels a cessation of agitation in regard to it. The result of the plebscitum in the [???]Emilian Provinces has completed the breach between the Pope and the King of Sardinia. His Holiness had addressed a letter to the King, bitterly censuring his policy, and concluding by launching an excommunication at the royal head. The missive and the thunder seem to have produced no effect upon the obdurate monarch. The King of Naples, it was reported, had announced an intention to advance his army into the Roman States simultaneously with the entrance of the Piedmontese troops into the Legations. Further conflicts of a sanguinary sort had attended the Spanish operations in Morocco. In addition to the battle in the neighborhood of Tetuan previously reported, a second contest in the same neighborhood occurred on the 11th ult., in which large masses of both armies were engaged, and the Moors were repulsed with great loss. From Hungary we learn that the excitement there is still fermenting The anniversary of Austrian perfidy in 1848 had been generally observed on the 15th of March. The death of the Shah of Persia is announced. The English news is of slight interest. Mrs. ANNA JAMESON, the distinguished writer upon topics associated with literature and art, was dead.

abstract: The objections put forward in the House on Thursday by Mr. HOOPER, the delegate from Utah, to the passage of the bill prohibiting Polygamy, are two in number. The first is, that not over a quarter of the Mormons have more than two wives; and the second is, that if the bill is passed, the Saints will resist its execution by force of arms, if necessary. What weight the House attached to this style of argument was evinced by the result of the division which followed, and there seems a fair prospect that the bill will eventually become a law.

abstract: Those who are accustomed to observe the rough cast iron, which ordinarily presents its uncouth surface in the more familiar forms of implements and machinery, can scarcely imagine that the same raw material, by, substantially the same process, can be moulded into the sharp, full and delicate outlines of the smoothest ornamental scrolls and figures -- the elaboration of metal which in olden time were illustrations of high art, chiefly because they were the costly and prolonged work, of the artificer's chisel and graver. When we imagine a furnace full of melted iron at three thousand degrees of heat, spouting with flames and coruscations into a hollow cavity of wet sand, the quiet settling and cooling of the livid mass into the most delicate indentations of the mould, is not the first suggestion of the spectacle to the uninitiated observer one of wonder? Yet the fact is, that practical science has reduced the moulding of this most rigid and unpromising metal, not only into the hard and solid forms of strength and durability, but into the finest tracery of elaborate ornamentation.

abstract: Prior to the year of grace 1848, the attention of the benevolent and philanthropic citizens of NewYork does not seem to have been particularly called to the condition of the neglected, vagrant and homeless children of the City. The House of Refuge was, indeed, performing its beneficent work for the juvenile delinquents; Orphan and half-orphan Asylums garnered up those who were deprived of parent's care, and were brought under their notice;
lead_paragraph: Prior to the year of grace 1848, the attention of the benevolent and philanthropic citizens of NewYork does not seem to have been particularly called to the condition of the neglected, vagrant and homeless children of the City. The House of Refuge was, indeed, performing its beneficent work for the juvenile delinquents; Orphan and half-orphan Asylums garnered up those who were deprived of parent's care, and were brought under their notice; the Randall's Island Nursery, and the Home for the Friendless, took charge of many of those who were utterly dependent and helpless; but there were very few who were not startled, when told in the report of Mr. G.W. MATSELL, Chief of Police for the year 1848-9, that there were nearly 10,000 children in the City not reached by any of these institutions, who never attended the Public Schools, but who lived upon the streets, many of them having no other home, night or day. They were not criminals in the eye of the law, for their thefts, if they were guilty of stealing, were of very small amounts, and almost entirely food or fuel to keep them from perishing. Some of them gained a precarious subsistence for themselves or their parents by pilfering and begging; others swept the crossings, picked over the ash-boxes, gathered rags, bones and refuse paper; others still sold matches, tooth-picks, or other small articles, or peddled apples, oranges and flowers; a large class were newsboys, and print and ballad sellers; others were organ-grinders, statuette-sellers, or venders of Bohemian and Dresden ware.

abstract: FELLOW-CITIZENS OF MADISON COUNTY: Learning from a reliable source that the Revolutionary Committee of Madison are about to meet in Richmond on next Monday, to take into consideration who are again to be proscribed, and having understood that I only escaped their denouncement last Tuesday by a small majority, and that I am again to be considered on Monday, I avail myself of this means of making my protest and defence. I would greatly prefer always to meet my accusers face to face and there make my defence, but as friends have insisted on my avoiding any pretence for a conflict, I yield to their wishes and make this written appeal:

abstract: The work of removing the shad poles from the navigable waters of the harbor was continued yesterday, under the supervision of Sergeant BREVOORT, of the Harbor Police, assisted by three boats' crews, numbering fifteen men. The business was prosecuted with as much moderation as the nature of the undertaking allowed, and in all cases where a disposition was manifested to conform to the requirements of the law, some indulgence was extended to the fishermen by giving them more time to attend to the removal themselves.

abstract: In reply to a letter of inquiry addressed to an officer of the Military Academy at West Point, the Observer has received a curious statement of facts, showing that the Army has furnished a number of candidates for the Ministry. The writer states that several professors in the Academy have resigned their commissions, at different times, to become clergymen; and that, at the present time, ten or twelve of the professors and instructors, and as many as thirty of the cadets, are members of the Christian Church, while "many earnest hearts are yearning for an increase of piety." Among the professors who have become clergymen, the following are named: Rev. C.W. HACKLEY, who resigned his Army commission in 1813; Rev. W.N. PENNINGTON, of Virginia, who resigned in 1833, and entered the Episcopal ministry: Prof. BLEDSOE, Rev. Dr. VINTON, Rev. M.P. PARKS, and others. The officer who contributes these statements adds some reflections upon the moral character of the military profession. He says: "The Christian soldier must ever deprecate the terrible extremity of taking human life, though he be called under Providence to the sad office of executing the spy and slaying the foe of his country. I have had many doubts and misgivings on the subject of my profession, and have tried by prayerful inquiry to ascertain the path of duty."

abstract: Benjamin H. Field vs. Augustus Schell. This was an action against the defendant as Collector of this port, to recover back duties amounting to about $600, imposed by the defendant upon a quantity of caustic soda imported by the blaintiff in the year 1859, which duties were paid by him under protest. Caustic soda is not mentioned in the Tariff act of 1857, and
lead_paragraph: Benjamin H. Field vs. Augustus Schell. This was an action against the defendant as Collector of this port, to recover back duties amounting to about $600, imposed by the defendant upon a quantity of caustic soda imported by the blaintiff in the year 1859, which duties were paid by him under protest. Caustic soda is not mentioned in the Tariff act of 1857, and the Collector thereupon imposed a duty upon this importation of fifteen per cent., which, by the first section of the Tariff act of 1857, is imposed upon all non-enumerated articles. The plaintiff, on the contrary, claimed that the article was liable only to a duty of four per cent. under the twentieth section of the act of 1842, which provides that on every non-enumerated article which bears a similitude either in material, quality, texture, or the use to which it may be applied, to any enumerated article chargeable with duty, there shall be charged the same rate of duty which is levied and charged on the enumerated article which it most resembles in any of the above particulars, because caustic soda held such a similitude to soda ash which is charged with a duty of four per cent. This similitude was proved by the plaintiff.
headline: {'main': 'Duty on Caustic Soda Similitude.; UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT, APRIL 6 BEFORE JUDGE SMALLEY.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Duty on Caustic Soda Similitude.; UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT, APRIL 6 BEFORE JUDGE SMALLEY.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Flames were discovered, soon after 4 o'clock on Saturday morning, in the grocery No. 110 East Twenty-second-street, kept by TULLY MCDONALD, and before they could be extinguished, the contents of the store were destroyed. The upper part of the building was occupied by several families, who were driven back by the smoke in their efforts to escape by the hall-way, and some of the more frightened among them lowered themselves by means of bed-cords from the windows. From certain circumstances connected with the matter, MCDONALD was arrested on suspicion of having intentionally fired his premises, and Justice KELLY committed him, pending the result of the Fire-Marshal's investigation. The prisoner is the same man who was nearly killed, a few months since, by a Hungarian who suspected him of being too intimate with his wife, and his face is shockingly disfigured by the scars he received on that occasion. His stock, which was worth about $200, was insured for $700 in the Eagle Insurance Company. The furniture of the tenants was injured to the exent of $100, and was uninsured. The building is owned by JOHN HEGEMAN, and it will cost $400 to repair it. It is insured in the North River Company.

abstract: The largest vote ever polled in Connecticut before was in the Presidential election in 1856, when the total was 80,325. The natural increase in Connecitcut in four years, as shown by tables of the vote for twenty years past, is about four thousand, and we have no doubt that from three to four thousand illegal
lead_paragraph: The largest vote ever polled in Connecticut before was in the Presidential election in 1856, when the total was 80,325. The natural increase in Connecitcut in four years, as shown by tables of the vote for twenty years past, is about four thousand, and we have no doubt that from three to four thousand illegal and fraudulent votes were cast for the Locofoco ticket on Monday last. The largest Republican vote ever before polled was in 1856, when FREMONT had 42,715; BUCKINGHAM has 44,483, showing about half the natural increase. But the largest Democratic vote ever polled was for PRATT in 1859 -- 38,369. Allowing half the natural increase, and the legal Democratic vote would be about 40,000. Instead of that, 43,874 were polled on Monday, another indication that nearly four thousand fraudulent votes were cast for that ticket.

abstract: There is nothing more fascinating in the way of speculative science than the nebular theory of the astronomers. To imagine the magnificent evolution from mist and vapor, from mere inorganic chaos, of a new world, solid and
lead_paragraph: There is nothing more fascinating in the way of speculative science than the nebular theory of the astronomers. To imagine the magnificent evolution from mist and vapor, from mere inorganic chaos, of a new world, solid and splendid, prolific with life and glorious with light, is to assist in fancy at the most majestic spectacle which it can enter into the mind of man to conceive. And yet, for those who truly measure the worth and dignity of human welfare and of human progress, the political process now going on with such stately and steadfast steps in the Italian Peninsula, must have an interest scarce inferior. There, from the distractions and contradictions of an unnatural and intolerable Past, a great people, the acknowledged peers of the proudest nations of the earth in the grandest attributes of humanity, are now emerging, State by State, and province by province, to gravitate around one common centre into a new national unity and independence. Before the simple fact that, in this sixtieth year of the Nineteenth Century, the world is witnessing the practical realization of a purpose and a hope which have never died out of the brain and heart of Italy throughout all the trials and intrigues and temptations -- all the discouragements and defeats and disappointments of five hundred years -- the merely formal and diplomatic and temporary aspects of what we call the "Italian Question" are dwarfed and disappear. The "treaties of 1815," the "defences of Germany beyond the Alps," the "balance of power in Europe," are matters about which the small wise men who rule the world, according to OXENSTIERNA, with so very economical an expenditure of brains, may be allowed to prate in Parliaments and to prose in dispatches. The achievement of Italian independence, like the establishment of the American Republic, or the overthrew of feudalism in France, is an event which can only be justly estimated and fairly comprehended when it is looked at from the foreground of the Future.

abstract: Mr. FITZGERALD TASISTRO'S RECITATIONS. The unpretending announcement that Mr. TASISTRO would recite SHAKESPEARE'S "Hamlet," at Dodworth's Hall, on last Thursday evening, drew together an audience of about two hundred persons, which, under the circumstances, was a marked compliment to his reputation as an elocutionist and interpreter of SHAKES
lead_paragraph: Mr. FITZGERALD TASISTRO'S RECITATIONS. The unpretending announcement that Mr. TASISTRO would recite SHAKESPEARE'S "Hamlet," at Dodworth's Hall, on last Thursday evening, drew together an audience of about two hundred persons, which, under the circumstances, was a marked compliment to his reputation as an elocutionist and interpreter of SHAKES PEARE's text. Mr. TASISTRO began by making a few introductory explanations as to the causes which had induced him to commit to memory some of the most sublime creations of the immortal bard, and then proceeded with the business of the play in a style at once novel and surprising. As his announcement led us to infer, he uses no book or memoranda of any kind, but recites every part from memory with perfect fidelity to the text, modulating his voice, which possesses great flexibility, so as to place each character before the audience in its proper light. These remarkable changes of intonation constituted the distinguishing trait of Mr. TASISTRO's performance throughout, while the great soliloquies were delivered with a degree of pathos and nicety of distinction which are seldom equaled on the stage. The audience was highly delighted, and the applause was loud and spontaneous. That Mr. TASISTRO will make his mark in this new sphere of intellectual exertion, there can be little doubt; and since SHAKESPEARE has been, as it were, banished from the stage by the sensation drama, it is pleasant to witness the success of a gentleman in bringing them, in a still more striking form, before the public. We presume these recitations will be continued.

abstract: For a long time a bitter rivalry has existed between the proprietors of two dance-houses in the First Ward, each of whom had enlisted on his side the sailors who resorted at the respective establishments. On Thursday night an open rupture occurred between the frequenters of the salon No. 161 Washington street, kept by one Freidschutz, who, having
lead_paragraph: For a long time a bitter rivalry has existed between the proprietors of two dance-houses in the First Ward, each of whom had enlisted on his side the sailors who resorted at the respective establishments. On Thursday night an open rupture occurred between the frequenters of the salon No. 161 Washington street, kept by one Freidschutz, who, having gone to the place of Martin Butts, corner of Carlisle and West streets, commenced an assault upon its patrons. The fight resulted, however, in no material injury to the combatants, except that Butts, it is said, discharged a pistol at one of the assailants, the ball from which missed its mark and inflicted a slight wound in the leg of his own wife. At a late hour on Friday night, Henry Dedrickson, a Swedish sailor, who is said to have been one of the attacking party on the previous night, was knocked down with either a club or a slung-shot by a member of the antagonistic clique, several of whom were standing at the corner of Carlisle and West streets, as he, partially intoxicated, passed by them on his way to his boarding house, conducted by a sober acquaintance. The outcries of the injured man's companion attracted Officer Ryan to the scene of the assault, but the assailants had secreted themselves before he came up. Dedrickson, who had been rendered insensible by the blow, was removed to the New-York Hospital, where it was found that his skull had been terribly fractured, and the physician pronounced his injuries to be of a fatal character. He still remains at the institution, and has not yet returned to consciousness. A man named John Greenwood was subsequently arrested on suspicion of having been one of Dedrickson's assailants, and after an extended search Sergeant Denton finally apprehended one Jeremiah Murphy at a seaman's boarding house in Oliver-street, who, from the statement of a young man who witnessed the assault, is thought to be the person by whom the murderous blow was struck. Justice CONNOLLY committed both prisoners to the Tombs.

abstract: "The results of the elections in Connecticut and Rhode Island have called out no rejoicing from either party in Washington. I have never witnessed so little desire to trifle or make merry about anything.

abstract: THE ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The work on the Brooklyn Academy of Music is advancing very rapidly. The walls at both ends, and the rear wall, are up to the third story, and the front wall is up to the second story. The front is to be constructed with the best kind of pressed brick, with stone trimmings, and the work throughout is of the most substantial character. It will be completed by the 1st of December next.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE. There is a kind of respectable piece a sort of drama of well-dressed but scheming society which can be played at Wallack's Theatre, and nowhere else. It depends on talk without epigram; scenes without situations; is dull, real
lead_paragraph: WALLACK'S THEATRE. There is a kind of respectable piece a sort of drama of well-dressed but scheming society which can be played at Wallack's Theatre, and nowhere else. It depends on talk without epigram; scenes without situations; is dull, real and uninteresting, but polite and well-bred. With a company remarkable for its knowledge of the nicely toned commonplaces of society, Mr. WALLACK can occasionally play such a piece. At any other house the feat would be dangerous, if not impossible. We are led naturally to these remarks by a consideration of the comedy called "Leading Strings," produced on Saturday night, and which, more than any other recent production, falls short of every ordinary critical excellence. The story is simply that of a step-mother who desires to wean her son from an affection which she conceives to be hasty and ill-founded. She does so, and effects a change in the gentleman's feelings by convincing him that the lady of his choice is a matrimonial schemer. A thread so taut and straight admits of no ingenious entanglement, and hence we look to the dialogue for our immediate sensations of pleasure. We were unable to detect any excellence in this specialty. Mr. TROUGHTON, the author, has failed to say a good thing, and in point of fact, never, from beginning to end, attempts anything higher than a polite platitude. To account for the comparative success which the piece achieved, we must return to the original proposition, that Mr. WALLACK's company can do things which at another house would provoke locked-jaw. Mrs. HOEY, as the step-mother, contrived by some unaccountable means, known only to herself, to make the part not only elegant, but interesting, -- an achievement which we regard as marvelous. Dreary wastes of language bloomed with nice maternal meaning as this sterling actress hovered over them, and mere episodes became domestic epochs by the quiet naturalness of her intensity. Mr. LESTER WALLACE, too, was excellent, not only in a keen perception of the broad weariness of his part, but in the elaboration of innumerable little irritations, without which it would be absolutely nothing. To these two artists belong the success of the piece. Mr. BLAKE -- dressed like a banker -- impersonated a butler, and elicited some welcome merriment by grimacing and wearing his hands constantly in his pockets. For one or both of these achievements he was called out after the piece, and incited to make a little speech. Miss GANNON played with her usual arch vivacity, and was thoroughly good. The subordinate parts were respectably supported, and Mr. LESTER WALLACE announced the comedy for repetition to-night. We do not expect for it a long career.

abstract: The Herald, TIMES and Tribune have contracted with the Hudson River Railroad Company to run a train expressly for conveyance of their papers to Albany, so as to reach the trains leaving that city in the morning. For instance, the newspaper train is expected to connect with the steamboat train on the Central Railroad leaving Albany at 7 1/2 A.M. This train is due here at at 7:40 P.M., Buffalo time. To do this, the newspaper train must leave New-York as early as 3 o'clock in the morning.

abstract: The readers of the TIMES who recollect the full and exclusive report of the transactions of the last annual meeting of Dr. Cheever's Church (Society), that appeared in this paper on the morning succeeding that meeting, will remember that the triumph of Dr. Cheever's friends in the election of Trustees was announced
lead_paragraph: The readers of the TIMES who recollect the full and exclusive report of the transactions of the last annual meeting of Dr. Cheever's Church (Society), that appeared in this paper on the morning succeeding that meeting, will remember that the triumph of Dr. Cheever's friends in the election of Trustees was announced as having been effected by a majority of two votes. It now appears that subsequent to the meeting, and before having certified to the result, the deacons, W.H. SMITH and G.H. WHITE, who presided as inspectors of election, became satisfied that illegal votes had been cast by Dr. Cheever's friends. The deacons therefore gave the certificates of election to two of the anti-Cheever Trustees, who, not counting the illegal votes, they decided to have been elected.

abstract: Dr. ABRAHAM GESNER lectured before this Association last evening, in Clinton Hall, on "Recent Elevations and Depressions of the Lands of Northern America." The audience was by no means numerous, though it was not wanting in appreciative attention. By way of exhibiting his theory in a popular form, Dr. GESNER made use of a large and admirably drawn map of the Western Hemisphere, on which the course of the Gulf Stream was represented with much accuracy. A sectional view of the coast line of North America was also shown, and did most material service in illustrating the Doctor's views.

abstract: The Niagara, with European files to March 24 and telegraphic advices to the 25th, reached Halifax on Saturday afternoon. The news is of interest. The annexation of Tuscany to Sardinia had been consummated, a decree to that effect, accepting the demand of the Etrurians, having been issued
lead_paragraph: The Niagara, with European files to March 24 and telegraphic advices to the 25th, reached Halifax on Saturday afternoon. The news is of interest. The annexation of Tuscany to Sardinia had been consummated, a decree to that effect, accepting the demand of the Etrurians, having been issued by VICTOR EMANUEL. The withdrawal of French troops from Lombardy, having been commenced simultaneously with this action, the Paris Constitutionnel had explained that this course had been pursued through no ill-feeling on the part of France; but because the independence of Italy was thus irrevocably assured. The Sardinian army had at the same moment commenced the evacuation of Savoy. The anticipated French dispatch commenting on the annexation of that province, repudiated the idea of the measure being the inaugural step of a restoration of natural frontiers. The replies of the Great Powers to this statement are reported to have been of one tenor, namely: that they saw no reason to oppose a measure thus stripped of objectionable attributes. The Reform bill and the Budget had been further debated in the British House of Commons. The income tax of ten-pence in the pound had been agreed to. The Reform bill appeared to attract little public attention or interest. Commenting upon the recent speech of Mr. SEWARD in the Senate, the London Times regards its tone as indicative of a better state of feeling between the two sections of the country; and with so modified a programme, it judges it to be possible for the Republicans to withstand the advances of Pro-Slavery aggression. From China, we learn that the rebellion is assuming new energy, and that at Swatow a fatal collision had occurred between the Custom authorities and a British vessel. The news from India is without importance.

abstract: Mr. WIGFALL, the new Senator from Texas, in one of his recent speeches in the Senate, said he denied that "we at the South draw any distinction between slaves and any other property. We ask simply," said he, "that that property shall be put upon the same footing as every other species of property. We ask that, and we ask nothing more."

abstract: VICTOR HUGO, still in exile through his stubborn unwillingness to accept any favor at the hands of the Emperor, has just finished a novel called Les Miserables.
lead_paragraph: VICTOR HUGO, still in exile through his stubborn unwillingness to accept any favor at the hands of the Emperor, has just finished a novel called Les Miserables. It is a collection of touching tales designed t illustrate the sufferings of the people, -- and will be first published in a Review which M. HETZEL, the well-known publisher, is about to establish in Paris. Two novels, one by LAMARTINE, and the other by Mad. SAND, will appear in the same Review immediately after the work of VICTOR HUGO.

abstract: A mass meeting of the Republicans of Newark was held in the Newark theatre last evening, under the auspices of the Young Mens' Republican Working Club. The occasion was the fourth anniversary of...
lead_paragraph: A mass meeting of the Republicans of Newark was held in the Newark theatre last evening, under the auspices of the Young Mens' Republican Working Club. The occasion was the fourth anniversary of the organization of the Republican Party in Newark -- and, in fact, in the State of New-Jersey -- and also an inauguration of the Club, which has just been formed with a view of forwarding the interests of the Republican Party during the coming Presidential campaign. The call of the meeting invited all those "in favor of the prevention of the extension of the spread of Slavery," and under that lucid invitation an audience of about a thousand assembled, including a number of ladies, for whom seats were reserved in the upper tier of the Theatre.

abstract: The business in this Court, for this and the ensuing week, will consist of murder and manslaughter cases, to be tried before Judge EMOTT. Yesterday the District-Atrorney called on for trial the case of John Pfromer.
lead_paragraph: The business in this Court, for this and the ensuing week, will consist of murder and manslaughter cases, to be tried before Judge EMOTT. Yesterday the District-Atrorney called on for trial the case of John Pfromer. It will be remembered that on the night of March 25, 1859, Charles Sturges, attended by other rowdies, went to the saloon kept by Pfromer, at No. 36 Bowery, and there created a disturbance with one of the employes, which Pfromer endeavored to quell, when Sturges, diverting his attention from his antagonist, turned and assaulted Pfromer. The latter, being, as he considered, in danger of bodily harm, took a pistol from behind the bar, and fired it at Sturges, who fell, mortally wounded, and subsequently died. Pfromer was tried in this Court in the following month, before Judge Davies, and convicted of manslaughter in the second degree. The case was carried up to the General Term, Supreme Court, where the verdict was set aside, and a new trial granted.

abstract: As boats' crews Nos. 1, 2 and 8 of the Harbor Police were returning, about 5 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, in the steamtug Magnolia from the Narrows, where they had been engaged in removing shad poles, their attention was attracted by a signal of distress on board the ship Ironsides, lying near Ellis' Island, and bound for St. Johns' New-Brunswick.
lead_paragraph: As boats' crews Nos. 1, 2 and 8 of the Harbor Police were returning, about 5 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, in the steamtug Magnolia from the Narrows, where they had been engaged in removing shad poles, their attention was attracted by a signal of distress on board the ship Ironsides, lying near Ellis' Island, and bound for St. Johns' New-Brunswick. The tug was headed for the ship, which she reached in advance of a boat that had been dispatched from the revenue cutter McClelland, to ascertain what the matter was, and the police learned that a desperate fight was in progress among the crew, most of whom were under the influence of liquor. Three of the more riotous of the men, named James McLoud, James Welsh and Thos. O'Mara, were secured, although they made a stout resistance to the officers. Peter Nelson, John Brown and Michael Moore, also belonging to the ship, whose lives had been threatened by the prisoners, and two of whom already had been badly cut in the shoulder and neck with knives, and beaten with slung-shots, were detained as witnesses. The timely arrival of the Police doubtless prevented the murder of these last named men; and it was found necessary to iron the desperate ruffians heavily before they could be brought on share. O'Mara is a powerful fellow, and a murderous looking slung-shot, besides a large sheath knife, were taken from him. He attempted, even after the fetters were upon him, to assault one of the officers. All the prisoners were confined for the night in the First Precinct Station-house.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The season commenced here last evening with a good performance and a fine house two irreproachable conditions of success.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The season commenced here last evening with a good performance and a fine house two irreproachable conditions of success. ROSSINI's opera of the "Barbiere" was performed with a cast similar in all respects to that of last season. Miss PATTI was received with enthusiasm, and executed her role with the usual neatness. Signor BRIGNOLI, who was in good voice, infused some vivacity into the part of the Count -- an achievement which is worthy of record. SUSINI, AMODIO and FERRI were good.

abstract: Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, moved in the Senate yesterday a resolution calling upon the President for information in regard to the seizure of Mexican vessels in time of peace, and their disposition agreeably to the law of prizes applicable to a state of war. It was adopted. Notice was given by Mr.WILSON, of Massachusetts, of a bill to suppress the Slave-trade.
lead_paragraph: Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, moved in the Senate yesterday a resolution calling upon the President for information in regard to the seizure of Mexican vessels in time of peace, and their disposition agreeably to the law of prizes applicable to a state of war. It was adopted. Notice was given by Mr.WILSON, of Massachusetts, of a bill to suppress the Slave-trade. Mr. DAVIS' resolutions were subsequently called up, when Mr. CHESNUT, of South Carolina, argued in support of them, chiefly because they shunned the excess of Congressional intervention in territorial affairs on the one side, and squatter sovereignty on the other. He laid much stress upon the value of the South to the North not only in a political, but conspicuously in a commercial point of view; inferring that in pursuing a policy which was hourly weakening the ties of union, the Republican Party was ruining both sections alike. Mr. CHESNUT spoke at great length, and was listened to with marked attention. At the close of his remarks Mr. HUNTER endeavored to call up the Indian Appropriation bill. Messrs. WADE and JOHNSON (Tenn.) urged the consideration of the House Homestead bill instead; and by a vote of 26 to 22, caused that measure to have precedence of all other bills upon the calendar. Resolutions addressed to the President, inquiring into the state of the Slave-trade, the enforcement of the laws against the traffic, and the propriety of farther preventive legislation, were offered in the House by Mr. MORSE. Mr. BOCOCK and other Southern members proposed amendments tending to fix the responsibility of the trade upon the Northern States; and with them, the resolutions were adopted. Territorial business, at the instance of Mr, GROW, was made the special order for May 2 and 3. Mr. COVODE brought in a report of his Investigating Committee, relative to the recusancy of Mr. AUGUSTUS SCHELL, and called upon the House to take action in the premises. Mr. WINSLOW, of North Carolina, made a minority report, which was decided to be out of order; and the subject was postponed for three weeks. The Special Committee on the President's protest, through Mr. HICKMAN, the Chairman, then reported. The report controverts all the positions assumed by the President; shows how essential the powers claimed by the House are to the exercise of its power of impeachment, of its legislative functions, and for the protection of its privileges; and declares the exemption demanded by Mr. BUCHANAN, for his office, to be dangerous to the rights of a free people. The report concludes by recommending a series of resolutions epitomizing the argument of the Committee. On the part of the minority of the Committee, Mr. HOUSTON announced that they had had no time to prepare a minority report; but that each would present his own views. He proceeded to read a paper setting forth his reasons for dissenting from the majority, the principle point being that if money had been wrongfully used in any State to control elections, it was for that State, and not for the Federal Government, to redress the wrong. Mr. TAYLOR, also of the minority, is to present his views to-day. Pending a motion to print and refer, the House adjourned.

abstract: It is strange how witnesses will keep away, and how counsel won't be ready, in cases wherein both have been notified that they would be put on the calendar. But so it is, and it occurs every day. The Recorder has done his best to make it otherwise; the fault, if anywhere, lies with the District Attorney. Yesterday, again, there was a large calendar, but only four small cases were disposed of, three of which resulted in verdicts of acquittal.

abstract: When, in a nation or union of States, the elementary States, or sections, or races, of which the Union is composed, are to be represented in the General Government, not precisely per capita, nor by States, but by a fixed unit of population in each, it becomes one of the most interesting problems to know how time and growth have modified the political relations of States, races and sections.
lead_paragraph: When, in a nation or union of States, the elementary States, or sections, or races, of which the Union is composed, are to be represented in the General Government, not precisely per capita, nor by States, but by a fixed unit of population in each, it becomes one of the most interesting problems to know how time and growth have modified the political relations of States, races and sections. No country except our own has presented a fair opportunity of doing this; and it is evident that there can be no better test of the power and value of each element of civilization which enters into the growth of the whole. What we mean by this may be illustrated by some significant examples. Take that of races. The colored race of the United States was, in 1790, 19 per cent. of the whole population; but in 1860 it will be but 13 1/2 per cent. -- showing that it is relatively declining. Again: take States. Virginia had, in 1790, 9 per cent. of the Representatives of the Congress; but in 1860 she will have but 5 per cent. -- having relatively declined nearly one-half. In regard to sections, the Northwestern States had, in 1790, not a single vote; but in 1860 they will have one-fourth of the House of Representatives. This increase has evidently been at the expense of the older States. Let us see, then, how and in what proportion these changes have been effected. We have stated in a former article the probable population of each State, and the representative population. Let us suppose the country to be divided into four sections -- viz.: the old Northern States, the old Southern States, the Northwest and the Southwest. Contrast the representation of these sections in 1800 and in 1860.

abstract: NEW-YORK RESCUING COMPANY PUBLIC EXHIBITION: A volunteer association with the above title, which has lately been started in this City for the purpose of saving life and property in case of fire, gave a public exhibition yesterday afternoon in the rear of No. 171 Christie-street.
lead_paragraph: NEW-YORK RESCUING COMPANY PUBLIC EXHIBITION: A volunteer association with the above title, which has lately been started in this City for the purpose of saving life and property in case of fire, gave a public exhibition yesterday afternoon in the rear of No. 171 Christie-street. The association is composed entirely of Germans, and numbers at present about 60 members. The officers are L. FROELICH foreman; JOEEPH STROHMENGER, assistant-foreman and Dr. OTTO, physician. If it should meet with proper encouragement and assistance from the City Government, and from the Insurance Companies, it is proposed to extend the organization into every fire district in the City. The exhibition yesterday was highly successful, and was witnessed by several hundred people,including representatives from various Insurance Companies, City officials and members of the Press. The apparatus employed was similar to that used in European cities, but it is the intention of the Company to avail themselves of every improvement that may be made in fire escapes -- the object of the organization being to get the advantage of skill and practice in their application. This advantage was illustrated by the exhibition yesterday. In the rear of No. 171 Christie-street are two four-story brick buildings which are about to be torn down, and the Company were allowed to experiment on them in any way they pleasad. At the sound of a trumpet from the Foreman, they commenced scaling the walls by means of small ladders, going up one story at a time, and breaking in the windows on their way, until they reached the top of the building. Then, throwing down a rope, they drew up the sack, made it fast, and commenced sliding down in rapid succession, the sack being held at the lower end by their companions, and sufficiently removed from the building to make the descent easy. Trunks, furniture and flour barrels were also rescued through the sack in the same way. This experiment was repeated, and on the second trial not more than two minutes elapsed from the sound of the trumpet before the men were safely sliding down the sack from the fourth-story windows. Experiments were also made with a simpler fire-escape, consisting merely of a sheet of thick canvas, about fifteen feet square, held up by means of ropes passing over the shoulders of men standing on the ground. Between twenty and thirty men, one of them weighing over 200 pounds, jumped from the roof of a four-story building on to this canvas, without sustaining the least injury. The exhibition was concluded by a speech from Mr. HENRY S. SMITH, in which he acknowledged on behalf of the spectators the pleasure they had derived from the spectacle, and awarded due praise to the German population of the City, for being the first to initiate such a praiseworthy organization.

abstract: BOLD INCENDIARISM. -- During the last week not less than fifteen buildings were fired by incendiaries in different parts of the city. One man, named NORTH, has been held to answer a charge of having set fire to buildings on DeKalb-avenue and Fulton-place; another has been arrested at Greenpoint, and yesterday officers OATS and CARROLL, of the Third Precinct, arrested CHARLES WRIGHT, on suspicion of having set fire to a tenement house, on Sunday night, at the corner of Amity and Columbia streets, when the building was damaged to the extent of about $200. Had not this fire been discovered early in its progress, many lives must have necessarily been lost. At 8 1/2 o'clock Sunday night a pile of lumber at the foot of North Second-street, owned by RALPE KENYON, was set on fire, and yesterday morning, at about 4 o'clock, Officers MCMAHON and FARRELL, of the Second Precinct, discovered smoke issuing from a house in Fleet's-alley, between York and Front streets. Upon entering the premises, they discovered a man named LYNCH watching a fire which he had kindled upon the floor of the first story of the building, which was unoccupied. The upper stories were occupied by five families, numbering in all some thirty persons. LYNCH was taken before Justice CORNWELL yesterday, and upon examination was discharged, there being no evidence that he intended to fire the building.
