abstract: An inquest was held yesterday at the NewYork Hospital on the body of an aged Frenchman named JEAN BAPTISTE LA ROCHELLE, who died in consequence of shocking burns received on the 20th ult., while engaged in setting fire to the crockery store No. 233 Greenwich-street, occupied by the brothers DEDACE and CORNE MORRISSETT.
lead_paragraph: An inquest was held yesterday at the NewYork Hospital on the body of an aged Frenchman named JEAN BAPTISTE LA ROCHELLE, who died in consequence of shocking burns received on the 20th ult., while engaged in setting fire to the crockery store No. 233 Greenwich-street, occupied by the brothers DEDACE and CORNE MORRISSETT. For some days prior to his decease, in addition to suffering intense physical torture, ROCHELLE betrayed great uneasiness of mind, which at times was of a very agonizing character. Finally, on Thursday last, believing the moment of his dissolution near, he expressed a desire to see Fire Marshal BAKER, to whom he made a confession or his guilt. He stated that three weeks before the fire occurred DEDACE MORRISSETT intimated his intention to burn out the store, because the adjoining crockery establishment of JOSEPH NORTON was doing a more successful business. Afterwards, at MORRISSETT's request, ROCHELLE said that he purchased at different times two gallons of camphene, which were placed in the store. He had been informed by MORRISSETT, on the day the fire occurred, that it was to take place that evening, and consented to assist in the transaction upon the promise of MORRISSETT to start him in a little place for himself, should he be successful in obtaining the insurance money. Accordingly, about 7 1/2 o'clock, on the evening in question, a man whose name ROCHELLE did not know, the brothers MORRISETT and himself, were in the store, and the stranger having applied the match to the pile of inflammable stuff that had been collected, ROCHELLE was directed by DEDACE MORRISETT to throw his overcoat upon the flames. As he was in the act of complying, a glass jar full of camphene, which stood near, was overturned, and some of the liquid saturated his clothing, and fell in his boots, and the flames coming in contact with it, he was instantly set in a blaze. He rushed into the street to save himself, in spite of the opposition of MORRISSETT, who sought, he said, to prevent an exposure by burning him along with the store. White the dying man was making this confession, the brothers MORRISSETT, who have been in custody ever since the occurrence of the fire, stood by his bedside. He accused them of having brought him to his terrible death, and in his frenzy invoked the judgment of heaven upon them. They made no response, and declined to ask him any questions. The only testimony taken at the inquest was as to the manner in which deceased obtained his injuries. A verdict was rendered that he died in consequence of burns received while engaged in the commission of incendiarism. The MORRISETTES' stock, valued at $700, was damaged to the extent of $500, and they had an insurance of $1,000 upon it in the Williamsburgh City Fire Insurance Company. Mr. NORTON, their neighbor, of whose success they were jealous, lost $1,200 worth of property by the fire. It is said that the prisoners owed their landlord nearly $200 for rent, and this is mentioned as an additional incentive to the incendiarism. Yesterday afternoon they were fully committed by Justice CONNOLLY on a charge of arson. In their examination before the magistrate, DEDACE stated that he was a Canadian by birth, 22 years of age, and in reference to the charge against him, he had nothing to say. His brother is also a native of Canada. He protested his innocence.

abstract: The weekly report of the City Inspector shows that during the week ending on the 7th inst. he had 395 men employed, who removed 26,869 loads of manure, dirt, rubbish and ashes, at a cost of $8,474 89, of which $2,942 25 was paid to sweepers, $3,024 to dirt and manure cartmen, and $2,498 to ash cartmen. This is a reduction of over $2,000 on the expenses of the previous week.

abstract: Mr. Speaker PENNINGTON seems, we feel bound to say, greatly wanting in one part of his duty, at least. One of his most important functions is the preservation of order in the House.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Speaker PENNINGTON seems, we feel bound to say, greatly wanting in one part of his duty, at least. One of his most important functions is the preservation of order in the House. Not simply the technical order -- which consists in putting the proper motions at the proper time, and having them disposed of in the proper way -- but real order, which consists in the proper and gentlemanly behavior of the members in their observance, not of the rules of parliamentary procedure, but of the usages of civilized society.

abstract: Mr. BEECHER, speaking in his sermon on Sunday night of moral courage among business men, said:  I have been a silent spectator I think I have said little about it of the desperate effort which has lately been made to get up another merchant fever.
lead_paragraph: Mr. BEECHER, speaking in his sermon on Sunday night of moral courage among business men, said: I have been a silent spectator I think I have said little about it of the desperate effort which has lately been made to get up another merchant fever. How many have been ashamed to honestly admit themselves to be Anti-Slavery men, Abolitionists! How many that drank in the drop of Liberty with their mother's milk, have, from an ignominious fear, been attempting to curry favor with the South! These men are fit only to be cast out, and to be trodden under foot! They are salt without savor. They have lost function, in losing manhood. Do you suppose there could be pinned up in hell a more exquisite roll of infernal honor than that exhibited by those men -- I think there were some twelve hundred of them -- who signed a petition asking the Legislature to permit Southern slaveholders to bring their slaves into this State, for fear they should not be thought to be sound in favor of Slavery -- for fear they should lose custom and reputarion? I do not know but what they will save their reputation, but as to saving their souls, I am afraid there is not much to save in that direction! If there is, then there is a doctrine of infinitessimals that is beyond any comprehension of mine. What dastards, what contemptible things wearing the form of men, must they be, who, ou[???]ieing Judas, make haste to sell their principles and their Master, without the pretence of any other temptation than that of saving a little pelf -- and that, too, when they were rich enough to retire long ago! But it is comforting to think that there is some use in the worst of things! When things have become corrupted, they are, at any rate, good for manure; and let us hope that out of this reeking filth a more luxuriant harvest of virtue may spring up!

abstract: The United States vs. George Dower. -- This case was submitted to the Jury after being summed up by Mr. Dwight for the prosecution and Mr. Ridgway for the accused. The Judge charged that it was not necessary that the corpus delicti should be proved; it was a question for them to determine, whether Humphreys was killed by the falling overboard, and that they could find a verdict of manslaughter or of murder, as they saw fit. The Judge alluded to the cruelties practiced on American ships, in speaking of the alleged malice shown against the deceased on the part of Dower, in very strong terms. His charge bore hard against the prisoner.

abstract: LOUIS NAPOLEON is neither so bad nor so able as is currently supposed. "It is his fate," said one who knew him well, "to be always misconceived. People used to think him a cretin, and now they think him a god." As we turn over page after page of his writings, we are compelled to admit that he has ideas and aspirations which are, to a certain extent, reflected in his policy. True, the ideas are often wrong-headed, while the policy is dyed deeply with self-interest and a low kind of expediency; but he is not a vulgar tyrant of the old-world type. With regard to his intellect, the mot d'enigme was hit on by a statesman who served him before the coup d'elat, who speaking lately of the sudden turns of his policy, observed, "Il ne sait pas la difference etre rever et penser." He carries out his projects with great prudence and coolness; but he devises them in the spirit of an enthusiast. Hence arise strange contradict dictions. The fire and the water meet, and the whole vanishes in vapor. It was thus that his dream of Italy free from the Alps to the Adriatic invited away in front of that grim Quadrilateral, It was thus that his design of raising Hungary in rebellion, and avenging on Austria the wrongs which she had inflicted on his uncle, disappeared before the shadow of a coming Coalition. LOUIS NAPOLEON is a sufficiciently acute man to have foreseen both the difficulties of the Lombardo-Venetian campaign and the possible complications which might have resulted from an insurrection on the Danube; but his imagination was powerfully affected by the picture" which it called up, and reason was silent till he was face to face with possible disaster.
lead_paragraph: LOUIS NAPOLEON is neither so bad nor so able as is currently supposed. "It is his fate," said one who knew him well, "to be always misconceived. People used to think him a cretin, and now they think him a god." True, the ideas are often wrong-headed, while the policy is dyed deeply with self-interest and a low kind of expediency; but he is not a vulgar tyrant of the old-world type. With regard to his intellect, the mot d'enigme was hit on by a statesman who served him before the coup d'elat, who speaking lately of the sudden turns of his policy, observed, "Il ne sait pas la difference etre rever et penser." He carries out his projects with great prudence and coolness; but he devises them in the spirit of an enthusiast. Hence arise strange contradict dictions. The fire and the water meet, and the whole vanishes in vapor. It was thus that his dream of Italy free from the Alps to the Adriatic invited away in front of that grim Quadrilateral, It was thus that his design of raising Hungary in rebellion, and avenging on Austria the wrongs which she had inflicted on his uncle, disappeared before the shadow of a coming Coalition. LOUIS NAPOLEON is a sufficiciently acute man to have foreseen both the difficulties of the Lombardo-Venetian campaign and the possible complications which might have resulted from an insurrection on the Danube; but his imagination was powerfully affected by the picture" which it called up, and reason was silent till he was face to face with possible disaster.

abstract: The following particulars of the death of Jullien are given in the English papers: "The anxiety consequent on the getting up of a new series of concerts, upon which he calculated establishing in the French capital the high reputation he had gained in the course of twenty years in England, was too much for a temperament at all times keenly sensitive and excitable, and loss of reason was the result. On Sunday last, M. Jullien's first concert was to be given, but two days previously, M. Jullien was conveyed to a private lunatic asylum, having exhibited the worst phases of madness. There are no particulars of his demise further than that, in consequence of some severe course of antiphlogistic treatment, the patient caught a severe cold which fastened on his lungs, and terminated in inflammation. M. Jullien's reason returned some hours previous to his decease, and he passed away in perfect consciousness of what was passing around. The subscription which was advertised, and which in a few days amounted to a considerable sum, will, no doubt, be appropriated to his widow and family, and to the expenses attending his illness and death."

abstract: MATERIAL FOR POLISHING. -- Some of our cotemporaries have copied from the Peterboro' Review, Canada West, a statement of an alleged important discovery, at Port Hope, of Tripoli, a much valued deposit used for polishing; and it appears that a Company has been formed to work it, and have patented the discovery. A quantity of it has been obtained by Mr. ARTHUR M. EDWARDS, a microscopist of this city, who found it to be nothing more than an extremely fine sand, and not tripoli at all. It would rather scratch than polish metals. True tripoli is made up of the remains of minute vegetables. What is known as fresh water tripoli, is found under peat bogs and swamps. The marine deposit is obtained at Oran, in Africa, Isle of France; and the City of Richmond, Va., stands upon a wide-spread surface of tripoli -- in fact, this bed extends from Piscataway, in Maryland, to Petersburgh in Virginia. At Richmond it is thirty feet deep. Only think of the vast amount of minute vegetable matter necessary to make all this. The forms found in this substance, when submitted to the power of the microscope, are most exquisite and wonderful. The late Prof. BAILEY of West Point was the first to find tripoli under the hill upon which Fort Putnam stands.

abstract: A portion of the Mormons have at last become disgusted with the proceedings of the Saints at Utah, and have taken steps to get rid of the tyranny of BRIGHAM YOUNG. A letter from a correspondent, which we publish in another column, gives an interesting account of the proceedings of the Mormon Conference just held at Amboy, in Illinois.
lead_paragraph: A portion of the Mormons have at last become disgusted with the proceedings of the Saints at Utah, and have taken steps to get rid of the tyranny of BRIGHAM YOUNG. A letter from a correspondent, which we publish in another column, gives an interesting account of the proceedings of the Mormon Conference just held at Amboy, in Illinois. The Mormon church everywhere acknowledges the rightful authority of young JOE SMITH, son of the founder of the sect; -- and steps have for some time been in progress to induce him to assume the Presidency. This has at last been accomplished. He has been inducted into office, and made an address on the occasion, which will be found at length in another column.
headline: {'main': 'A Split among the Mormons.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Split among the Mormons.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. WINSLOW, it is said, is about to apply for subpoenas directed to HORACE GREELEY, THURLOW WEED, and other Republican notabilities, for the purpose of examining them as to the amount and final disposition of the Republican contributions in aid of their cause at the Pennsylvania election in 1856. If he does make any such application, we hope the Committee will have the good sense to refuse it, not because the inquiry would do no good, but because the present Committee is not competent to make it. It has been appointed for the sole and express purpose of investigating the conduct of the officers of the existing Administration, and the use which these gentlemen have made of funds belonging to the public treasury. In so far as it travels outside this line, its action is impertinent and unauthorized. What it has to discover is, what use Mr. JAMES BUCHANAN and his subordinates and appointees have made of the Government money and Government contracts, and whether any portion, and, if so, what portion, of this money or these contracts, has been devoted to electioneering in the interest of a political party.

abstract: THE ST. NICHOLAS FESTIVAL. -- The time-honored observance of the Paas Festival, which, in common with the holidays dedicated to the perpetuation of the customs of the imported nationalities, is annually observed at Easter by that decent and decorous contingent of our community, the descendants of the Dutch, was duly, commemorated last evening at the St. Nicholas Hotel. The Chair was occupied by Hon. HAMILTON FISH, who had on his right, as invited guests, Rev. Dr. Vermilye, Rev. Dr. Bethune, David T. Valentine, ex-Mayor Kingsland and ex-Judge Roosevelt. On his left, Hon. Gulian C. Verplanck, ex-Gov. King, and Shephard Knapp. Miscellaneously dispersed among the company, we noticed Dr. Woodruff, Augustus Schell, Henry Morton, and many other gentlemen besides whose commercial standing or professional reputation are publicly known and appreciated. In the course of the evening impromptu speeches were made by the Chairman and many of the guests, including both the Ex-Governors, all the clergymen, and Mr. SCHELL. As a pleasant variation in the enjoyments of the night, Mr. HENRY MORTON and Mr. LOUIS LANG delighted the assemblage with some exquisite vocalizations. Of course, the hereditary weakness for schnapps, unconscionably long pipes, and pink-dyed eggs, was exhibited to a degree almost threatening in its results on the nervous system. Everything, however, (but in regard to this we speak only of the period over which our personal observation extended,) was conducted with characteristic solemnity. We are obliged to avow that, as the morning advanced, some of the gentlemen who were called upon to speak indulged in a latitude of expression which might, under other circumstances, be considered as fairly open to criticism.

On his left, Hon. Gulian C. Verplanck, ex-Gov. abstract: Dates from Bogota are to March 12. Great agitation prevailed there in Government circles, on the reception of the news of MOSQUEBA'S victory and movements in Cauca. It was reported he was preparing to march upon Bogota, and President OSPINA, in consonance with authority given him by the last Congress, was contemplating the removal of the capital and Congress to Medelin, in Antioquia.

abstract: The Memphis Avalanche says there are not less than 250 of the Knights (K.G.C.'s.) in this city, fully armed and equipped for a foray into Sonora or an attack upon Vera Cruz. We have seen in the hands of one of these gentlemen a plat of the City of Vera Cruz, and a perfect drawing of San Juan d'Ullos. It is now the design of the K.G.C's., if we are correctly informed, to cooperate with the Juarez party, and three or four of our prominent citizens are enlisted in the enterprise; among others we wot of a gentleman formerly connected with the Press of this city, and an official of high character, both actively interested in the prosecution of the designs of the K.G.C's.

abstract: Punch represents the youthful King of Naples as playing, in great glee, with the manacles and other instruments of despotism which were the instruments of his father's serious occupation. This young monarch is evidently ambitious of eclipsing the unenviable notoriety which his father acquired by his despotism. At a period when a Murat is plotting for his crown, and the work of Italian independence is carried on so gloriously, it is somewhat hazardous, one would think, for a Sicilian king to test too severely the patience and forbearance of his subjects. Recent outrages, however, against the personal rights and liberties of numerous respectable citizens of Naples prove that FRANCIS II, and his Ministers are of quite a different opinion. A detailed account of these outrages has been communicated to the British Foreign Secretary by Mr. ELLIOT, in a dispatch we have published at length. That document closed, it will be remembered, by stating that his request for an interview with the King, in order that he might warn his Majesty of the fatal consequences of so iniquitous a policy, had been presented to the Minister, and that M. CARAFA promised to convey it to the monarch; but, as no answer had been received up to the date of Mr. ELLIOT's last dispatch, we may presume that the honor sought for was not to be accorded to him. The British Charge need not, however, repine at his failure, as the French, Spanish and Austrian Representatives were equally unsuccessful in their efforts to divert the Neapolitan Government from its purpose.

abstract: The TRIBUNE entered upon its twentieth year. What it has been, is, and aspires to be, its readers mainly know. Its size, when not increased by a Supplement, is at least trebled since its start; its amount of matter more than quadrupled. Its weekly expenses are now some twenty-fold what they were at the outset; the number regularly borne on its pay-roll has increased in proportion. Its Circulation is at this moment greater, we believe, than that of any journal of Politics and News ever issued in this or any other country. That Circulation, the localities reached by it, and a comparison with what it was one year ago, are exhibited by the following tables, compiled from our books as they stood on the 1st instant:

lead_paragraph: It is generally supposed that the object of advertising is to reach the public, and that the only motive which the Common Council can properly have for advertising its proceedings is, to keep the great mass of the people regularly and properly informed in regard to them. The manner in which this object is sought just now is a little peculiar. A report has just been made by the Comptroller to the Board of Councilmen, setting forth the sums paid to the proprietors of the various newspapers in the City, for advertising for the Common Council and the Departments during the fourteen months ending on the 1st of March. As it is something of a curiosity in its way, we publish this return at length:

abstract: A small frame dwelling-house in Eighty-fourth-street, between Third and Fourth avenues, was totally destroyed by fire between 8 and 9 o'clock last evening. It was owned and occupied by AUGUST TEUBNER, who estimates his loss at $1,000 upon which he had an insurance for $700 in the Bowery Company. It origin was accidental.

abstract: It appears that Lord BROUGHAM's actual honors in the peerage are not after all to be transmitted to his brother. The barony of BROUGHAN and VAUX was created for the great orator in 1830, and as not a few statesmen, captains, lawyers, country gentlemen and millionaires have since been rewarded by a grateful country with the cap and balls of honor, the BROUGHAM peerage has gradually risen to quite a respectable point of precedence. The heir of the Chancellor is not to be allowed to enjoy this particular feature of his brother's titular distinction. A new barony of BROUGHAM is to be created, bearing date in 1860, and consequently coming in as the puisne title of the peerage, and this will be made out with remainder to Mr. WM. BROUGHAM. One person, at least, will delight in this arrangement -- a certain Lord VAUX, whose glory has been permanently dimmed by the addition of his own title to that of the encyclopedic Nestor of the British Parliament.
lead_paragraph: It appears that Lord BROUGHAM's actual honors in the peerage are not after all to be transmitted to his brother. abstract: The Prince Albert, from Galway March 31, reached St. Johns, N.F., on Monday, and her news came to this City last evening. It is of interest. The Savoy Treaty had been published. Its contents verify the abstracts hitherto given. Switzerland, it was said, was about to publish a protest; and it was also rumored that a general Congress would meet to consider the subject. In the French Senate a vote, prompted by petitions in favor of the temporal power of the Pope, had been taken, by which a majority of that body appeared to be unfavorable to the petitions. In the meantime, His Holiness had issued his major excommunication against all who had counseled or aided the annexation of the Romagna to Sardinia, and had sent a circular protest, on the same subject, to the Great Powers. Austria had also made the annexation of the Duchies the topic of a protest addressed to the Diet at Frankfort. The terms of the pending treaty between Spain and Morocco have been published at Madrid. They involve, on the part of the latter power, the payment of $20,000,000, the cession of a large strip of territory, submission to a Spanish occupation of Tetuan, and the celebration of a liberal commercial treaty. The English news is of secondary moment. In the House of Commons, Lord JOHN RUSSELL had stated that the San Juan difficulty was in course of negotiation, promising an early adjustment. The Atlantic Telegraph Company had announced a change of programme. It now proposes to raise Â£25,000, by way of mortgage, upon the value of the submerged cable, to be applied to raising it. In regard to the great prize fight, measures had been taken to cause the arrest of all parties concerned, and to prevent the contest from taking place.
lead_paragraph: The Prince Albert, from Galway March 31, reached St. Johns, N.F., on Monday, and her news came to this City last evening. It is of interest. The Savoy Treaty had been published. Its contents verify the abstracts hitherto given. Switzerland, it was said, was about to publish a protest; and it was also rumored that a general Congress would meet to consider the subject. In the French Senate a vote, prompted by petitions in favor of the temporal power of the Pope, had been taken, by which a majority of that body appeared to be unfavorable to the petitions. In the meantime, His Holiness had issued his major excommunication against all who had counseled or aided the annexation of the Romagna to Sardinia, and had sent a circular protest, on the same subject, to the Great Powers. Austria had also made the annexation of the Duchies the topic of a protest addressed to the Diet at Frankfort. The terms of the pending treaty between Spain and Morocco have been published at Madrid. They involve, on the part of the latter power, the payment of $20,000,000, the cession of a large strip of territory, submission to a Spanish occupation of Tetuan, and the celebration of a liberal commercial treaty. The English news is of secondary moment. In the House of Commons, Lord JOHN RUSSELL had stated that the San Juan difficulty was in course of negotiation, promising an early adjustment. The Atlantic Telegraph Company had announced a change of programme. It now proposes to raise £25,000, by way of mortgage, upon the value of the submerged cable, to be applied to raising it. In regard to the great prize fight, measures had been taken to cause the arrest of all parties concerned, and to prevent the contest from taking place.

abstract: The Senate closed the fillibustering on the Almshouse resolution this afternoon, by ordering the bill to be read a third time at 7 o'clock this evening. At that hour it was read, and the vote being taken, the resolution was lost-ayes 16, noes 13. Five Republicans voted in the negative. A motion to reconsider was made, and laid on the table. The bill will pass the Senate.

abstract: In order to afford the public an additional opportunity of being made familiar with the details of Dr. HAYES' projected expedition in search of an entrance into the open Polar Sea, a meeting, to which were admitted gratuitously all who felt any interest in the matter, was held last night in the Cooper Institute, under the auspices of the Geographical and Statistical Society. The hall was nearly filled by an audience of the most respectable character, and on the platform were many gentlemen not only well known in connection with the Society, but of high reputation in their respective professions.

abstract: The defeat of the New-York Health bill in the Assembly causes more sadness than indignation among the reflecting portions of our community. Its object is so purely beneficent, the necessity for some measure of the kind is so pressing and imperative, and the lives of thousands of children during the approaching Summer depend so directly upon its enactment, that no one can regard its rejection without sorrow and profound regret.

lead_paragraph: OPERATIC. Mr. MARETZEK'S season at the Winter Garden will commence positively to-night. All the arrangements necessary for an energetic campaign have been completed, and the innumerable artists of the house (which, we may here add, is one of the strongest ever presented to a New-York audience) are palpitating with zealous desire to show their mettle: To-night, Mine. GASSIER makes her rentree as Lucia and Signor ERNANI his debut as Edgardo. Concerning the lady there can be no doubt; and if the journalists of Havana are to be relied on, the gentleman is also certain of the reception always awarded to a first-class artist. Signor GASSIER and Signor GASPARONI appear in the other parts.

abstract: The annual election of Wardens and Vestrymen of Trinity Church took place yesterday. Unusual interest was manifested in this election, in consequence of an independent ticket having been put in the field by the Corporators -- who comprise owners and lessees of pews, and communicants of one year's standing -- in opposition to the regular ticket nominated by the Vestrymen. The precise grounds of this opposition it was difficult to discover at the scene of the election, as each party told a different story, and every man of each party seemed more anxious to secure a vote than to give a reason for the faith that was in him. As near as could be ascertained, however, the parties are at variance on several points. But the origin of the difficulty appears to have been the action of the Rector, Dr. BERRIAN, in appointing to the post of Assistant Rector, Rev. MORGAN L. DIX, a young man who, whatever his merit, which is said to be great, was not entitled, in the opinion of many of the corporators, to be thus promoted over the heads of his seniors. Mr. DIX is the son of Hon. JOHN A. DIX, Ex-Senator of New-York, who is one of the present Vestrymen, but whose name was omitted from the opposition ticket. Another ground of opposition was stated to be a proposed change in the policy of the Church, advocated by several of last year's Vestrymen, by which the stipends heretofore granted to poor Churches and the annuities awarded to the families of deceased clergymen, were to be cut off I was also argued that the practice which has heretofore prevailed, of allowing the Vestrymen to nominated their successors, while the Corporators contented themselves with merely indorsing, by their votes, the ticket thus nominated, should be broken up. These reasons, together with others, evidently of a personal nature, combined to make the election a very execiting one, and gave the vestibule of Trinity Church the apperance of a more wo[???]ly polling place. At the closing of the, polls it was announced that the whole number of votes polled was 210, nearly 100 more than were ever cast before. On canvassing the votes, it was found that the regular, or Vestrymen's ticket, was elected by about 180 majority, or nearly four to one Most of the names on the opposition ticket, however, were the same as those on the regular ticket, -- the only exceptions being, that on the opposition ticket the name of ANTHONY J. BLEECKER was substituted for JOHN A. DIX, GEO C. MORGAN for GOUVENEUR M. OGDEN, ABRAHAM H. LIVINGSTON for NELSON JARVIS, and WM.P. LEE for SAMUEL DAVIS. The following is the ticket elected:

abstract: The news of the passage of the amendments to the Metropolitan Police law created considerable stir at the Police Head-quarters yesterday. No little anxiety was manifested as to the probable policy of the new regime. As stated in the TIMES of yesterday, the new Board consists of but three members Messrs, STILLMAN, STRANAHAN, ULLSHOFFER, BAILEY and the two Mayors being dropped; Mr. BOWEN retained, and Messrs. AMOS PILSBURY and JOHN G. BERGEN added.
lead_paragraph: The news of the passage of the amendments to the Metropolitan Police law created considerable stir at the Police Head-quarters yesterday. No little anxiety was manifested as to the probable policy of the new regime. As stated in the TIMES of yesterday, the new Board consists of but three members Messrs, STILLMAN, STRANAHAN, ULLSHOFFER, BAILEY and the two Mayors being dropped; Mr. BOWEN retained, and Messrs. AMOS PILSBURY and JOHN G. BERGEN added. Mr. BOWEN has been Treasurer since the organization of the Board. Mr. PILSBURY is the well-known efficient Ex-General-Superintendent, and Mr. BERGEN is the gentleman who came within a few votes of representing Mr. SPINOLA's district in the State Senate. Messrs. BOWEN and BERGSN are staunch and strong Republicans, and Mr. PILSBURY is a Democrat, and no little interest is exhibited in the question as to whether they will all pull together.

abstract: On Tuesday evening, at the lecture-room of the Madison-avenue Church, (Dr. ADAMS',) Rev. S.H. MARSH, of Oregon, made some statements in regard to the country on the North Pacific coast, illustrative especially of the need of a College in that region. The section of Oregon and Washington west of the Cascade Mountains is the finest on the Pacific, and is capable of supporting a dense population, and possessed of the most important conditions of public prosperity. East of this section, beyond the Cascade Mountains, extending to the north far into British America, and eastward to the valley of the Missouri, the basin of the Columbia spreads out -- a vast region, containing many sub-sections of divers characters, as respects soil and climate, but the most of it likely, at no distant day, to be brought into the service of man.

abstract: This morning the National Academy of Design opens its Exhibition for 1860. Last night was reserved for the "Scribes and Pharisees," fashion and the critics, to whom a "private view" is graciously accorded by the rulers of the Academy. "Private" these views, in
lead_paragraph: This morning the National Academy of Design opens its Exhibition for 1860. From this time forth, all the world, Gentiles, publicans and sinners, may freely, though not gratuitously, enter in and enjoy the fruits of the palette in their season. Last night was reserved for the "Scribes and Pharisees," fashion and the critics, to whom a "private view" is graciously accorded by the rulers of the Academy. "Private" these views, in so far as they are views at all, must certainly be admitted to be; and in a sense which reminds us forcibly of an observation which we heard made in a sharp Yankee accent, one night at Rome, on leaving the Coliseum, after a most impressive display of blue lights, provided by Prince DEMIDOFF, in honor of the return of Pope PIUS from Gaeta. The reader may easily imagine that such a show in such a place must banish from the mind, for the time being, all external and sublunary thoughts. We imagined so ourselves, as we stood there in the arena, and watched the ghostly splendors flash and fade around the solemn circle of the eternal pile. But as we came out through one of the great vomitories, the familiar tones of New-England fell upon our ear, in these expressive words: "Private fortunes, do you say? Hem -- there are some of those private fortunes so infernally private you never can find 'em."

abstract: The ship Jacob A. Westervelt, Capt. WILLIAMS, belonging to H.L. RICH & CO.'s line of Liverpool packets, took fire yesterday, about 3 P.M., while lying at anchor in the North River, outward bound. The fire originated in the between decks, aft, and was caused by the upsetting of a lamp. The carpenter had gone below, in company with a boy, for the purpose of procuring stores for the steerage passengers, 18 in number, and while thus engaged the boy let the lamp fall; it broke, and set fire to the cotton stowed near by, and in a few minutes the smoke was so dense as to defy the exertions of the men sent below to low extinguish the flames.
lead_paragraph: The ship Jacob A. Westervelt, Capt. WILLIAMS, belonging to H.L. RICH & CO.'s line of Liverpool packets, took fire yesterday, about 3 P.M., while lying at anchor in the North River, outward bound. abstract: The New-York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church has just commenced its Twelfth Annual Session at Stamford, Connecticut. The business of the Conference will probably occupy it for a week or more. A larger number of delegates than usual are present, and the attendance of outsiders is also large, being drawn together by the exciting discussion touching the relations of the Church to the Slavery question, and the duty of the Church North towards the members of the Church in the Southern States, who are involved in the "guilt of Slavery." The business of electing seven delegates to the General Conference, which meets at Buffalo on the 1st of May, has been seized as the fitting occasion to decide whether the "General rule on Slavery" in the discipline shall be changed so as to exclude slaveholders from the Church.
lead_paragraph: The New-York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church has just commenced its Twelfth Annual Session at Stamford, Connecticut. abstract: The least regarded of DONIZETTI's innumerable works is probably "Don Pasquale," -- which is also one of his best. Its career in this City has never been brilliant. PICCOLOMINI, whose Norina was accepted in Europe as admirable, failed to make any sensation with the part here. It was enjoyed by the appreciative few and ignored by the remunerative many. No reason can be assigned for this, except that the idea of the opera is very quiet and domestic, and not at all of the sensational character which people fond of being astonished most affect. The music, thoroughly delicious, is filled with melodious ideas and graceful elaborations of musical figures. It is so eminently singable, too, that successful or not successful, it is sure, like the "Barbiere" of ROSSINI, to find its students in the foremost ranks of art. We are indebted to Miss PATTI for the present opportunity of hearing the work, and if we may judge by the numbers who shared our satisfaction, it is in a better way now of becoming popular than at any previous period of its cis-atlantic history. There was, in truth, a remarkably large audience to greet the pet prima donna in her new part, and to add it to her repertoire as a success. In all the more detached portions of the work, and in every passage where facility and delicacy were required, Miss PATTI sang excellently. In the ensembles there was occasional lack of power, and notably in the termagant finale to the second act, where experience of husbands and a knowledge of male excitants is needed. Apart from these slight drawbacks, the performance was in every way a success.
lead_paragraph: The least regarded of DONIZETTI's innumerable works is probably "Don Pasquale," -- which is also one of his best. Its career in this City has never been brilliant. We are indebted to Miss PATTI for the present opportunity of hearing the work, and if we may judge by the numbers who shared our satisfaction, it is in a better way now of becoming popular than at any previous period of its cis-atlantic history. abstract: This handsome building is now nearly completed, the first coating of paint is dry, the floors are being laid, and on the 1st of May the stalls will be up, the butchers will be at work and the Seventh Regiment, before the 1st of June, will take possession of its new quarters, In dimensions this building is 181 feet nine inches long, by 100 feet wide.
lead_paragraph: This handsome building is now nearly completed, the first coating of paint is dry, the floors are being laid, and on the 1st of May the stalls will be up, the butchers will be at work and the Seventh Regiment, before the 1st of June, will take possession of its new quarters, In dimensions this building is 181 feet nine inches long, by 100 feet wide. Of the three stories, in which it is divided by solid wrought-iron beams, three feet apart, running the whole width of the building, the first story is to be used as a market; the other two storles are to be exclusively dedicated to the use of "our gallant Seventh." The second story is divided into eleven company meeting or squad drill rooms, about 21 by 36 feet in dimensions, and two large company drill rooms; one 66 feet long by 36 wide, and the other 42 feet long by 36 wide. So there will be a room for each company, irrespective of the two large drill rooms, a room for the band and two rooms to spare, for meetings or any other purpose to which the Regiment may see fit to devote them.

abstract: We have received a long statement from a committee of the stone-cutters on the new Cathedral, giving the reasons for their refusing to go on with their work under the contractor. Two dollars a day, hey say, is the standard price during winter for their work; yet many of the best workmen among them could not earn over nine shilligs. A committee accordingly waited upon Mr. JOYCE, the contractor, to ask an increase of wages. He replied that he made his own regulations and paid his own prices, and those who did not like them could leave. They accordingly withdrew on the 14th of February, and although five committees have since waited upon Mr. JOYCE, they have been able to make no arrangement with him. The Committee state that they ask nothing unreasonable, but merely fair wages for their work. They refer to Archbishop HUGHES' statement on laying the corner-stone of the building, that its erection would give employment to the poor at fair compensation, which has not been fulfilled. They deny that they have ever used or threatened personal violence to any parties on account of this strike, and declare that they have no sympathy with any such demonstrations. They proposed to leave the matter to a Committee of day's-men working in the shop -- they to choose three and Mr. JOYCE two. He refused, and said he should manage his business to suit himself in spite of the workmen, the Archbishop or anybody else. The Committee conclude by denouncing his conduct as tyrannical and oppressive, and they appeal to the public to approve of the course they have adopted.

abstract: The Judiciary Committee, to whom Mr. BUCHANAN was so anxious to get his case transferred, has delivered judgment upon his plea in abatement, and overruled it with considerable emphasis. Mr. HICKMAN's majority report, presented to the House of Representatives on Monday, discusses the points of the President's protest seriatim, and disposes of them all with a facility and a clearness which, we venture to assert, were not surpassed even in the case of Judge PECK, in which Mr. BUCHANAN found so much consolation. The document has but one fault, and that is the occasional severity of its tone; but for this Mr. BUCHANAN has himself to thank. To have either examined or replied to so shrewish, undignified and ill-tempered a document as his message to the House, in the language of judicial calmness and moderation, would, perhaps, have been the wisest and most becoming course to pursue; but it is a course which, under such circumstances, ordinary mortals, of whom Congressional Committees are generally composed, find it extremely difficult to adopt.

abstract: The Metropolitan Police bill, which has just passed, whatever its defects may be, has one great merit -- and that is, that it removes the two Mayors from the Board. These officers are, and always will continue to be, thorough politicians, as incapable of performing any public duty uninfluenced by political considerations, as a fish of living out of water. They are the creatures of political intrigue; politics is their business, and all their ambition is political. They cannot avoid making all the influence they possess subservient to their advancement in their profession, and it is folly to expect them to do otherwise. Mayor WOOD, for instance, looks on his Mayoralty as simply a steppingstone to greater honors; and to suppose that he would not use the position in its fullest extent to help himself on in his career, is to give him credit for a disinterestedness of which he would himself be thoroughly ashamed.

abstract: Mr. MAX MARETZEK, the "indomitable," re  sumed his old position as operatic manager last night, having leased the Winter Garden for the purpose, and was welcomed back to his post in the orchestra with something more than the usual honors. The reception was deserved, for of the many directors we have had in this City and their numbers have been sufficient to throw discredit on their ability he is undoubtedly the one to whom the
lead_paragraph: Mr. MAX MARETZEK, the "indomitable," re sumed his old position as operatic manager last night, having leased the Winter Garden for the purpose, and was welcomed back to his post in the orchestra with something more than the usual honors. The reception was deserved, for of the many directors we have had in this City and their numbers have been sufficient to throw discredit on their ability he is undoubtedly the one to whom the "divine art" is most indebted for past services and present advancement. We say this with no desire to underrate the oftentimes meritorious efforts of others who have followed in his footsteps, but simply as a matter of truth which may gracefully be put on record at this moment. Something is due to the hardy pioneer who treads the path to progress and success, and this something is Mr. MARETREK's, as a glance at the record will prove. Much has been accomplished since the memorable epoch of the old Astor-place Opera-house. Italian opera has been established "on a permanent basis" at least a dozen times, and, whether successfully or not, we have secured by the efforts then iniatiated a succession of respectable operas and artists. The usual contests incidental to an enterprise promising great results have taken place over and over again; lessees have quarrelled with managers, managers with artists, artists with the public, and so on to the end of the chapter. No one save the parties pecuniarily interested have regretted these little episodes, for they have been the means of exciting a spirit of excellence and of educating the public in the school of comparison, which would not otherwise have been expected or effected. When the Academy of Music was erected, it was supposed that these old struggles would cease, and that, content with one spacious opera house, the Musical World would rest satisfied with what the managers chose to give them. Under ordinary circumstances this might have been regarded as a natural consequence of a wise and liberal speculation, but an injudicious system of leasing the Fourteenth-street house for a lengthy period, and of thus establishing, or attempting to establish a monopoly of Italian opera, has resulted -- as all such efforts result -- in a long series of oppositions. For the simple reason that the Winter Garden possesses better acoustic properties than any other establishment in the City, it has been invariably selected as the battle ground for the musical contestants. Besides many others, Mr. HACKETT, (with GRISI and MARIO,) Mr. STRAKOSCH, and finally Mr. MARETZEK, have in turn occupied it with their belligerent forces, -- numbering frequently some of the greatest and best artists we have ever had in this country. So much for the place and the cause of its selection. Mr. MARETZEK, like a cautious general, enters upon his present fight with ample resources. His company is unusually strong -- the strongest, probably, that has been in this City since the palmy days of the Marti troupe. Among his prime donne we find the names of Mesdames INEZ FABBRI, GASSIER, FREZZOLINI and WISSLER; his principal tenors are Signors ERRANI and STIGELLI; his baritones and bassos, Messrs. GASSIER, GASPARONI, ARDAVANI and MULLER. With this double force in all departments he is able to play six times a week, and will of course do so.

abstract: A young girl, a seamstress, dependent upon her daily labor for her livelihood, was crossing the Park yesterday morning, on her way to her work, when she was overtaken by Mr. DANIEL MCKAY, a book-keeper at No. 405 Broadway. In passing her, MCKAY made a spring in order to avoid a puddle, dropped a pistol from his pocket, which exploded on reaching the ground, and the ball, after striking the girl's forefinger, traversed her right wrist, and lodged in her arm, and so far, has not been extracted. The wound, if not dangerous, is painful, may probably disable her for life, and in the meantime, leaves her helpless in the hospital.

abstract: MORE ARSON CASES. -- A man named CHARLES WRIGHT was fully committed by Justice CORNWELL yesterday, to await the action of the Grand Jury on a charge of arson. The prisoner is charged with setting fire to a tenement house on the corner of Amity and Columbia streets....A small building on South Third-street, between First and Second streets, owned by Mr. MCAVERY and occupied as a cooper's shop, was set on fire Tuesday night and entirely destroyed. Loss $300.

abstract: The Senate rejected the bill to amend the Patent Laws by a vote of 19 to 19, the Vice-President voting against it. The bill relative to the transportation of the mails to California was taken up, but, after a brief conversation, was laid aside, and Mr. JOHNSON, of Tennessee, spoke at some length in favor of the Homestead bill. He was replied to by Mr. MASON, who was followed by the irrepressible WIGFALL on the same side. The bill was finally made the special order for Tuesday next, with the understanding that a vote would then be taken. The Kansas Admission bill engaged the attention of the House. Mr. MAYNARD, of Tennessee, argued against the bill, alleging that the Territory lacked the proper population; objecting to the clause of the Wyandotte Constitution which requires as a title to citizenship a residence of only six months; and insisting upon the exclusion of the Cherokee reserves from the boundaries of the State. He was succeded by Mr. GOOCH of Massachusetts, in oppositisn to, and Mr. QUARLES, of Tennessee, in support of his argument. Mr. COX, of Ohio, who had voted for the English bill, avowed his determination to sustain the present measure; referring to his declaration at the period of his former vote, that he should be for the admission of Kansas, whenever it came with a Constitution approved by its people. Mr. PRYOR arose to a question of privilege predicated upon a report of the disturbance on the occasion of Mr. LOVEJOY's recent speech. He objected to the published reports, as containing remarks of Mr. POTTER addressed to him; whereas he had not only not heard Mr. POTTER speak at the time, but was unaware of his presence. A conversation marked with extreme acerbity ensued between the two gentlemen; resulting in an intimation from Mr. PRYOR that his colloquist should be held to account elsewhere. Mr. GROW then closed the debate by a speech epitomizing the points urged by the friends of the bill; and then, upon the vote being taken, the bill was passed by a vote of 134 to 73. Mr. ENGLISH explained his reason for voting in the negative.

abstract: The Secretary of the Treasury communicated to Senate yesterday the amount of revenue collected and the expenses thereof, together with the number of persons employed. In 1858, the revenue amounted to $42,542,287; the, expenses to $3,529,788. The number of employees was 3,041. In 1859, the revenue collected amounted to $49,353,439. Expenses $3,395,030. The employes numbered 2,972.

abstract: STEET LABELS. -- The verdict of "careless sloven," if not of "culpable rascal," would be found by the public against a druggist who should serve them with medicines from an array of bottles and boxes having some the labels upside down, others with the inscription reading from right to left, and others yet, with no marks at all to indicate their contents. Without intimating that the public receptacles of ashes, filth, and garbage, in this City, commonly 'yelept "public thoroughfares," contain elements so well adapted to sanitary purposes as the druggist's ipecac, and arsenic, we still believe that the naming and numbering of the public ways are matters worthy of at least a tithe of the care which the clumsiest apothecary-boy in the town devotes to labeling bottles on the dusty shelves of a shoo.

abstract: There are annexations and annexations; and though the same term be applied to all transactions of this nature, they differ from each other not seldom, quite as widely as the jurisprudence of ROB ROY from that of JEREMY BENTHAM. Lord BYRON, when he permitted himself to abstract a single golden hair from that gleaming strand of LUCREZIA BORGIA's "gory locks," which has at once horrified and delighted so many romantic visitors to the Ambrosian Library, mildly stated in his diary that he had "obtained" the fair but formidable relic. Probably the respectable authorities of Milan felt disposed to label the proceeding with a different name.

abstract: ANNUAL MEETING OF THE FEMALE AUXILIARY BIBLE SOCIETY. The New-York Female Bible So  ciety, auxiliary to the New-York Bible Society, held their forty-fourth annual meeting at the Bible House, in Astor-place, yesterday. Dr. Brigham presided, and Rev. A.L. Hunt read the annual report of the managers.
lead_paragraph: ANNUAL MEETING OF THE FEMALE AUXILIARY BIBLE SOCIETY. The New-York Female Bible So ciety, auxiliary to the New-York Bible Society, held their forty-fourth annual meeting at the Bible House, in Astor-place, yesterday. Dr. Brigham presided, and Rev. A.L. Hunt read the annual report of the managers. The account of the doings of the Society showed that during the past year there had been collected $6,562 71, of which $716 45 had been paid for Bibles for distribution, and $5,846 26 to the American Bible Society. The latter organization has thus received from the ladies in forty-four years the sum of $112,968 73 out of $132,387 70 collected. The following officers were elected for the ensuing year: Mrs. David Codwise, First Directress; Mrs. Wm.B. Astor, Second; Mrs. James Brown, Third; Mrs. John Wurts, Recording Secretary; Mrs. Dr. Olin, Corresponding Secretary, and Mrs. Jacob Le Roy, Treasurer. The following ladies were chosen Managers: Mesdames Joshua Clibborn, L. Baker, S.J. Beebee, E.A. Livingston, Anson G. Phelps, Lindley M. Hoffman, T.C. Doremus, Richard Irvin, Samuel G. Smith, E.J. Woolsey, W. Truslow, J. Saydam, Graham, Wetmore, Dewitt, Dr. Holdich, G.G. Howland, F. Depeyster, Nicholson, J.A. Kennedy, D. Enel, H.J. Baker, Jessup, Carter, L. Bradish, and Misses Murray, Kissam, Duffy, Smith, Van Schaick, Westervelt, R.L. Kennedy, After addresses by Drs. Tyng and Bethune, the meeting was dismissed with a benediction by Rev. Dr. Brigham.

abstract: In the House of Commons, on the 26th ult., Mr. HORSMAN took an opportunity of referring to the subject of foreign policy, and especially with regard to the rights of the House to discuss questions connected with our foreign relations. When Parliament met there were numerous questions on foreign affairs on which no obstruction had been offered to the Government. There had been matters of controversy between the Governments of France and England on the subjects of the Suez Canal and the war between Spain and Morocco, but no information had been given to the House on the subject -- none had been given with regard to differences which had existed on the subject of the joint expedition to China. Turning to Savoy he said that at the end of last session assurances were given that the Emperor had no intention of territorial aggrandisement. At the beginning of this session the House was told that the Government had no official information of any step towards annexation on the part of France. That answer had been from time to time repeated, in spite of the assertions by Mr. KINGLAKE and Sir ROBERT PEEL that they had received information that the annexation of Savoy was complete, and without any consultation of the Powers of Europe. At length the Government admitted that a dispatch had been received showing that Savoy had been annexed, and without any consultation with the Powers of Europe. The answer of the Foreign Secretary to that dispatch had been forwarded by Lord JOHN RUSSELL, but it was still withheld, thus showing that the spirit of the noble lord was not that which dictated the foreign policy of the Government. It was stated in the French journals that that answer was a protest couched in the most friendly terms. It was evidently kept back from a fear of hostile criticism. It was stated that the proceedings of France had been precipitated by the discussions in the House of Commons. No doubt that was the case, because a hostile motion in that house would cause embarrassment, and take the matter out of the hands of a docile Government. At the moment that the Government thought it was negotiating, acts were doing which ended in the accomplishment of the annexation of Savoy, offering a strong contrast to the prescience of Mr. KINGLAKE, which entitled him to the confidence of the House, and it behaved them for the future to watch the Government, who were no match for the duplicity of their Imperial ally. He protested against the interference with the rights of the House involved in the doctrine which had been laid down, that members were to frame their speeches in consonance with the wishes of the Emperor of the French. It was in vindication of his right as a member of that House that he declared the policy of the Emperor in Italy, in Savoy, and Switzerland, was one of deceit, perfidy and injustice, while he made mere tools of the ministers of England. If he was to be rebuked for the expressions from the Treasury bench, he would retort that he saw there many who had fallen under the censure of the House, and he would warn those who wished to fetter a speech in that House to take care that they did not again incur a severe censure.

abstract: For several months past, a feeling of strong opposition has been gaining ground among the colored people against the "African Civilization" movement, that Society being regarded as a revival, under another name, and with more specious and deceptive appearances, of their ancient enemy, the American Colonization Society.
lead_paragraph: For several months past, a feeling of strong opposition has been gaining ground among the colored people against the "African Civilization" movement, that Society being regarded as a revival, under another name, and with more specious and deceptive appearances, of their ancient enemy, the American Colonization Society. The recent large meeting at Cooper Institute, with influential ministers in attendance to promote its objects, appears to have finally aroused this sentiment into action, and a counter movement was commenced by Mr. GEORGE DOWNING, Rev. Dr. PENNINGTON and others, to awaken the fears of the colored people as to the dangerous trap into which they were being conducted, principally under the leadership of Rev. H.H. GARNETT. Everything being in readiness for making a telling protest against this new scheme, a meeting was called at Zion Church last evening, and the house was crowded at an early hour. Both parties were strongly represented, and, as the sequel proved, were so equally balanced in numbers, and withal so excited upon the subject of their differences, that neither deliberation nor agreement were possible. Mr. GARNETT was warmly cheered on entering the house with Rev. Mr. MARTIN from Boston. It was some time before the semblance of an organization could be secured, an attempt being made by Mr. DOWNING to carry with the election of officers a general programme for the government of the speakers. This was resisted by Mr. GARNETT, and produced a long and wordy dispute, in which every person present appeared to have his say. Mr. WM.A. TYSON was finally elected to preside, and a number of letters were read from different parts of the country, among which was one from GERRIT SMITH, strongly condemning the African Civilization movement as a revival of their old proscriptive enemy the Colonization Society. A series of resolutions was next read, denouncing and condemning the Society in the strongest terms. Every stage of the proceedings was interrupted by cries, hisses, stamping and other noisy and violent demonstrations, growing out of the efforts, first of DOWNING and then of GARNETT, to obtain a hearing. In the midst of this scene of confusion, which at one time nearly brought the opposing parties into violent conflict, the reporters retreated to the pulpit, and surveyed the scene from that safe and advantageous point. Finding that nothing could be done, Rev. Mr. GRAY, the Pastor, declared the meeting adjourned, and the lights were turned off. The meeting, from beginning to end, was the best possible demonstration of the need of "African Civilization" in New-York.

abstract: The Seventeenth volume of the History of the Consulate and the Empire, by M. THIERS, just published, contains a note which M. JEROME NAPOLEAN BONAPARTE, " a French citizen residing at Baltimore in the United States," requested the publisher to insert. The note states: That on the 24th of December, 1803, JEROME BONAPARTE, then a naval officer in the service of the French Republic, married Miss ELIZABETH ...
lead_paragraph: The Seventeenth volume of the History of the Consulate and the Empire, by M. THIERS, just published, contains a note which M. JEROME NAPOLEAN BONAPARTE, " a French citizen residing at Baltimore in the United States," requested the publisher to insert. The note states: That on the 24th of December, 1803, JEROME BONAPARTE, then a naval officer in the service of the French Republic, married Miss ELIZABETH PATERSON, daughter of a citizen of the United States; that the marriage was celebrated by the Bishop of Baltimore according to the rites of the Catholic Church; and that the marriage was regularly registered. That JEROME BONAPARTE, then 19 years of age, had attained the age required by the French law to contract a valid marriage. That his father being dead, his mother, Mme. LETITIA BONAPARTE, did not within a year, as required by the French law, demand that the marriage should be declared null and void. That, on the contrary, Mme. LETITIA called M. JEROME NAPOLEON BONAPARTE, the issue of that marriage, "her dear son," and signed herself in a letter to him, "his very affectionate mother." That 1805, the Emperor NAPOLEON demanded of the Pope a bull annuling that marriage, and that the Pope replied that there was no reason to annul the marriage, and that were he to do so should be guilty of a most abominable abuse of his sacred ministry before the tribunal of God, and before the entire Church. An answer to this note, transmitted by Prince NAPOLEON, is annexed by the publisher.

abstract: We would call attention to certain features in the bill designed to abolish Capital Punishment, and have to ask the attention of the Legislature to our objections. Such a bill, while pretending to keep a possibility of capital punishment in reserve for certain cases ...
lead_paragraph: We would call attention to certain features in the bill designed to abolish Capital Punishment, and have to ask the attention of the Legislature to our objections. Such a bill, while pretending to keep a possibility of capital punishment in reserve for certain cases would really have the effect of making the death-penalty a gratuitous act on the part of the Governor, and not a punishment prescribed by law. Who supposes that, any incumbent of that office would order the death of a human being as a matter of his own volition, no matter how aggravated might be the facts and surroundings of the crime?

abstract: The New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church is holding its twelfth Annual Session here, in the pretty little church that casts its shadow on the village green. It will be a protracted meeting; the hour of adjourament, I am told, will not come until a week or more has gone. There are more clergymen present than usual, and it is the Slavery question chiefly that has drawn so many together.

abstract: The annexation of Savoy and Nice to France having been accomplished by the act of the two nations immediately interested, and accepted by a majority of the great Powers, the Republic of Switzerland has put forth a protest in behalf of certain treaty rights reserved for ...
lead_paragraph: The annexation of Savoy and Nice to France having been accomplished by the act of the two nations immediately interested, and accepted by a majority of the great Powers, the Republic of Switzerland has put forth a protest in behalf of certain treaty rights reserved for her particular protection, in regard to the territory of Savoy. This protest, of course, was at once caught up eagerly by the Opposition members of the English Parliament as a fresh and promising weapon of assault upon the Palmerston Ministry over the shoulders of the Emperor of the French; and we publish to-day the sum of an animated debate which took place in the House of Commons on the 26th of March upon the course of the Government in relation as well to the general recent policy of France, as to this particular act, by which the liberties of Helvetia were charged to have been put in imminent peril. The attack was led, not by any regular captain of the Tory line, but by one of the most calculating of condottieri, Mr. HORSMAN, a Liberal by profession, but by position a mal-content, and who seems to be aiming at securing for himself the same sort of anomalous authority with the Conservatives which Mr. GLADSTONE's eccentric independence has acquired for that illustrious Tory with the Liberals. A glance at Mr. HORSMAN's speech will satisfy any reader unhappily versed in the ways of the political world of its thoroughly partisan tone and purport. It was less Mr. HORSMAN's hope to prove that the French Emperor had been "deceitful, perfidious, and unjust," than to brand the Palmerston Ministry as "Imperial tools." And Lord JOHN RUSSELL did himself great credit in his reply, by the statesmanlike rapidity with which he passed over this low and unworthy aspect of the attack upon himself and his colleagues, to deal with the grave subject which that attack had brought forward upon broad and Governmental grounds.

abstract: A PREDICAMENT. A respectable broker in New-York, on Wednesday morning, purchased a horse in Gowanus, and gave a check on the Park Bank for the amount agreed upon for the animal. The check was immediately presented at the Bank; where the teller said "no funds," and refused to honor it. The holder immediately made complaint ...
lead_paragraph: A PREDICAMENT. A respectable broker in New-York, on Wednesday morning, purchased a horse in Gowanus, and gave a check on the Park Bank for the amount agreed upon for the animal. The check was immediately presented at the Bank; where the teller said "no funds," and refused to honor it. The holder immediately made complaint and a warrant was issued, and in the afternoon the drawer was introduced to Justice CORNWELL, when he produced a bank book showing that $400 had been deposited at the Park Bank where he kept his accounts but a few minutes after the messenger with his check had taken his departure. He knew that there was no money in the Bank when the check was given, but he expected to make a deposit before it was likely to reach the Bank. Notwithstanding all these facts, as the attendance of the complainant could not be obtained, the Justice had no alternative but to send the accused to jail for the night. He offered to pay the amount of the check in money, but this could not be received. The broker was finally relieved in part from his embarrassment, by Officer APPLEGATE, who agreed to take the accused in charge until yesterday morning, when the complainant was present, and the accused was speedily discharged from custody.

abstract: Theories of social and moral reform are plentiful as blackberries: practical reforms are more rare. Some of the most promising enterprises of our day have been blighted by the extravagances of their advocates, and the cool cunning of their foes. Few of them avoid the extremes of fanatiscism on the one side, or of a frigid conservatism on the other. The eager rush for the desirable often hazards what is attainable; and zealous devotion to "principle" sometimes overlooks the actual and the possible.

abstract: This splendid vessel, not long since the especial pride not only of her owners, but of the American people the embodiment of lines and power whereby the rival ships of Europe were to be signally beaten as to speed and economy the vessel whose merits
lead_paragraph: and demerits formed a general subject of discussion, rivaled in interest only by the Great Eastern -- the vessel which has held in reserve till the present moment her best qualities, while the doctors have tampered with her baby disorders -- whose elegant lines and proportions, whose very look of power and fleetness, as she lay at her dock, biding her time, was the good hope of the sanguine and the silent, the rebuke of the critic -- no less celebrated a vessel than the Adriatic. the fires already kindled in her furnaces, and her decks cleared for the peaceful encounter, this day leaves the unfortunate past behind her, and sets out on the broad Atlantic to vindicate her powers. Such at least is the popular feeling, on an occasion not a little momentous in its reference to the commercial interests and marine aspirations of Young America. And to take a very practical and unimpassioned view of the case, although iron (not cinder and iron) hulls, high steam and surface condensation, have recently wrought such splendid results, still they have not all been adopted by the particular rivals of the Adriatic, and there are various hopeful features in the construction of this vessel, which may yet make her to win back the laurels which have been earned by the Cunarders.

abstract: We publish to-day,in full, the record from the Congressional Globe of the proceedings which took place in the House of Representatives on the occasion of Mr. LOVEJOY'S oration upon Slavery and its fruits, apropos of Utah and the practice of polygamy.
lead_paragraph: Long as this record is, and repulsive to every man who respects the American name, and would gladly still repose some hope for his country's future in the character and conduct of his country's representatives, it is yet more than worth while -- it is almost a duty, for every good citizen to read it. We know, all of us, in a general way, that the halls of the National Congress witness a great deal of disorder; that brutality and violence and indecency are no strangers upon their floors; that the popular commission no longer carries with it decisive evidence of dignity and decorum, of moral refinement and mental vigor, in favor of the man who bears it. But few of us, comparatively, ever visit Washington; of those few, fewer still are ever, unluckily, lucky enough to stumble upon a Congressional orgie of the typical sort; and even in reading our morning papers, we constantly glide over the most characteristic because the most unconsciously-uttered traits of the Congressional nature, as it has developed itself so rapidly in these later days.

abstract: The Tribune in its new Prospectus declares its purpose to "show its faith in Republican principles by a free and fearless criticism of the errors and blunders of its own party." This is one step towards independence in journalism. If the Tribune will now go one step further, and applaud whatever, in the action of the opposite party, may deserve applause, and perform both these functions with fairness, candor, and with sole reference to the public interest, it will stand fairly upon the platform of independent Journalism.

abstract: It appears to us that the law has already fixed the status of the whole question, both as regards the States and the Territories, and that it is no longer an open one for selfish demagogues, like DOUGLAS, to agitate for their own personal ends. We have the Compromise of 1850, and the Dred Scott decision of the Supreme Court, to sustain the settlement, besides an actual repeal of the Missouri restriction by the act of 1854, in relation to Kansas and Nebraska. Here the South, at least, should plant herself, and we can see no necessity, in the contingency above named, for any further allusion to the subject than a plain, emphatic declaration, that all agitation of Slavery must cease -- we abide by the LAW as it stands. No man should be supported by the sound men of any section of the Union, who ignores, or repudiates this settlement, or who would construe it in such a manner as to reopen the question anew, and perpetuate the strife.

abstract: The Quadrennial Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church will commence its sessions in Buffalo on the 1st of May. The delegates will number
lead_paragraph: about three hundred, representing all the Free and three or four of the border Slave States. The six Bishops of the Church, Messrs. MORRIS of Cincinnati, JANES of New-York, SIMPSON of Illinois. AMES of Indiana, BAKER of New-Hampshire, and SCOTT of Delaware, will be present. Besides the delegates, five hundred or more ministers, some thousands of lay members, missionaries returned from labors, and others soon to leave, will be attracted to Buffalo by the importance of the Conference. During the sessions of the Conference a daily paper will be issued by the Methodist Book Concern, containing all the proceedings. This assembly has control and direction of all the internal affairs of the Methodist Church, and is a Court of Appeals to which cases that may have arisen during the past four years in the different State or local Conferences may be carried. It is expected the questions of Slavery, the extension of ministerial appointments, and the modification of the office of presiding Elder will consume a large share of the time devoted to Church government.

abstract: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Sunday, March 18, 1859. It is a melancholy sight to see the ruins of the  late confiagration in Bridgetown.
lead_paragraph: Nearly all the principal commercial stores in the city were destroyed, and many poor people have since been homeless, and even houseless. Large subscriptions have been raised here for their succor, and other West India Islands, especially the French Colonies of Martinique and Guadeloupe, are coming forward magnanimously to their aid. The loss occasioned by this fire exceeds two millions of dollars. Among the properties destroyed were two newspaper establishments -- the Barbadian and the Globe; but both, after a temporary suspension, have reappeared. The fire burnt for three weeks, and same of the coal depots are not yet entirely consumed. There are now in Bridgetown two large spaces, known as "Burnt Districts." The one on the leeward side of the town, of some fifteen years' standing, was purchased by Government for public buildings; but it seems that these edifices will now be erected on the newly-burnt district. It is an ill wind that brings no one any good, and the fires of Bridgetown will be the means of making it a more imposing city than it ever was before -- worthy its position as the capital of the most nourishing West India Dependency or the British Crown. This seems to be the desire of the Legislature, for already a bill has been introduced, and is under discussion in both Houses, for the improvement of Bridgetown, and its greater security against fire.

abstract: The unfortunate officers of the Brazilian corvette, Donna Isabel, are about to have " the hospitalities of the City " inflicted upon them. These gentlemen remained, we believe, for several days in the harbor without attracting the notice of the Common Council or any of our authorities. In an evil hour, however, they paid the Mayor the compliment of a visit at the City Hall, and thus revealed their presence to their tormentors.
lead_paragraph: From that moment they were doomed, and they will have this week to pass through the disgusting ordeal to which so many unhappy strangers have already been subjected. Aldermen DARRAGH, STARR, BAGLEY, HENRY and RUSSELL have been appointed a Committee of Torture, and these ill-fated Brazilians have probably by this time been delivered into their hands and apprised of the fate that awaits them. We sincerely wish, for their sakes, that they had cast anchor in some other port; and our only consolation, under the circumstances, is, that they are probably the last, or almost the last, foreign officials who will be subjected to our municipal civilities. The fame of our "hospitalities" is fast spreading over the globe, as a large number of distinguished strangers have already passed through the hands of our Common Council, and been subjected to our "institutions," and though the experience is not such as modest men care to recount, we may fairly presume the greater portion of the details have leaked out. New-York will consequently soon be as much shunned by foreigners, whose standing is likely to bring the Common Council down upon them, as Cairo in the plaguc. Nobody who has ever been introduced to the friends of the Aldermen in the City Hall, or has visited our leading nuisances under their guidance, is likely to forget his sensations.

abstract: The Conference was resumed yesterday morning at 8 o'clock. At the conclusion of the ordinary devotions, reports were received as to the character and standing of various candidates for admission to the ministry.

SEYMOUR VAN DUSEN was assigned to the office of prosecutor. The order of the day, which was the discussion of the Erie resolutions, was then taken up, and a lengthy debate ensued. abstract: the Sanborn case, took occasion to arraign the Senate Committee for partiality -- pointing to the fact that Ex-Gov. WISE asserted that he possessed information of the highest importance, and declared that under no pressure would he reveal it. Yet Ex-Gov. WISE remained at his home undisturbed, while Northern men, who knew nothing of the business, were dragged from their homes, handcuffed, and at night, by the myrmidons of the Senate. Mr. MASON denied the right of the Senator to criticise the Committee, of whose proceedings he knew nothing. The private calendar and an executive session occupied the remainder of the day. In the House, Mr. CURTIS, from the Pacific Railroad Committee, reported a bill on the subject, which was ordered to be printed, and was referred back. Private bills engrossed the rest of the session.

abstract: -- It is said that Mr. BUCHANAN, when he leaves off being President, intends to become an author. This is punishing the people for their dislike with a vengeance. In his Presidential capacity, Mr. B. has a perfect right to flood us with messages, and it is our duty to bear them patiently. In his private capacity he will, of course, have a right to inflict a book upon the public. But why should he? It is bad enough to be a poor President, but to become a poor author will be worse. We trust the President will think better of this determination.
