abstract: If there be such a thing as a weakness in the manly British bosom, it is a foible for truth and honesty. The strictly British journalist is never weary of proclaiming the immaculate veracity and the adamantine integrity of the race to which he belongs.
lead_paragraph: If there be such a thing as a weakness in the manly British bosom, it is a foible for truth and honesty. The strictly British journalist is never weary of proclaiming the immaculate veracity and the adamantine integrity of the race to which he belongs. Especially when "girding" at the Frenchman does he delight to exhibit his modest pride in these pleasing qualities, which have been conferred as a special boon on the British people by the same Providence which has given eyes to the peacock's tail, and horns to the owl, and to the toucan a bill nine inches long, with the power of making a noise like a bell, which can be heard at the distance of three miles. And when the shadow of the great French Empire broadens sadly on his mind, the British scribe turns to these inalienable prerogatives as his only consolation, in the presence of a phenomenon which he can neither tolerate nor abolish. It is truly a satisfaction to him to think that if France is hourly gaining new power in the councils of Europe, and the French Emperor daily opening new pathways of prosperity to his people, England is still the only country which has never broken its faith, and Englishmen are still the only mortals upon whom Astraea can look down with longing recognition from her chill exile in the clouds.

abstract: FAIR PLAY ALL ROUND. -- The Tribune revives the statement that JEFFERSON DAVIS some years since challenged the late Gov. BISSELL for words spoken in debate, and that he backed out of the affair when the challenged party insisted upon muskets as the weapon to be employed. The Tribune says that in thus acting Mr. DAVIS proved conclusively that, in spite of his bluster, he was at heart a coward.

abstract: TWO CHILDREN BURNED TO DEATH. On Saturday evening last, two little children of JAMES M. CLARY, residing at No. 184 South First-street, were burned to death by their clothes taking fire. The parents went out in the evening, leaving the children one three, and the other five years old locked up in
lead_paragraph: TWO CHILDREN BURNED TO DEATH. On Saturday evening last, two little children of JAMES M. CLARY, residing at No. 184 South First-street, were burned to death by their clothes taking fire. The parents went out in the evening, leaving the children one three, and the other five years old locked up in a room by themselves. They found some matches in the room, and while playing with them they became ignited, and the clothes of the children were set on fire, by which they were burned so severely that they died soon after the accident.

abstract: About 5 A. M., on Saturday, as private watchman BALDWIN was engaged in his duties on the Cu nard dock at Jersey City, his attention was attracted to something in the water at the end of the Yorkstreet dock. Upon closer inspection, he discovered the feet of a human being, with the head and body under water.
lead_paragraph: About 5 A. M., on Saturday, as private watchman BALDWIN was engaged in his duties on the Cu nard dock at Jersey City, his attention was attracted to something in the water at the end of the Yorkstreet dock. Upon closer inspection, he discovered the feet of a human being, with the head and body under water. Thinking that this might be one of the victims of the sloop Spray, or the oyster-boat E.A. Johnson, Officer BALDWIN summoned his partner, and the two attached a rope to one of the legs, and attempted to draw the body to the surface of the water, when they found that it was held firmly by some weight attached to it. They then made the line fast to the dock, and notified Coroner MORRIS. The Coroner shortly proceeded to the spot, and upon taking out the body found it to be that of a woman in a perfectly nude state, with the exception of the yoke of a chemise, and about three inches of the top of a white cotton stocking.

abstract: The correspondence arising out of the difficulty between Messrs. PRYOR and POTTER in the House of Representatives will be found in our special dispatch from Washington. It develops no facts not previously stated by the friends of the respective parties, except the circumstance that the action of Mr. PRYOR's second, in peremptorily declining the...
lead_paragraph: The correspondence arising out of the difficulty between Messrs. PRYOR and POTTER in the House of Representatives will be found in our special dispatch from Washington. It develops no facts not previously stated by the friends of the respective parties, except the circumstance that the action of Mr. PRYOR's second, in peremptorily declining the terms offered by Mr. POTTER, no sooner came to the knowledge of Mr. PRYOR, than that gentleman addressed a note directly to his antagonist, accepting the conditions. That note, Mr. CHISMAN, the second in question, after conference with several friends of Mr. PRYOR at Washington, withheld, and, by his note declining further correspondence, avoided the duel.

abstract: To-day the champions of England and America meet in the dreadful shock of battle to decide the rank of their respective nations in the scale of civilization. Of course all other events of contemporaneous history subside into comparative insignificance before the absorbing grandeur of this momentous contest. The noble rivalry of
lead_paragraph: To-day the champions of England and America meet in the dreadful shock of battle to decide the rank of their respective nations in the scale of civilization. Of course all other events of contemporaneous history subside into comparative insignificance before the absorbing grandeur of this momentous contest. The noble rivalry of FRANKLIN with KANE in the arduous paths of Arctic adventure; the struggles of COLLINS with CUNARD for supremacy in the steam-navigation of the Atlantic; the steadfast toil and endeavor of our literature, our art, our science to win a place for America in the hierarchy of intellect by the side of her illustrious cousin beyond the sea: these are but the dim, uncertain strivings of our people after fame. To-day, in the sturdy person of HEENAN, the Genius of Columbia clutches boldly at the very crown of national greatness.

abstract: We have not the slightest doubt that the Executive Chamber at Albany, like another place still more celebrated, is " paved with good intentions." But these alone will never prove productive of valuable practical results.
lead_paragraph: We have not the slightest doubt that the Executive Chamber at Albany, like another place still more celebrated, is " paved with good intentions." But these alone will never prove productive of valuable practical results. Gov. MORGAN has evinced an "intention" of protecting the interests of this City from flagitious and rapacious legislation: -- but the beginning he has made, in vetoing the Washington Market bill, does not encourage the hope of any considerable success in that laudable endeavor. His veto is professedly in the interest of the City: -- yet, if sustained, it will either cost the City a million of dollars, more or less, or else it will deprive the City of lands which ought to be in its possession.

The Conference met, however, at the appointed hour, (8 in the morning,) and proceeded at once, after the opening devotions were over, to the...
lead_paragraph: The Slavery question, which had been the subject of discussion throughout the morning and after noon sessions of Friday, was not resumed of a Saturday until nearly the hour at which the adjournment took, place. The Conference met, however, at the appointed hour, (8 in the morning,) and proceeded at once, after the opening devotions were over, to the transaction of its normal Business. Reports from committees in favor of superannuated and infirm ministers, and an address by Dr. STRONG in behalf of the Troy University, were the leading features of the earlier portion of the session.

abstract: We publish in full the belligerent correspondence between Messrs. PRYOR and POTTER and their respective friends. It is about as grim
lead_paragraph: We publish in full the belligerent correspondence between Messrs. PRYOR and POTTER and their respective friends. It is about as grim and savage a chapter as has ever adorned our political literature. Dug up a thousand years after the burial of some overwhelmed Pompeii or Herculaneum, it would convey to posterity rather a shuddering conception of the modes of thought and habits of life "usual among gentlemen" of the era to which it referred. An enlightened mind would doubt whether such a correspondence could possibly have taken place in any century of the Christian era, -- and would have been very slow to believe that it could have occurred among any people which had ever read the Sermon on the Mount. In the nineteenth century and the model Republic, such a correspondence certainly ought to be as impossible as the roasting of a heretic for a defect of doctrine, or the slaughter of a dozen children on the steps of the Capitol as a sacrifice to the gods of the nation. Unhappily it is not.

abstract: Mayor WOOD is giving us an idea of what he meant by " a single eye to the public good " by starting again for Charleston, where he will probably be absent for some weeks.
lead_paragraph: Mayor WOOD is giving us an idea of what he meant by " a single eye to the public good " by starting again for Charleston, where he will probably be absent for some weeks. It is only a week since he came home from his stumping tour in Connecticut, and as soon as the Charleston nomination is made, there can be very little doubt that he will betake himself to the field immediately in behalf of the Democratic candidate, and keep it until the Presidential election in November next. Should "his man" be elected, he will then have to start at once for Washington to secure his share of the New-York offices, and will probably not be much seen in this City until after the inauguration in March. It will then be high time to go to work to secure his own reelection in the following Autumn, as the "Spartan band of Republicans" will probably by that time begin to give indications of an intention to make another "heroic effort" to defeat him.

abstract: DEPARTURES FOR EUROPE. The steamship Adriatic, of the North Atlantic Steamship Company Capt. JOSEPH J. COMSTOCK, left her dock at the foot of Canalist., at noon on Saturday, for Southampton and Havre, with 197 passengers, and $605,000 in specie. A large crowd assembled on the pier, and awaited the...
lead_paragraph: DEPARTURES FOR EUROPE. The steamship Adriatic, of the North Atlantic Steamship Company Capt. JOSEPH J. COMSTOCK, left her dock at the foot of Canalist., at noon on Saturday, for Southampton and Havre, with 197 passengers, and $605,000 in specie. A large crowd assembled on the pier, and awaited the final signal for sailing with the most impatient interest. The decks of the steamers Atlantic and Baltic, the bridge-way surrounding the pier, and even the top of the sheds were black with eager spectators, many evidently having come to take leave of friends, but the larger portion no doubt attracted by their interest in the noble steamer, and by sympathy with the new career upon which she has entered. She wore the French tri-color at the fore, the private -- old Collins line -- signal at the main, and the American ensign at the mizzen. As she moved away from the pier cheers were given by the crowd, and responded to from on board the steamer, accompanied with the waving of handkerchiefs. Three rousing cheers and a tiger were given for Capt. COMSTOCK. A salute was fired from the end of the pier. DODWORTH's Band, which had assembled to play a parting serenade to Mr. D.R. SANFORD, gave several lively airs, not forgetting the tribute of the "Marsellaise" to the French tricolor, "Old Lang Syne" for their friend, and "Hail Columbia" as a finale. The crowd lingered upon the pier until the steamer was nearly out of view. The steamer Bavaria, which sailed at the same hour for Hamburg, took out 185 passengers; and the Kangaroo, which left for Liverpool, 185 passengers. Among the passengers who sailed were: Rev. Dr. MURRAY, of Elizabeth, N.J.; Rev. Dr. SEYBURN, of Philadelphia; Rev. Dr. JAMES DEMAREST, of Lowell; Rev. Dr. SCOTT and Rev. Dr. SPIER, of Brooklyn. They intend to make a tour through Switzerland and Southern Europe. On Saturday morning there was quite a large meeting in the Grand-street Church, corner of Crosby, of which Dr. THOMPSON is pastor, to bid them farewell -- Rev. Dr. STEVENSON presided, and after prayer and singing by the congregation, brief addresses were delivered by the Rev. tourists.

abstract: The grandest enterprise of the Nineteenth Century the construction of a railroad communication between the Atlantic and Pacific coasts is at last in a fair way of accomplishment, and has assumed a tangible form before the country. For more than ten years Congress has had this subject under consideration, but for various reasons has never before taken hold of the matter seriously, nor evinced any strong desire for its success.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, D.C., April --, 1860.

abstract: The Conference opened with devotional exercises at the usual hour yesterday morning. The early part of the session was devoted to the examination of characters of the traveling and other preachers, the reports being taken from the presiding elders, who, in their turn, were spoken of by the preachers of their districts. In particular, the celebrated preachor
lead_paragraph: The Conference opened with devotional exercises at the usual hour yesterday morning. The early part of the session was devoted to the examination of characters of the traveling and other preachers, the reports being taken from the presiding elders, who, in their turn, were spoken of by the preachers of their districts. In particular, the celebrated preachor to "Thieves and Harlots," WM.P. CORBITT, was spoken of by his presiding older, Rev. Dr. OSBON, as a man in "whom was found no guile, and whose preaching was sure to draw a full house." A motion was also made by the same reverend doctor, that the General Conference be requested not to interfere with the Five Points Missions, as the preachers there required time for training, and as soon as they really became acquainted with the localities they had been removed, that being just the time when they were most required. The motion passed unanimously.

abstract: In the Board of Aldermen, last evening, Alderman STARR offered a preamble and resolution in relation to the Hoboken Ferry-boats, to the effect that they are old and dilapidated, and totally unfit for the purpose for which they are used; that the Ferry
lead_paragraph: In the Board of Aldermen, last evening, Alderman STARR offered a preamble and resolution in relation to the Hoboken Ferry-boats, to the effect that they are old and dilapidated, and totally unfit for the purpose for which they are used; that the Ferry Company has wholly disregarded the covenants contained in their grants; and, as the lease of the Ferry from the foot of Christopher-street will expire on the 30th inst., that it be required to substitute more commodious boats on the said Ferry, in lieu of the boats known as the Phoenix and Newark; and in the advertisement of the sale of the Ferry lease the Comptroller be directed to incorporate such provisions as will secure greater comfort and safety. The resolution was referred.

abstract: LEIBIG, the eminent chemist, lately startled the imperturbable gravity of John Bull, by demonstrating the fact that the very marrow of the British Islands was rapidly escaping into the sea through the sewers of London, and prophesying that, unless has bestirred himself and stopped this waste, his fair territory would ere long be as barren and unproductive as a desert. A moment's...
lead_paragraph: LEIBIG, the eminent chemist, lately startled the imperturbable gravity of John Bull, by demonstrating the fact that the very marrow of the British Islands was rapidly escaping into the sea through the sewers of London, and prophesying that, unless has bestirred himself and stopped this waste, his fair territory would ere long be as barren and unproductive as a desert. A moment's reflection upon the increase of two articles of importation, would have satisfied a political economist that the British soil was becoming impoverished, though the cause might not have been so apparent. We refer to the importation of bread stuffs as food for the people to supply the deficiency of their home agricultural productions, and of guano as a fertilizer of the soil.

abstract: Since the adjournment of our State Legislature our city election has been the leading excitement of the day. It has come and gone, and all parties seem perfectly satisfied, excepting only the officers elected. It is no news to your readers that no city of the West struggles under a heavier load of municipal disgrace, corruption, and folly than Milwaukee.
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the New-York Times.

abstract: The project for supplying the New-York papers to towns and cities along the railroad lines on the day of their publication will be of advantage to Albany and Troy, and perhaps to the central cities of the State. It is of no great benefit to this city, for the reason that the papers do not reach here until 8 P.M., and at that time those of our citizens who reside in the upper wards of the city are at home and do not come down until morning, and cannot therefore obtain the New-York papers. The only way by which the new enterprise can be made of advantage to the city, is to place the papers in the hands of pamphlet and periodical venders, and make it profitable for them to distribute the papers on their arrival forthwith to subscribers. News from New-York at 7 1/2 or 8 P.M. will not command a large sale, for the reason above assigned, and from the fact that they did not when we used to get them at 8 P.M; and for the further reason, that the New-York journals are valuable mainly for their commercial record and quotations, and for the foreign news, the former of which we get by telegraph, and the latter is just as interesting at 9 A.M. of the next day as it is on the very day of publication. We should imagine that the enterprise would prove prejudicial to the Albany journals, for that city becomes literally what the New-York journals have already designated it, a provincial city tributary to the City of New-York, and the same may be said of all the towns and cities on the Hudson River.

abstract: Since the revulsions of 1857, it is probable that new railways will not be built much faster  than they are wanted, and that those already operating will not indulge in many of the outrageous counting-room mistakes and extravagances which characterized the most of them a few years ago. Singularly enough, there is
lead_paragraph: Since the revulsions of 1857, it is probable that new railways will not be built much faster than they are wanted, and that those already operating will not indulge in many of the outrageous counting-room mistakes and extravagances which characterized the most of them a few years ago. Singularly enough, there is now a general and quite prominent notion that the hauling of trains over an iron road, by steam, is in some way connected with mechanical and engineering science, of which the especial violation is at least unnecessary to economical railway working. These facts having the present advantage of universal admission and attention, have therein paved the way for those long hoped for and vital changes -- those improved adaptations, functions and processes, which are every day becoming more standard and reliable. There is good reason to believe that one quarter, and in many cases one half, the working expenses of railways may be saved, by means of a judicious expenditure of money now, and that this money will also have been paid back by the improvements, in addition to the regular saving, within a period of say five or six years.

abstract: The steamship Empire City arrived at this port on Saturday from Havana, bringing as prisoner George Ellis, late a seaman on board the bark Henry Warren, who has been sent here by the United States Consul to answer a charge of having mortally wounded the second mate of that vessel with a knife in an affray which occurred during the voyage. Francis Morris, first mate, and J.P. England, seaman, of the Warren, were also sent on as witnesses. Ellis was placed in custody of the United States Marshal.

abstract: The new enterprise just inaugurated from NewYork to Albany per Hudson River Railroad, in the early delivering of the different morning papers of New-York, has been succesful. Starting at three o'clock and twenty minutes A.M., the train reaches Albany at nineteen minutes past seven, and thence by the New-York Central Railroad, passing Utica at fifteen minutes after eleven, it arrives at Buffalo at...
lead_paragraph: The new enterprise just inaugurated from NewYork to Albany per Hudson River Railroad, in the early delivering of the different morning papers of New-York, has been succesful. Starting at three o'clock and twenty minutes A.M., the train reaches Albany at nineteen minutes past seven, and thence by the New-York Central Railroad, passing Utica at fifteen minutes after eleven, it arrives at Buffalo at six o'clock in the evening, having made the Hegira in fourteen and two-thirds hours. These morning flights will soon be as common as the telegraphic aids which bring distance to our doors, and annihilate the boundaries of States and nations. From the Metropolis in all directions, upon all the iron tracks, shall go out these morning messengers, with their car loads of news fresh from the mint, for the thousand hungry eyes that await its arrival. A public want cannot long remain unsatisfied; and now that this one, so long felt, is finally supplied, and the grain-growing region of the West comes a step nearer the Metropolis, the use will bring the necessity, and it will not willingly retrograde to its former distant position. The country press will now be compelled to spur up those slow-coach arrangements by which they have hitherto been propelled, or they will be left irretrievably behind by the progressive strides of the age. The New-York papers in Central New-York, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, and other States by twelve o'clock each day, enjoying a suburban circulation (for the country is but the suburbs of this commercial centre of the world) the proportions of which will allow a copy of either to he sold at three cents, will soon place the country press, to a certain extent, as rivals of the distance-devouring leviathans of New-York.

abstract: A TREMENDOUS CRISIS. If we are to credit the editors of the New-York papers, this country is about to be revolutionized. We are about to abolish the Federal Government at Washington, and establish a newspaper government at New-York. We are to have no more Presidents, or Congresses, or Supreme Courts, or Governors, or Legislatures. These are to...
lead_paragraph: A TREMENDOUS CRISIS. If we are to credit the editors of the New-York papers, this country is about to be revolutionized. We are about to abolish the Federal Government at Washington, and establish a newspaper government at New-York. We are to have no more Presidents, or Congresses, or Supreme Courts, or Governors, or Legislatures. These are to be abolished, and in their place we are to have New-York newspapers! BUCHANAN is to be extinguished, and in his place we are to have the Herald; in the place of Congress we shall have the Tribune; and in the place of the Judiciary the TIMES. The Departments, we presume, will be apportioned among the other journals; the Evening Post getting the Post-office, the Commercial the Treasury, the Police Gazette the Army, the Clipper the Navy! This is the millennium of American politics to which we are to look forward, if the boasts of our New-York cotemporaries are to be believed!

abstract: On the 10th instant, at the lecture-room of the Madison-avenue Church, (Dr. ADAMS',) Rev. S.H. MARSH, of Oregon, made some statements in regard to the country on the North Pacific coast, illustrative especially of the need of a College in that region.
lead_paragraph: On the 10th instant, at the lecture-room of the Madison-avenue Church, (Dr. ADAMS',) Rev. S.H. MARSH, of Oregon, made some statements in regard to the country on the North Pacific coast, illustrative especially of the need of a College in that region. The section of Oregon and Washington west of the Cascade Mountains is the finest on the Pacific, and is capable of supporting a dense population, and possessed of the most important conditions of public prosperity. East of this section, beyond the Cascade Mountains, extending to the north far into British America, and eastward to the valley of the Missouri, the basin of the Columbia spreads out -- a vast region, containing many sub-sections of diverse characters, as respects soil and climate, but the most of it likely, at no distant day, to be brought into the service of man.

abstract: We are gratified to find that the Tribune, when it speaks out its whole mind, really accepts the views of independent journalism maintained by the TIMES, as sound, practical and equal to the demands of the present day.
lead_paragraph: We are gratified to find that the Tribune, when it speaks out its whole mind, really accepts the views of independent journalism maintained by the TIMES, as sound, practical and equal to the demands of the present day. It is true that our contemporary apparently labors under the belief that its own creed, as now fully set forth by itself, differs in some mysterious way from the creed of the TIMES; but this, as we shall presently show, is a delusion, which we are sure the Tribune will thank us, in the interest of fraternal good-feeling and human progress, for dissipating. There may be some difference between the practice of the TIMES and the practice of the Tribune under a creed common to both. We think, indeed, that such a difference exists. But, as we cannot conscientiously charge ourselves with creating it, it is a matter for the consideration rather of our contemporary than of ourselves.

abstract: We have experienced that rare sensation, an agreeable disappointment. Gov. MORGAN has vetoed the City Railroad bills. He has thus done what he could to save our City from the most oppressive net-work of monopolies ever devised for its people. Whether his action
lead_paragraph: We have experienced that rare sensation, an agreeable disappointment. Gov. MORGAN has vetoed the City Railroad bills. He has thus done what he could to save our City from the most oppressive net-work of monopolies ever devised for its people. Whether his action will prove effectual remains to be seen; but so far as he is concerned, it deserves, and will receive, the unqualified commendation of the great mass of our citizens.

lead_paragraph: The remains of the woman which were taken from the water at Jersey City, and concerning whose death there is still so much mystery, have been kept at Mr. HOPE's, the undertaker, where a large number of persons have called for the purpose of identifying the body. Thus far, no one has appeared who can identify it with certainty, and there is some fear that the rapid progress of decomposition may oblige the Coroner to have it buried before any positive clue can be obtained to the name of the young woman, or to her tragic end.

abstract: Another of the Herald's foreign programmes has fallen through. A week ago our neighbor announced, as a piece of special and exclusive intelligence, that Swiss troops had occupied Faucigny and Chablais, in Savoy, and based upon this item...
lead_paragraph: Another of the Herald's foreign programmes has fallen through. A week ago our neighbor announced, as a piece of special and exclusive intelligence, that Swiss troops had occupied Faucigny and Chablais, in Savoy, and based upon this item a leader demonstrating the certainty that French troops would immediately drive them out, that the war would be at once renewed and that Europe was on the eve of a general conflagration. It turns out, not only that the Swiss have done no such thing, but that they have no thought or intention of it. It is a great thing for a public journal to be ahead of the facts, although it does lead sometimes to very awkward stultifications.

abstract: COMMON COUNCIL. A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening. A communication was received from the Mayor vetoing the action of the Board in secret session, appropriating $26,000 "to defray all expenditures which may be made or incurred by the Special Committee on Ferry and Water Rights in the matter of cheap ferriage,...
lead_paragraph: COMMON COUNCIL. A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening. A communication was received from the Mayor vetoing the action of the Board in secret session, appropriating $26,000 "to defray all expenditures which may be made or incurred by the Special Committee on Ferry and Water Rights in the matter of cheap ferriage, now before the Court and Legislature," because, in his opinion, such a sum cannot be appropriated for any legitimate purpose. Laid on the table and ordered printed. Estimates for building Engine houses Nos. 9 and 21 in the Western District, and Engine houses Nos. 4 and 1 in the Eastern District, were presented, opened and referred to committees for report. The right of way for constructing the South Fourth-street Horse Railroad, was awarded to JOHN WHITTLESEY & SON. A resolution was presented by Alderman DOUGLASS, censuring the Legislature for passing the amended Metropolitan Police bill, which was lost by a tie vote. A resolution was adopted thanking the Legislature for passing the Prospect Hill Park and Parade Ground bill, and the Board adjourned to Wednesday evening next, to consider the report on Water Rates.

abstract: George D. Bulen vs. William Burdell. This was an application for leave to plaintiff to serve an amended complaint. The action is brought for the  partition of the estate of Harvey Burdell. This action has been tried before William Mitchel, Esq., referee, who prepared his report some seventeen months since. Plaintiff now asks that he be allowed...
lead_paragraph: George D. Bulen vs. William Burdell. This was an application for leave to plaintiff to serve an amended complaint. The action is brought for the partition of the estate of Harvey Burdell. This action has been tried before William Mitchel, Esq., referee, who prepared his report some seventeen months since. Plaintiff now asks that he be allowed to amend his complaint by alleging therein that he expended some $4,000 counsel fees and witness fees, including about $1,200 for stenographic reports in the proceedings before the Surrogate for letters of administration upon the personality. Plaintiff alleges that his action before the Surrogate for the benefit of the realty, aided in the discovery of the bogus baby plot, (which terminated the controversy,) and that through his counsel he learned those "startling developments" in advance of the knowledge of the District Attorney.

abstract: It is known to our readers that there are three principal trails across the Continent, each of which is advocated by its friends as being the most feasible route to the Pacific. The most northern of these, explored and advocated by Gov. STEVENS, starts from St. Paul,
lead_paragraph: It is known to our readers that there are three principal trails across the Continent, each of which is advocated by its friends as being the most feasible route to the Pacific. The most northern of these, explored and advocated by Gov. STEVENS, starts from St. Paul, Minnesota, and follows mainly the 49th parallel to the Dalles in Oregon. The next is the great central route from St. Joseph, Mo., via Salt Lake to Placerville, in California; and the third or Southern route extends from San Antonio across Texas to El Paso, and so westward through Arizona to the Pacific. Across the two latter of these we now have a mail service; but formed by disjointed links, running at semi-monthly intervals and at a slow pace, its main benefit hitherto has been to demonstrate the practicability of Overland Mail transportation.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. VERDI'S opera of "Ernani" was produced here last night to an extremely good house. The cast was as follows : Mine. INEZ FABBRI as Elvira; Signor STIGELLI as Ernani; Signor ARDAVANI as Carlo; and Herr WEINLICH as Silva. The...
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. VERDI'S opera of "Ernani" was produced here last night to an extremely good house. The cast was as follows : Mine. INEZ FABBRI as Elvira; Signor STIGELLI as Ernani; Signor ARDAVANI as Carlo; and Herr WEINLICH as Silva. The latter character was conscientiously but inadequately rendered. It requires a basso of the first-class, and an actor of more than ordinary intelligence and dignity. Mr. WEINLICH is frequently excellent, but as the successor to MARINI, who was perfection in this particular part, he is unsatisfactory. He seemed more over to labor under the disadvantage of knowledge of this fact.

abstract: The United States vs. Edward Marlor. -- This was a motion to diminish bail. Marlor was a witness in a prosecution instituted on behalf of the Government against one John Lloyd for passing false invoices. He had been Lloyd's clerk, and was familiar with the matter, and had access to the papers held by the Government in reference to the affair. Some time ago he left for Europe, and the papers turning up missing also, he was, on his return from Europe some weeks since, arrested as a witness. On being brought before Judge BETTS, he was directed to give bail for his appearance on the trial in the sum of $5,000, with two sureties.

abstract: The project mentioned in a dubious dispatch, published in our issue of yesterday morning, of an adjournment of the Legislature until May, in order to defeat any intention of the Governor to pocket the Railroad bills, was brought to an untimely end yesterday. The Governor sent into the Assembly
lead_paragraph: The project mentioned in a dubious dispatch, published in our issue of yesterday morning, of an adjournment of the Legislature until May, in order to defeat any intention of the Governor to pocket the Railroad bills, was brought to an untimely end yesterday. The Governor sent into the Assembly his veto of the bills, taking the ground that the valuable franchises conferred by the bills should be made profitable to the City, and a suitable amount should be paid into the City Treasury, to aid the tax-payers in return for such franchise; if not, at least the fare should have been so restricted as to insure protection to the masses who use the roads. Another objection is the perpetuation of the franchises which give away the franchises forever, and without the power reserved to the Legislature to revoke or amend them. Other objections were urged, such as the utter want of responsibility attached to the corporations; the absence of restrictions as to the time of the completion, or to prevent them from breaking up roads into parcels and charging fare on each section. The Governor admits the necessity of railroad facilities for the city, but thinks the privileges granted are too sweeping in their character to warrant his signature to the bills. The veto was laid on the table, and at the evening session was taken up and read. Mr. JAQUES, of this City, made a speech in support of the veto; after which a vote was taken, and the bills passed 82 to 25. Their passage through the Senate is confidently anticipated. The bills confirming the Ninth-avenue grant, mitigating capital punishment, and the Anti-Rent bill, obtained the Governor's signature. The usual votes of thanks to its officers were unanimously accorded by the Senate. The Railroad Toll bill, non-concurred in by the Assembly, had been the subject of further conference, at which the two Committees failed to agree. The Senate voted to adhere to its amendments, thus killing the measure for the present session.

abstract: Ward and Gilbert vs. The Washington Fire Insurance Company. -- This was an action in the Superior Court, before Justice ROBERTSON, to recover of the defendants the amount of a policy of insurance for $1,600, made to one E.B. Monell in November, 1856. The property insured was a stock of merchandise, consisting of a quantity of liquors, cigars, teas, &c., contained in a building also owned by him, known as Poplar Hall, in Poplar-street, Brooklyn. There were two other insurances of $1,000 each on the stock in other Companies, of which notice is claimed to have been given to the defendants. A fire occurred in the building on the night of Jan. 6, 1857, which completely destroyed it, together with the entire stock on hand, excepting a few barrels of beef and a small amount of tea.
lead_paragraph: Ward and Gilbert vs. The Washington Fire Insurance Company. -- This was an action in the Superior Court, before Justice ROBERTSON, to recover of the defendants the amount of a policy of insurance for $1,600, made to one E.B. abstract: Emanuel A. Stone vs. Isaac F. Fisher and Aaron L. Hamburger, and two other cases. These were  actions brought by the plaintiffs therein, as judgment creditors of the defendant Fisher, to set aside an assignment made to the defendant Hamburger, on the...
lead_paragraph: Emanuel A. Stone vs. Isaac F. Fisher and Aaron L. Hamburger, and two other cases. These were actions brought by the plaintiffs therein, as judgment creditors of the defendant Fisher, to set aside an assignment made to the defendant Hamburger, on the 30th day of December, 1858. The plaintiffs allege that the assignment was made to defraud them, and to deprive them of their just dues. The defendants deny all allegations of fraud, and aver that the assignment was made in good faith, and for the benefit of creditors. The assignment was for a large amount, and the combined indebtedness of the defendant Fisher to the plaintiffs is also heavy.

abstract: However disastrous to our commercial success may have been that remorseless brake on the wheel of American enterprise the disregard of scientific discovery and engineering skill the active and untiring energy of our engineers and manufacturers has done much to restore the balance of power and progress, and is destined to...
lead_paragraph: However disastrous to our commercial success may have been that remorseless brake on the wheel of American enterprise the disregard of scientific discovery and engineering skill the active and untiring energy of our engineers and manufacturers has done much to restore the balance of power and progress, and is destined to place this country at the head of nations in the production of those twin agents of civilization and wealth -- cheap iron and cheap power. Although, it has been found impossible in this City, during the past Winter, to secure the first dollar towards the establishment of a radically improved line of steamships, under the very auspices of the established and authenticated results of high steam and surface condensation in England; although our railway direction persistently adheres to many of those systems and processes which a better practice, has proved to be simply abuses of nature -- there are still elements at work which are destined to drive us unto reform and improvement whether we will or no.

abstract: On Thursday morning JAMES DUGAN, a boy 10 years of age, determined not to remain at school, where he had been taken by his parents, and having run away, amused himself by riding on the freight cars of the Hudson River Railroad. In attempting to jump from a car, at the corner of Jay and Hudson streets, he slipped beneath the wheel, and sustained...
lead_paragraph: On Thursday morning JAMES DUGAN, a boy 10 years of age, determined not to remain at school, where he had been taken by his parents, and having run away, amused himself by riding on the freight cars of the Hudson River Railroad. In attempting to jump from a car, at the corner of Jay and Hudson streets, he slipped beneath the wheel, and sustained such frightful injuries that his death resulted at the New-York Hospital on Saturday. His parents reside in Twenty-fifth-street, near Ninth-avenue....MICHAEL CONWAY, 3 years and 8 months old, residing with his parents at No. 70 Houston street, was run over on Saturday morning at the corner of King and Varick streets by car No. 15 of the Sixth-avenue line, and sustained injuries which caused his death in a few hours. The driver of the car, a man named HEINE, was arrested and taken before Justice KELLY, by whom he was discharged, as the occurrence was believed to be accidental. In both cases Coroner SCHIRMER held the inquest..... The investigation of the circumstances attending the death of MARY SMITH, an Irish woman, 30 years of age, who was run over by a Harlem Railroad train on the 10th instant, and whose decease resulted at Bellevue Hospital, a few days since, in consequence of her injuries, was concluded on Saturday by Coroner O'KEEFE. Deceased it appeared was walking on the down track, near the Melrose station, when to avoid an approaching train from Norwalk, she stepped upon the other track, and was knocked down by a train going out before its engineer could prevent the accident.

abstract: SALE OF UNCLAIMED PARCELS BY ADAMS' EXPRESS COMPANY. Once a year Adams' Express Company disposes of unclaimed packages at auction.  The sales are always largely attended, and there are always a great deal of interest and amusement for...
lead_paragraph: SALE OF UNCLAIMED PARCELS BY ADAMS' EXPRESS COMPANY. Once a year Adams' Express Company disposes of unclaimed packages at auction. The sales are always largely attended, and there are always a great deal of interest and amusement for the spectators, arising from the fact that, when the packages are put up for sale, unopened, the bidder is totally in the dark as to what he is really bidding on. A yearly sale was commenced yesterday. The bidding was brisk, and the fun was continuous. Boxes, bags, and a great variety of parcels, were sold at prices ranging from 50 cents to $22, and the purchasers remained in hope and fear, in relation to the value of these bargains, until 4 P.M., when the sale closed for the day, and the packages were delivered. The delivery created great excitement. As soon as a buyer received his parcel, he was surrounded by some hundred persons, all in the best of humor, who cried loudly for the opening of the package. If the purchaser showed the least inclination to comply, he was hustled incontinently to the front of the room, and every assistance freely rendered. A number of packages were thus opened, and whenever one proved to be of less value than its purchaser had fondly hoped for, the owner came in for a storm of jokes and mock sympathy, which, however they may have effected the speculator, created unbounded mirth among the bystanders. A lucky purchaser was suffered to take away his prize without remark, out if any selfish man ran away with his package to enjoy the opening of it privately, he was sure to be followed by groans, and requests that he would publish the contents of his parcel in Vanity Fair. Later in the afternoon the merry spectators retired with a resolve to be at No. 59 Broadway again this morning, and witness another day's sale.

abstract: The Allgemeine Zeilung states that since the suicide of the Austrian Gen. EYNATTEN, who was detected in frauds upon the Government it has been ascertained that it was through his agency that the French were apprized of the intention of the Austrians to attack them, in advance...
lead_paragraph: The Allgemeine Zeilung states that since the suicide of the Austrian Gen. EYNATTEN, who was detected in frauds upon the Government it has been ascertained that it was through his agency that the French were apprized of the intention of the Austrians to attack them, in advance of Solferino, and that they were thus enabled to anticipate that movement, and by marching very early in the morning, to make the attack themselves. The grounds upon which this belief is based are not given.

abstract: After the express train from Boston had left New-Haven last evening, the messenger of Adams' Express Company left his apartment to converse with the mail agent. While he was absent from his post, it is supposed that parties who have probably long been on the watch, pushed the safe in which the valuables were deposited from the side door.
lead_paragraph: After the express train from Boston had left New-Haven last evening, the messenger of Adams' Express Company left his apartment to converse with the mail agent. While he was absent from his post, it is supposed that parties who have probably long been on the watch, pushed the safe in which the valuables were deposited from the side door. The packages in the sate contained ten $500 notes on the Atlantic Bank of Boston; $2,900 in bills of small denominations of the Langdon Bank, Dover, N.H.; $755 in Ogdensburgh Bank notes; $620 on the Park Bank of this City; $1,000 on the Mechanics.' Banking Association, and $200 on the Shoe and Leather Dealers' Bank in Boston. Other packages, it is estimated, increase the amount which the safe contained to $16,000. Messengers with hand cars and an extra locomotive were dispatched yesterday morning to ascertain, if possible, where the safe was thrown from the car. As the messenger did not discover his loss until reaching this City, he cannot surmise on what part of the route the robbery was perpetrated.

abstract: The upshot of the Pryor-Potter difficulty has not been much more imposing than the result of the grand duel between Duke NICK and JOHN of Lancaster, commemorated so solemnly by the austere Muse of SWIFT. But the matter can hardly be suffered to pass out of the public mind without subjecting the whole question of dueling, as well in the abstract as in its direct applications to American political life, to fresh and searching criticism. It would be idle to deny that the conduct of Mr. POTTER, in this instance, has commanded a certain degree of sympathy, not to say of admiration, at the North. The very men who are loudest in condemning the duel as a barbarous and inhuman thing, are secretly disposed to applaud one American member of Congress for accepting the ordeal of battle thrust upon him by another; and the general satisfaction of the Northern public in an issue which has spared the country the horror and shame of an internecine fight between two of its ordained legislators, is really heightened by the consideration that it was a Northern man who offered, and a Southern man who declined, those peculiar terms of conflict, to which alone this pacific issue must be attributed.

abstract: An intelligent deaf-mute, apparently about 30 years of age, giving the name of O.F. Phelps, was arrested yesterday morning by Detective Elder, on board the steamship Marion, at Quarantine, at the instance of the Chief of Police of Charleston, S.C. The prisoner is charged with having stolen $415 in gold coin and a gold watch from a gentleman in Charleston, just previous to the departure of the steamer, upon which he took passage with the hope of escaping arrest. Phelps is an itinerant card-writer by occupation, and protests his innocence of the charge. During the evening he was discharged by order of Acting General Superintendent Carpenter, who decided that the evidence did not warrant his further detention.

abstract: VERDICT AGAINST THE HUDSON-RIVER RAILROAD COMPANY. The case of ELECTA THOMPSON and her husband, JOHN THOMPSON, against the Hudson River Railroad Company, to recover damages for injuries sustained by Mrs. THOMPSON on that road on the 18th of January last, was brought to trial yesterday in the Circuit Court before Judge LOTT and a Jury.
lead_paragraph: VERDICT AGAINST THE HUDSON-RIVER RAILROAD COMPANY. The case of ELECTA THOMPSON and her husband, JOHN THOMPSON, against the Hudson River Railroad Company, to recover damages for injuries sustained by Mrs. THOMPSON on that road on the 18th of January last, was brought to trial yesterday in the Circuit Court before Judge LOTT and a Jury. The facts as briefly stated in the complaint are, that on the 18th day of January last Mrs. THOMPSON purchased a ticket of defendants at Poughkeepsie for New-York. The train was stopped between Sing Sing and Tarrytown, to make some repairs, and while at this point was run into by another train, going in the same direction. In this collision Mrs. THOMAS W. FIRLD, of Brooklyn, married that morning, was killed, and several others were seriously injured. Among the latter was the plaintiff in this suit, who had her collar bone broken and fractured in different places, the bones of one leg below the knee and the ankle were broken, and she was otherwise bruised and injured. The defence acknowledged carelessness on the part of the conductor of the train, and consequently the case was much simplified. After examining witnesses to show the circumstances attending the accident, Dr. ISAACS, Dr. MASON and several other medical gentlemen were examined as to the character and extent of the injuries sustained by plaintiff. They were of opinion that she would not be able to walk without a crutch for three years or more, and that her shoulder would not be in a condition so that she could use a crutch for several months. The case was summed up for the defendants by T.M. NORTH, and for the plaintiff, by MITOHELL SANFORD. After a brief charge from the Court, the jury retired, with directions to bring in a sealed verdict this morning The first ballot stood: Five for $8,000, fire for $7,000, one for $7,500 and one for $9,000: and it is understood that they finally agreed upon $7,000 for plaintiff.

lead_paragraph: George Green vs. David Fay et al. This was an action before Judge McCARTHY, in the Marine Court, to recover damages for an alleged injury to his horse. The plaintiff is a cartman, and on the 6th of last January stabled in the rear of No. 92 Monroestreet, where defendants have a soap factory. The plaintiff alleges that from this factory large quantities of hot ley, and other liquids, are allowed to flow into Cherry-street, flooding over the side-walk and gutter in front of his stable, and that while passing, his horse stepped into the stream and had his hind leg so badly burnt that he was unfit for use for several weeks, and permanently injured; also that while the animal was useless his labor was worth $3 per day.

abstract: THE ADAMS' EXPRESS SALE. This sale was continued and closed yesterday, having afforded for two days a fund of amusement to hundreds who, having nothing of present importance to engage their attention, were glad to while away their time in watching the "fools who came there for bargains."
lead_paragraph: THE ADAMS' EXPRESS SALE. This sale was continued and closed yesterday, having afforded for two days a fund of amusement to hundreds who, having nothing of present importance to engage their attention, were glad to while away their time in watching the "fools who came there for bargains." The crowd was doubtless much increased by the announcement that one patty, who had purchased a sailor's chest for $6, found in it nearly $200 in gold, and one consequence was, that any bag, box or chest which had the aroma of far about it was eagerly sought for, and bid in at fabulous prices. Another party who had purchased a box for $5, sold his purchase within fire minutes for $100, as it turned out that he had secured a box of shell combs. These facts gave a spirit of animation to yesterday's biddings, but we were not informed of any more such fortunate speculations. One party, we chance to know, invested $12 in various unseen packages, the sum total of which, when exposed to view, disclosed one pair of very dilapidated pants; one pair shoes, do.; one pair cotton drawers; one red flannel shirt, which had evidently done faithful service to some Marblehead fisherman; one dozen bottles syrup, of yellow dock, and one dozen bottles of bitters. The fortunate purchaser, considering that he had been well bitten, transferred his claims to a venerable darkey, who appeared to be an active member of the firm, and consoled himself with the reflection that he might have lost more, if he had bidden for more. The sale, which has been conducted by Messrs. BUTLEE, SHULTCZ & MATTHEWS, passed off in the happiest manner, the auctioneers managing by well-timed, and sometimes witty remarks, to keep the incongruous assembly in good humor through many hours.

abstract: The semi-annual session of the Presbytery of New-York (Old School) was continued yesterday in Dr. POTTS' Church, from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. The principal business was the reception of verbal reports from the pastors and ruling elders of the different Churches.
lead_paragraph: Among other interesting statements made, it appeared that the Nineteenth-street Church raised $60,000 last year, and although somewhat embarrassed by the recent loss of their pastor, are otherwise in a flourishing condition. They have 700 members and flourishing Sabbath and industrial schools. The colored Church in Seventh-avenue, of which Mr. WILSON is pastor, is flourishing. Twelve members were added last year on profession of faith. The Sabbath School has 65 children. The Third Presbyterian Church of Jersey City is doing well: has purchased the church edifice of the Reformed Dutch Church. The Staten Island Church is in a flourishing state, and the meetings are well attended. The members have contributed from $2,400 to $2,500 last year -- defraying all expenses of the Church. The Haverstraw Church is prospering, and the ill feeling which existed between them and the New School Church has in a great measure subsided. The Greenbush Church hopes to soon become self-sustaining. Mr. IMBRIS, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in Jersey City, held out flattering hopes for Presbyterianism in that locality. The Throg's Neck Church has been suffering from transitory population and "fancy prices" for the necessaries of life. The pastor's salary is $800, and he has to pay $500 for rent. Their spiritual condition, was, however, encouraging.

abstract: The new Senator from California, Mr. LATHAM, has made his first mark in the Senate by setting his State right with the Union. It has been confidently asserted in divers quarters, that the Southern or Pro-Slavery element in California, not having been strong enough to fasten the Patriarchal institution upon the young Commonwealth of the Pacific, would yet be found able to carry the gold mines of the Sacramento and the silver of Washoe into the Treasury of the new Southern Republic, which is to be founded when the Union falls. Senator GWIN himself has been frequently quoted as authority for this notion, which was really beginning to force its way into a respectable degree of credibility by sheer force of iteration. Senator LATHAM on Monday drew from his colleague an emphatic denial that he had ever used any language which would bear such a construction.

abstract: The excitement in regard to the mysterious murder of an unknown female found at the York-street Dock on Saturday last, continues unabated, and as the facts become more generally known, inquiries from persons who have missing friends, come from all directions. Owing to the rapid decomposition of
lead_paragraph: The excitement in regard to the mysterious murder of an unknown female found at the York-street Dock on Saturday last, continues unabated, and as the facts become more generally known, inquiries from persons who have missing friends, come from all directions. Owing to the rapid decomposition of the remains, the undertaker, Mr. HOPE, caused them to be interred at the New-York Bay Cemetery yesterday. Previously, Dr. QUIDOR, the City Physician, removed the head, which he has preserved in spirits, for identification. The Doctor, on examination, found a small scar close behind the left ear, apparently caused by a running sore. The left eye was also found to have been affected.

abstract: The Legislature devoted its last day to making laws, without the Governor's signature. The veto of the Susquehanna Railroad Subsidy reaching the Senate at its morning session. Mr. RAMSEY, of Schoharie, made a long and earnest speech in favor of the bill, when it was passed over the veto  16 to 8. It was subsequently lost in the Assembly.
lead_paragraph: The Legislature devoted its last day to making laws, without the Governor's signature. The veto of the Susquehanna Railroad Subsidy reaching the Senate at its morning session. Mr. RAMSEY, of Schoharie, made a long and earnest speech in favor of the bill, when it was passed over the veto 16 to 8. It was subsequently lost in the Assembly. The West Washington Market bill was also passed through both Houses over the veto. The City railroads were equally triumphant over the Executive, all passing by the constitutional vote. The bills authorizing the erection of a new City Hall in Madison-square, and the sale of the old City Hall to the Federal Government, were both passed. Doubts are expressed as to the fate of the former, of the two and of the Insolvent Law with the Governor. The New-York Tax Levy, containing the appropriation for the Commissioners of Records, was likewise passed. At the Evening Session, the bill abolishing the New-York Almshouse Department was passed, and was subsequently signed by the Governor. The adjournment was effected about midnight. Much good feeling prevailed among the members, and the leave-takings, congratulations and regrets occupied the earlier morning hours. The Governor, abandoning his opinion that no bills should be signed after the adjournment, will take time to reflect upon several measures still in his hands.

abstract: The Legislature has been guilty of a great oversight in not depriving the Governor of the pardoning power, in the cases defined by the act abolishing capital punishment as "murder in the first degree." As we have already said in discussing this subject, the great merit of capital punishment, if it have any merit at all, lies in the fact that once inflicted it cannot be undone. It is this incident which gives it most of its terrors in the eyes of evil doers, and consequently makes it most valuable in the repression of crime. If it were possible, however, to substitute a punishment which, while as certainly cutting off the culprit from all that makes life dear, would still leave him the possibility of proving his innocence in case he were unjustly condemned, and thus remove all hesitation on the part of jurors about handing a criminal over to his fate, on having a fair case made out against him -- justice would unquestionably be a great gainer, and society, we believe, would lose nothing by the change. In other words, if every man who meditates a murder were as certain, that if convicted of the crime, and sentenced to imprisonment and hard labor, for life, he would sever regain his liberty unless he could subsequently prove his innocence, as that if he were once hanged he would never come to life, we believe the community would, on the whole, gain by the abolition of the gallows. But, unfortunately, no such result as this can ever be brought about. As long as there is life, there will always be hope. There is always the chance of escape in some way or other. Walls are but stone, jailors are but men, and liberty is a great prize; and from these drawbacks to its efficiency imprisonment can never be freed, by any amount of legislation. No act of the Legislature can make anything on this side of the grave absolutely sure, or deprive any human being of the consolation which this uncertainty inspires.

abstract: Soon after 10 o'clock last night a fire was discovered in the lower part of the six-story brick building No. 244. Water-street, occupied by EPHRAIM TREADWELL a cracker and ship-bread bakery.
lead_paragraph: Soon after 10 o'clock last night a fire was discovered in the lower part of the six-story brick building No. 244. Water-street, occupied by EPHRAIM TREADWELL a cracker and ship-bread bakery. The firemen quickly responded to the alarm, but their exertions were ineffectual to subdue the fire, which the light wood-work in the interior of the building served to feed, and in a very brief space of time the whole edifice was wrapped in flames. The neighborhood is densely populated, chiefly by sailors and the inmates of low groggeries, all of whom were thrown into the wildest consternation by the occurrence, and at once commenced the removal of their effects. Soon the rear wall of the building fell upon the roof of the coppersmith-shop and bell-foundry adjoining, No. 265 Water-street, occupied by E. DUSENBERRY, crushing it in and involving a damage of several hundred dollars to the building. A number of firemen, in their eagerness to be of service, rushed into No. 269 Water-street, the oil-clothing manufactory of W.A. HILT, and threw about $500 worth of goods into the street, while the contents of another store, occupied as a tailoring establishment by the same individual, were somewhat damaged. Mr. HILT is insured for $10,000 upon stock, in the National and People's Insurance Company. The loss that Mr. TREADWELL has suffered is estimated at between $50,000 and $60,000. He is probably insured for nearly the full amount, although it was impossible to ascertain the full particulars, or the names of the companies. This same bakery was destroyed by the same fire that consumed the ships Great Republic and Joseph Waller, in 1836. Two steam fire-engines were at work on the burning building, and did good service, though the supply of water from the hydrants was inadequate for both of them, and one had to obtain water from the river. The building is still burning as we go to press, but the flames have been confined to the bakery.

abstract: The annual session of the Troy Conference commenced at the Methodist Church in Lansingburgh on Wednesday morning last. The place of meeting is three miles north of this city, in a pleasant country town, where the members find hospitable treatment. The Conference embraces Troy, Albany, Western Massachusetts, Northern and Eastern NewYork. It is about 200 miles long and 50 wide, and numbers about 250 members.

abstract: George Ellis, late a seaman on board the bark Henry Warren, of Bath, Me., was sent home by the U. S. Consul at Havana, by the steamer Empire City, charged with the murder of John A. Peterson, second mate of the bark, while lying in the harbor of Havana. The accused was brought before the Commissioner for examination yesterday. Frank Morris,...
lead_paragraph: George Ellis, late a seaman on board the bark Henry Warren, of Bath, Me., was sent home by the U. S. Consul at Havana, by the steamer Empire City, charged with the murder of John A. Peterson, second mate of the bark, while lying in the harbor of Havana. The accused was brought before the Commissioner for examination yesterday. Frank Morris, the first mate of the bark, who was sent home as a witness, testified that on the 6th of March the second mate and the prisoner had an altercation, in which hard words were passed; that the second mate picked up a serving mallet and raised it, as if to strike the prisoner, when the first mate said "Don't strike," and raised his arm, receiving the blow on his arm, and the mallet fell on deck. The two men then clinched, and after a moment's struggle the second mate pushed the prisoner from him, and cried out "I am stabbed;" he then ran aft a short distance, fell upon the deck and expired without a struggle; while witness was looking to see if the prisoner had a knife, he suddenly turned upon him and gave him a severe stab in the left side. He was only able to give the order to have the prisoner put in irons when he was carried below in a fainting condition. The wound was severe, and laid him up in the hospital over two weeks, during which he was not expected to live. One other witness was examined, who substantially corroborated the foregoing statement of the first mate, and also stated that there was a severe cut over the right eye of the prisoner, from which the blood was flowing profusely; how or by whom the blow was given he could, not state. The accused was fully committed on the charge of murder.

abstract: VERDICTS AGAINST RAILROAD COMPANIES.  The jury in the case of LYDIA RILEY against the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, tried in the City Court yesterday, rendered a verdict in favor of plaintiff for $2,250. The action was brought to recover damages for injuries received by plaintiff, while leaving one of defendants' cars called "extras," at Bedford on the 1st of March last.
lead_paragraph: VERDICTS AGAINST RAILROAD COMPANIES. The jury in the case of LYDIA RILEY against the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, tried in the City Court yesterday, rendered a verdict in favor of plaintiff for $2,250. The action was brought to recover damages for injuries received by plaintiff, while leaving one of defendants' cars called "extras," at Bedford on the 1st of March last. On the day in question Mrs. RILEY was about stepping from the car, the body of which revolved on a pivot, when the driver commenced turning so suddenly that she, being an elderly person, fell heavily to the pavement, receiving severe and permanent injuries....In the case of ELECTA THOMPSON against the Hudson River Railroad Company, tried in the Circuit Court Tuesday, the jury brought in a sealed verdict yesterday morning, awarding $8,000 damages.

abstract: The year 1860 threatens to follow the bad example set by its predecessor, and to enrich its own chaplet of memories at the expense of the literature of the world. The month of March has taken from England one of her most accomplished scholars, and from the culture of ancient history one of its most successful laborers. Col. WILLIAM MURE, of Cladwell, the "easy chief" of all British writers on the Literature and Language of Ancient Greece, who combined the critical accuracy of a DONALDSON with the enthusiasm of a MITFORD, has just passed away, leaving his great work, like ARNOLD, and NIEBUHR, and MACAULAY, a magnificent torso. Col. MURE was the head of an ancient and eminent family, one member of which now worthily represents Her Britannic Majesty's Government as Consul at New-Orleans; and he had played a respectable part in the contemporary politics of Great Britain, entering Parliament as member for Renfrewshire, in the Conservative interest, but following the fortunes of Sir ROBERT PEEL, when that great leader braved the mob of country gentlemen in behalf of Free-Trade and the rights of the English people.

abstract: The will in this case, now offered for probate, disposes of a property estimated to be worth nearly a million of dollars, mostly situate in this City, but partly in Maine, where decedent formerly resided. About twenty years ago the testator removed to this City, and commenced operations in the leather and hide business, in which, at the time of his death, he was largely engaged. He died in January last, having made a will devising the bulk of his property to his children and others, and not bequeathing to his widow an amount equal to the one-third part allowed to her by the laws of Maine. She therefore contests the will, basing her claim upon the allegation that her late husband was, at the time of his death, and always had been, a resident of the State of Maine, and there domiciled.

abstract: Private letters from Madrid announce that both, the Queen and the public are equally dissatisfied with the peace, and indignant against O'DONNELL; that the feeling is so strong that the Ministers determined to resign; that their determination was communicated to O'DONNELL, who has also tendered his resignation; and that Her Majesty has refused to accept it until they shall have rendered an account to the Cortes of the whole proceeding. It is added that the greatest anger is manifested at Madrid against the Ministers, at the result of this ill-advised war.

abstract: The Paris correspondent of the Times says: "Public opinion in the financial and commercial world is greatly agitated by alternate hope and fear, in consequence of the uncertainty which prevails with respect to the future position of the country. Every commercial man admits the importance of Lord JOHN RUSSELL'S last speech on the annexation of Savoy and Nice to France."

abstract: Joseph Woodruff, a young man who is well known in the Fifth Ward as a fireman, and whose brother is now a member of the State Legislature, called about 19 o'clock last evening at the house No. 101 Mercer-street, and suddenly, as is alleged, without any provocation, attempted to kill Josephine Wilson, a young woman with whom he had been conversing.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Woodruff, a young man who is well known in the Fifth Ward as a fireman, and whose brother is now a member of the State Legislature, called about 19 o'clock last evening at the house No. 101 Mercer-street, and suddenly, as is alleged, without any provocation, attempted to kill Josephine Wilson, a young woman with whom he had been conversing. He succeeded in severing nearly all the arteries in her left hand with a large pocket knife, and also cut her badly in the face. Officer Palmer, of the Eighth Precinct arrested him in Broadway, as he was endeavoring to escape, and he was detained at the Station-house for the night. Jealousy is said to have incited the act. The woman's wounds were sewed up by Dr. Kemp, who pronounces the one in the hand to be of a very serious character.

abstract: Dates from La Paz are to the 17th of March. President LENARES still kept up a large military force, on account of the threatened war of Peru against him. The country is quiet, and President LENARES, appears to be firmly seated, and to have the good will of the influential and peaceable portion of his people. Bolivia, which has now no national debt, and has always faithfully fulfilled her obligations with foreign creditors, is now in need of money, to enable her President to carry out some important reforms, and the Government was expecting a favorable response to her Commissioners, who have been sent to the United States to negotiate for $1,000,000, with the custom dues of the port of Cobiza as collateral security.

abstract: It is hardly fair to expect that the Senate should not contribute its share to the unusual "spiciness" by which this session of Congress has been marked; but we must say that we think its quota might have been furnished in same form a little more pleasing than the recent passage at arms between Messrs. MASON...
lead_paragraph: It is hardly fair to expect that the Senate should not contribute its share to the unusual "spiciness" by which this session of Congress has been marked; but we must say that we think its quota might have been furnished in same form a little more pleasing than the recent passage at arms between Messrs. MASON and SUMNER on the Sanborn affair. We do not think Mr. MASON a model of impartiality and moderation. In all matters in which the question of Slavery is in any way mixed up, he is apt to be a good deal sharper, more energetic, supercilious and one-sided than the occasion calls for or good sense dictates. His display of homespan was not all that could be desired as a political demonstration, either in point of effect or of taste.

abstract: Is Slavery, after all, the greatest evil that afflicts this Republic? Is there no other danger looming on the political horizon, which good men should watch and guard against? Here, in this State of New-York, is there not some peril quite as great as that which grows out of the Lemmon Slave Case, and the effort of Virginia to bring Slavery into our borders?
lead_paragraph: Is Slavery, after all, the greatest evil that afflicts this Republic? Is there no other danger looming on the political horizon, which good men should watch and guard against? Here, in this State of New-York, is there not some peril quite as great as that which grows out of the Lemmon Slave Case, and the effort of Virginia to bring Slavery into our borders? We respectfully ask our neighbors of the Tribune whether this State, -- the whole country, -- and the entire fabric of representative government are not in greater danger of being conquered, disgraced and ruined by venality and corruption than by negro slavery?

abstract: Hon. ROBERT J. WALKER has at last published Mr. BUCHANAN'S celebrated letter to him, urging the submission of the Lecompton Constitution to the People of Kansas. We give this interesting document in another column of this morning's TIMES.
lead_paragraph: Hon. ROBERT J. WALKER has at last published Mr. BUCHANAN'S celebrated letter to him, urging the submission of the Lecompton Constitution to the People of Kansas. We give this interesting document in another column of this morning's TIMES. It will abundantly repay perusal. It comes before the public just in time for the Charleston Convention. That illustrious body will have an opportunity to see how thoroughly and entirely President BUCHANAN was the champion of Popular Sovereignty in Kansas -- how carefully and accurately he himself marked out the programme which Gov. WALKER followed with so much ability, and how perfectly treacherous and base was the treatment which the Governor afterwards experienced at the hands of the President. They will find, too, the President was then quite as ardent a champion of Popular Sovereignty as Mr. DOUGLAS himself.

abstract: The Giornale di Roma publishes a letter of Gen. GOYON, declaring that several journals have given a very inaccurate account of the proceedings of the 19th of March. He says he cannot admit, as has been pretended, that the French officers brought about the release of the persons arrested by the Pontifical gendarmes. The General also protests against this supposition as incompatible with discipline, and concludes by saying, "We are all conscious of our duty, and the object of our mission is to assist the Pope to the best of our power."

abstract: Mr. CHARLES STEARNS, a man of wealth and position in Springfield, Mass., died recently in the Northampton Lunatic Asylum. He was a remarkable character, in various ways. By trade a mason, he became an active operator in real estate, and petted a mania for putting up houses. His invariable answer to applicants for tenements was, "I have none now, but I can build one immediately."
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. CHARLES STEARNS, a man of wealth and position in Springfield, Mass., died recently in the Northampton Lunatic Asylum. He was a remarkable character, in various ways. By trade a mason, he became an active operator in real estate, and petted a mania for putting up houses. His invariable answer to applicants for tenements was, "I have none now, but I can build one immediately." He served several terms in both branches of the Massachusetts Legislature. Mr. STEARNS' curious proclivity for building recalls the history of a similar character, who is still living in the village of Middletown, in this State. He builds a handsome cottage in the space of three months, moves his family into it, gets it warm, sells it, moves out and builds another, into which, again, he removes, and then sells it, and so on, ad infinitum. Quite a settlement has grown up in this way on the outskirts of the place, and it is popularly known as "Van Hornville."

abstract: From Chili there is but little of importance. The Government troops had severely chastised the Indians of Arauco in several encounters, until they had plead for peace. abstract: The United States vs. Albert Hicks -- The trial of the issue of jurisdiction on this case did not take place yesterday as expected. Judge HALL, after consultation with counsel for the prosecution and for the defence, said that the question of the jurisdiction of this Court over the case was so important a one, especially as the case was a capital one, that it seemed to him desirable, after examining the question and conferring with Judge BETTS, that it should be disposed of before two Judges, in order that there might be, if desired, a certificate of division of opinion between them, that the matter might thus be carried to the Supreme Court of the United States.

abstract: President CASTILLA has resumed the Presidential chair, filled by Dr. MAR during his absence in Ecuador, and issued a preclamation, bragging of his exploits in that country, in which nobody was killed and the same number wounded, and concludes by threatening to undertake an equally brilliant campaign against Bolivia. I wrote you in my last that his Ministers had refused their assent to a war on Bolivia.

abstract: The good people of Cork, in Ireland, are greatly exercised in their minds by a mysterious craft which has been lying in the offing of the man-of-war roads at Queenstown, for nearly four months. This vessel, which, except that she is apparently stationary, might well be believed to be the "Flying Dutchman," is a rakish clipper of 700 tons burden, hails from Philadelphia, is called the Charles B. Truitt, and has on board a cargo of 23,000 finely finished rifles. The Irish Correspondent of the London Times has called attention to her existence, and to the profound mystery which enshrouds her. She is perfectly seaworthy, has her full complement of hands, and yet behaves like "a painted ship upon a painted ocean." Is she waiting for the proclamation of the Irish Republic? or has she some secret connection with the Carlist revolution which has just broken out in the mountains of Spain? But for the "rifles" and the "fine finish," we might suspect this phantom-ship of some connection with GEORGE LAW and his peripatetic cargo of muskets. As it is, what do our brethren of the Quaker City mean by sending out such mysterious missionaries upon the high seas?
lead_paragraph: The good people of Cork, in Ireland, are greatly exercised in their minds by a mysterious craft which has been lying in the offing of the man-of-war roads at Queenstown, for nearly four months. She is perfectly seaworthy, has her full complement of hands, and yet behaves like "a painted ship upon a painted ocean." Is she waiting for the proclamation of the Irish Republic? or has she some secret connection with the Carlist revolution which has just broken out in the mountains of Spain? But for the "rifles" and the "fine finish," we might suspect this phantom-ship of some connection with GEORGE LAW and his peripatetic cargo of muskets.
