abstract: The Arago, with dates from Southampton to April 4, arrived here last evening. Her news is of less than usual interest. A Congress of the Great Powers upon the questions of Italy and Savoy is now said to be determined upon.
lead_paragraph: The Arago, with dates from Southampton to April 4, arrived here last evening. Her news is of less than usual interest. A Congress of the Great Powers upon the questions of Italy and Savoy is now said to be determined upon. The Swiss Government had addressed a fresh protest to the French Foreign-office, against the transfer of Faucigny and Chablais. In the meantime, French troops had occupied Nice and Savoy. At the opening of the Sardinian Chambers, King VICTOR EMANUEL had made the customary speech, reviewing the condition of the kingdom. The progress of Italian unity was made the especial topic of felicitation. It is understood that the King of Naples has abandoned the idea of throwing troops into the Papal States. Austria has at last protested in form against the annexation of Savoy by France, and of Central Italy by Piedmont. She regards both as substantial violations of the conditions of Villafranca. From Spain we learn that a movement in favor of Don CARLOS had been inaugurated by Gen. ORTEGA, at the head of 3,000 men. His troops had not been attacked by Government forces. General discontent prevailed in Spain among all classes, in regard to the Moorish treaty. It was understood that the O'Donnell Cabinet would be obliged to resign immediately. The English Parliament had adjourned to April 16. Warrants for the arrest of SAYERS and HEENAN had been issued by the authorities of Hertfordshire, who were resolute to prevent the great prize fight taking place within the limits of that county.

abstract: A dispatch dated at Hertford, March 31, says: "This afternoon a warrant was granted to apprehend THOMAS SAYERS and JOHN C. HEENAN, in order that they night be bound over to keep the peace. It is understood that the warrant would be at once executed, and the parties required to find sureties to a heavy amount, as the magistrates are determined to prevent, if possible, the fight from coming off in Hertfordshire."

abstract: MRS. HOEY'S BENEFIT. This accomplished and deservedly popular actress, announces her benefit at Wallack's Theatre for Saturday evening. Mrs. HOEY took her benefit morally at the Academy of Music yesterday, when she generously came forward at the eleventh hour, to rescue the Dramatic Fund Association, suddenly left in the vocative by the failure of another leading actress to fulfill her engagement.
lead_paragraph: MRS. HOEY'S BENEFIT. This accomplished and deservedly popular actress, announces her benefit at Wallack's Theatre for Saturday evening. Mrs. HOEY took her benefit morally at the Academy of Music yesterday, when she generously came forward at the eleventh hour, to rescue the Dramatic Fund Association, suddenly left in the vocative by the failure of another leading actress to fulfill her engagement. It is by precisely such indications of private worth and personal good feeling as this, that Mrs. HOEY has won for herself a more than artistic popularity with the classes that truly support the "legitimate drama" in New-York, and we are sure these classes will rejoice to hear that another opportunity will be given them on Saturday for proving the value they set upon their favorite.

abstract: The indictment upon which the defendant, Henry Karples, is now being tried in this Court, charges him with larceny and embezzlement of twenty barrels of flour on the 28th of June last from his employers, Hecker & Bro. It will be remembered that in January last the prisoner was tried upon an indictment in the General Sessions, charging him with the larceny and embezzlement of twenty barrels of flour from the same premises on the 27th of June, 1859. He was then defended by A. Oakey Hall and Edmon Blankman, and found not guilty. After the perpetration of the alleged offence Karples fled to Canada, from whence he was extradited under the provisions of the Ashburton Treaty.

abstract: This Court was occupied yesterday till a late hour. Charles W. Brown was tried on an indictment for forgery in the second degree, in attempting to pass counterfeit $5 bills on the Merrimack Bank, Massachusetts. The evidence was inconclusive, failing to show beyond a rational doubt that the defendant was aware of the spurious character of the bills. He was accordingly acquitted.
lead_paragraph: This Court was occupied yesterday till a late hour. Charles W. Brown was tried on an indictment for forgery in the second degree, in attempting to pass counterfeit $5 bills on the Merrimack Bank, Massachusetts. The evidence was inconclusive, failing to show beyond a rational doubt that the defendant was aware of the spurious character of the bills. He was accordingly acquitted.

abstract: Thorn vs. The Old Forge Coal Company. -- In this action judgment was obtained against the Old Forge Coal Company, and proceedings supplementary to execution were instituted to compel the Treasurer of the Delaware and Lackawana Railroad Company to pay the judgment -- it appearing that this Corporation was indebted to the Coal Company on a contract for the delivery of coal. The order was served on A.J. Odell, as Treasurer of the Company; and counsel, in opposing the motion, contended that the Corporation was not properly in Court -- first, because the order was addressed to the Treasurer, and not to the Corporation; secondly, because there was no way provided by law for getting a foreign Corporation into Court, except upon the commencement of an action; thirdly, that the Treasurer had no right to disburse moneys of the Company, without being authorized to do so by the Board of Directors, who were not subject to the jurisdiction of the Court. Counsel, however, expressed a willingness to pay the money into Court, inasmuch as it was claimed by two parties. The matter was heard before Justice BONNEY, at Chambers of the Supreme Court. Decision reserved.
lead_paragraph: Thorn vs. The Old Forge Coal Company. -- In this action judgment was obtained against the Old Forge Coal Company, and proceedings supplementary to execution were instituted to compel the Treasurer of the Delaware and Lackawana Railroad Company to pay the judgment -- it appearing that this Corporation was indebted to the Coal Company on a contract for the delivery of coal. The order was served on A.J. Odell, as Treasurer of the Company; and counsel, in opposing the motion, contended that the Corporation was not properly in Court -- first, because the order was addressed to the Treasurer, and not to the Corporation; secondly, because there was no way provided by law for getting a foreign Corporation into Court, except upon the commencement of an action; thirdly, that the Treasurer had no right to disburse moneys of the Company, without being authorized to do so by the Board of Directors, who were not subject to the jurisdiction of the Court. Counsel, however, expressed a willingness to pay the money into Court, inasmuch as it was claimed by two parties. The matter was heard before Justice BONNEY, at Chambers of the Supreme Court. Decision reserved.

abstract: A large number of the New-York (Wood) delegates to the Democratic National Convention at Charleston left yesterday in the steamer Nashville, of SPOFFORD  TILESTON'S line. There were also in company with them a number of gentlemen, and some ladies, who go to witness the proceedings, and to take a more or less active part in them.
lead_paragraph: A large number of the New-York (Wood) delegates to the Democratic National Convention at Charleston left yesterday in the steamer Nashville, of SPOFFORD TILESTON'S line. There were also in company with them a number of gentlemen, and some ladies, who go to witness the proceedings, and to take a more or less active part in them. There was a large gathering of the political friends of the delegates to see them off. All the staterooms were taken up before the day of sailing, and quite a number of the passengers were obliged to put up with a standee. For other creature comforts, however, they appeared to be well provided in the shape of "small stores," any quantity of baskets and mysterious packages being sent on board up to the moment of departure. No demonstrations were made by the crowd upon the pier, except the rather questionable compliment of a shower of small and stale oranges which flew thick and fast between the steamer and the spectators, while she was backing out of the slip, by which several coats were bespattered and rendered the worse for wear.

abstract: As the "last argument of Kings" seems in a fair way to become the first argument of Re- publicans, and the ancient fashion of voiding all differences between man and man by a peremptory appeal to the God of Battles is fast coming once more into vegue, it is worth while to fix the particular style of combat which Christian gentlemen may properly offer and accept. Of course, should HEENAN have
lead_paragraph: As the "last argument of Kings" seems in a fair way to become the first argument of Re- publicans, and the ancient fashion of voiding all differences between man and man by a peremptory appeal to the God of Battles is fast coming once more into vegue, it is worth while to fix the particular style of combat which Christian gentlemen may properly offer and accept. Of course, should HEENAN have been victorious over SAYERS, fisticuffs will be all the rage. But this still being uncertain, we hesitate between the hot shot and the cold steel. Mr. PRYOR and his seconds declare, against Falstaff's friend, for gunpowder, and think the bowie-knife "inhuman, brutal, and vulgar." But the bowie-knife is after all only the American sword; and we find in a recent number of Le Nord the following excellent and timely plea for the blade as opposed to the ball. The writer is commenting upon a duel at St. Petersburg, in which an artillery officer has been sorely wounded by a pistol-shot, and he proceeds: "I think the pistol adds greatly to the odiousness of the duel. Firearms lame and disfigure you when they do not kill you. The cold steel kills, too, but if it wounds it does not spoil you. Then with the sword you defend yourself while you attack; you put your courage into your blade, which becomes animated as it were, and a part of yourself. The steel, in a word, is simply your arm armed. Of course, chance plays its part in sword-duels; but that part is less important than is played by courage, coolness and skill."

abstract: Nothing of especial interest had occurred in Havana since the sailing of the last steamer. The city had settled down into the usual Summer quiet and routine, visitors and pleasure seekers having mostly left for cooler latitudes. On Sunday, the 15th, the Captain-General, with the Civil Secretary of the Government, made a visit of inspection to the new iron warehouse at Regla, attended by the President and Superintendent of the Regla Company. This warehouse, now nearly completed, is of great size, said to have room for the storage of 360,000 boxes sugar.

abstract: The Diario de la Marina, of Havana, condemns in the strongest terms the capture of MARIN's steamers. It claims that the presence of Gen. LLAVE on board the Indianola was proof of the complicity of the authorities of Vera Cruz. The only possible way in which it thinks trouble can be avoided will be by the United States Government apologizing for the course taken by Capt. TURNER, and paying a handsome indemnity to the injured parties. That this will be the ultimate issue of the affair the Diario thinks probable, from the fact that the crews of the vessels in question have been released.

abstract: Justice OSBORNE committed Martin Hines for snatching a purse containing $30 from Mrs. J.C. Wheeler, of. No. 45 Grove-street. Robert Whitehill, a clerk at No. 356 Canal-street, caught the rogue.... Lawrence Cesneras was committed by the same official, despite his earnest protestations of innocence, for having stolen $30 from Jacob La Viera, a fellow-boarder at No. 3 Catharine-street.... John H. Bache, whose office is in Thirty first-street, near Broadway, was arrested on a warrant issued by Judge RUSSELL, and required by Justice BRENNAN to find $1,000 bail, on a charge of dealing in lottery tickets.... In consequence of the illness of counsel, the trial of Mr. Thomas J. Mundy, Ex-Assemblyman, and Clerk in one of the District Courts; was postponed. he is charged with having acted in an unbecoming manner toward a little girl. An additional surely of $500 was reqired of Mr. Mundy. The Police Justices declared it to be their purpose to send the matter before the Grand Jury.... The man who committed an assault upon a young woman in Mercer-street is no relative of Hon. Christian B. Woodruff, Assemblyman from the Third District, whose brother he claimed to be.

abstract: The office of the Comptroller was yesterday enlivened by the presence of some hundreds of anxious expectants, to whom the City has been indebted for the last two months, commencing at Judges, and running down to clerks and messengers. The passage of the Tax Levy bill, and its signature by the Governor, enabled the Comptroller to pay off the back salaries for February and March, and the recipients were as well pleased as was the Comptroller, who has been daily a dunned since February. The item of $80,000 inserted for the "Commissioners of Record," will only be paid after adjudication by the proper legal tribunals. Meanwhile the two million of unbound sheets, stored in Liberty-street, and which have cost over half a million of dollars, will remain intact, subject to the decision of the Courts. Among those who were jubilant at the payment of their salaries were the members of the Police force -- a check for $100,000 having been drawn in favor of the Board of Commissioners, and late in the afternoon the respective amounts for the various Precincts were placed in the hands of the Captains, by whom the funds were disbursed to the needy subordinates.

abstract: CHARLES BICKLEY, K.G.C., Aid-de-Camp to Commander-in-Chief of the Knights of the Golden Circle, is out with a card in defence of his principal. It will be remembered that the Knights in New-Orleans, some time since, held a meeting expelling Gen. BICKLEY from the Circle, appointing another Commander-in-Chief in his steadand, also, a "receiver" for the assets of the institution. Sir CHARLES BICKLEY says that the
lead_paragraph: -- CHARLES BICKLEY, K.G.C., Aid-de-Camp to Commander-in-Chief of the Knights of the Golden Circle, is out with a card in defence of his principal. It will be remembered that the Knights in New-Orleans, some time since, held a meeting expelling Gen. BICKLEY from the Circle, appointing another Commander-in-Chief in his steadand, also, a "receiver" for the assets of the institution. Sir CHARLES BICKLEY says that the order was established by Gen. BICKLEY, in the year 1854, since which time the General has devoted his time, talents and fortune to bringing it to its present position. (This, considering its "present position," sounds somewhat ironical.) He says that the K.G.C. was intended to embrace only gentlemen of character and respectability, but that in the establishment of the New-Orleans branch it was rather unfortunate, and gathered in rowdies, gamblers, and other disreputable elements. In regard to the "assets," &c., Sir CHARLES intimates that as the Order has none, the appointment of a receiver was useless. He says that Gen. BICKLEY will take no notice of his expulsion; that he has already issued a call for a Convention at Raleigh, N.C.; that steps will be taken to purge the order of all unworthy members; and that hereafter it will only consist of "Southern gentlemen, by birth, education and practice -- men capable of building up a high grade of civilization in the country towards which their energies a re directed." Really, according to Sir CHARLES BICKLEY's showing, the K.G.C. is quite as worthy an organization as the Tract Society, and will quite supersede the Board of Foreign Missions. Let us suggest Washington City as a very suitable point to concentrate their civilizing and christianizing efforts and energies.

abstract: Mr. J.L. LOWERRE, of Pittsburgh, Penn., exhibited yesterday working models of a new fire hydrant, which has been in use in that city for some time, and which he hopes and seeks to have introduced here, The plan, which scarcely deserves the patent claimed for it, is very simple, being merely eight openings from one centre, thus enabling eight companies to attach their hose to a common hydrant -- conditioned, however, that the company first placing this new hydrant will permit it, for it is intended that each engine shall carry one of these patent hydrants, and attach them to the ordinary hydrants, when they reach the scene of a conflagration -- thus allowing eight companies to use the water from one hydrant. The New-York firemen are not re-remarkable for the readiness with which they inter-change courtesies, and the idea of having eight streams from one source of supply would be rejected as absurd, or if adopted, would result in just as many fights. It any reader doubts this assertion, he has only to attend one fire, and watch the jealous care with which the hydrant first secured in guarded by the "first comers." Mr. Lowerre's principle is correct, but as the Fire Department is at present organized, its value will not be properly appreciated. Mr. Craven, the Chief Engineer, and Dr. Rollins, Water Purveyor, have decided to give it a trial, and when the first shall be laid, and a fair trial had, we shall chronicle the result.

abstract: Shocking revelations had been made concerning the Coolie-trade in the Southern ports of China. On information derived from the deposition of 105 men taken from the coolie receiving ships, an inquiry was ordered by the allied Commander-in-chief, and it was ascertained that in three coolie vessels; two American ships and the other an Oldenburg bark, the coolies had been kidnapped, and a nominal consent to an eight-years' engagement in Cuba wrung from them by horrible modes of torture.
lead_paragraph: Shocking revelations had been made concerning the Coolie-trade in the Southern ports of China. On information derived from the deposition of 105 men taken from the coolie receiving ships, an inquiry was ordered by the allied Commander-in-chief, and it was ascertained that in three coolie vessels; two American ships and the other an Oldenburg bark, the coolies had been kidnapped, and a nominal consent to an eight-years' engagement in Cuba wrung from them by horrible modes of torture.

abstract: We do not believe that a Debating Society of young men ever existed through three consecutive weeks, without indulging at least twice during that time in the luxury of altering, amending or repealing its Constitution.
lead_paragraph: We do not believe that a Debating Society of young men ever existed through three consecutive weeks, without indulging at least twice during that time in the luxury of altering, amending or repealing its Constitution. There seems to be something supremely attractive of criticism and reform in any Constitution or laws for governing a Society, which is sure to put to utter route the tamer discussion of mere literary topies. This mania for law tinkering is not always confined to young men, or to societies avowedly organized for debate. Annually it seizes hold of the Legislature at Albany, and results in such a change of little out-of-the-way technicalities of our remarkable Code of Practice, as to render a new edition of that delectable production necessary at least once in two years. The lawyers grumble at legislative fun so expensive to them, and the booksellers rejoice in the plenty that results to their coffers.

This is really too bad, if it be
lead_paragraph: It is positively asserted by the Philadelphia Press that not only will Mr. FERNANDO WOOD be unable to procure admission for his private peculiar delegates to the Charleston Convention, but that his, attempts to procure it are already exciting considerable amusement at Charleston. This is really too bad, if it be true, and though the spectacle of a good man bravely struggling with adverse fates is always a pleasing one to every well balanced mind, no one can contemplate the repulse of our worthy Mayor and his worthy followers from the gates of the Democratic temple without experiencing an emotion somewhat akin to pain.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.?An audience of nearly a thousand persons, comprising the elite of the musical public of New-York, assembled by invitation at the Academy yesterday morning to witness what we may call the tentative debut of a young lady of this City, who has been devoting the last three years to preparation for the career of a lyric artist.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- An audience of nearly a thousand persons, comprising the elite of the musical public of New-York, assembled by invitation at the Academy yesterday morning to witness what we may call the tentative debut of a young lady of this City, who has been devoting the last three years to preparation for the career of a lyric artist. This lady, Miss LOUISA KELLOGG, is still in the very budding prime of youth; far too young to commence in earnest a life so arduous and exacting as that of a prima donna must be for a singer who possesses her really remarkable qualities of intellect and of voice. Her appearance of yesterday, therefore, we hope, is only to be regarded as a brilliant point reached in her studies, and not as her definitive entrance upon her profession. Judged in this light, Miss KELLOGG's execution of the striking and difficult role selected for her in "Il Poliuto" must be chronicled as the most interesting musical event of the current season. In point of force and of quality, this young lady's voice leaves nothing to be desired which time and simple physical development may not be reasonably expected to bring to her. In the upper register it is singularly fresh, vigorous and expressive; and it possesses, beyond a question, that rarest and most precious of vocal qualities, a musical magnetism of tone pliant to the will of the singer, and carrying the sentiment of her song directly to the musical consciousness of the hearer. Under all the disadvantages of a rehearsal out of costume, Miss KELLOGG made this gift of hers "tell" with emphatic effect, in the brilliant cavatina of the first act, and in her duo with BRIGNOLI. How difficult it is for n inexperienced singer to do this, when tenor and baritone and chorus alike stalk unconcernedly about the stage in the round hat and pantaloons of common Broadway life, and a dim twilight of mingling day and gas robs the house of its stimulating splendor, we need not say. For a debutante to achieve so positive an effect upon her first appearance before a great audience, and thrown almost entirely upon her own resources by the utter absence of any attempt at dramatic action on the part of the company, was certainly little less than amazing.

abstract: The Senate Committee, appointed to investigate rumored abuses of the public printing, made its report yesterday. The evidence, which embraces testimony from CORNELIUS WENDELL, Collector BAKER, of Philadelphia, RICE, formerly of the Pennsylvanian, Col. FLORENCE, and others, places beyond question the fact of the extensive profit and patronage of the printing having been employed, under the direction of the President, to reward his partisan friends, and to influence elections. The subject is shown to have been a favorite one with Mr. BUCHANAN, and his devotion to it to have been incessant and indefatigable. Two thousand extra copies of the report were ordered to be printed. The House bill in regard to the census was passed. Mr. BAYARD, from the Judiciary Committee, reported a bill relative to private property taken for public uses, and prescribing the mode of valuation and compensation. After a debate in which Messrs. MASON, WIGFALL and COLLAMER participated, the bill was set aside, and the Homestead bill taken up. Mr. GWIN modified his amendment respecting the occupancy of mineral lands, by excluding foreigners who have merely declared their intentions from the advantages of the Act. Mr. LANE, of Oregon, and Mr. BRAGG, of North Carolina, opposed this modification; and it was rejected. Mr. FITCH offered an amendment, which was rejected, permitting all soldiers who had been in actual service to locate a quarter section. Mr. CRITTENDEN Proposed and argued at length for an amendment restricting the benefits of the bill to persons actually resident in the country at the passage of the act. The amendment was opposed by Mr. JOHNSON, of Arkansas, and was unsuccessful. The subject was finally made the order for May 2, when it is understood the vote shall be taken, and the Senate went into Executive session. The House of Representatives, in Committee of the Whole, discussed the Senate amendment to the Military Academy bill, whereby some 800,000 are appropriated to raise and equip a regiment of mounted volunteers in Texas. Messrs. REAGAN, PENDLETON, and MCRAE successively spoke in favor of the regiment, while Messrs. STEVENS and STAUNTON opposed it: the latter proposing an amendment, which failed, authorizing the President to employ the same money to mount any infantry regiment of the regular army, and detail it to the Indian service. Mr. OTERO, the delegate from New-Mexico, moved for a similar appropriation for his Territory. A vote was at length obtained upon the Senate's amendment, when it was lost, 50 to 69, and the Committee rose. The House then accepted the Senate's amendment by a close vote, and adjourned.

abstract: The democracy of Switzerland have taken a leaf from the book of their brethren in our own Gulf States. The question of the occu- pation by France of the Chablais and Faucigny, the "neutralized" districts of Savoy, being still under diplomatic discussion, certain would-be William Walkers, of Geneva, undertook to settle the matter by raising the flag of the Cantons in these provinces. A band, in
lead_paragraph: The democracy of Switzerland have taken a leaf from the book of their brethren in our own Gulf States. The question of the occu- pation by France of the Chablais and Faucigny, the "neutralized" districts of Savoy, being still under diplomatic discussion, certain would-be William Walkers, of Geneva, undertook to settle the matter by raising the flag of the Cantons in these provinces. A band, in numbers hardly equal to the army of JOHN BROWN at Harper's Ferry, crossed the Lake of Geneva to Thonon, in the Savoyard territory, and called upon the victims of Sardinian selfishness and French ambition to accept their independence at the hands of the children of WILLIAM TELL. The "victims" replied by marching a squad of gendarmes to the shore and arresting all their liberators -- doubtless to the intense surprise of Sir ROBERT PEEL and his little knot of friends in the British Parliament -- who have been proclaiming so loudly the pitiable case of these poor Savoyards, longing for union with Switzerland, and condemned to be Frenchmen against their will.

abstract: Prof. WISE, Sen., the veteran aeronaut, made a successful ascension, in his new balloon Ganymede, yesterday afternoon, from Palace Garden. The announcement drew a large crowd of the curious to the vicinity, a majority of whom, as usual, availed themselves of the neighboring roofs and upper windows, to enjoy the spectacle gratis. The balloon, which is the smallest the Professor has ever used, is 27 by 29 feet in diameter, and bears the inscription Ganymede, with the mottos "Extra Flammantia," "Menia Mundi," on its sides, the name being in large letters. It is not quite half as large as his balloon Jupiter, and contains, when fully inflated, about 10,000 cubic feet of gas. It is made of light cambric linen, and is coated with a varnish of the Professor's own invention. It is only capable, when inflated with common gas, of sustaining one person, besides the necessary ballast, while, with pure hydrogen gas, it would easily support two persons of the Professor's weight. The basket was a neat one, made of the usual material, about 3 1/2 by 2 1/2 feet square, and 20 inches deep. A grappling of some 15 pounds was deposited in the bottom of the basket, to which was securely attached the end of a small line, some ten fathoms in length, of three strands, and made of linen thread, very strong and pliable. The netting was of strong cotton twine of a small size, the basket ropes attached to the circular hoop being of hemp, about the size of an ordinary clothes-line. The balloon was placed upon a raised platform in the middle of the open space, and the process of inflation commenced at twenty minutes before three P.M., the gas being conducted from the main in the street through a varnished cloth hose, six inches in diameter. Prof. LA MOUNTAIN and Mr. CONNER assisting. While the spectators were waiting for the time announced for the ascension, the band beguiled the time by playing lively music. At 4 o'clock the Professor, seeing that the audience was still small, but that the quarters were gradually coming in, asked for fifteen or twenty minutes' delay, which was unanimously granted. At 4 1/2 o'clock the order for unloosing the cords from the sand bags was given; three of the smaller sacks were deposited in the basket as ballast, and an extra coat as protection against the cold. The Professor himself then stepped in, holding in his hands two miniature flags. At 4 3/4 P.M., the wind having slightly lulled, the only rope which held the balloon was severed by the Professor's knife, and the Ganymede rose slowly but majestically into space, amid the cheers of the multitude. Prof. WISE now mounted the sides of the basket, holding by the hoop, and waved his little flags, the crowd from below and from the house-tops cheering vociferously. In a moment more the balloon rose above the houses, and was caught by the fresh southeast wind, which carried it rapidly toward the northwest. At the altitude of about half a mile it took a southerly current, and, on going half a mile higher, during which the aeronaut was seen to discharge considerable ballast, he struck a current which carried him slowly toward the East River. When last seen, he was passing in a northeast direction, towards Flushing, and it was believed that he would alight, before dark, somewhere on Long Island.

abstract: The Democratic members of our State Legislature have issued an address to their constituents. It is prolix on the question of the Finances and the Canal Enlargement, and eloquent upon the subject of Negro suffrage.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic members of our State Legislature have issued an address to their constituents. It is prolix on the question of the Finances and the Canal Enlargement, and eloquent upon the subject of Negro suffrage. But it has nothing whatever to say of the leading measures of the session, -- the Toll bill, the City Railroads and the general corruption which ruled and regulated the action of both branches of the Legislature. These omissions are a good deal more significant than anything which the address contains.

COLEMAN, of the Eataw House, who supposed that the matter was scarcely worthy of more than a passing notice. He was surprised, therefore, upon being called upon by a Committee of the Company, who presented him with the following acknowledgment, inclosed in a most chaste and super[???]frame, and executed in a style of penmanship which we have never yet seen equalled. It is very highly [???]rized by the recipient, and is suspended from a conspicuous place in the house"

abstract: We are heartily rejoiced that the Covode inquisition have obtained possession of the private letter addressed by the President to Gov. WALKER on the 12th of July, 1857. Various rumors concerning the contents of this letter have been long in circulation, which will all be instantly dissipated by the perusal of the letter itself; and we take pleasure in laying it before our readers to-day.

abstract: A young man named JOHN SHOUFFER, residing in Dalton, Ohio, committed suicide by shooting himself through the head with a rifle. The only cause assigned for the rash act was, that he was in love with a young lady, but could not afford to get married. More instances are on record of men shooting themselves because they were married, than because they were not.

abstract: THE LATE MYSTERIOUS MURDER. -- Yesterday afternoon Coroner MORRIS employed a number of men to drag the bottom of the dock at the York-street Pier in Jersey City in hopes of raising the other barrel of pitch, which was missing at the same time that the one to which the body of the murdered female was attached disappeared. It is believed that to this barrel is attached the clothing of the woman. The men several times succeeded in fastening a pair of oyster tongs to some heavy body, but at every attempt to raise it the tongs slipped off. Once they brought up a piece of tarred cord about two feet in length, which had apparently been fastened to something and broke loose. Nothing transpired yesterday throwing additional light upon this mystery.

YOUNG finally left the house and WEST locked the door after him, remarking that he was afraid Young would return and shoot him. The person to
lead_paragraph: Judge BENNETT writes to the Nebraska City News, detailing a cold-blooded murder perpeirated in Auraria on the 13th. MOSES YOUNG and WILLIAM WEST bad a quarrel over some title deeds which the later held to secure a debt of $125 one him from YOUNG. YOUNG finally left the house and WEST locked the door after him, remarking that he was afraid Young would return and shoot him. The person to whom he made this remark, writes Judge BENNETT, "Walked to YOUNG's house, and when within three or four steps of the door saw YOUNG level his gun at WEST, who was walking obliquely by the house. Witness said, 'Mose, don't shoot.' YOUNG replied, 'I said I would,' and immediately fired, and fifteen buckshot, from YOUNG's double barreled shot gun, took effect in the right hip and side of WEST. WEST fell, and cried out to arrest YOUNG for he had murdered him, and expired in about twenty minutes thereafter. YOUNG fled, and secured himself in the attic of a store room in Denver. He was found about sundown under a big pile of harness in one corner. The crowd, and there was an immense one, exhibited great moderation, and decided to give him a fair public trial on the next day.

abstract: We are confident that we can justly claim that the delegates from this State go to Charleston with purposes as disinterested and patriotism as pure as actuate those of any delegation in the Union. They will fail to respond to the general sentiment at home, if, in all the business which may come before the Convention, they do not shape their action with reference to the well-defined and old-fashioned principles of the Party, and its success in the great struggle upon which it is now entering. They may rest assured that their constituents will be content with the Party platform, as unanimously adopted at Cincinnati and ratified by the people in 1856, and do not think that this is the time to try new experiments, or agitate the country over any new article of political creed. Rather let the Democratic Party of the nation, in this critical juncture, stand simply upon the Constitution, insisting upon fidelity to all its provisions, and rallying under this banner all national and patriotic men against the hosts of sectionalism, fanaticism and disunion.
lead_paragraph: We are confident that we can justly claim that the delegates from this State go to Charleston with purposes as disinterested and patriotism as pure as actuate those of any delegation in the Union. They may rest assured that their constituents will be content with the Party platform, as unanimously adopted at Cincinnati and ratified by the people in 1856, and do not think that this is the time to try new experiments, or agitate the country over any new article of political creed. Rather let the Democratic Party of the nation, in this critical juncture, stand simply upon the Constitution, insisting upon fidelity to all its provisions, and rallying under this banner all national and patriotic men against the hosts of sectionalism, fanaticism and disunion.

abstract: PROBABLE MURDER BY BURGLARS -- ARREST OF SUSPECTED PARTIES. -- At about 3 o'clock Thursday morning, two burglars entered the house of Dr. NELSON A. GARBISON, on the Jamaica Plank Road. OWEN COX, a man in the employ of Dr. G., heard the burglars at work in the second story of the house, and stationed himself at the foot of the stairway with a spear, and when they were leaving he attempted to stop them and called for Dr. GARRISON, who was also in the house. Finding their chance of escape doubtful, one of the burglars discharged a pistol at COX, the bullet from which entered the left side near the heart, inflicting, it is supposed, a mortal wound. The burglars then made their escape, taking with them $40 in money and a quantity of silverware. Yesterday the police of the Ninth Precinct arrested JAMES and DANIEL LUDLAM, silversmiths, at No. 16 Maiden-lane, New-York, on suspicion of being the parties who committed the offence, and they were committed for examination by Justice CORNWELL. House No. 131 Willoughby-street, occupied by AARON VANDERBECK, was robbed, yesterday, of property valued at $150.
lead_paragraph: PROBABLE MURDER BY BURGLARS -- ARREST OF SUSPECTED PARTIES. -- At about 3 o'clock Thursday morning, two burglars entered the house of Dr. NELSON A. GARBISON, on the Jamaica Plank Road. OWEN COX, a man in the employ of Dr. G., heard the burglars at work in the second story of the house, and stationed himself at the foot of the stairway with a spear, and when they were leaving he attempted to stop them and called for Dr. GARRISON, who was also in the house. Finding their chance of escape doubtful, one of the burglars discharged a pistol at COX, the bullet from which entered the left side near the heart, inflicting, it is supposed, a mortal wound. The burglars then made their escape, taking with them $40 in money and a quantity of silverware. Yesterday the police of the Ninth Precinct arrested JAMES and DANIEL LUDLAM, silversmiths, at No. 16 Maiden-lane, New-York, on suspicion of being the parties who committed the offence, and they were committed for examination by Justice CORNWELL. House No. 131 Willoughby-street, occupied by AARON VANDERBECK, was robbed, yesterday, of property valued at $150.

abstract: It is remarked among the publishers that the number of Southern buyers who attended the recent Trade sales in this City, greatly exceeded that of any former year. Whether this fact is attributable to an increased thirst for knowledge among the people of the South, or to the unanswerable assertion that Northern houses produce books of better quality more cheaply, it matters little. That buyers from Southern cities should not share in the panic, which we have previously demonstrated to have been far from general in other branches of trade, is very natural and reasonable. Literature, unlike dry goods, needs to be of prime quality to satisfy the appetite of thirsty readers; -- homespun may answer the requirements of bodily decency, but rough-edged books are neither seemly nor desirable. Wherefore this general verdict in favor of the New-York Book Market is a pleasant sign of the times. The activity of trade sends a current of new life through the book shops, and the sunniest-faced men you meet on Broadway to-day are the publishers. Curiously enough, the balance hangs nearly even between the religious and the secular. When a novel is announced, a book of sermons hangs over against it; when poem tumbles out from the press, another press over the way is sure to turn over to you a new volume of the "Correspondence" of some Reverend theologian, whose memory is fragrant in the large class of his surviving parishioners. For instance: Mr. SCRIBNER's place in Grand-street is in juxtaposition with that of RUDD & CARLETON. The latter announces the first volume of a new edition of the novels of BALZAC: the former instantly offsets it by Dr. JAMES W. ALEXANDER's Forty Year's Correspondence. This latter volume will be published in May, simultaneously with a collection of the Sermons of Dr. ADDISON ALEXANDER.

abstract: A short time since the child of one of our up town families was suddenly seized with a sickness which seemed so serious that immediately the family physician, a man of long beard, long bills, and its accompaniments, was sent for in great haste; but alas, he came not, and the sudden culmination of the disease into a terrific convulsion compelled the family to abandon their regular doctor and send for the nearest one, who proved to be an educated man of the old school -- a serious objection, indeed, to the family, but which, in their distressed situation, could not well be helped. The character of the difficulty was quickly perceived, and an emetic speedily removed a quantity of undigested and improper food, restoring the child to comparative health. The thanks of the whole family were prodigally bestowed upon the physician, the preserver of their child, who was requested to continue his attendance till the child was entirely recovered. The next morning brought the tardy Dr. PELLETS, who was met with a storm of reproaches for his neglect and inattention, and with the statement that if they had waited for him their child would now have been a corpse, and that now, as the doctor had done so much for them, they could never repay him, and be should continue to attend the child, and an intimation was held out that they should continue to employ him in the future. Dr. PALLETS could not afford to lose so valuable a family without a struggle to retain it; so he said commisseratingly: "I regret, my dear madam, the alarm you have been under and the danger in which your darling beautiful has been. At what hour did you say the child began to improve?" "It was just as the clock struck four," was the answer. "Ah, my dear lady, I thought it was so. It was five minutes before 4 o'clock when I entered my house and saw your call on my slate. My spirit was put into immediate communication with your child, and through it I was enabled to act upon the convulsed spirit of your charming little cherub!" "Is it possible, my dear Doctor PELLETS? We thought it was almost a miracle, and foolishly attributed it to the action of this allopathic's poisonous emetic, which indeed only brought a few raisin skins and stones and a little bit of mince-pie it had eaten. Ah! Doctor, forgive us for doubting you, and the hard words and harder thoughts we have had for you."

abstract: Justice BRENNAN yesterday held for examination Edward England, a farmer from Long Island, who is charged with reckless driving. The accused, who was quite intoxicated, it is alleged, turned his wagon quickly around the corner of Grand-street into Broadway, and came in contact with the cart of Bernard Riley, striking the shaft with such force that it broke and pierced the horse's neck, injuring the animal so severely that he will probably die. Officer Marin, of the Fourteenth Precinct, pursued the reckless farmer and captured him, notwithstanding his endeavors to drive off. England, it is said, has lately retired with a competency which he obtained by acting as carrier for the Herald. Mr. Riley intends to prosecute for the recovery of the value of the horse.

abstract: The spacious and beautiful Church in Rutgersstreet was filled, on the evening of 15th inst., with the children of the Sunday School, and their parents and friends, celebrating the 24th anniversary of the Childrens' Missionary Society. The School consists of 400 children, nearly all of whom were present. They are organized as an auxiliary of the Domestic Board of Missions of the Presbyterian Church, and have contributed upwards of $4,000 to its funds. Their con
lead_paragraph: The spacious and beautiful Church in Rutgersstreet was filled, on the evening of 15th inst., with the children of the Sunday School, and their parents and friends, celebrating the 24th anniversary of the Childrens' Missionary Society. The School consists of 400 children, nearly all of whom were present. They are organized as an auxiliary of the Domestic Board of Missions of the Presbyterian Church, and have contributed upwards of $4,000 to its funds. Their contribution last year was $265. An interesting feature of their relation to the Board is in having a particular missionary assigned to them, with whom they regularly correspond, so that they know precisely where and on whom their contributions are expended, and they receive regular reports and details of the cultivation of the field which is more especially their own. The missionary at present correspondent with them is Rev. ALLEN H. BROWN, (son of the late SILAS BROWN, of this City,) whose devoted labors in "The Pines" of New-Jersey have been, and continue to be, so largely blessed in establishing Sunday-Schools, and planting thrifty churches in that remarkable and too long neglected region. They are also about to take up, in connection with a Ladies' Association in the same Church, a missionary in Texas, who was originally a scholar in their school.

abstract: The publication of the President's letter to Ex-Governor WALKER has not only carried sorrow to the White House, but peril to the person of Attorney-General BLACK. The challenge sent him by the ireful Mississippian was declined, but with the remark, "I suppose WALKER will murder me," which the latter gentleman is understood to regard as fitting provocation to that deadly purpose. In the meantime the Ex-Governor has laid before the Covode Committee the letter from Kansas relative to Territorial affairs, which evoked the President's response. Nothing could more clearly indicate the understanding with which WALKER was sent to Kansas, and the cowardly treason which betrayed it.

abstract: I am very fond of music, especially of sacred music. I like sacred music principally on account of its heavy base. For, musically, not morally, speaking, the whole tenor of my life has been base. Accordingly, on noticing by an advertisement in the Herald, that a sacred concert was to be given at the Volks' Garten on Sunday evening, I determined to go. This determination was strengthened by the announcement that the young lady atttendants were the prettiest in the City. Can you conceive of any bait at which a saint would be more apt to bite than at such a fly as this -- body of sacred music; wings of gauze, feathers and flounces; and well-proportioned ankles for the feet? It is needless to say that the subscriber snapped like a trout at a June bug!

abstract: The Newspaper Express Train is becoming a permanent and a popular institution. Its working, thus far, has been even more successful than was anticipated, -- and every day gives it greater efficiency by perfecting the details of the arrangement and enlarging the sphere of its operations. The number of newspapers taken into the interior by this train has steadily increased, until now not far from 15,000 copies of the TIMES, Tribune and Herald are taken every day, and before the Summer is over this number will be more than doubled. We have already stated that the managers of the Hudson River Railroad are entitled to a very large share of the credit for this enterprise, as they embarked in it without any expectation of receiving an immediate return for their outlay. But there are already from ten to fifteen passengers every morning, who embrace this opportunity to reach Albany some hours earlier than they could do by any other train, and their number will naturally increase.

abstract: If the "up-town movement" among merchants which has been going on so rapidly for the last four or five years, and which is still progressing as rapidly as ever, indicated a corresponding growth and increase in the business of the City, the prosperity of New-York during this period would be one of the greatest marvels of the age. But, unfortunately, this is not the case. Change is not always progress, nor is progress always improvement, nor do both together indicate a corresponding growth. The fact that the whole body of dry-goods jobbers, and other dealers who follow in their wake, have moved out of the First Ward into the Third and Fifth, does not prove that they have increased in numbers or in business, nor does it show that they have been compelled to change their locality by the natural growth and increass in the general business of the City. The fact is the Third Ward has been built up at the expense of the First, and the Fifth is rapidly building at the expense of the Second. Deserted tenements and depreciated property is the legacy left to the First Ward by the marble palaces that have sprung up in the Third.

abstract: Col. F. W. LANDER, who has achieved extensive notoriety as the second of Hon. J.F. POTTER in the duel which did not take place between that gentleand Mr. PRYOR, left yesterday for California by the steamer North Star.
lead_paragraph: Col. F.W. LANDER, who has achieved extensive notoriety as the second of Hon. J.F. POTTER in the duel which did not take place between that gentleand Mr. PRYOR, left yesterday for California by the steamer North Star. As was suggested in the TIMES of Thursday morning, some of Col. LANDER's friends paid him the compliment of a serenade late on the evening of that day at the Metropolitan Hotel, where he stopped during his brief sojourn in the City. DODWORTH's Band furnished the music, which proved sufficiently attractive to draw quite a crowd to the front of the building. Repeated calls were made for Col. LANDER, and finally that gentleman stepped upon the balcony, amid hearty cheers, and spoke as follows:

abstract: Workmen have been engaged during the past week in erecting the "Time-ball" on the Custom-house, and from the street it seem complete although not yet in operation. The idea is to drop a ball at precisely 12 o'clock, noon, the time being found by astronomical means at the Dudley Observatory in Albany, and the ball dropped by an electric current from the Observatory to the ball. If this be well done, it will be a complete substitute for an astronomical observation here, and chronometers may be rated or clocks and watches set without resorting to astronomical means, the falling ball and naked eye being all-sufficient.
lead_paragraph: Workmen have been engaged during the past week in erecting the "Time-ball" on the Custom-house, and from the street it seem complete although not yet in operation. abstract: There is one point on which the Covode investigation will serve Mr. BUCHANAN rather than injure him. It will give the public a far higher idea of his industry and versatility than anything previously known of his career would have led them to entertain. When one
lead_paragraph: There is one point on which the Covode investigation will serve Mr. BUCHANAN rather than injure him. It will give the public a far higher idea of his industry and versatility than anything previously known of his career would have led them to entertain. When one reads the list of enterprises, as revealed by the witnesses which he personally directed -- the number of "arrangements" he superintended, now as "the President," now as the Executive, now as "J.B.," and now as JAMES BUCHANAN -- one is astonished, at the confidence expressed in the close of his letter to Governor WALKER, that Providence would bring him through them all. He must be either a very sanguine man or a very audacious one, to expect any such interposition on his behalf. He not only looked after BRIGHAM YOUNG and Kansas in the first year of his Administration, but he took special charge of almost all the Democratic newspapers in the country. He fixed the amounts which were to be paid to these struggling organs out of the proceeds of the public printing, and at what times they were to be paid; and more than all, he selected the particular newspapers that were to receive the largest contributions.

abstract: By a curious coincidence, which we trust may not be altogether unprofitable to the cause of humanity, the Legislatures of England and America have been almost simultaneously called upon to consider the abuses of the Coolie-trade in the East. The report of Mr. ELIOT, of Massachusetts, upon this traffic, has just been laid before the House of Representatives, and through the press before the people of the United States. In this report it
lead_paragraph: By a curious coincidence, which we trust may not be altogether unprofitable to the cause of humanity, the Legislatures of England and America have been almost simultaneously called upon to consider the abuses of the Coolie-trade in the East. The report of Mr. ELIOT, of Massachusetts, upon this traffic, has just been laid before the House of Representatives, and through the press before the people of the United States. In this report it was proved with terrible distinctness that in the absence of any regulations weighted with the national authority to restrain them from violating the instincts of humanity, American merchants and ship-masters have been gradually drawn into the most atrocious practices in connection with the Coolie-trade on the coasts of the Chinese Empire. The traditional horrors of the African middle-passage have been reenacted, are indeed continually reenacting, under the American flag in the Chinese ports and on the Indian seas. Men are kidnapped by the agents of American mercantile houses, huddled into the unventilated holds of American clipper-ships, restrained of their liberty by force of arms, transported thousands of miles to foreign lands, there disposed of under instruments which they cannot comprehend to masters whose language they do not speak, and condemned to labors which in nine cases out of ten can have no end but death, and to a life from which death is a welcome and desirable release.

abstract: One of the most delightful, instructive and piquant of contemporary writers has just died at Paris, after a short illness. The memory of the Abbe HUC, a French missionary in China and Thibet, who carried the Cross into the heart of Central Asia, and studied the ritual of Buddhism in the very Meccas of that strange and wide-extended faith, deserves a place in the literary Pantheon, as well as in the more sacred shrines of the Church which he served with so single-hearted a devotion.

abstract: Great was the rush yesterday at the residence and office of the Comptroller, to whom is assigned the delicate and responsible duty of appointing four Commissioners of the Almshouse to take the place of the retired and retiring "ten." Mr. HAWES, whose life is not insured, and who is the father of a family, wisely determined that the better part of valor was discretion, and so far as was possible, kept aloof from the crowds of friends who waited upon him. We announce by his authority that the appointments for these two-year offices will not be officially promulgated until to-day; therefore, expectants as well as betters must await his adjudication.

abstract: Rev. Dr. TYNG is giving, through the columns of the Independent, a complete view of the Sunday-School system. Having already defined the uses of that agency in Christian education, and enlarged upon the duties of parents, he devotes a considerable part of his last letter to an exposition of the qualifications, of successful teachers, and gives the following salutary counsel to persons holding the office of Superintendent: "The Su
lead_paragraph: -- Rev. Dr. TYNG is giving, through the columns of the Independent, a complete view of the Sunday-School system. Having already defined the uses of that agency in Christian education, and enlarged upon the duties of parents, he devotes a considerable part of his last letter to an exposition of the qualifications, of successful teachers, and gives the following salutary counsel to persons holding the office of Superintendent: "The Superintendent's manner must be simple, prompt, calm, adequate to command attention, or he fails entirely. He must be a person of few words and peaceful habits. A perpetual haranguing, -- long, indefinite, and dilatory prayers, -- jangling an disjointed exhortations, -- habits of chattering and familiar interference with teachers or scholars, are more out of place in a Sunday-School, perhaps, than anywhere beside. Everything must be real, actual, self-demonstrative, to command the attention or to win the confidence of children. These are all simple and external qualifications, but they are of immense consequence in the successful management of this work."

abstract: A novel and very pretty "application of the Arts to life" took place on Thursday evening at the Cooper Institute. Certain rooms of that building have been for some time occupied, as our readers know, or ought to know, by the pupils of the New-York School of Design for Women. This excellent institution, under the supervision of a committee of accomplished ladies, and the very competent direction of Mr. T. ADDISON RICHARDS, has gradually begun to win for itself the place which it deserves to hold in the public estimation. Every effort to open new avenues of honorable personal independence to women is a duty done to society and to civilization. But the education of a class of young women in the principles and practice of the Arts of Design has a special value in this country, where the services of such a class are imperatively demanded by the backwardness of our manufacturing industry in those higher branches which depend for their vigor and fruitfulness upon the taste of the manufacturer. Beauty, as the industries of France have proved, has a market value all the world over; and the less-cultivated workmen of England have of late years been roused to recognize this fact, and to put themselves into training for a course of serious competition with the Gaul, whose subtle grace, passing into the fabrics of the furnace and the loom, had given him, at almost every point, the advantage over his British rivals. In America, the aesthetics of industry are still less fully developed than they are in England. Most of our leading manufacturers still import their "designers" from abroad. If the naturally tasteful instincts of our women can be fortified and educated into really artistic capacity, this condition of American manufactures offers them a wide -- almost an unbounded -- field for the honorable, useful, and profitable employment of their faculties, in a direction thoroughly congenial with the female nature, and eminently becoming in point of character. The New-York School of Design affords the means of securing this desirable end; and on Thursday evening the Lady Managers threw open the spacious rooms of the Cooper Institute to some hundreds of their own friends and the friends of the pupils of their school, in order that some sound judgment might be formed on the success which has already attended their enterprise. The galleries were filled with drawings and paintings by the pupils, more than a hundred in number, over whom Mr. RICHARDS exercises his artistic care. Many of the paintings were creditable as copies, but the chief interest of the exhibition belonged to the drawings, which offer the best indication of the progress of the pupils in the principles of design. We are glad to see that the paramount importance of instruction in these principles is evidently recognized in the course of the School. By its fidelity in this respect the institution must stand or fall. For its object is not to make poor painters, but good designers.

abstract: A special meeting of the Board of Councilmen was suddenly called last evening, to the great astonishment, not only of the outsiders, but also of many of the members, and the secrecy preserved concerning the purpose of the meeting was equal to the mystery of the antecedents of BARNUM's "What is it?" A
lead_paragraph: A special meeting of the Board of Councilmen was suddenly called last evening, to the great astonishment, not only of the outsiders, but also of many of the members, and the secrecy preserved concerning the purpose of the meeting was equal to the mystery of the antecedents of BARNUM's "What is it?" A few waggish members availed themselves of this state of anxiety to perpetrate one of the most egregious "sells" known since the famed search after FRANK MCLAUGHLIN, of California, who, it will be recollected, was represented as having an inestimable amount of gold for everybody whom the wags could succeed in sending in search of him. The sell consisted this time in the circulation of a report that the Common Council intended to bestow their salaries, just alloted to them by the Legislature, to the Widows' and Orphans' Fund of the Fire Department. All the Councilmen present but one got wind of the joke, and enjoyed hugely the chagrin of the City Father who innocently believed that there was a serious intent to thus charitably dispose of his salary. He counted noses among the members to see whether the measure would pass. He tried to get away, so as to leave the Board without a quorum, but the Sergeant-at-Arms was sent after him. He vowed he "wouldn't be robbed," he "would test the matter in the courts," "they never should get his money without his consent," he "would give them a hard tug for it." His brother members led him on, by debating the legality of the plan before him, and finally capped the climax by considering a resolution while the Board was waiting for a message from the Aldermen. They moved to refer it to various committees, including the one of which the victimized member was chairman, and worked him up to a pitch of excitement which may be imagined when it is remembered that he supposed he had the sum of $1,200 at stake. The poor fellow was, however, finally relieved by the arrival of papers from the Board of Aldermen, which gave the Councilmen something to do, and the bogus charitable resolution was withdrawn.

abstract: TERMINATION OF THE LABORS OF THE POLAR EXPEDITION. -- Though by no means the most experienced of navigators, yet during the past fourteen days an expedition, composed of an officer and fifteen men of the Harbor Police, occompanied by seven [???]rly steve[???]ores, have traveled from pole to pole, overcoming the numerous obstructions that contested almost each foot of their progress, and finally attained, from Spuyten Duyvel Creek at the north, to the Narrows at the south, a harbor free from shed poles. abstract: It is highly probable that the local Government of this City has a right to pave its streets without the interference of the Albany logrollers; at least, this time-honored custom will not probably be made illegal before the next session of our valuable Legislature.
lead_paragraph: It is highly probable that the local Government of this City has a right to pave its streets without the interference of the Albany logrollers; at least, this time-honored custom will not probably be made illegal before the next session of our valuable Legislature. Such being the case, it is not only possible, but convenient and feasible, for our local Government so to pave our streets, and for our omnibus owners so to modify their vehicles, as to reduce the cost and increase the comfort of City travel, irrespective and independent of the City railroads. Let us relieve our minds once for all, of the common and absurd error that a flanged car wheel runs with less power and cost than an ordinary flat tire. On the contrary, it is wholly a question of surface and diameter of wheel, with the exception of the abnormal flange friction, which largely increases the resistance to car wheels.

abstract: Mr. LYONS, residing at No. 119 West Forty-fifth-street, called at the New-York Hospital on Saturday morning and identified the body of the young man who died in that Institution on Thursday evening, as was at first believed in an epileptic fit, but whose death a post-mortem examination developed had been occasioned by a fractured skull, as that of his son WM.H. LYONS. Coroner JACKMAN was unable to procure evidence as to how or by whom the injury was inflicted, and the matter will probably remain involved in mystery. Deceased was 27 years of age, unmarried, and had an excellent reputation for sobriety and industry. For several years he had been employed as a driver for ADAMS' Express Company, in whose service he was when he met his death.
lead_paragraph: Mr. LYONS, residing at No. 119 West Forty-fifth-street, called at the New-York Hospital on Saturday morning and identified the body of the young man who died in that Institution on Thursday evening, as was at first believed in an epileptic fit, but whose death a post-mortem examination developed had been occasioned by a fractured skull, as that of his son WM.H. LYONS. Coroner JACKMAN was unable to procure evidence as to how or by whom the injury was inflicted, and the matter will probably remain involved in mystery. Deceased was 27 years of age, unmarried, and had an excellent reputation for sobriety and industry. For several years he had been employed as a driver for ADAMS' Express Company, in whose service he was when he met his death.

abstract: There could not be a more instructive commentary upon the absolute worthlessness, in an electioneering point of view, of violent and extravagant language and reckless behavior, on the part of candidates for the Presidency, than is afforded by Gov. WISE'S letter of the 18th inst. to the Virginia delegates, announcing his final withdrawal of his name from the list of competitors.
lead_paragraph: There could not be a more instructive commentary upon the absolute worthlessness, in an electioneering point of view, of violent and extravagant language and reckless behavior, on the part of candidates for the Presidency, than is afforded by Gov. WISE'S letter of the 18th inst. to the Virginia delegates, announcing his final withdrawal of his name from the list of competitors. At a period when so many politcal adventurers are in the habit of placing their main reliance in the struggle for the topmost places of the Republic upon the use of frantic denunciation, ferocious and extravagant threats, and wilful and labored exaggerations, it is but right that the attention of the public should be called in emphatic terms to the swift destruction which has come upon the ambitious hopes of the most truculent and turbulent of all the agitators, whose gyrations and contortions form so large a portion of our national calamities.

abstract: The Comptroller, on Saturday, made and announced the appointees of the four Almshouse Commissioners who are to relieve the Board of Ten Governors of their arduous and responsible duties. The gentlemen to whom is entrusted the entire control of the charitable institutions belonging to the City, and supported by the tax-payers, are Messrs.
lead_paragraph: The Comptroller, on Saturday, made and announced the appointees of the four Almshouse Commissioners who are to relieve the Board of Ten Governors of their arduous and responsible duties. The gentlemen to whom is entrusted the entire control of the charitable institutions belonging to the City, and supported by the tax-payers, are Messrs. MOSES H. GRINNELL, (just elected a Commissioner of the Central Park vice CHARLES H. ELLIOTT,) SIMEON DRAPER, JSAAC BELL, Jr., and JAMES B, NICHOLSON, all well-known citizens, and fairly representing the great parties -- Messrs. DRAPER and GRINNELL being as well-known Republicans as Messrs. BELL and NICHOLSON are Democrats.

abstract: At St. George's Church, Stuyvestant-square, last evening, was held the sixteenth anniversary of the Protestant Episcopal Church Missionary Society for Seamen in the City and Port of New-York. The spacious edifice was about half filed, and Rev. Dr. VINTON presided over the services.
lead_paragraph: At St. George's Church, Stuyvestant-square, last evening, was held the sixteenth anniversary of the Protestant Episcopal Church Missionary Society for Seamen in the City and Port of New-York. The spacious edifice was about half filed, and Rev. Dr. VINTON presided over the services. After the reading of the appropriate evening lessons and prayer, the sixteenth annual report was read. From this document it appeared that the object of the Society is to extend all possible moral and religious aid to sailors in this port, accompanied by judicious and discriminating charity in some cases. The aim is to keep a guardian care over poor Jack Tar, and to help him to be able to enjoy the fruits of his hard toil. Two floating chapels have been maintained, one on the North River and one on the East, and stated service has been held in the vicinity of Coenties-slip, public worship being maintained throughout the year at all these points. At Coenties-slip the worship is mainly in the open air, although in stormy weather a neighboring shipping office is opened, where also the books and tracts for distribution are stored, and distributed to such as desire them.

abstract: The National Democratic Convention assembles to-day, at Charleston. Full delegations from every State in the Union are present, with, however, an unusually slender attendance of outstde members, speculators, spectators and regulators; a deficiency probably due to the astonishing stories heretofore current regarding the extortions contemplated by the publicans of Charleston.
lead_paragraph: The National Democratic Convention assembles to-day, at Charleston. Full delegations from every State in the Union are present, with, however, an unusually slender attendance of outstde members, speculators, spectators and regulators; a deficiency probably due to the astonishing stories heretofore current regarding the extortions contemplated by the publicans of Charleston. A general survey of the coming contest reveals as yet nothing decisive. The fact that Mr. DOUGLAS has a majority, is, we believe, conceded on all sides. The belief that he lacks the strength necessary to a two-third vote is also general, and it is certain that the protesting or Anti-Douglas States of the South will not accede to the nomination of the Illinois statesman upon any condition. As Messrs. WISE and HUNTER have both practically withdrawn from the contest, there is little doubt that either Mr. DOUGLAS or a representative of his views will be the nominee.

abstract: The Tribune tells a tale of a Republican dog, who is sent regularly to a news-stand for the morning papers. It says that he curls his tail contemptuously at the TIMES, but is greatly elated when the Tribune is placed in his mouth. This only proves that he is a dogged devotee of party.
lead_paragraph: -- The Tribune tells a tale of a Republican dog, who is sent regularly to a news-stand for the morning papers. It says that he curls his tail contemptuously at the TIMES, but is greatly elated when the Tribune is placed in his mouth. This only proves that he is a dogged devotee of party. He likes to wear a collar and follow a master himself, and he naturally prefers a newspaper that does the same thing. Besides, the Tribune must remember that he can't read, -- he judges newspapers, like everything else, by the sense of smell: and the stronger the scent the clearer the case. "Am I not a dog and a brother?" is probably the exclamation that rises to his tail when he sees, or rather nose, that the Tribune is before him. We haven't the slightest doubt that he is a good dog, and a good Republican dog: -- but we can't say that we should subscribe for a newspaper on the strength of his judgment.

abstract: After all, we are inclined to think the Legislature has done the City more good than harm by its Winter's work. Attention has been so absorbed by one or two very bad bills, that we have had no thought for other laws which have been enacted.
lead_paragraph: After all, we are inclined to think the Legislature has done the City more good than harm by its Winter's work. Attention has been so absorbed by one or two very bad bills, that we have had no thought for other laws which have been enacted. It is never easy to tell precisely what losses have been sustained until the action is over, and the field can be examined at leisure. Many who were at first supposed to be dead are then found to be only wounded, and others, who were among the missing, prove to have been a good deal more scared than hurt.

abstract: Soon after 12 o'clock on Saturday night a fata stabbing affray occurred in Orchard-street, near Canal, in which Thomas Greenan, a brass founder residing at No. 124 East Broadway, was the victim. Deceased, in company with his friend John Crinnion, had been spending the evening at the house of his brother, and while returning home together through Orchard-street, they were met by three Germans, one of whom jostled violently against Greenan, who thinking the act intentional, made use of abusive language. One of the Germans retorted and the altercation resulted in a fight, which ended in Greenan's obtaining the advantage of his antagonist. As soon, however, as he permitted the German to rise from the sidewalk, where he had thrown him, the latter stabbed him twice in the back, the wound penetrating both lungs, and producing almost instant death. The noise of the altercation attracted the attention of Officer Wright, of the Tenth Ward, who, learning the particulars of the case from Crinnion, obtained the assistance of other Policemen and started in pursuit of the Germans. Charles Robert, a young German baker, residing at No 34 Hester-street, was soon afterwards arrested, while endeavoring to obtain access to a saloon in the neighborhood, and after looking at him, Crinnion positively asserted that he was one of the three Germans who had occasioned the disturbance, and he also believed him to be the man who had used the knife. The prisoner denied an[???] knowledge of the affair, and said that he had been alone all the evening. He was, nevertheless, detained, as were Crinnion and a man named Samuel Calhoun, a witness of the affray, to await the result of an investigation which will be made by Coroner JACKMAN. The body was removed to the Tenth Ward Station-house, where Drs. Beach and Gallagher made a post mortem examination. They found two incised wounds between the shoulders and near the spinal column, which had probably been inflicted with a dirk knife, penetrating the lungs and sufficient to cause death in a very short time. A jury was summoned, but the Coroner decided to adjourn the examination of witnesses until to-day, when further evidence will probably be obtained. Greenan is said to have been a man of correct habits. He was 26 years of age, unmarried, and worked in the foundry of James Gregory, in annon-street, near Houston

abstract: At the opening of the regular meeting, last week, Mr. Fisher, Chairman of the Committee to whom was referred the subject of the proposed amendment of the United Status Patent Laws, now under consideration by Congress, with the view of memorializing Congress, if thought advisable, made a report, approving a portion of the proposed amendments, and advocating a change in others.
lead_paragraph: At the opening of the regular meeting, last week, Mr. Fisher, Chairman of the Committee to whom was referred the subject of the proposed amendment of the United Status Patent Laws, now under consideration by Congress, with the view of memorializing Congress, if thought advisable, made a report, approving a portion of the proposed amendments, and advocating a change in others. In the opinion of the Committee, the system of models should be abolished, and only such models as, in the discretion of the Commissioner, were thought advisable to have, should be retained in the Patent Office. The model system was at present a great incumbrance to the Patent Office, occupying a great amount of room which should be devoted to other purposes, tending to confuse rather than simplify the transaction of business. Models, in most instances, were entirely useless, and Mr. Fisher himself, although in this particular the Committee did not entirely agree with him, thought that the system of models should be entirely abolished. At present the models not only produced confusion inside of the Patent Office, but it resulted in confusion, annoyance and expense outside of the Patent Office, and among parties interested in patents. One source of confusion arose from the fact that in many instances the models did not agree with the specifications and drawings. The drawings and specifications might perfectly correspond in all points, and a party having only these before him, and unable to inspect the model at Washington, would take his impression as to what was really intended to be patented from these, whereas an inspection of the model might discover something entirely different.

abstract: DOMESTIC TROUBLES AND MURDER. -- The Mobile Mercury says: "We have learned certainly, that the homicide of ENOS TARTT, at the hands of THOMAS SIMMS, on last monday morning, did occur at the said SIMMS' house, six miles west of Sumterville, and eight miles east of Gainesville Junction, on the Mobile and Ohio Railroad. At the last accounts, the coroner was holding an inquest over the body of TARTT. SIMMS made a statement before the jury, from which we infer he made no attempt to evade the law. As told to us his statement ran thus: He said he believed he ought to have killed TARTT three years ago, but lacking positive evidence that his suspicions were well grounded, he did not. On Monday morning, awhile before day, his wife got up out of bed, and was absent about a half an hour. She returned and went to bed again, but presently got up and went out of the house again. He arose and watched her movements cautiously. She went into a clump of bushes in one corner of the enclosure. There he saw her meet with another person, and he attempted to gain another point nearer, which he thought he could approach without being observed, and from which he thought he could hear what might be said, and see what might be done, as well as discover and identify the person she had met. While he was making this movement his wife and the person with her disappeared. Subsequently he met his wife in the house, and she told him that he 'needn't trouble himself about her any longer -- that she was going to leave him and wouldn't live with him any longer; that Mr. TARTT was coming that day and was to carry her away.' He said TARTT drove up to his gate that morning in a buggy, and deliberately got out and hitched his horse and came in. A quarrel ensued, and TARTT got out his knife, and he (SIMMS) got his double-barrel gun and shot him. Our informant says SIMMS desired to make further statements, but his friends insisted he should say no more and restrained him. SIMMS' wife was a witness before the jury, and contradicted her husband's statement, but what her testimony was we could not learn."

A quarrel ensued, and TARTT got out his knife, and he (SIMMS) got his double-barrel gun and shot him.
