abstract: THE MYSTERIOUS MURDER. -- The authorities as yet have failed to unravel the mystery connected with the murder of the unknown female found bruised, gagged and sunk at the York-street Pier in Jersey City on Saturday, the 14th inst. The Coroner's jury are to meet again this (Monday) evening, but as far as can be ascertained no additional facts will come before them, and it is feared the affair will ever remain a mysery to all except those who were directly concerned in the crime.
lead_paragraph: THE MYSTERIOUS MURDER. -- The authorities as yet have failed to unravel the mystery connected with the murder of the unknown female found bruised, gagged and sunk at the York-street Pier in Jersey City on Saturday, the 14th inst. The Coroner's jury are to meet again this (Monday) evening, but as far as can be ascertained no additional facts will come before them, and it is feared the affair will ever remain a mysery to all except those who were directly concerned in the crime.

abstract: I have been requested to meet a number of my friends. Delegates to Charleston, at Richmond, on the 19th inst. Determining not to do so, for obvious reasons, I have come to this city for family purposes alone, on my way to attend to professional duties in Accomac.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON CITY, April 18, 1860.

abstract: We publish in another column the act passed by the Legislature at its late session, providing for the transfer to the City of all lands along the North and East Rivers belonging to the State. abstract: The clipper Andrew Jackson came into port on Saturday afternoon in 89 days and 7 hours from NewYork, thus beating the Flying Cloud, which has hitherto borne the palm for the shortest trip, by six hours. She came in firing rockets and thundering a salute from her deck to the astonished town. The Andrew Jackson is Boston-built, and not a full clipper.

abstract: The announcement in the newspapers of Dr. CHEEVER's intention to lecture on "Northern Strikes and Southern Slavery," and "God's Bill for Unpaid Wages," attracted quite a large audience last evening to the Church of the Puritans. The edifice was well-nigh, if not completely filled. The Doctor's text was taken from the fourth chapter of Paul's Epistle to the Colossians. His discourse mainly turned on the first verse, in which the obligation is imposed on masters to give unto their servants that which is just and equal; knowing that they also have a master in Heaven. He represented this chapter as containing the most terrible denunciations of the sin of Slavery, on the ground that Slavery itself was the most terrible form of extortion. In arguing the point, he claimed that in the primitive days of the Church the exacting of labor, without compensation, was not only unknown but condemned. A Christian man was forbidden to lay the burden of Slavery on any other man. The relation of slaveholding was reprobated in the New Testament as sinful in itself. The crime of manstealing had been set down along with that of murder, as being subject to the penalty of death, and this was taught under the authority of the Gospel itself. No man could be a Christian and a slaveholder. This applied as well to those who oppressed the hireling laborer in the North to help to maintain slavery in the South -- to those who trod down the bleeding hearts of the workers, boys and girls, men and women, so truly described in HOOD's "Song of the Shirt," -- those who, with their incomes of fifty, sixty, or seventy thousand dollars a year, paid away more in a single election to sustain the slave Democracy than they expended in a whole year's clerk hire, -- those who drove their laborer's as remorselessly as a factory does its spindles, compelling them, to his (Dr. CHEEVER's) personal knowledge, to labor into the hours of the Sabbath or so to overtax their powers that the Sabbath must be spent either in sleep or in the reaction of sensual indulgence. If due regard had been had for the dignity and rights of laboring men, as set forth in God's word, there would never have been such a crime as that of Slavery. The reducing of men to Slavery worked like a repressed elemental fire; nay worse, it was a macerating of them into masses in which they could be used as beasts of burden by ambitious despots who, as the instruments of Satan, degraded labor, and deprived it of its rights to knowledge, happiness, and liberty. It was the duty of Christians to obey God and break down the walls of such caste between capital and labor. They should obey God by taking the laborer by the hand, by regarding him as a brother, and by doing so they would pluck from out the world one-half of Satan's means for driving men into perdition. After God's declaration of the parent crime itself, nothing could be more astonishing than the recent declaration of a Christian minister to one of the congregations of this City, and in a Christian assemblage, that the buying and selling of men might be just. God's declaration was this, that either for the buying or selling of a man the offender shall be put unto death. Considered as a matter of natural light, Slavery was a sin, because it was wrong to withhold from a man that which is his due. If his work were worth a dollar a day, and any man withheld a part of that dollar from him, he stole from him just to that amount. Slavery was an act of still greater meanness, for instead of stealing merely a man's wages, it stole himself. "The laborer is worthy of his hire." And again, the Scripture says: "The laborer is worthy of his reward." The man who refused to do this was as bad as King JOHN, who, to extort money from a Jew, pulled a tooth every day from out the Hebrew's head until he complied with his demands. The extortioner was Mentioned among other great sinners as one who could not enter into the kingdom of Heaven. The Christian church would never keep company with the extortioner; it would never tolerate him while he committed such things as the institution of Slavery involved. According to the construction of our national law, by our national tribunal it was impossible to steal anything from the slave, because though as a laborer we owed him his wages, yet as a slave and chattel we, as owning himself, owed him nothing. There could be no possibility of stealing anything from a slave, because he possesses nothing; no possibility of committing adultery against him, because his marriage has no legal force; no hindrance to taking his wife and children from him, because he has no marital rights. Every slaveholder sustained this system with all its horrible concomitants -- its atheism, its debauchery, its brutality; and every church which favored slaveholding upheld it with all these moral enormities. The reverend doctor continued to urge that the Church was everywhere bound to use its utmost endeavors to procure the abolition of Slavery, and alluded incidentally to the sympathy for the abolition cause which had recently been expressed by Dr. CAUDLISH and others, at a public meeting in Edinburgh. He quoted freely from the speech of Mr. O'CONNOR, at the Union meeting in the Academy of Music, and characterizes that gentleman's theory that the natural condition of the colored race in this country is one of pupilage, as a doctrine not only arrogant but impious. He alluded also to the system of Slavery as it affects the commercial economy of the country, and declared that it Slavery were abolished, and the negro paid fair wages as a freeman, the wealth of both the North and South would be doubled. If, he said, such corruption of the heart as that exhibited in the speech to which he referred were not thrown off, it would grow on us; it would become hardened in us; the land would become a region of horror, as if the lizards and snakes of the Pre-Adamite world were crawling over us; the sin would enter into our bones; all the meanness, the fraudulence and the degradations -- all the brutality, the cruelty, the low wickedness, would enter into our character, and we should become a contempt among the nations. The evil influence would bore into us like an augur of solidified sulphuric acid. Did the passage of human enactments in favor of Slavery render it any less a violation of God's law? Did the compound hydraulic ram of legal interpretation diminish the guilt by making it wholesale? Dare the Church of God deny it to be sin, or encourage its existence as a matter of political expediency? Its vested rights were vested devils, assuming the figures of angels.

He quoted freely from the speech of Mr. O'CONNOR, at the Union meeting in the Academy of Music, and characterizes that gentleman's theory that the natural condition of the colored race in this country is one of pupilage, as a doctrine not only arrogant but impious. He alluded also to the system of Slavery as it affects the commercial economy of the country, and declared that it Slavery were abolished, and the negro paid fair wages as a freeman, the wealth of both the North and South would be doubled. If, he said, such corruption of the heart as that exhibited in the speech to which he referred were not thrown off, it would grow on us; it would become hardened in us; the land would become a region of horror, as if the lizards and snakes of the Pre-Adamite world were crawling over us; the sin would enter into our bones; all the meanness, the fraudulence and the degradations -- all the brutality, the cruelty, the low wickedness, would enter into our character, and we should become a contempt among the nations. The evil influence would bore into us like an augur of solidified sulphuric acid. Did the passage of human enactments in favor of Slavery render it any less a violation of God's law? Did the compound hydraulic ram of legal interpretation diminish the guilt by making it wholesale? Dare the Church of God deny it to be sin, or encourage its existence as a matter of political expediency? Its vested rights were vested devils, assuming the figures of angels.

abstract: PROBABLE MURDER. -- Early on Sunday morning, Mr. JOHN WOOD, a respectable citizen of Rossville about 50 years of age, was found lying in a barnyard , about three miles from home. He had received a severe cut across the temple, and his body was much bruised and mangled. The appearance of his clothes gave evidence that he had gone through with a severe struggle, for they were nearly torn from him, and his pockets had been rifled of their contents. Mr. WOOD left home about 8 o'clock on Saturday evening, to purchase a quantity of eggs, and after having accomplished his errand, started for home, stopping on the way at a house in the neighborhood, which he left about 10 o'clock. A spot on the road near where Mr. WOOD was found, was trampled as if there had been a serious contest, and it is generally supposed that the unfortunate man, although he had but little money on his person, was attacked for the purpose of robbery. Mr. WOOD was a temperate and peaceable man, and was much respected by his neighbors. It is doubtful if he survives his injuries. The authorities of Richmond County are making every exertion to detect the perpetrators of the assault.

abstract: The Police Commissioners met yesterday. John Cokeley was dismissed the force for intoxication. The resignations of W.H. Bennett and Richard Austin were received. Mr. BOWEN informed the Board that, under the provisions of the new law, the Sanitary Police had been organized and were at ...
lead_paragraph: The Police Commissioners met yesterday. John Cokeley was dismissed the force for intoxication. The resignations of W.H. Bennett and Richard Austin were received. Mr. BOWEN informed the Board that, under the provisions of the new law, the Sanitary Police had been organized and were at work. Six or eight tenement-house owners were ordered to cleanse their premises on pain of having them cleansed by the authorities -- the cost to be a lien on the property. It is believed by Mr. BOWEN that the sanitary condition of this City will be greatly improved by the action of this force, so as to affect materially the health of the City during the coming Summer. As the law gives the sanitary company and the Police judges summary power to abate all nuisances on ferry-boats, tenement-houses, edifices suspected of being unsafe, manufactories and slaughter-houses, if these powers are exercised in the manner that Mr. BOWEN declares they will be, our City will present a novel spectacle of cleanliness during the coming warm season.

abstract: FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDENTS. -- On Saturday last, as the 7 A.M. Dunkirk Express on the New-York and Erie road was rounding a curve near the Goshen depot, a girl 13 years of age, daughter of RICHARD MCGOWEN, was struck by the locomotive, throwing her some 50 feet and causing injuries that resulted in her death a short time afterwards. The girl was walking on the track for the purpose of ascertains if her father, who is a brakeman, was upon a freight train which was coming in at the time from the opposite direction. An inquest was held and a verdict of accidental death was rendered....At Paterson, the same day, a boy whose name was not ascertained, was killed by attempting to jump upon some cars attached to the drill-engine, but missing his hold, fell under the wheels and was instantly killed.

abstract: The Charleston Convention, "great parent" of Democratic measures and of Democratic men, began its labors yesterday in the manner usual with such bodies by doing nothing, or next to nothing at all.
lead_paragraph: The Charleston Convention, "great parent" of Democratic measures and of Democratic men, began its labors yesterday in the manner usual with such bodies by doing nothing, or next to nothing at all. It contented itself with attacking, without solving the important problem of organization; and if we are to draw any inference from the style of these preliminary proceedings to the future of the Democratic canvass, in the coming Presidential contest, the final organization of the Convention will only be accomplished at the expense of the disorganization of the party itself. The National Committee, indeed, preserved yesterday the outward forms of discipline, and carried the body of the Convention, with its own programme, against the stormy remonstrances of a clamorous section. The regular delegations from New-York and Illinois were confirmed in the provisional possession of the floor, to which the Committee had admitted them, but excluded from action upon the organization of the Convention; and the attempts of one or two "Wise men" from Virginia to force a letter from Mayor WOOD upon the consideration of the inchoate body were defeated, Hon. JOHN COCHRANE, of this City, battling stoutly against them. But the temper in which these attempts were made and met was anything but "harmonious," and prefigures an intensity of personal animosity in the decisive struggle for the nomination, never before exhibited so openly in any national gathering of the Democracy.

abstract: An inquest upon the body of THOMAS GREENAN, the man who was stabbed in a street encounter with CHARLES ROBERT, a young German, at the corner of Orchard and Canal streets, was held yesterday by Coroner JACKMAN. JOHN CRINNION, the friend of deceased, deposed that in passing down Orchard-street,
lead_paragraph: An inquest upon the body of THOMAS GREENAN, the man who was stabbed in a street encounter with CHARLES ROBERT, a young German, at the corner of Orchard and Canal streets, was held yesterday by Coroner JACKMAN. JOHN CRINNION, the friend of deceased, deposed that in passing down Orchard-street, about 12 o'clock on Saturday night, deceased jostled against one of three men who were approaching from the opposite direction, whereupon a fight ensued, during which both fell upon the walk, and when deceased got up he cried, "I'm stabbed." SAMUEL CALHOUN testified that he saw ROBERT soon after the affray occurred, standing at the doorway of a saloon near the corner of Canal and Orchard streets, and heard him remark, "Me kill a man." Very soon afterwards an officer came up and took the prisoner into custody, and when they reached the Station-house he claimed an umbrella that had been found at the scene of the affray. Officer WRIGHT, who apprehended the prisoner, deposed that a rag and some small change found in his pockets were covered with blood, and the lining of the pockets also had red spots upon it. PETER and GILBERT GAYLER, both Germans, swore that they were in the prisoner's company, at the corner of Canal and Orchard streets, at the time of the affray, when deceased and another person came up and said to ROBERT, "Hallo, Bub!" and offered to fight him. Finally, deceased struck the prisoner, and the two clinched, both falling to the ground in the struggle. They saw no knives drawn, but went away before the fight had terminated. The testimony of Drs. GALLAGHER and BEACH, who made the post mortem examination, was then taken, when the case was given to the jury, who soon returned a verdict that "Deceased came to his death by wounds inflicted with some instrument by CHARLES ROBERT, while engaged in a street fight, on the 21st of April, 1860. The prisoner is 21 years of age, and resides at the corner of Orchard and Division streets. He persistently denies his guilt. At the conclusion of the inquest the Coroner committed him to prison.

abstract: The National Democratic Convention, embodying full delegations from all the States, met yesterday at Charleston. It was called to order by Judge SMALLEY, Chairman of the National Committee, who nominated FRANCIS B. FLOURNOY, of Arkansas, temporary Chairman. Mr. FLOURNOY was chosen by acclamation; and, with equal una- ...
lead_paragraph: The National Democratic Convention, embodying full delegations from all the States, met yesterday at Charleston. It was called to order by Judge SMALLEY, Chairman of the National Committee, who nominated FRANCIS B. FLOURNOY, of Arkansas, temporary Chairman. Mr. FLOURNOY was chosen by acclamation; and, with equal unanimity, WILLIAM F. RITCHIE, of Virginia, was made Secretary. After prayer, Mr. FISHER, of Virginia, arose, proposing to read a letter from the Wood Party, explanatory of their claims. He encountered the opposition of Mr. COCHRANE, of New-York, who, after a severe struggle, succeeded in obtaining the floor, and defeating the attempt of Mr. FISHER. A resolution requesting the Chairman to nominate a Committee upon Credentials was then adopted. Upon a resolution to exclude the New-York Tammany delegates from the Committee, a vote was taken, which resulted 44 Ayes to 241 Noes. A vote requesting them to refrain from participation, in the proceedings until the Committee had reported, was rejected by a vote almost identical. These votes are regarded as indicating the strength of Mr. DOUGLAS in the Convention; and as predetermining the nomination. The Convention adjourned to meet this morning at 10 o'clock. It is understood that a portion of the men only from Georgia, Alabama, and Louisiana, are preparing to bolt, and name a straight-out Southern candidate. The Committee on Credentials was in busy session last evening. Among documents submitted to it, was a protest of Mr. FERNANDO WOOD against the admission of the Soft delegation.

abstract: There is a bill before Congress to amend the Patent Laws. There is room for vital change and improvement, and few public measures are of greater importance, since a comprehensive, reliable and healthy system of protecting inventions lies at the foundation of the success of a commercial age. It is proposed to dis-
lead_paragraph: There is a bill before Congress to amend the Patent Laws. There is room for vital change and improvement, and few public measures are of greater importance, since a comprehensive, reliable and healthy system of protecting inventions lies at the foundation of the success of a commercial age. It is proposed to dispense with models, whenever the Commissioner can do without them. Now since models do not always agree with the specifications and drawings, they are frequently a source of inconvenience to those searching after the whole truth, as in case of patent suits; and since drawings and specifications can and should thoroughly define inventions in a more complete and imperishable form, models are positively useless, -- their cost being probably greater on the average than that of specifications, drawings and Government fees, they are an unnecessary tax on inventors; and as they are not portable, what information they do give is at the cost of a journey from the antipodes, it maybe, to Washington. They are useless and inconvenient lumber in the office, and for each of the reasons stated they should be abolished altogether.
headline: {'main': 'The Patent Laws.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Patent Laws.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The whole weight of European diplomacy in Mexico seems to have been thrown into the scale of priestcraft and tyranny. When Mr. McLANE, a year ago, recognized the JUAREZ Government, as both de jure and de facto in possession of power, it seemed almost certain that the representatives of foreign Powers would yield to the pressure of events, and take steps for the protection of their own citizens who were living in Mexico.
lead_paragraph: The whole weight of European diplomacy in Mexico seems to have been thrown into the scale of priestcraft and tyranny. When Mr. McLANE, a year ago, recognized the JUAREZ Government, as both de jure and de facto in possession of power, it seemed almost certain that the representatives of foreign Powers would yield to the pressure of events, and take steps for the protection of their own citizens who were living in Mexico. This expectation has been disappointed, and we see all the Ministers from European States doing their utmost to crush the Liberal cause.

abstract: To the eternal memory of this matter. As the Catholic Church, founded and established by the Lord Christ for the everlasting salvation of mankind, has acquired the form of a perfect society by its divine character, it ought, therefore, in fulfillment of its sacred ministry, to possess that freedom by which it may not be subject to any civil Power.
lead_paragraph: To the eternal memory of this matter. As the Catholic Church, founded and established by the Lord Christ for the everlasting salvation of mankind, has acquired the form of a perfect society by its divine character, it ought, therefore, in fulfillment of its sacred ministry, to possess that freedom by which it may not be subject to any civil Power. And furthermore, in order to obtain that, the Church required those guarantees which were in accordance with the conditions and necessity of the times. It was, therefore, in accordance with Divine Providence, that after the fall of the Roman Empire and its consecutive division into several kingdoms, the Romish Pope, whom Christ has established as the chief and the centre of his whole Church, obtained temporal power. Therefore, it has been ordered by God in the wisest manner, that as such a great number and variety of princes exist, the Holy Pope should enjoy that political liberty which is so much wanted in order to exercise his spiritual power, authority and jurisdiction in the whole world, without any impediments. And, therefore, it was necessary that the Catholic world should not have any reason to suppose that the Romish Pope is subject to any influence of temporal powers, or biassed in the exercise of the religious powers which the Holy See has to fulfill over the greater part of the Christians. It is easily understood that the dominion of our Roman Church, although having the appearance of something temporal, nevertheless is really of a spiritual character, by the holy distinction which it enjoys, and by the close ties by which it is connected with all Christian affairs. But this does not prevent that all these things which conduce to the secular welfare of the peoples may be obtained by the Church, as the history of the temporal reign of the Roman Popes during so many centuries shows most clearly. The general good and welfare of the peoples being increased by the temporal power which we are alluding to, it is not astonishing that the enemies of this Church endeavor to weaken and to embarrass it by many intrigues and all kinds of attempts.

abstract: SERMONS FROM STONES.--Rev. WILLIAM ALVIN  BARTLETT, of the Brooklyn Tabernacle, last Sunday evening preached a sermon to his people from Exodus, XII., 41. His subject was: Moving, as Means of Christian Discipline. He illustrated the great princi-
lead_paragraph: SERMONS FROM STONES.--Rev. WILLIAM ALVIN BARTLETT, of the Brooklyn Tabernacle, last Sunday evening preached a sermon to his people from Exodus, XII., 41. His subject was: Moving, as Means of Christian Discipline. He illustrated the great principle of motion in the Universe, dwelt upon the necessity of activity in the Church, and then narrowed his theme to the present day and time, drawing from the great moving-day of Israel eloquent lessons for those of his congregation who were about to "rehearse Exodus."

What a pity that the "girls" and "women" who throng our streets by night, with painted ...
lead_paragraph: -- The intrinsic worth of woman is fully appreciated in Richmond, Va. From the report of a late auction sale we learn that the black "fair sex" were valued and sold as follows: Girls, 13 to 14 years old, $1,150 to $1,200; women, $1,200 to $,300. What a pity that the "girls" and "women" who throng our streets by night, with painted faces, had not colored their faces black instead of imitating the hues of the lily and rose, and transported themselves to Richmond before entering upon a life of shame. It would have saved them the sad necessity of staining their souls.

abstract: FEMALE SYMPATHY FOR LYNN. A mass-meeting of the working-girls of New-York was advertised to be held at Botanic Hall, in East Broadway, last evening, to express sympathy for their sister-strikers of Lynn, but the small number who answered the call ...
lead_paragraph: FEMALE SYMPATHY FOR LYNN. A mass-meeting of the working-girls of New-York was advertised to be held at Botanic Hall, in East Broadway, last evening, to express sympathy for their sister-strikers of Lynn, but the small number who answered the call would seem to indicate that Lynn, like Africa, had come to be regarded by the "masses" a bore. Only twenty-two girls were in attendance, who occupied the front seats, and were supported in the rear by about half the number of boys, who had come to see the fun. Mr. JAS. MOORE appointed CHAS. MCCARTHY Chairman, and Mr. MCCARTHY returned the compliment by appointing Mr. MOORE Secretary. Mr. MCCARTHY stated the object of the meeting, and repeated the substance of his speech delivered while acting as Chairman of the Workingmen's Sympathy Meeting at the Cooper Institute. In answer to repeated calls for a speech from the ladies, Mrs. HAGUE, an interesting looking, middle-aged woman, made some very sensible remarks, expressing her belief that the appropriate sphere of woman was in domestic and household work, but that when from the death or neglect of her husband she was compelled to enter another field of labor, she was entitled to the highest wages. A resolution was then adopted, expressing the sympathy of the meeting for the Lynn sisters, and appointing the following Committee to collect subscriptions in their aid: Mrs. Hague, Miss Nugent, Mrs. Johnson, Miss Seymour, Miss Fitzgerald, Miss McCarthy, two Misses Pearl, Mrs. J. Moore. A collection was taken up amounting to $1 33, and the meeting adjourned to meet at the same place on Monday night next.

abstract: A large number of persons were yesterday examined by Coroner SCHIRMER at the inquest upon the body of HENRY DEDRICKSON, the Swedish sailor, who died at the New-York Hospital on Monday, in consequence of having been severely wounded in the head with a slung-shot or other instrument by a party of sailors, who attacked him at the corner of Washington and Carlisle streets. None of the witnesses, however, could identify MURPHY, GREEENWOOD, WILLIAMS and MOSS, the sailors under arrest, as having been implicated in the homicide, and therefore they were discharged from custody. From the testimony of JAMES RAY, keeper of a boarding-house at No. 8 Carlisle-street, it is believed that two men, called JAMES FARRELL and "Scotty," who were apprehended on suspicion, but discharged for lack of evidence, and who subsequently went to sea, are the parties who inflicted the injuries, and the Jury returned a verdict that death had resulted "from injuries received on the 7th day of April, 1860, at the hands of some persons or person unknown." To this, they added, "we suspect that JAMES FARRELL and WILLIAM -- , alias 'Scotty,' are implicated either as principals or accessories to his death." The Coroner issued his warrant for the arrest of the accused.
lead_paragraph: A large number of persons were yesterday examined by Coroner SCHIRMER at the inquest upon the body of HENRY DEDRICKSON, the Swedish sailor, who died at the New-York Hospital on Monday, in consequence of having been severely wounded in the head with a slung-shot or other instrument by a party of sailors, who attacked him at the corner of Washington and Carlisle streets. None of the witnesses, however, could identify MURPHY, GREEENWOOD, WILLIAMS and MOSS, the sailors under arrest, as having been implicated in the homicide, and therefore they were discharged from custody. From the testimony of JAMES RAY, keeper of a boarding-house at No. 8 Carlisle-street, it is believed that two men, called JAMES FARRELL and "Scotty," who were apprehended on suspicion, but discharged for lack of evidence, and who subsequently went to sea, are the parties who inflicted the injuries, and the Jury returned a verdict that death had resulted "from injuries received on the 7th day of April, 1860, at the hands of some persons or person unknown." To this, they added, "we suspect that JAMES FARRELL and WILLIAM -- , alias 'Scotty,' are implicated either as principals or accessories to his death." abstract: We are sorry to see that the Board of Aldermen are preparing themselves for the reception of the Japanese Embassy, and still sorrier to find that they are intent upon showing them the " Institutions." lead_paragraph: We are sorry to see that the Board of Aldermen are preparing themselves for the reception of the Japanese Embassy, and still sorrier to find that they are intent upon showing them the " Institutions." The public is so familiar with what an Alderman means when he talks of showing anybody the "Institutions" of the City, that it is unnecessary for us to explain it further than to repeat that our "Institutions," in Aldermanic parlance, include at least all the dirty and disagreeable places within the Municipal boundary. This practice of carting off all strangers to Blackwell's Island, and treating them to a minute inspection of the blotches and sores of our civilization, arose under a regime which, it is to be hoped, has now passed away. In the days of the Ten Governors, and in the old time before them, a tour of the "Institutions" meant a day of free whisky, and gratuitous cigars, and a general carouse, at the public expense. When a visit to the Island, in charge of distinguished foreigners, meant a day's eating and drinking, and boating, and joking with paupers, lunatics and convicts, we can hardly wonder that no stranger was ever allowed to escape the infliction. But the gentlemen now in charge of the "Institutions" have, it is to be hoped, taken measures to render the "Island" a less attractive resort for merry-making Committees of Reception than it used to be; and we hope, therefore, that a visit to the jails and hospitals of that savory locality will be left out of the list of tortures which are preparing for the unfortunate Japanese. When it is proposed to accord a public welcome to a stranger, one would think that even an Alderman might see the propriety of taking him to see nothing but a pleasant sight in itself -- of forcing upon him none but agreable thoughts and associations -- of exhibiting to him, in short, our best and brightest side, and not our worst and darkest. When a private individual welcomes a guest to his house, he puts on his best clothes, receives him in his best rooms, spreads before him his best fare and keeps him clear of everything that may be repulsive or unsightly. He never thinks of producing the dirty linen or spreading it out before him in the parlor, or of inviting him to peep into the sewer, or make an inspection of the kitchen sink, or an examination of his children down with the measles. All highly civilized communities should act upon the same rule in their corporate capacity. When a distinguished stranger visits Paris he is treated to a sight of all that is most wonderful, most glorious and most beautiful in the great capital. He is led through the picture galleries and the palaces. He is taken to drive, and hunt and shoot in the imperial parks and forests. He has his imagination fired by the sight of noble historic monuments. On the Champ de Mars he is shown the finest soldiers in the world defiling in all the pomp and pride and circumstance of matchless discipline and efficiency. If he is asked at all to visit scenes in which decrepitude, decay and disease are the most prominent features, it is where decrepitude, decay and disease call up the stirring memories of a heroic epoch, and where they are inseparably associated with the greatness and glory of France. If he enters an hospital at all, as an unsought courtesy, it is the great asylum which shelters the last relics of a grand generation, the oldest heroes of a nation of soldiers. In like manner, if he crosses the channel to London he visits the cathedrals, the Houses of Parliament, the royal palaces, the parks, the tower, and is complimented with a review on Woolwich Common. But in neither case does it enter into anybody's head to drag him to the retreats which society has in self-defence or in pity provided for vice and suffering. He is not led by the nose, under pretence of doing him a kindness, to inspect the cells and wards in which thieves and prostitutes expiate their wickedness, or in which friendless lunacy is left to rave and chatter. There are persons, no doubt, who, from philanthropic or other honorable motives, may desire to visit such scenes, but a polite host only reveals them on the visitor's own request.

abstract: The proprietors of this wonderful invention, which is now in successful operation in the cities of Boston, St. Louis and Baltimore, and is about to be introduced in New Orleans, gave an exhibition of its workings at Tammany Hall yesterday, to a large, number of invited guests, including both branches of the City Government, members of the Press, and others. The exhibition was entirely successful, and the superiority of this telegraph over all others in use for the same purpose, was made apparent to all. As the exhibition is to be open to the public for several days, during which all our citizens who feel an interest in the subject will have an opportunity to witness its operations for themselves, an extended description of it is unnecessary. Suffice it to say, that by means of this telegraph the exact location of a fire breaking out in any district in the City may be made known to all the firemen of that district, or of any or all other districts, or even to every inhabitant of the City, if necessary, within five minutes from the time it is discovered by the persons in the house where it originates. The alarm is first given to the head-quarters of the telegraph, by turning a crank in a box stationed nearest to the fire, (these boxes may be placed on every block,) and thence spread over the whole City, if necessary, by telegraphic wires, which connect with the tower bells of each District, with gongs at every engine-house, and also with small bells inside of every alarm-box -- any one of which, or all together, may be set to ringing instantaneously by the man in attendance at head-quarters. The gongs at the engine-houses, and the bells in the alarm-boxes, are not of such magnitude as to be a nuisance on account of their noise, for the first would not be heard outside the engine-houses, and the last can only be heard by putting the ear to the box; but their object is to enable all firemen, and such other citizens as desire the information, to ascertain the exact locality of a fire before running in pursuit of it. So with regard to the tower bells: the telegraph is enabled to ring them all simultaneously if necessary, but in ordinary cases only the bell of the District in which the fire is located would be set in motion. The locality of the fire is indicated by the number of strokes on the small bells in the alarm-boxes. Equal facilities are afforded to the Police Department by these alarm boxes, in enabling any policeman to call for assistance at any given point, and also to indicate the amount of help required. The whole apparatus is extremely simple, not liable to get out of order, and does its work with a rapidity, precision and certainty truly astonishing. It has one serious objection, however, which will probably prevent its ever being introduced into this City. It dispenses with the services of bell-ringers, and would thus deprive several friends ??? our Aldermen and Councilmen of positions worth ??? per annum.

abstract: The Democracy at Charleston are rapidly "settling to their work." They yesterday completed their organization, selecting Hon. CALEB CUSHING as their permanent Chairman, and appointing a Committee to draw up the platform on which they propose to stand or fall in the coming contest.
lead_paragraph: The Democracy at Charleston are rapidly "settling to their work." They yesterday completed their organization, selecting Hon. CALEB CUSHING as their permanent Chairman, and appointing a Committee to draw up the platform on which they propose to stand or fall in the coming contest. The nomination of General CUSHING so far indicates a brightening prospect of harmony in the party, that the illustrious orator of Massachusetts belongs to the ornamental staff rather than to any active division of the Democratic host. He is a disciple of the school of the Vicar of Bray, and represents the flesh-pots of Egypt rather than any section or faction fanatically bent on a victory or an exodus of principle. That he should have been chosen to preside over the Convention, shows that the "cohesive force of the public plunder" has not been absolutely paralyzed by the explosive force of sectional fanaticisms or personal animosities. The unprecedented adoption of a rule deferring all ballots for the Presidential nomination till the platform of the party shall have been squared and settled, is an unmistakable concession to the demands of the friends of Mr. DOUGLAS; and the vote by which it was also resolved that no majority of a delegation should have power to utter the voice of the State as a unit, unless in obedience to instructions given by the State Convention which appointed the delegation, if it be not a victory of the Douglas men, is at least a defeat of the so-called coalition of the Administration with the South. The front of this coalition is evidently broken. Whether it will be successfully rallied, upon the decisive battle over the platform, remains to be seen; but the proceedings of the Convention, up to this moment, while they do not, indeed, decisively prefigure the final harmony of the Democracy, very plainly intimate an impending defeat of the extreme Southern policy. A volunteer champion of this policy, indeed -- Mr. JOSIAH RANDALL, of Philadelphia, long a leading Whig, and lately made famous by his declaration to Mr. COBDEN that he "had never known corruption to be used in an American election" -- seems to have been severely disciplined yesterday by Mr. RICHARDSON, of Illinois, with the pretty general applause of the Convention.

abstract: FIRES. -- At about 11 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the upper part of R.J. TODD's furniture store, No. 90 Fulton-street, caused by a defective flue. The firemen turned out promptly and extinguished the fire before much damage was done. Mr. TODD's store and No. 92 adjoining, occupied by I.D. MCCLOSKEY, were flooded with water, damaging property to the value of about $500....Late Monday night, house No. 32 Dean-street, occupied by STEPHEN WHALEN, was set on fire by the explosion of a fluid lamp, doing about $200 worth of damage.

abstract: The Democratic National Convention was permanently organized yesterday, Mr. CALEB CUSHING, of Massachusetts, being the Permanent Chairman, aided by an army of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries. The Committee upon Organization reported as an additional rule, that individual members of uninstructed delegations may vote independently. A sharp contest ensued over this innovation, which was designed to set at liberty certain Douglas...
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Convention was permanently organized yesterday, Mr. CALEB CUSHING, of Massachusetts, being the Permanent Chairman, aided by an army of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries. The Committee upon Organization reported as an additional rule, that individual members of uninstructed delegations may vote independently. A sharp contest ensued over this innovation, which was designed to set at liberty certain Douglas votes from Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and elsewhere, otherwise overwhelmed by an unfriendly majority. Mr. JOSIAH RANDALL, a fragment from Old-Line Whiggery, opposed the new rule vehemently, exposing himself to a severe rebuke from Mr. RICHARDSON, of Illinois, for laying down laws to a party of which he is so recent a member. The personal altercation caused for a moment great excitement. A vote having been taken upon the motion to table the rule, the motion failed, ayes 101, noes 198. The rule was then adopted. An amendment to the resolution appointing a Committee upon the platform, declaring that no ballot shall be had until the Committee shall have reported, was offered, and after the Committee (whose names the telegraph fails to send us,) had been appointed, it was moved that the amendment be tabled. The motion was negatived, ayes 32 1/2, noes 270 1/2, and the amendment was unanimously accepted. A proposition to limit the time to be consumed by each member in speaking upon any question, occasioned some debate, but was finally postponed. Judge MEEK, of Alabama, submitted the platform adopted by the Convention of his State. It was referred to the Committee upon the Platform. The Committee upon Credentials announced that it would report this morning, and the Convention accordingly adjourned to 10 A.M. to-day.

abstract: -- At the Newmarket Craven meeting, Mr. TEN BROECK's Pomona beat Desdemona by three-quarters of a length, in a race of five furlongs and 140 yards. At a subsequent sweep-stakes, Mr. TEN BROECK's Maggiore came in second in a heat of three furlongs and 217 yards, having been beaten by Mr. ALEXANDER's Thunderbolt. In the former match, Desdemona led half way up to the cords, when Pomona collared her.
lead_paragraph: -- At the Newmarket Craven meeting, Mr. TEN BROECK's Pomona beat Desdemona by three-quarters of a length, in a race of five furlongs and 140 yards. abstract: J.C. Van Loon, Guardian, &c., vs. The Hartem Railroad Company. -- This is an action to recover for injuries sustained by Michael Giffon, a lad about six or seven years old, and a ward of the plaintiff. The complaint states that on October 10, 1857, the cars of defendants were being driven to their depot in this City by horses, and as they were in the neighborhood of the Tombs in Centre-street, the lad was knocked down and so injured in his leg, that amputation was necessary. The plaintiff alleges that the cars were proceeding at an unwarrantable rate, and that it was wholly from this fact and the negligence of those having them in charge, that the child was injured.

abstract: The Convention at Charleston made material progress in business yesterday. After some discussion, the rule limiting the speeches to fifteen minutes' duration was adopted. An exception was introduced in favor of discussion upon the Platform, where an hour's grace is to be given. In the course of the morning the Committee on the Platform decided, in deference to Southern members who objected to its ambiguity, not to...
lead_paragraph: The Convention at Charleston made material progress in business yesterday. After some discussion, the rule limiting the speeches to fifteen minutes' duration was adopted. An exception was introduced in favor of discussion upon the Platform, where an hour's grace is to be given. In the course of the morning the Committee on the Platform decided, in deference to Southern members who objected to its ambiguity, not to readopt the Cincinnati Resolutions; the vote -- 17 to 15. At the afternoon session, the Committee upon Credentials presented its report. In regard to contested seats, it admitted to the Convention the Richmond delegation from New-York, the Richardson delegation from Illinois, with Messrs. Doherty and Chapin, Douglas contestants from Massachusetts, and Messrs. Lanahan and Brandt, Douglas contestants from Maryland. A report from a minority, consisting of the Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, Texas, Arkansas and California members, proposed to give seats to one-half of each New-York delegation, each half to cast seventeen votes. The reports having been read, Mr. BROOKS, of Alabama, and of course of the minority, proceeded to sustain its report. He was followed by Mr. WHITLEY, of Delaware, on the majority side, in a speech of effective strength. Mr. BARRY, of Mississippi, then spoke for the minority report in a harangue of much bitterness. The previous question was then demanded, and the minority report rejected, by a vote of 210 to 55. The negative vote was composed of the entire delegations of Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi and Texas, with portions of those from Virginia, North Carolina, Missouri and California. South Carolina, it will be observed, supported the majority report; as did also Florida and Louisiana. The vote was understood to decide the question as to the nomination; and Mr. DOUGLAS is now regarded as the inevitable candidate, -- none but the Southern ultraists, whose extreme strength is denoted by the minority vote on the delegations, having any further purpose of opposition. The Platform Committee is expected to report to-day, and then the first ballot will doubtless remove all doubt. The Convention, after deferring the appointment of the Executive Committee and passing resolutions of respect to the memory of Gov. ROBINSON of the Vermont delegation, who died suddenly on Tuesday night of apoplexy, adjourned at 7 P.M.

abstract: The Courier and Enquirer announces the discovery of a new silver-lead mine in Pennsylvania, "within eight hours' ride of the City of New-York," the ore from which has been examined, among other "reliable men," by Prof. TORREY of the Assay-office, and found to yield silver to the value of "three times the rich placers of Arizona."
lead_paragraph: The Courier and Enquirer announces the discovery of a new silver-lead mine in Pennsylvania, "within eight hours' ride of the City of New-York," the ore from which has been examined, among other "reliable men," by Prof. TORREY of the Assay-office, and found to yield silver to the value of "three times the rich placers of Arizona." We are delighted to hear of this discovery, and can only hope that it will not stimulate our neighbors of Pennsylvania to demand a prohibitive duty on the importation of silver from abroad. But the Courier and Enquirer, after stating its facts, goes on to put the following query:

abstract: Last night, just before 12 o'clock, an encounter took place in the liquor store of PATRICK MULLEN, No. 107 Bayard-street, corner of Baxter, between JOHN MCGOWAN, a carman in the employ of the Croton Aqueduct Department, and JOHN MCANDREW, a laborer, who is unknown to the police of the Ward. MCGOWAN, who lives in the upper part of the building where the affray occurred, had been drinking all the evening, and in company with his friend JAMES FOLEY, a clerk in a neighboring grocery, went into the bar-room in question to take a parting drink before going to bed. They had been served with their liquor, and were about to leave the premises, when MCANDREW and one THOMAS KELDY entered and called for some refreshments at the bar. While MULLEN was mixing their drinks, MCANDREW made a remark, which was not heard by the barkeeper, but which induced MCGOWAN to inquire if it referred to him. MCANEREW denied that it did, but his statement failed to satisfy his interrogator, who immediately seized him by the collar and a scuffle ensued. MULLEN leaped over the bar to separate the antagonists, but ere he could accomplish his purpose, MCGOWAN fell to the floor, stabbed in two places, the severer wound being just over the apex of the heart, and penetrating to a depth of two inches, while the other was below the left nipple. The noise of the altercation attracted Officer CADDELL, of the Sixth Precinct, who at once secured MCANDREW, and took him to the Station-house, not, however, without an unsuccessful attempt at rescue on the part of his friend KELDY, who was subsequently taken into custody and locked up for his pains. The wounded man was taken to the Station house and his wounds examined by a physician, who stared that the patient was cying from internal hemorrhage, after which he was removed to the City Hospital.

abstract: Mayor WOOD's fillibustering expedition to Charleston has come to an unhappy end. He has been refused admittance to the Conven-- tion by a very decisive vote. In the Committee on Credentials his claims were supported by only six States,--and these the most remote from New-York, and, therefore, the least likely to have any accurate knowledge of the facts which those claims involved.
lead_paragraph: Mayor WOOD's fillibustering expedition to Charleston has come to an unhappy end. He has been refused admittance to the Conven-- tion by a very decisive vote. In the Committee on Credentials his claims were supported by only six States,--and these the most remote from New-York, and, therefore, the least likely to have any accurate knowledge of the facts which those claims involved. We presume that facts had very little to do with the votes of these delegations. They had a general impression that WOOD was more of a Pro-Slavery man than his opponents, and that he would be more likely to vote according to their wishes upon the platform and the candidate; and that was all the information they cared for in the premises.

abstract: SUPPOSED SUICIDE BY SHOOTING.--The body of an unknown man, apparently a German about 30 years of age, was found yesterday afternoon lying at the foot of the hill leading to West Hoboken, under circumstances which leads to the supposition that he had committed suicide by shooting.
lead_paragraph: SUPPOSED SUICIDE BY SHOOTING.--The body of an unknown man, apparently a German about 30 years of age, was found yesterday afternoon lying at the foot of the hill leading to West Hoboken, under circumstances which leads to the supposition that he had committed suicide by shooting. Upon examination, it was found that a bullet had entered the mouth passing out at the back of the head. Deceased was about five feet six inches in height; had black hair, heavy sandy whiskers and monstaches, and dark blue eyes. He had on a brown overcoat, black vest, light cassimere pants, and a pair of boots with a hole cut on the side of one of the insteps. On his person was found powder and bullets, a silver watch, two brass and three iron keys, and a blue pocket handkerchief, with white spots. An inquest will be held to-day.

abstract: Louis Samson, an English lad, about 16 years of age, represented to Mr. George Bergman, of No.66  Nassau-street, that his employers, Messrs. Sickles  Kling, of No. 450 Grand-street, had sent him for a set of jewelry, valued at $92. Soon after he had obtained it he pawned a portion for $5, and offered to sell the balance at such a low price that he was arrested on suspicion of having stolen it.
lead_paragraph: Louis Samson, an English lad, about 16 years of age, represented to Mr. George Bergman, of No.66 Nassau-street, that his employers, Messrs. Sickles Kling, of No. 450 Grand-street, had sent him for a set of jewelry, valued at $92. Soon after he had obtained it he pawned a portion for $5, and offered to sell the balance at such a low price that he was arrested on suspicion of having stolen it. When taken before Justice CONNOLLY, he stated that a desire to make a present to a young lady impelled him to commit the crime, but that this was the first dishonest transaction in which he had engaged. He was committed to answer a charge of attempting to obtain goods by false pretences.

abstract: The schooner Sarah Burton, at Boston, and the brig Baltimore, at this port, bring advices from St. Marks, Hayti, to the 16th. They report that on the 8th inst., a very heavy shock of an earthquake was felt at that place. Several buildings were thrown down and much damage done in different parts of the town. Up to the 12th inst. several slight shocks had occurred, which so alarmed the inhabitants that they abandoned the houses and slept in the street. It was supposed that a large amount of damage was sustained in other parts of the Island. The shocks were felt on board the vessels lying in the harbor, causing their masts to shake violently.
lead_paragraph: The schooner Sarah Burton, at Boston, and the brig Baltimore, at this port, bring advices from St. Marks, Hayti, to the 16th. They report that on the 8th inst., a very heavy shock of an earthquake was felt at that place. Several buildings were thrown down and much damage done in different parts of the town. abstract: Inquests were yesterday held by Coroners SCHIEMER and JACKMAN upon the bodies of five persons who had been found within the previous forty-eight hours, in the East and North Rivers, only one of which, that of MARY ANN McCUTCHEON, a widow woman, 55 years of age, who has been missing since last Thanksgiving Day, was recognized.
lead_paragraph: Inquests were yesterday held by Coroners SCHIEMER and JACKMAN upon the bodies of five persons who had been found within the previous forty-eight hours, in the East and North Rivers, only one of which, that of MARY ANN McCUTCHEON, a widow woman, 55 years of age, who has been missing since last Thanksgiving Day, was recognized. The other bodies were those of a young colored man, found at the foot of Murray-street, who had apparently been in the water at least three months; a white man, about 40 years of age, who, from the fact that a thimble, needles, and thread were found in his pockets, is supposed to have been a tailor; a young man, of respectable appearance, taken from the oyster-slip, at the foot of Spring-street, and a colored man, aged about 36 years, found at Pier No. 50 East River. As no wounds were visible on the remains, a verdict of death from "supposed drowning" was rendered in each case.

abstract: The friends and patrons of the Prize Ring' cannot be expected to be particularly familiar with the Scriptures. Perhaps, if they were so they might find other prizes of a higher calling than the Champion's belt, more worthy the consideration of a civilized man. Certainly, if they were so, they would not have been so easily taken in and done for as they yesterday evening were, by a deceitful Spirit of the Times, pretending to...
lead_paragraph: The friends and patrons of the Prize Ring' cannot be expected to be particularly familiar with the Scriptures. Perhaps, if they were so they might find other prizes of a higher calling than the Champion's belt, more worthy the consideration of a civilized man. Certainly, if they were so, they would not have been so easily taken in and done for as they yesterday evening were, by a deceitful Spirit of the Times, pretending to be the true Spirit of Mr. GEORGE WILKES, speaking the truth as to the "Great Fight" all the way across the Atlantic. The beloved apostle would have reminded them to "believe not every spirit, but try the spirits: because many false prophets are gone out into the world." The true profits in this case went into the pockets of a small army of newsboys, and of some subtle rival of the enterprising WILKES, who issued, just after nightfall, an elaborate "Extra," purporting to contain a "special report" from the steamer Vanderbilt, off Cape Race, of the tremendous contest between HEENAN and SAYERS, which had taken place on the 16th inst. at Mildenhall, in Suffolk; had lasted one hour and ten minutes, and had resulted, after a "hard fought battle," in the victory of the Benicia Boy, who "forever polished off the gallant TOM, and snatched the double Championship of Two Hemispheres."
headline: {'main': 'A False Spirit on the Fight.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A False Spirit on the Fight.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Education, last evening, the School Officers of the Fifth Ward asked for an appropriation of $500, out of the Seth Grosvenor bequest, for the purpose of fitting up a School Library in their Ward. The communication was referred.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Education, last evening, the School Officers of the Fifth Ward asked for an appropriation of $500, out of the Seth Grosvenor bequest, for the purpose of fitting up a School Library in their Ward. The communication was referred. The Officers of the Twenty-first Ward sent in a memorial relative to building the new schoolhouse in Twenty-seventh-street. The Board, at a former meeting, resolved to insert, between the iron beams, additional wood-work. The local Board now ask that that resolution be rescinded, and that the Board of Education order the building to be completed as proposed by the architect. The memorial was accepted as an amendment to the resolution, and, as amended, was adopted.

abstract: If there were nothing else about Slavery and the Anti-Slavery agitation that everybody  must see with regret and foreboding, their influence upon the Courts and judicial decisions would furnish ample cause for anxiety and alarm. The conflict between the supporters and opponents of the institution" has even...
lead_paragraph: If there were nothing else about Slavery and the Anti-Slavery agitation that everybody must see with regret and foreboding, their influence upon the Courts and judicial decisions would furnish ample cause for anxiety and alarm. The conflict between the supporters and opponents of the institution" has even reached such a pitch of excitement and exasperation that the judges are gradually giving way to the pressure of one side or other, and ceasing even to pretend to administer the law as they find it, or to stand by the old rules of interpretation in any case in which the interests of slaveholders are involved. It would be a waste of our space to cite in support of this assertion the rulings of Southern Courts on the trial of Abolitionists, or Anti-Slavery men, or Slave-traders. In more than one of what Mr. SEWARD chooses to call the "capital States," judges have repudiated the authority of all previous decisions in Slave cases, not on the ground of their unsoundness in point of law, but because the public opinion of the district had changed since they were made. The effect of this monstrous doctrine upon the rights of free negroes, upon the emancipation of slaves by will -- a practice once so common -- and more recently upon the revival of the Slave trade, is something with which most of our readers are tolerably familiar, and upon which it is, consequently, unnecessary for us to descant at length. The Supreme Court itself has not been exempt from the fate which has overtaken the humbler and less pretentious tribunals of the States. Whatever one's opinion may be of the authority of the Dred Scott decision, it is impossible to overlook the advocate's eagerness to make out as good a case as possible for the winning side, by which the whole judgment is marked.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN.--The most popular opera of the Italian repertoire is undoubtedly the "Trovatore," for where and whenever produced it never fails to attract a brilliant audience. This was the case last evening, when Madame FREZZOLINI, for whom it was written, made her rentree as the heroine.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- The most popular opera of the Italian repertoire is undoubtedly the "Trovatore," for where and whenever produced it never fails to attract a brilliant audience. This was the case last evening, when Madame FREZZOLINI, for whom it was written, made her rentree as the heroine. The European success of the opera has always been ascribed to Madame FREZZOLINI, and although she is no longer the greatest of living prime donne, it cannot be disputed that she has moments of supreme excellence, when the fabulous stories of her past triumphs become present realities. VERDI, who wrote the music expressly for the FREZZOLINI of the present day, has undoubtedly preserved to us some of the best characteristics of her style and voice. In the first and second acts she is very good, and in the fourth thoroughly magnificent. Without resort to the usual expedients of sensation singers she succeeds in producing the best and most legitimate of effects.

abstract: The last National Democratic Convention of this State afforded a most charming illustration of the difference between principle and practice. The platform, which they adopted with a reasonable degree of harmony for so heterogeneous an assembly, most decided condemned the heresy of squatter sovereignty, and cordially indorsed the administration of JAMES BUCHANAN as wise, efficient, and truly Democratic.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, Tuesday, April 24, 1860.

abstract: FASHIONABLE AUCTION SALE IN UNION-SQUARE. -- One of the most noteworthy sales of fashionable household furniture that ever took place in this City has been going on for the last two days, under the hammer of H.H. LIEDS & CO., from the large and elegant mansion of Mr. J.T. PENNIMAN, in Union-square. Mr. PENNIMAN is one of the few millionaires who has had the taste to select, as well as the ability to purchase, and the result has been one of the most elegant and recherche collections of household furniture and works of art to be found in any private residence in this country. Being about to spend several years in Europe with his family, he has put his whole domestic establishment under the hammer, and we venture to say that Mr. LEEDS never smiled upon a more select and fashionable throng of bidders than has gathered around him for the last two days. The sale of all that portion of the furniture not classed as works of art was completed yesterday. The prices paid were generally regarded as liberal, though not by any means reaching the original cost. The furniture of the two main pariors brought $2,000; that of the smaller rooms in proportion. Of the table furniture, the most expensive article was a claret set, with solid silver jug, plated tray with silver edges, and 24 ruby glasses with solid silver stems, which brought $170 -- original cost $400. An elegant ormolu cigar-stand brought $80. The family plate was not entered in the catalogue. The most important and the rarest portion of the sale will take place to-day, when the whole collection of works of art, comprising some of the choicest paintings, statuary, and artistic gems of various descriptions, to be found in any private residence in this City, will be offered for sale. Among the marble statuary are the productions of SPENCE, WYATT, TROCHEL, ROSETTI, TADOLINI, BENZONI and GREBNOUGH, all of which were purchased by Mr. PENNIMAN from the artists themselves. Among the gems are three studies in terra cotta, by TROCHEL, representing the "Holy Family," "Death of Adonis," and "Pandora." Also, several elegant Roman bronze groups by HOFTGARTEN. In painting may be found the works of RAPHAEL, ("Holy Family,") SHEGOGUE, MULLER. WOUVERMANS, FURINI and THOMAS DOUGHTY. Besides these are several illustrated works, among which are AUDUBON's Quadrupeds of America, and a copy of the Bologna Gallery. It may not be uninteresting to state, as showing the upward tendency of business, and the encroachments that are being made upon the fashionable portions of the City, that the dwelling from which this sale takes place, and which is the largest and most elegant mansion in Madison-square, has been leased to E.V. HAUGHWOUT, the well-known dealer in crockery and Chinaware, and is to be occupied by him as an up-town branch of his business. The upper portion of the house will be let to artists for studios. The dwelling No. 1 Union-square has also been leased to DUNCAN & SON, Grocers, of No. 404 Broadway, who will take possession on the first of May.

abstract: --The Herald has discovered that Abolitionism has a demoralizing effect on the clergy, and the editor of that paper straitway makes a pulpit of one of his columns, announced his new discovery as the text, and with singular unction delivers a sermon for the benefit of those misguided ministers who uphold the equality of races, and preach the Gospel of Abolitionism.
lead_paragraph: -- The Herald has discovered that Abolitionism has a demoralizing effect on the clergy, and the editor of that paper straitway makes a pulpit of one of his columns, announced his new discovery as the text, and with singular unction delivers a sermon for the benefit of those misguided ministers who uphold the equality of races, and preach the Gospel of Abolitionism. It is interesting to see the Reverend Editor in the pulpit, and to hear him discourse upon religious topics. But his piety is only periodical, and bears a striking resemblance to the way in which old Touchwood's sons "feared the Lord." These sons were sadly addicted to wicked practices; and one Sunday morning the minister of the parish met one of them starting for the woods with a gun on his shoulder. Seeking out the father, the clergyman told him that he ought to admonish his sons, and bring them up in the fear of the Lord. "Fear the Lord," replied old Touchwood, "they are so afraid of him now that they daren't stir out on Sunday without a double-barreled shot-gun in their hand!' In this sense, as opposed to the Abolition of Slavery and of Sunday amusements, the editor of the Herald may be said to fear the Lord.

abstract: An additional term of this Court is ordered to commence on the second Tuesday of June, for which causes must be noticed and notes of issue filed, and which will run into the regular June term, fixed by law. This has been the arrangement of late years found most convenient, as it enables the term to close before the Summer heat. -- Albany Argus.

abstract: By an act passed by the last Legislature each member of the Board of Aldermen and Councilmen is allowed $1,200 salary per annum. That portion which was due for the first quarter was promptly demanded, and as promptly paid by the Comptroller, but several applicants were disappointed to find that little bills...
lead_paragraph: By an act passed by the last Legislature each member of the Board of Aldermen and Councilmen is allowed $1,200 salary per annum. That portion which was due for the first quarter was promptly demanded, and as promptly paid by the Comptroller, but several applicants were disappointed to find that little bills for carriage hire, which they had been running up on the supposition that they would be settled from the City Treasury, were to be deducted from their individual salaries. One gentleman who had got the City indebted to livery stable keepers to the amount of $20, made a terribly long face when his check for $280 was presented to him, and he departed vowing any considerable amount of vengeance, but he drew the money, and was very glad to secure it.

abstract: The members of the New-York Club met on Wednesday, on their ground at Hoboken, for a day's play, but the unpropitious state of the weather proved a serious interruption to their pleasure. The ground looks in fine order, but in consequence of the improvements which are going on in Hoboken by street openings, &c., it has been, since last season, very much reduced in size.

abstract: One of the last as well as one of the best known of the noble estates which once decorated the upper part of the Island of Manhattan, is about to disappear under the advancing tide of municipal improvement. The " Elm-wood" house and park, of Col. THORN, have long been a conspicuous feature in the fast diminishing "scenery" of our Metropolitan rides and drives.
lead_paragraph: One of the last as well as one of the best known of the noble estates which once decorated the upper part of the Island of Manhattan, is about to disappear under the advancing tide of municipal improvement. The " Elm-wood" house and park, of Col. THORN, have long been a conspicuous feature in the fast diminishing "scenery" of our Metropolitan rides and drives. They have now been brought by the death of their late possessor, himself for years a "feature" of New-York society, under the remorseless hammer of the auctioneer, which, like the [???]ot of "pallida mors," in the Horatian ode, knocks with impartial force at the doors of the palace and the hut.

abstract: The Evening Post devotes an elaborate article to reminiscences of the original formation and subsequent action of the Free-Soil Party of 1848, and of the career thus far of the Republican Party. Its special, practical object is to show that, while the Whig wing of that Party has shaped its policy hitherto, they must...
lead_paragraph: The Evening Post devotes an elaborate article to reminiscences of the original formation and subsequent action of the Free-Soil Party of 1848, and of the career thus far of the Republican Party. Its special, practical object is to show that, while the Whig wing of that Party has shaped its policy hitherto, they must not persist in so doing if they hope or wish for the cooperation of the Democratic section. The Post recalls the fact that Gov. CHASE was originally elected United States Senator from Ohio by a coalition of the Free-Soilers and Democrats, -- that CHARLES SUMNER was elected in Massachusetts by a bargain between the same parties, "all the State offices, including the appointment of CALEB CUSHING as a Judge of the Supreme Court, being given to the Democrats," and that Mr. SEWARD's reelection in 1854 was effectually blocked by the attempt to perpetuate Whig ideas in this City, and was only accomplished by the "magnanimity" of the Know-Nothings.

abstract: Another meeting of the Police Commissioners was held yesterday. Present--Messrs. BOWEN and BERGEN. Mr. PILSBURY has been absent from the last two sessions of the Board, and is understood to have resigned, although no official announcement of the fact has been made. Gov. MORGAN was in consultation with the Commissioners at the Head-quarters...
lead_paragraph: Another meeting of the Police Commissioners was held yesterday. Present--Messrs. BOWEN and BERGEN. Mr. PILSBURY has been absent from the last two sessions of the Board, and is understood to have resigned, although no official announcement of the fact has been made. Gov. MORGAN was in consultation with the Commissioners at the Head-quarters yesterday, previous to the session of the Board, as is supposed, in reference to the appointment of a successor to Mr. PILSBURY, but such is the secrecy maintained at Head-quarters relative to the doings or sayings of the new Commission, that quid nuncs are completely nonplussed, and can only await patiently the developments of each day, be thankful for what they can get, and be careful and not look the gift horse in the mouth. After nearly two hours of secret session, yesterday, the chief clerk issued out from a hole in the wall, like a mouse from a cheese chest, and announced the following as the result of the mountain's labor: Officer John Brackle, Eleventh Precinct, resigned; D.B. Hasbrouck, appointed first deputy clerk; D.R. Summercorn, D. Wood and Thomas Cromby appointed patrolmen. Capt. Gibson, of the Harbor Police, reported that he had removed all the shad poles from the bay, and it was now fair sailing clear down to Sandy Hook. The Sanitary squad reported twenty-eight places in New-York and thirteen in Brooklyn, (mostly privies,) that needed looking to. The Commissioners resolved to invest the Captain of each Precinct with power to abate the nuisances repotted by the Sanitary Squad, which is to be done at the expense of the owners of property on which said nuisances exist after three days' notice, according to the terms of the new law. Adjourned till to day at 1 o'clock.

abstract: It has been the boast of British civilization for near a thousand years, that all ferocious wild animals, brutes in human shape alone excepted, have been thoroughly exterminated from the "inviolate isles." It is a glory of the reign of EDWARD the Victorious, far more important to his people than any of his blood-stained foreign laurels,...
lead_paragraph: It has been the boast of British civilization for near a thousand years, that all ferocious wild animals, brutes in human shape alone excepted, have been thoroughly exterminated from the "inviolate isles." It is a glory of the reign of EDWARD the Victorious, far more important to his people than any of his blood-stained foreign laurels, that in his time the cruel and cowardly wolf disappeared from the kingdom. Here in New-York, after eighty years of national independence and republican self-government, it might have been supposed by any enthusiastic believer in the progress of the race, that the poor, the sick, the weak, the helpless, the mother in her travail, and the new-born babe in its innocence, could repose under the shelter of our corporate charity, at least as safe from savage beasts of prey as if their lot had been cast in mediaeval Europe. The report which appears in our columns to day, under the auspices of the Commissioners of Public Charities and Correction, upon the hideous story of MARY CONNER and her child at the Bellevue Hospital, which yesterday startled the most apathetic of New-York readers by its loathsome horrors, proves, most unhappily, that such is not the case.

His petition averred, among other facts, that he was one of the, grand-children of Abraham Thompson, and was a general legatee. That none of the residuary legatees were natural persons, and that none of the executors named in the will had qualified except Henry Sheldon, who has since died, leaving assets of the estate unadministered.

abstract: Much excitement was caused about 1 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, among the inmates of the tenement house No. 187 Avenue C, by the discovery of fire in the apartment on the second floor occupied by SEBASTIAN AUGUSTINE, a German tailor. Before, however, the flames had attained much power, they were extinguished, and an investigation showed that the fire had been kindled beneath a bed in a large quantity of shavings and pine wood. Suspicion was immediately fixed upon AUGUSTINE and his wife, the woman having been seen to leave the room just previous to the discovery of the fire, and Officer CARLAND, pf the Eleventh Precinct, subsequently took both into custody to await the result of an examination by Fire Marshal BAKER.

abstract: THE NEW UNITED STATES STEAMER PAWNEE. -- The Philadelphia Ledger, April 26, says: "A partial test of the engines of the United States steamer Pawnee, lying at the Navy-yard, was made at 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Steam was raised, and a pressure of twenty pounds to the square inch applied to the engine. The result was fully satisfactory, answering all the expectations of the builders. The revolutions of the wheel were not timed or counted, but the entire machinery worked admirably. The boilers, which are yet to be covered, showed no evidences of leaky joints, and the large number of gentlemen who witnessed the working of the steamer predicted that, in her running time, she would exceed the calculations previously made, of fifteen miles an hour. There was a slight thumping of the engine, a fact attributable to the want of a complete cleaning. Later in the afternoon there was another trial, attended with the same successful result. The calculation is, that there will be a hundred revolutions of the wheel to forty strokes of the engine. In about two weeks the steamer will be put in moving order, when a full test of the engines will be made. She will not be ready for sea, however, for at least a month, as there is yet considerable labor to be performed on board. The entire list of her officers has not yet been announced.

abstract: One of the worst effects of the Abolition agitation has been that it silences all open discussion of Slavery in the Slave States. By menacing the communities in which Slavery exists with the peril of invasion and insurrection from without, it compels all men of all shades of opinion to combine for the common defence,...
lead_paragraph: One of the worst effects of the Abolition agitation has been that it silences all open discussion of Slavery in the Slave States. By menacing the communities in which Slavery exists with the peril of invasion and insurrection from without, it compels all men of all shades of opinion to combine for the common defence, and to suppress all debate about the evils of the system, in order to avoid the still greater evil involved in its compulsory abolition. When Slavery became a theme for Federal discussion, -- an element of national politics, -- it ceased inevitably to be canvassed and criticized within the States themselves. No Anti-Slavery Party could exist in a Southern State without incurring the fatal suspicion of being in league with foreign foes. In time of war, any man who sympathizes with the opinions and sentiments of the enemy is set down as a traitor; -- and any Southern man who, during the Abolition excitements of the day, takes Anti-Slavery ground at home, is in peril of a similar fate.

lead_paragraph: The Commissioners of the Department of Public Charities and Correction have promptly investigated the case of the infant of MARY CONNER, which was mutilated by rats at Bellevue Hospital, and the death of which is supposed to have resulted from that cause. Messrs. DEAPER, GEINNELL, BELL and NICHOLSON spent several hours at the Hospital, night before last; examined all who had anything to relate with regard to the occurrence, and had several of the alleged culprits, or members of their numerous family, before them, -- for the rats at Bellevue are a bold and reckless race, and do not hesitate to come forth from their hiding-places, and scamper about even in the presence of men in high position. The evidence thus collated was arranged in due form, and presented before the Commissioners at their meeting yesterday afternoon. The details are uninteresting and unfit for publication. The leading points are as follows:
