abstract: ANOTHER NEW STEAM FIRE ENGINE.--Yesterday was a day of jubliee with the active and honorary members of Southwark Engine Company No. 38, the occasion being the reception of a beautiful steam fire engine that has just been completed at the Novelty Works by Messrs. LEE  LARNED for their use.
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER NEW STEAM FIRE ENGINE.--Yesterday was a day of jubliee with the active and honorary members of Southwark Engine Company No. 38, the occasion being the reception of a beautiful steam fire engine that has just been completed at the Novelty Works by Messrs. LEE LARNED for their use. The cost of the machine is about $5,000; it is 11 feet in length, exclusive of the pole, and weighs 5,300 pounds. Having large wheels and sensitive springs, it will run, however, as easily as an ordinary, fire-engine of 500 or 600 pounds less weight, and easier than the average of first-class hand-engines. Its best single stream for distance is 1 1/4 inch diameter, but for ordinary fire duty it will handle, with good effect, two one-inch streams, drawing its own water. The steam-power is derived from one of LEE & LARNED's patent annular boilers, of 225 feet of heating surface, with which steam can be raised to working pressure in from 6 to 8 minutes. The pump, which is of brass, and highly finished, is CARY's patent rotary, driven by a single reciprocating engine of 9 inches bore and 8 1/2 inches stroke, with a pair of balance-wheels to carry it over the centres. It is intended to make from 200 to 400 revolutions per minute. An elaborately-ornamented bronze lamp, having a triple series of powerful lenses, and resting on a highly-polished silver air-globe, is placed in front of the engine. This lamp, which is a very artistic production, was made by DE VOURSNEY BROTHERS, and cost the company $250. After receiving the engine at the Novelty Works, the company paraded down Broadway, preceded by Dodworth's Band, passing through Wall, and several of the other principal streets downtown, returned to the Engine-house, No. 28 Ann-street, where the event was commemorated with a collation. Southwark Company, without being invidious, may be said to be among the finest in the City, and, by obtaining the steam-engine, has again placed itself among the pioneers in the introduction of improved engines in the Fire Department -- the double-bank or Philadelphia-style engine having been first used in New-York by this Company, although its introduction excited great opposition, for the machine was looked upon as an innovation, the same as steam-engines are by a portion of the Department at this time. Mr. GEORGE T. ALEER is Foreman, and Mr. S. HAGAN Assistant-Foreman of the Company, whose complement is 70 men, many of the members being down-town merchants. Now, that they have obtained a new engine, the company justly feel that the City should provide them a more suitable house than their present cramped quarters. This is the third steam fire-engine that has been surrendered to the Fire Department, Companies Nos. 42 and 8 having the others. Messrs. LEE & LARNED have ten more in course of construction, 5 of which are for this City, and the remainder for different parts of the country. Orders for the manufacture of six others have been received by the builders.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen last evening refused to refer to the Croton Aqueduct Committee a bill of the American and Foreign Iron Pavement Company of $3,625,05, for paving Nassau-street opposite the Post-office with iron pavement in 1855, and interest.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen last evening refused to refer to the Croton Aqueduct Committee a bill of the American and Foreign Iron Pavement Company of $3,625,05, for paving Nassau-street opposite the Post-office with iron pavement in 1855, and interest. Councilmen LENT, DECKER and PINCKNEY favored the reference, in order to afford time for investigation as to the cost of the work, &c. They urged upon their fellow members that no one of them would pass such a bill if sent to him individually, and that the pavement was put down by the Company as an experiment. Mr. SHAW and the Democrats generally refused to lay the bill on the table one week to give an opportunity to members to investigate. Mr. PINCKNEY next moved to strike out the item of interest, ($1,008,) and to refer the paper to the Committee on Finance. Both these motions were lost, and the bill was finally passed by a vote of 15 to 5.

abstract: THE LONG DOCK COMPANY. -- The Long Dock Company are now preparing the slips and dock at the foot of Pavonia-avenue, preparatory to establishing a ferry at that locality. abstract: The critical conflict is now waging in the Democratic camp. The Committee on the Platform, "this way and that inclining its swift mind," is discussing the extreme point at which a reasonable regard to the possibilities of Federal success can be conciliated with judicious concessions to the angry and rather...
lead_paragraph: The critical conflict is now waging in the Democratic camp. The Committee on the Platform, "this way and that inclining its swift mind," is discussing the extreme point at which a reasonable regard to the possibilities of Federal success can be conciliated with judicious concessions to the angry and rather irrational exigencies of excited Southern feeling. Whether that point can be found, and whether, being found, a working majority of the Convention can be induced to recognize it, are questions not to be settled at this distance, and by spectators. If we are to accept the representations of the delegates who are acting under the command of the ultra Southern leaders as the infallible indications of the settled Southern sentiment, we must believe that it cannot and will not be either found or recognized. In that case, we may expect a volcanic explosion of the whole Convention, and with it the final disruption and disarray of the Democratic Party, with other consequences too remote and too important to be dwelt upon here. But those who are watching the progress of affairs at Charleston with impartial and disinterested eyes, will do well to remember that the intensity with which the great captains of the Southern host press their absolute demand for a recognition of slaves as mere downright property, to be protected always and everywhere like any other property, is seriously aggravated by the personal hostility of these captains to the most conspicuous of the Democratic candidates. This fact is so well understood at Charleston that it can hardly fail to have its effect upon the deliberations of the Convention. And should the partisans of power, "pure and simple," the seekers after place and authority, who are at least as numerous in the South as in the North, and in the Democratic as in the Republican ranks, eventually make up their minds to the hope of victory rather than to the assertion of doctrine, it is quite possible that a secession, general or partial, of certain delegations, such as those of Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama, may take place from the Convention, without at all entailing the secession from the party of those States themselves in the subsequent hour of the Presidential election. A delegate from Alabama, Mr. PERCY WALKER, yesterday indicated the existence of a decided Southern under-tow in the direction of a practicable policy, by offering a resolution asserting the duty of Congress to afford "all legal protection to slave property in the Territories and on the high seas." This resolution, which might be offered and passed at Chicago as well as at Charleston, may perhaps prefigure the real character of the new "platform" which is to replace the platform of Cincinnati. It would certainly have this advantage over the programme upon which Mr. BUCHANAN was carried into power -- that it will bear a much larger variety of interpretations than that venerable "scheme of faith," while at the same time it will doubtless be far more emphatic in phraseology, and more imposing in its superficial aspect of constitutional fidelity to the rights of everybody everywhere. The fate of the Democracy, and with that fate the tone of the coming contest for the Presidency, rests now with this much-burdened "Committee on the Platform," and with the chaos of recommendations out of which it is striving to educe a feasible order of battle.

abstract: A most important bill, designed to protect the inhabitants of this City and Brooklyn against the fearful and hourly danger of boiler explosions, passed the House unanimously, received only one dissenting vote in the Senate, but still awaits the signature of the Governor.
lead_paragraph: A most important bill, designed to protect the inhabitants of this City and Brooklyn against the fearful and hourly danger of boiler explosions, passed the House unanimously, received only one dissenting vote in the Senate, but still awaits the signature of the Governor. And singularly enough, it is feared -- it is by many even believed, that the Governor will refuse to sign it. He thinks the bill has not been called for! Perhaps if His Excellency should find himself flying over the houses amid bricks and splinters, some fine morning, as has happened to quite too many of our citizens within the past few months, he would find the bill called for loudly enough. It is a notorious and terrible fact that steam-boilers in every stage of depreciation, under the charge of the most ignorant, careless and reckless of raw laborers, in situations where an "accident" would tear down buildings and murder innocents in the most wholesale fashion, do, this very day, literally pervade the very foundations of the cities of New-York and Brooklyn. They underlie our sidewalks and hiss in the cellars of lofty buildings; they are to be found, too, on every floor, at every height, at every depth.

abstract: The happy family at Charleston has fallen into melancholy discord, the Platform being the apparently incurable source of distraction. The Southern delegations, encouraged by outside influences hostile to Mr. DOUGLAS, insist upon the insertion of a clause approving of Congressional intervention...
lead_paragraph: The happy family at Charleston has fallen into melancholy discord, the Platform being the apparently incurable source of distraction. The Southern delegations, encouraged by outside influences hostile to Mr. DOUGLAS, insist upon the insertion of a clause approving of Congressional intervention for the protection of slaveholders in the Territories. The Convention was wholly occupied yesterday in listening to propositions of this tendency, under every form of modification; the most explicit and extreme emanating, it is understood, from the pen of Mr. SLIDELL, of Louisiana. Members from Pennsylvania and Rhode Island presented more moderate forms of the doctrine; and all as fast as produced were referred to the Committee upon the Platform. That Committee has thus far been unable to complete its report. Serious differences are said to exist among the members as to the Territorial question, and it is even stated that three reports will be presented, and the selection from them be left to the Convention. A majority is represented to be favorable to a resolution yesterday offered to the Convention by Mr. WALKER, of Alabama, and referred, which declares it to be the duty of the Government to provide for the protection of the property of American citizens, as well within the United States and the Territories, as upon the high seas. With these vague terms, the question, it is hoped, may be postponed. At the close of the proceedings yesterday, a resolution requiring the Committee to report progress this morning at 10 o'clock was adopted. The excitement is intense. All manner of assertions and speculations obtain currency; among others, a statement that the adoption of the dogma of Federal protection to slave property in the Territories will be the signal for the Douglas party to bolt. The delegations from the Gulf States are loud in their declaration, that if Squatter Sovereignty be not distinctly repudiated in the platform, they will retire and place in nomination JEFFERSON DAVIS and FERNANDO WOOD. As there is no likelihood of this being done, and as Mr. DOUGLAS has required his friends to insist upon the insertion of the doctrine in question, the secession may be regarded as certain. At Washington last evening the impression had gained ground that the Convention would be obliged to disperse without nominating. The friends of Mr. DOUGLAS, on the other hand, are confident of his nomination, and care nothing for the threatened schism.

abstract: The worship of success is the worst of idolatries; but honorable success, legitimately won by tact, industry and ability honestly exercised, fully deserves the cordial recognition which it is tolerably sure to receive. And we know no better instance of this well-deserved and creditable kind of...
lead_paragraph: The worship of success is the worst of idolatries; but honorable success, legitimately won by tact, industry and ability honestly exercised, fully deserves the cordial recognition which it is tolerably sure to receive. And we know no better instance of this well-deserved and creditable kind of triumph than the prosperity which has been attained by our contemporary, the Courrier des Etats-Unis. This "organ of the Franco-American populations" has now seen a whole generation of readers grow up under its auspices. Founded thirty-two years ago as a weekly journal, with the special hope of making its way in the strictly literary world, and published in a small upper chamber at No. 55 Wall-street, the Courrier des Etats-Unis, after passing through, eleven changes of residence and all the usual ups and downs of newspaper, which are vastly more startling and incalculable than the ups and downs of individual life, has now installed itself in a new and handsome building of its own at No. 92 Walker-street; has become a recognized political influence in the land, and issues from its ever-busy presses a daily edition, a weekly edition, an edition for California and an edition for Europe. Such a career would be noticeable m the case of any journal whatever, but it is doubly remarkable in the case of a newspaper printed in a tongue foreign to the great mass of Americans, and not supported like the German journals upon the perpetual influx of a vast immigration.

abstract: The Buffalo Express thinks the City of NewYork has been justly punished by the Railroad bills for its indifference or rather hostility to the Pro-Rata freight bill, which was defeated in the same Legislature, and, as the Express intimates, by the same corrupt means which...
lead_paragraph: The Buffalo Express thinks the City of NewYork has been justly punished by the Railroad bills for its indifference or rather hostility to the Pro-Rata freight bill, which was defeated in the same Legislature, and, as the Express intimates, by the same corrupt means which passed the others. This, as near as we can understand it, is the drift of its comments upon our remarks upon Legislative corruption as illustrated at the last session. We have no special objection to it. We have never asked or expected that Buffalo would feel any "pity" for New-York, or take any special interest in the management or mismanagement of its municipal affairs. When New-York representatives shamelessly sell out their constituents, and betray their interests for so much cash per vote, we cannot expect either the members or the people of other sections to concern themselves much about the consequences.

abstract: --An escaped nun, a handsome damsel of seventeen, is creating a sensation in Cleveland She tells a long story of convent life in Montreal, declares that she suffered unheard-of hardships, that her parentage was concealed, and that the only name she ever had was LIZZIE. Having been compelled to take the white veil, the time...
lead_paragraph: --An escaped nun, a handsome damsel of seventeen, is creating a sensation in Cleveland She tells a long story of convent life in Montreal, declares that she suffered unheard-of hardships, that her parentage was concealed, and that the only name she ever had was LIZZIE. Having been compelled to take the white veil, the time was approaching when the final vows were to be administered, and then, alarmed at the prospect of perpetual seclusion, she fled -- finding her way to Buffalo, and thence to Cleveland, where she became an inmate of the house of a Baptist clergyman. After remaining in her new quarters for a week or two, she disappeared mysteriously at twilight, and has not since been seen. The Rev. gentleman who received her is reported to be in a dubious frame of mind; unwilling to admit that he is a victim of false pretences, but half inclined to the opinion that the story of the nun was none other than a huge romance.

abstract: --The City's three-cornered pet will soon be advertised for sale; the City Hall Park will pass into the hands of the General Government, and the inclosure now sacred to the occupancy of small apple-merchants, itinerant pea-nut venders, and little boys enthusiastic in their desire to "black your boots," will soon know their forms ...
lead_paragraph: --The City's three-cornered pet will soon be advertised for sale; the City Hall Park will pass into the hands of the General Government, and the inclosure now sacred to the occupancy of small apple-merchants, itinerant pea-nut venders, and little boys enthusiastic in their desire to "black your boots," will soon know their forms no more for ever. The fountain will not be permitted to play, even on Sundays; as indeed it has not been for the last year; the notices to "keep off the grass" will be removed; the telescope and microscope men will have to absquatulate; the Union-savers will have to beat up other quarters; the bells will have to follow the lead of other belles, who long since moved up town to exhibit themselves; and another place will have to be selected in which to let off fire-works and burn City Halls. The now empty space will become a solid wedge of masonry, splitting the trunk of the City in halves, and keeping Broadway and Chatham-street eternally separate and distinct from each other. And the generation of the present day will witness, with perfect complacency, the cutting down of the trees under whose spreading branches it is probable that their parents made the arrangements which resulted in their existence and the present population of the City; will chuckle over the destruction of the basin where their nurses used to lead them to see the swans, and behold the grass whereon they used to roll, in defiance of the warning placards, plucked up by the roots without a murmur. Cities, as well as Republics, are ungrateful. Why could we not permit the old servant, who so long has borne our tramplings, and sustained his time-honored burden, the City Hall, without a murmur, to enjoy a quiet old age, without piling additional masses of architecture on the already weary shoulders. Years ago, when the Park gates were removed, to facilitate the ingress and egress of ladies and Aldermen, we foresaw, at no distant day, the total removal of our father's triangular favorite. Why could not the Park have been suffered to remain intact? Surely there was nothing very green about it!

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, Mr. James Hurlburt, a farmer from Herkimer County, who know his right's, and, knowing, dared maintain them, was induced, by the exceedingly cheap way in which watches were knocked down in the auction-store of one Wilson, at No. 189 Greenwich-street, to bid as high as 18 shillings for a silver time-piece, of the hunting[???] description. The auctioneer said "Gone" to the [???] and Huriburt was prompt to offer the amount; but, to his surprise, was informed that, instead of 18 shillings, he bad bid $18. This way of doing business he didn't understand, and wouldn't submit to -- so, seizing the auctioneer by the neck, he jerked him from his pedestal, obtained the watch, put down the sum he had bargained to give, and was about triumphantly to leave the shop, when a policeman, whom the dispute brought to the place, took both parties into custody. Justice CONNOLLY, having heard the facts, decided in favor of the country man, and, much to the astonishment of the auctioneer, allowed him to keep the watch. The time-piece was one that had been used as a "blind," its value being about $25. Instances are rare where City sharpers have been more prettily overreached.

abstract: If we are to take Lord JOHN RUSSELL as our authority Great Britain is in the market for an ally. With that petulant anxiety to define his own personal position independently of his official colleagues, which is one of the most uncomfortable tastes a statesman can possess, and which Lord JOHN has once and again indulged to the innnense annoyance of every
lead_paragraph: If we are to take Lord JOHN RUSSELL as our authority Great Britain is in the market for an ally. With that petulant anxiety to define his own personal position independently of his official colleagues, which is one of the most uncomfortable tastes a statesman can possess, and which Lord JOHN has once and again indulged to the innnense annoyance of every Government with which he has ever been connected, the English Foreign Secretary, after defending in the main the conduct of the English Cabinet on the question of Savoy, took occasion, some weeks ago, to astonish the House of Commons, and to bewilder Europe, by asserting his belief that France had entered, on a dangerous career, and that it was time for England to think of making new alliances on the Continent.

abstract: The Democratic bark is fairly launched upon the troubled waters. The Convention is engaged in discussing the Platform; it commenced this task yesterday, but when it will finish it. we shall not venture to predict. The temper and scope of the opening speeches, so
lead_paragraph: The Democratic bark is fairly launched upon the troubled waters. The Convention is engaged in discussing the Platform; it commenced this task yesterday, but when it will finish it. we shall not venture to predict. The temper and scope of the opening speeches, so far as they can be inferred from the meagre reports received by telegraph, indicate a protracted and an angry debate, without much hope of any substantial and cordial agreement. It is not at all unlikely that an apparent harmony may be reached; -- but we see little chance for anything more, for the differences between the two sections are radical and incapaple of compromise.

abstract: Muscle is King. Cotton is not. Nigger is not. Muscle is. Brains used to have some claim; so did worth; so did honesty, capability and education, but that was a long time ago. Muscle has taken precedence over everything, and the man who "strikes from the shoulder," and is a good, hard hitter, is the man for the people's money now-a-days.
lead_paragraph: Muscle is King. Cotton is not. Nigger is not. Muscle is. Brains used to have some claim; so did worth; so did honesty, capability and education, but that was a long time ago. abstract: JUSTICE on, NOT in, THE CITY HALL. -- The appearance of various ropes and pullies and spars, on the summit of the City Hall Cupola yesterday, gave that venerable edifice the look, at a distance, of having been rigged up for marine service. And the belief prevailed to some extent that our recent proposition for floating the hall up the river to Albany was about to be put in execution. The fact, however, that the cables pending from the summit reached the ground, and were tied to the trees in the park, gave rise to directly opposite opinions. And the rumor was not long in originating and spreading, abroad that the Governor had signed the bill for removing the Hall, and that the enemies of the bill, determined on resistance, had taken this means of anchoring the pile to the spot. Among a variety of other opinions that prevailed was one that the Mayor, in view of the shock which the country will sustain when the "Charleston split" shall occur, had telegraphed order to have the City steeple stayed by guys lest u should tumble down in unsightly ruins, to remain a public eyesore to another generation, as the remains of its predecessor did to the last. The conviction at last became general that the ropes and pullies were merely to be used in hoisting a statue of justice to its place on the cupola while the Mayor is away. But we do not believe that the goddess would consent to grace the building even in effigy, unless she had previously been deluded into the belief that his Honor's present absence is to be permanent. Nor was it probably a very difficult task to impose this belief upon the dame, considering the utter oblivion info which our great City Father has fallen in these political times concerning the wants and interests of his municipal children. If the design of the ropes be really that to which we have last referred, we shall doubtless see within a few years -- that is, if the work progresses in the future as it has in the past -- the City Hall once more complete, with Justice, in effigy, looking down on the roof, beneath which the goddess, in person, so seldom enters.

abstract: COKE is responsible for the opinion that "Every man ought to know a little of law," and "perhaps," says A'BECKET, "the less the better"--in which latter opinion we believe all will concur whose legal lore is the result of experience in the tribunals of this State.
lead_paragraph: COKE is responsible for the opinion that "Every man ought to know a little of law," and "perhaps," says A'BECKET, "the less the better"--in which latter opinion we believe all will concur whose legal lore is the result of experience in the tribunals of this State. So dilatory have proceedings in most of our Courts of record become, that a lawsuit therein, joins plaintiff and defendant with a litigious bond likely to endure "till death doth them part." From one to two years is the shortest time in which a case can be reached after it has been put on the calendar, even if no unusual delay occurs.

abstract: It was telegraphed, via Queenstown, on the 12th inst., that on that day the Bank of England raised its minimum rate of discount from 4  to 5 per cent. The event was preceded by a revival in the demand for money, the applications at the Bank of England having become extraordinarily numerous. The jointstock banks and discount houses raised their allowance on deposits to 4@4  per cent.

lead_paragraph: This Court, after a recess of some days, met yesterday, Recorder BARNARD presiding, to receive a huge batch of indictments from the Grand Jury. The Court-room presented a singular spectacle. The seats usually devoted to visitors, adjoining the jurybox, were entirely filled with prisoners, for whom no room could be found in the ordinary prisoners' cell, and already several cases are awaiting the action of the next Grand Inquest, to be impanneled at the opening of the May term.

abstract: The accounts relative to the insurrection in Sicily are conflicting. The official statements put forth by the Neapolitan Government assert that order reigned at Palermo and throughout Sicily, and that the inhabitants were tranquil. It is also represented that the land-owners had offered to cooperate with the Government, and that an excellent feeling prevailed among the troops.
lead_paragraph: The accounts relative to the insurrection in Sicily are conflicting. abstract: On the 20th inst., VALENTINE COURTENEY, a German, 60 years of age, was committed by Justice QUACKENBUSH, on a charge of being a vagrant, and sent to the Blackwell's Island Workhouse, where he occupied a cell with two other paupers. His health at the time appeared to be good, and it so continued until the rooming of the fourth day, when he was discovered to be very ill, and before night he died. A post-mortem, examination having been made of the body, it was found in a terribly-mangled condition, all the ribs on the left side having been broken, some in two places, while three of those on the right side were like wise fractured. There was also an extensive fracture on the left side of the skull, the right shoulder was dislocated and the bone broken, white his limbs were bruised in eighteen places. Opinion is divided as to how these injuries were inflicted, the more plausible theory being that his fellow-prisoners murdered him, although the keeper asserts that he heard no noise during the night, and is inclined to the belief that, the wounds were occasioned by a fall. Coroner JACKMAN has charge of the case, but he has postponed the inquest until Sunday morning, in order that certain witnesses may be present.

abstract: From present indications trouble is likely to arise with reference to the paving of the upper streets, many of which were filled in under direction of the late Street Commissioner. It appears that in nearly all the deep fillings the contractors were allowed to use the stone blasted out from the cuttings, and one consequence is that in some of the streets, between the Fourth and Seventh avenues, there are fillings of heavy stone from the foundation to the full grade of the street, ranging from 10 to 25 feet in depth. When it is rendered necessary to pave these streets, the contractor has first to remove the stone filling to allow his sixteen inches of sand for the foundation. As a matter of course the sand will sift through the loose stones, and what does not get through by its own gravity, will be washed through by the first rain, and the pavement will drop to the rough, jagged stone. This matter has attracted the attention of the Croton Board, which will at once take some action to prevent the very serious damage and additional expense which the City must incur unless prompt measures are taken to remedy the difficulty.
lead_paragraph: From present indications trouble is likely to arise with reference to the paving of the upper streets, many of which were filled in under direction of the late Street Commissioner. As a matter of course the sand will sift through the loose stones, and what does not get through by its own gravity, will be washed through by the first rain, and the pavement will drop to the rough, jagged stone. This matter has attracted the attention of the Croton Board, which will at once take some action to prevent the very serious damage and additional expense which the City must incur unless prompt measures are taken to remedy the difficulty.

abstract: A NEW IDENTIFICATION. -- Mrs. MARGARET CURLEY, of Boston, yesterday morning identified the features of the unknown woman found drowned in Jersey City, as those of her daughter, who has been missing for the last five weeks. She said that her child left home to seek a situation in New-York, but disappeared from her boarding-house, No. 111 Chrystie-street on the morning after her arrival in the city, since which time nothing has been heard of her. Mrs. CURLEY described accurately the contents of two unclaimed trunks which have been lying at the Stonington steamboat depot, and which belonged to her daughter. As others have identified the remains more positively than Mrs. CURLEY, it was thought best not to allow her to remove them for burial.
lead_paragraph: A NEW IDENTIFICATION. -- Mrs. MARGARET CURLEY, of Boston, yesterday morning identified the features of the unknown woman found drowned in Jersey City, as those of her daughter, who has been missing for the last five weeks. abstract: Anniversary Week will open on Sunday, May 6 with the annual sermons before the Bible Society, the American and Foreign Christian Union, and the Seamen's Friend Society. As the business meetings of the American Tract Society for some years have been so protracted as to prevent the careful consideration
lead_paragraph: Anniversary Week will open on Sunday, May 6 with the annual sermons before the Bible Society, the American and Foreign Christian Union, and the Seamen's Friend Society. As the business meetings of the American Tract Society for some years have been so protracted as to prevent the careful consideration of its religious and benevolent objects, the Managers have decided that a preliminary meeting shall be held on Tuesday evening, May 8, in the Lafayerte place Church, and that the business meeting shall take place on Wednesday morning. May 9, at the Academy of Music. The Independent, however, professes to be suspicious of this programme, conceiving that the change "is a ruse to secure a nominal vote for the adoption of the annual report at a religious anniversary, and then to claim in the business meeting that the report having been adopted, nothing remains but the election of officers. If this shall prove to be the fact, (adds the Independent.) it will be decidedly the worst blunder yet committed by the Management."

abstract: --The death of WASHINGTON IRVING has naturally prompted Mr. PUTNAM, his publisher, to issue a new and complete edition of his works. The first volume, comprising the Sketch Book, has already been published, and gives a most excellent and stimulating idea of the style of the series. It is one of the most elegant and, at the same time,
lead_paragraph: --The death of WASHINGTON IRVING has naturally prompted Mr. PUTNAM, his publisher, to issue a new and complete edition of his works. The first volume, comprising the Sketch Book, has already been published, and gives a most excellent and stimulating idea of the style of the series. It is one of the most elegant and, at the same time, one of the most substantial of the recent issues of the Press -- beautifully printed upon heavy, superfine paper, and illustrated by very neat vignettes on steel and wood. The whole series, including the Life of Washington, is to embrace 21 volumes -- of which one will be issued each month. This is well styled the National Edition, for it will unquestionably supersede all others, and leave no room for anything more in the same direction. The Life and Letters of IRVING are announced as soon to be issued in uniform style with this edition. Mr. PUTNAM has also published BRYANT's discourse on IRVING.

lead_paragraph: Official correspondence between Lord J. RusSELL and Mr. ALCOCK, the British Consul-General in Japan, and between the latter and the Consular offi cers of his jurisdiction, which has been presented to Parliament, affords a view of all that has taken place in Japan, with reference to the opening of the trade of that country to the nations of the West, from June last to the commencement of the present year. Mr. ALCOCK took up his residence at Yedo in July, about the same time as Mr. HARRIS, the American Minister. The earlier portion of the correspondence refers chiefly to the commencement of trade, the currency difficulties, and the interruption of commerce, as related in dispatches which have already been published, through the misconduct of the foreign merchants. abstract: I inclose you an extract of a letter recently received by me from Judge GRIMKE, of Chillicothe, who is justly regarded as one of the most able jurists and civilians of our country. In my judgment, its publication cannot fail to do good. Its thought and tone place it entirely beyond the sphere of ordinary party association, aad are a happy proof that
lead_paragraph: I inclose you an extract of a letter recently received by me from Judge GRIMKE, of Chillicothe, who is justly regarded as one of the most able jurists and civilians of our country. In my judgment, its publication cannot fail to do good. Its thought and tone place it entirely beyond the sphere of ordinary party association, aad are a happy proof that the exciting political topics of the day may be discussed with good temper and philosophic calmness. The extract has been highly instructive to me, and I trust your publication of it may make it so to others.

abstract: The Democratic Convention at Charleston is unable to frame a Platform sound enough to sustain a united party. The difficulty lies in finding a safe man between the Douglas extreme on the one hand, and the Alabama fire-eaters on the other; and if the multitudinous attempts thus far made ineffectually are indications of the future, there is little hope of a Platform, and less of a candidate. The majority of the Committee on
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Convention at Charleston is unable to frame a Platform sound enough to sustain a united party. The difficulty lies in finding a safe man between the Douglas extreme on the one hand, and the Alabama fire-eaters on the other; and if the multitudinous attempts thus far made ineffectually are indications of the future, there is little hope of a Platform, and less of a candidate. The majority of the Committee on Resolutions reported the usual common-places on general topics; and with regard to the territorial question, a resolution suggested by Mr. BAYARD, denying the right of Congress or of a Territorial Legislature to impair the right of property in slaves, and declaring that the rights of persons and of property, whether upon the high seas, or within the jurisdiction of this Government, are entitled to federal protection. There were three minority reports, each differing in regard to this resolution; the Douglas wing declining to abandon the Cincinnatti doctrine of popular sovereignty, and the Davis faction demanding a more explicit declaration of the protective dogma. An excited discussion followed the the presentation of the reports, Mr. AVERY, of Tennessee, appealing to them to yield; and Mr. PAYNE, of Ohio, eloquently appealing to the South not to sacrifice the party for an abstraction. Mr. BUTTER, of Massachusetts, implored the Convention to reiterate simply the Cincinnati Resolutions, predicting the destruction of the party at the North upon any other platform. Mr. COCHRANE, of this City, submitted a substitute for the disputed resolve in which he equally conceded the doctrine of the federal obligation to protect Slavery in the Territories. The debate on the platform occupied the afternoon and evening, Messrs. KING and PUGH taking positions against the majority report, and Mr. YENCEY defending it. A new substitute was presented by Mr. BAYARD, which was even more ultra than the resolution of the majority.

abstract: PARTY CONTESTS -- THE CHARLESTON CONVENTION. -- The Washington Constitution notices the immense importance attached to the proceedings of the Charleston Convention, as shown by the fact that even Congress is paralyzed while awaiting the action of that body. This is quite true, -- but it is nothing new. Party interests for many years have taken precedence of the public welfare, in the eyes of politicians. It is of a good deal more importance to them to know who is to keep and who to get office, than to provide by prudent legislation for the good of the country.

abstract: Mr. EMERSON'S celebrated dictum, "When half gods go the gods arrive," was whimsically illustrated in this City on Saturday morning. When the small impostors who had "taken in" the whole City, from the First Ward to the Fifth-avenue, on Wednesday night,...
lead_paragraph: Mr. EMERSON'S celebrated dictum, "When half gods go the gods arrive," was whimsically illustrated in this City on Saturday morning. When the small impostors who had "taken in" the whole City, from the First Ward to the Fifth-avenue, on Wednesday night with their false tale of the "Great Fight," went forth shouting at the top of their shrill voices the real news brought by the Vanderbilt, they found their market just as fresh as if Astraea had always sat in the printing-offices, and hoaxes were as little known in New-York as we are bound to suppose they were in Arcadia. Their "sell" had produced no more ill effect upon their trade than the kindred "sell" perpetrated by their London fellow-venders. For it appears that on Monday evening, the 16th, the Cockneys were enormously humbugged in like manner with the Gothamites, by "Extras," announcing the great fight as having come off that morning. Only, with a patriotic eye to ready custom, the London extra-merchants of course proclaimed the "defeat of HEENAN," just as ours published the "defeat of SAYERS." The Vanderbilt had truly and unquestionably brought the news. Her passengers brought it, and rapidly dispersing to their hotels and homes, sent it circulating all over the City. Some of them even had seen the great battle-field, and one at least declared that with his eyes he had beheld the evil-minded JOHN MORRISSEY inflict that cut upon the ropes which perhaps saved SAYERS from strangulation, and almost certainly cost the Benicia Boy his hard-won belt. Her mails brought it, and struck off upon the "manifold" of the Associated News Agent; it was rapidly transferred to the presses of a dozen morning journals, and thence shot forth in flights of "extras" far and near. Ten thousand of these were disposed of from the TIMES office alone, within half an hour, thanks to the promptitude with which we always present ourselves, first alike at feast and fight. Then followed the vast packages of illustrated newspapers -- Wilkes' Spirit of the Times, Frank Leslie's and the Illustrated News -- struck off in England, ordered and assorted on the voyage, and scattered broadcast immediately upon the arrival of the Vanderbilt. It is safe to say that nearly a hundred and fifty thousand of these sheets went into circulation at the rate of sixpence a piece before 10 o'clock of Saturday morning. By noon, therefore, of the same day everybody in New-York who ever knows that anything has happened since Gen. JACKSON crushed the bank knew that HEENAN and SAYERS had met, not exactly in the "tented field," but in the "roped arena;" that two thousand Englishmen and half a hundred Yankees had watched the varying progress of the conflict between them for more than two hours; and noted with eager exultation or reluctant despair the gradual obliteration of all signs of humanity from one and the other of those interesting pair of countenances; that HEENAN had knocked the English champion down, at least thirty times, and had been himself only once; that the B.B. had exhibited the most unlooked-for "game" qualities, taking, with smiles as long as he could, and when he got beyond smiles, with affable grins, which would, no doubt, have frightened any two-year-old child into convulsions and idiocy, a "punishment" which gradually closed up his left eye altogether, and put his two cheeks on a level with his nose, and that the final result had been overwhelmed in utter mystery and uncertainty by a rush of the English mob upon the ropes, and a general "muss," evaporating in the police and a promiscuous scamper from the grounds.

abstract: James Flammings, residing in Seventh-avenue, near Fortieth-street, was dangerously stabbed in the breast with an oyster-knife by Michael O'Rourke, a stage-driver, during a fight which occurred between them at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, in the oyster saloon kept by Lewis Ward, in Broadway, between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth streets. O'Rourke, who alleges that he used the knife in self-defence, was subsequently apprehended by Officers Dennett and Cook, of the Twenty-second Precinct, and Justice QUACKENBUSH committed him for examination. Flammings was removed to the New-York Hospital, but it is not probable that he will survive his injuries.

abstract: THE SUNDAY LIQUOR TRAFFIC. -- INTERFERENCE OF THE COUNTY JUDGE. -- Two liquor dealers named ANDREW CROSSON, corner of York and Pearl-streets, and PATRICK HARVEY, corner of Plymouth and Pearl-streets, were arrested by officers WHITE and PHALON, of the Second Precinct Police, for violation of the Sunday Liquor Law, and committed to the Second Precinct Station-house, to await an examination on Monday morning. The friends of the accused obtained counsel, and towards night Judge GARRISON, of the County Court, opened Court at the City Hall, issued writs of habeas corpus, returnable forthwith, and had both parties brought before him, when they were discharged on bail. Judge GARRISON, it is understood, holds that a Policeman has no right to enter through a rear way to a saloon when it is closed on the street, and arrest a man for violating the law-without a warrant. It is stated that this is the first instance in this city where a habeas corpus has been issued and the parties heard and discharged on Sunday.

abstract: News from Zacatecas states that the Reactionary General, SILVERIO RAMIREZ, formerly Governor and Military Chief of Zacatecas, had a battle with the Liberal Governor of the same city, GONZALEZ ORTEGA, at Salinez, the latter having been defeated, after which RAMIREZ entered the city to rob, or force a loan, as customary. The inhabitants and merchants, learning his movements, immediately fled the city, depositing their money with the French, English and Spanish Consuls. RAMIREZ, not finding money in the houses of the merchants, immediately entered by force the houses of the foreign Consuls, forcing open their safes and breaking the seals of the Consulates, taking as much money as suited his purposes. The said Consuls are now in Mexico, making their reclamations. You are aware that these Consuls are friendly to the factious cause, their respective Governments having recognized the Government of MIRAMON. RAMIREZ fled the city as soon as he secured his plunder.

abstract: The London journals announce the death of the great Hungarian statesman, Count SZECHENYI. He committed suicide in his chamber, by blowing out his brains with a pistol. The immediate provocation was a visit paid to his house by the Austrian Police;--there is no doubt that he had become actually maddened by the sight of the misery of his...
lead_paragraph: The London journals announce the death of the great Hungarian statesman, Count SZECHENYI. He committed suicide in his chamber, by blowing out his brains with a pistol. The immediate provocation was a visit paid to his house by the Austrian Police;--there is no doubt that he had become actually maddened by the sight of the misery of his country, and driven to despair by Austrian tyranny and persecution. Thus has ended a life whose prime was passed in a career of usefulness such as few even among the greatest of the world can hope to emulate -- whose latter years were passed in grief and tears, and whose gray hairs were brought in sorrow to the grave dug for him by Hapsburg perfidy.

abstract: Between 4 and 5 o'clock on Saturday afternoon a fire broke out in Pell-street, between Mott and the Bowery, involving the total destruction of the two five-story brick buildings, Nos. 20 and 22, occupied chiefly for manufacturing purposes. No. 20 was tenanted in the basement by JAMES TITUS, veneer-shaver; loss $300; uninsured; the first floor by Allen & CO. as a moulding-mill; loss $8,000; insured for $1,000 in the Quaker City Insurance Company; second floor by P.P. DENIS, scroll-sawyer; loss $1,800; insured for $1,000 in the Safeguard insurance Company, (an exploded concern;) third floor partly by WILLIAM ROBINSON, wood-turner; loss $1,000; uninsured; also by BRUDE & ESSER, etagere manufacturers; loss $600; no insurance. Fourth and fifth floors by CARTWRIGHT & LEWIS, cotton batting manufacturers; loss $6,000; no insurance. No. 22 was occupied in the basement by J. STACEY, tool grinder; loss $300; no insurance. First, second and third floors by JOHN SPERRY, oval and gilt frame maker; loss $1,500; insured for $1,000. Fourth floor, partly by E. BRACKETT, surgical instrument maker, and partly by Mr. CLARK, cotton batting manufacturer; loss of the former about $200, uninsured -- and of the latter about $500, also uninsured. Mr. BIRMINGHAM, frame maker, on the fifth floor, suffered a loss of $1,500. The fire originated in the cotton batting manufactory of Mr. CLARK, and thence extended with fearful rapidity through the entire building, soon communicating to the adjoining premises, No. 20. The walls in falling demolished the blacksmith shop of JOHN MADDEN, and the upper part of a three-story tenement house in the rear of No. 22; also the upper part of a brick building, rear of No. 18 Pell-street, occupied by E.B. CONLIN, furniture manufacturer. Mr. CONLIN's loss is $1,500; insured for $1,000 in the Quaker City and Everett Companies. The buildings Nos. 22 and 20, as well as those in the rear, were owned by W.W. WINANS, and were valued at $12,000; they were partly insured. The building in the rear of No. 18 is owned by J.C. BALDWIN; damage about $600; partly insured. The fire is supposed to have been caused by friction of the machinery.

abstract: The Charleston Convention passed an inharmonious and unsatisfactory day on Saturday, wrangling over the question of a platform, and finally recommitting the whole subject to the Committee, whence it was again reported at the...
lead_paragraph: The Charleston Convention passed an inharmonious and unsatisfactory day on Saturday, wrangling over the question of a platform, and finally recommitting the whole subject to the Committee, whence it was again reported at the afternoon session. Early in the day, the Bayard resolutions were presented by Mr. BIGLER, who supported them in a speech, in which he pleaded for conciliation, but pleaded in vain. The resolutions affirmed the Cincinnati Platform, rejected the doctrine of squatter sovereignty, and left the question of slave property to be settled by the Supreme Court. After an angry contest, the resolutions were recommitted to the Committee by one majority -- Ayes 152, Nays 151. The entire New-York vote was cast in the negative. The minority vote was regarded as the first test of DOUGLAS' strength in the Convention. The Georgia delegation had a minority of Douglas men, who remonstrated against a decision that the vote of that State must be cast as a unit, and it asserted that DOUGLAS lost two votes by this manoeuvre. The platforms having been recommitted, the Convention took a recess at 5 1/2 P.M. The Platform Committee returned with two reports. The majority report was presented by Mr. AVERY of North Carolina. It sets out with an affirmation of the Cincinnati platform, subject to certain explanatory resolutions, which declare that all citizens have a right to settle in the Territories, "without their rights, either of person or property, being destroyed or injured by Congressional or Territorial legislation;" that it is the duty of the Federal Government to protect these rights; and that the State sovereignty begins only with the formation of a State Constitution. The remainder of the majority platform goes for Cuba, the enforcement of the Fugitive Slave law, and a Pacific Railroad. The minority report of the Committed presented by Mr. SAMUELS, of Iowa, also reaffirms the general principles of the Cincinnati Platform; but meets the question of the Territories by declaring that "inasmuch as differences of opinion exist," the Democratic Party "will abide by the decision of the Supreme Court over the institution of Slavery within the Territories." The acquisition of Cuba and the construction of a Pacific Railroad are planks of this report, similar in all respects to those laid down by the majority. Mr. SAMUELS made a powerful appeal to Southern members to adopt the report of the minority. He expected the South not to persist in "an abstraction which would drive one-half the Northern Democrats into the army of the Black Republicans," and it appears that he was heard by the fire-eating party with respectful attention. Mr. BUTLER, of Massachusetts, presented a third report, which proposed the adoption of the Cincinnati Platform, without explanations or addenda. A violent discussion followed the reception of the reports, in the midst of which a motion prevailed to adjourn until Monday morning. The friends of Mr. DOUGLAS profess to feel entire confidence in the nomination of their candidate, and count up the votes they rely upon to secure that result; while to outsiders the prospects of that gentleman appear to darken with every day of delay.

abstract: The last four or five years have made very great changes in the form and substance of our City Government. Very much of the lumbering old machinery which tradition had fastened upon us, as essential to a municipal system, has been swept away, and more effective...
lead_paragraph: The last four or five years have made very great changes in the form and substance of our City Government. Very much of the lumbering old machinery which tradition had fastened upon us, as essential to a municipal system, has been swept away, and more effective agencies have been adopted in its stead. The City Police has been put into the hands of a Commission; -- the City Charities are administered by an Executive Board; -- the Central Park is governed by Commissioners, -- the Health of the City is in charge of the Police, -- and the Fire Department will ere long probably be handed over to a small body of hired employes, provided with steam fire engines, and competent to do their work with more system and less disturbance to the public peace than now characterize the operations of this branch of the public service.

abstract: --It is pleasant to find a great truth now and then embodied in the dreary volumes of our Congressional debates. Mr. BINGHAM, of Michigan, on Thursday, informed a Mr. SMITH, of Virginia, that he was not likely to expunge any of the facts of history, by calling him a calumniator.
lead_paragraph: --It is pleasant to find a great truth now and then embodied in the dreary volumes of our Congressional debates. Mr. BINGHAM, of Michigan, on Thursday, informed a Mr. SMITH, of Virginia, that he was not likely to expunge any of the facts of history, by calling him a calumniator. Mr. BINGHAM is quite right. Whether Mr. SMITH perceived the point is another thing. Probably not. The general impression of the class of men to which he belongs seems to be that strong epithets and round vituperation will turn the whole current of history and of human progress. Many of them apparently believe that, by vigorous cursing and swearing, they can expurgate the decalogue.

abstract: ALPHONSO GASKILL, a middle-aged Englishman, formerly a clerk in the Military Hospital at Bermuda, took a quantity of cyanide of potassium on Friday night, and was found dead in his bed on Saturday morning. Deceased had been much depressed in spirits for some time in consequence of haying to engage in employment which he considered unsuitable to his birth and education, and latterly sought to drown his cares in the wine-cup. He went to his boarding-house, No. 182 Grand-street, on Friday evening, much intoxicated, and having retired to his room, was not again seen alive. Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest upon the body.
lead_paragraph: ALPHONSO GASKILL, a middle-aged Englishman, formerly a clerk in the Military Hospital at Bermuda, took a quantity of cyanide of potassium on Friday night, and was found dead in his bed on Saturday morning. Deceased had been much depressed in spirits for some time in consequence of haying to engage in employment which he considered unsuitable to his birth and education, and latterly sought to drown his cares in the wine-cup. abstract: The inquest upon the body of VALENTINE COURTNEY, an aged pauper, who died in the Almshouse on Blackwell's Island, on the 24th inst., in consequence of injuries received in some unascertained manner, was concluded yesterday by Coroner JACKMAN. From the evidence it appears that deceased was sent to the Island on the 20th inst., on a charge of vagrancy, he being of intemperate habits, and in destitute circumstances. He was placed in a cell with two idiotic persons, and received similar treatment to the other prisoners, with the exception that he was not required to perform any labor. He seemed to be in perfect health up to Tuesday morning last, when his keeper found him in his cell, in a dying condition. He was immediately removed to the Hospital, but his death, speedily resulted. Upon a post mortem examination the skull of deceased was found fractured, his ribs nearly all broken, his shoulder dislocated and shattered, and terrible bruises on his limbs. No evidence, however, was elicited as to the manner in which these injuries were inflicted. The keepers state that they heard no noise in the cell that the unfortunate man occupied, neither were there any signs of a disturbance having taken place there, and the supposition is that, in wandering about the grounds the deceased fell into a stone quarry, although it is difficult to understand how in such a terribly mangled condition he could have returned to the Almshouse without the knowledge of his keepers, particularly as his injuries were such that the physicians think his death must have quickly followed their infliction. In their verdict the Jury, after enumerating the injuries to deceased, say: "We believe the injuries were received but a short time previous to his death, and consequently after his admission to the Workhouse. And we censure in the severest terms, the keeper, who, having plenty of empty cells, placed the deceased in a cell with idiots or crazed prisoners, wholly irresponsible for their actions, and who may at any time violently assail a fellow-prisoner.
lead_paragraph: The inquest upon the body of VALENTINE COURTNEY, an aged pauper, who died in the Almshouse on Blackwell's Island, on the 24th inst., in consequence of injuries received in some unascertained manner, was concluded yesterday by Coroner JACKMAN. From the evidence it appears that deceased was sent to the Island on the 20th inst., on a charge of vagrancy, he being of intemperate habits, and in destitute circumstances. He was placed in a cell with two idiotic persons, and received similar treatment to the other prisoners, with the exception that he was not required to perform any labor. He seemed to be in perfect health up to Tuesday morning last, when his keeper found him in his cell, in a dying condition. He was immediately removed to the Hospital, but his death, speedily resulted. Upon a post mortem examination the skull of deceased was found fractured, his ribs nearly all broken, his shoulder dislocated and shattered, and terrible bruises on his limbs. No evidence, however, was elicited as to the manner in which these injuries were inflicted. The keepers state that they heard no noise in the cell that the unfortunate man occupied, neither were there any signs of a disturbance having taken place there, and the supposition is that, in wandering about the grounds the deceased fell into a stone quarry, although it is difficult to understand how in such a terribly mangled condition he could have returned to the Almshouse without the knowledge of his keepers, particularly as his injuries were such that the physicians think his death must have quickly followed their infliction. In their verdict the Jury, after enumerating the injuries to deceased, say: "We believe the injuries were received but a short time previous to his death, and consequently after his admission to the Workhouse. And we censure in the severest terms, the keeper, who, having plenty of empty cells, placed the deceased in a cell with idiots or crazed prisoners, wholly irresponsible for their actions, and who may at any time violently assail a fellow-prisoner.

abstract: It is not true, as reported from here, that Lord LYONS is fitting up his residence for the reception of the Prince of Wales. He has no knowledge of the intention of the Prince to visit Washington, but thinks it probable he may do so.
lead_paragraph: Special Dispatch to the New-York Times.

abstract: The darker the day, the darker the deed. A tremendous and windy storm has prevailed both inside and outside of the Convention. Prayer has been dispensed with, though the same cannot be said of imprecation.
lead_paragraph: Special Dispatch to the New-York Times.

abstract: This is certainly an age of revivals. Whether the inventive faculties of the race have been exhausted, or whether the theory of PYTHAGORAS and Boatswain CHUCKS, that all things come round continually in cycles, be correct,...
lead_paragraph: This is certainly an age of revivals. Whether the inventive faculties of the race have been exhausted, or whether the theory of PYTHAGORAS and Boatswain CHUCKS, that all things come round continually in cycles, be correct we may leave it to the philosophers to decide. If they fall into the fashion of the moment, they will get at the truth by a neat little "set-to" in the grounds of Columbia College; and may "the best man win" the faith of his fellows.
